text: Photos from Gaza, India, Kashmir and Thailand.

headline: Notes on 2012 North American Auto Sales
text: The just-released 2012 North American auto sales data offer some insights into some marquee sales match-ups, like the crown for America’s best-selling vehicle, Ford vs. Chevy for muscle-car bragging rights and how well America’s definition of luxury stacks up against foreign competition.

headline: Cleanup Crews Near Fukushima Plant Dump Waste in Rivers, Newspaper Reports
text: According to Japan’s Asahi Shimbun, cleanup crews working near the ruined Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, “dumped soil and leaves contaminated with radioactive fallout into rivers.”

headline: ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ Star Would Be White Knight for Small Coffee Chain
text: He only plays a doctor on TV. But Patrick Dempsey is about to become a real-life coffee magnate.

headline: Rally Signals Fatah’s Rift With Hamas May Ease
text: JERUSALEM — Turning the streets of Gaza City into a swarm of sunshine-yellow flags, hundreds of thousands of Palestinians celebrated the anniversary of the Fatah faction on Friday in the heartland of its militant Islamist rival, Hamas, the latest in a series of signals heralding possible reconciliation between the parties after their bitter five-year rift.

headline: Will Biomimicry Offer a Way Forward, Post-Sandy?
text: As neighborhoods devastated by Hurricane Sandy begin drafting plans for reconstruction, some progressive architects and urban planners are arguing that the emerging science of biomimicry offers a way forward. The notion is that the next generation of waterfront designs could draw inspiration from the intricate ways that plants and animals have adapted to their situations over hundreds of millions of years.

headline: Less Bronx-Whitestone Bridge Yielded More Stability During Hurricane Sandy
text: One very windy day in 1968, the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge began to oscillate crazily, leading drivers to abandon their cars in panic.

headline: Living In | Commack, L.I.
text: Tucked behind the highways and the shopping areas on busy streets are quiet neighborhoods, most created from the 1950s to the 1980s.

headline: Sensible, Even on Scarlett Drive and Rhett Court
text: WHEN Maria Diomataris and her husband, Tony, moved to Commack seven years ago from Old Bethpage, they were looking for good schools and a larger property. “The prices were ridiculous in our area,” Ms. Diomataris said. They bought a two-story contemporary on half an acre for about $625,000, she said.

headline: Letting the Piano Find Its Inner Harp
text: A premium is placed on musicians’ constantly showing different sides of themselves and presenting different aspects of their repertories in each recital. But there is something to be said for treading the same ground over and over, for making sure that listeners have certain works, particularly those recently written, firmly in their ears.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $50,000,000
text: Another in the skein of palatial domiciles with Central Park vistas and/or impeccable Fifth or Park Avenue pedigrees that named their price in a resurgent 2012 luxury market and received it without the nuisance of negotiations, a full-floor co-op at 944 Fifth Avenue that sold for $50 million was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. And it wasn’t even a penthouse with wraparound terraces. In fact, it is not a penthouse nor does it possess any outdoor space.

headline: An Old-Fashioned Family Hauler
text: Joe Mamola of Wyckoff, N.J., has brought “Station Wagon Living” into the 21st century with his 1964 Ford Fairlane 500 Ranch Wagon.

headline: Morgan Stanley Discloses Payouts to Senior Deal Maker
text: Morgan Stanley disclosed on Friday the timeline for some of its retirement awards to Paul J. Taubman, the senior deal maker who co-led its securities business.

headline: Removing the Need to Refill Tires
text: THE steady flow of reminders to keep tires at the automaker’s suggested inflation levels — even President Obama chimed in — demonstrates just how far the demands of auto maintenance have diminished. With spark plugs that seem to last forever and oil-change intervals stretching to 10,000 miles and more, many owners continue to slack off when it comes to looking after tire pressures.

headline: Digital Connections Will Increase as a Selling Point, Study Says
text: AUTOMAKERS are racing to ramp up their digital offerings, linking in-dash systems to smartphones and services like traffic monitors faster than you can say Pandora.

headline: Patience and Progress in the Bronx
text: AS the founder and president of the Bronx Pro Group, a family-run, neighborhood-based company in Morris Park that builds, renovates and manages low- and moderate-income housing in the Bronx, Peter Magistro, 63, has seen the borough struggle and come back to life. A Bronx native and longtime resident who now lives on the Upper West Side, he has an intimate knowledge of local housing trends. He knows where the Bronx has been and where it’s headed.

headline: Video Shows Airstrikes Near Crusader Castle in Syria
text: Video posted online by Syrian opposition activists on Friday appeared to show fresh airstrikes near the historic medieval castle Krak des Chevaliers, in Qalaat al-Hosn, west of the city of Homs near the Lebanese border.

headline: As Plans for Afghan Exit Are Sketched, Hope Turns to Hatred
text: Many of the insider attacks for which the Taliban take responsibility actually start off as offers by enraged Afghan soldiers and police officers, Matthew Rosenberg reported in The Times on Thursday.

headline: Azarenka Withdraws After Pedicure Injury
text: The most anticipated match of the young 2013 season was called off on Friday, when top-ranked Victoria Azarenka pulled out of her Brisbane International semifinal against third-ranked Serena Williams, citing an infection in her right big toe. It would have been a rematch of the dramatic United States Open final between the two, which Williams won, 7-5, in the third set after Azarenka had served for the championship.

headline: That House Grandma Left Her Is a Mess
text: Let’s see, how many name actors have enrolled in the “Texas Chainsaw Massacre” school of hard blows over that horror franchise’s history? There are Viggo Mortensen (class of 1990); Matthew McConaughey and Renée Zellweger (1994); Jessica Biel (2003); and Matt Bomer of “White Collar” (2006). Now add Alexandra Daddario (of “Percy Jackson & the Olympians”), Scott Eastwood (yes, Clint’s son) and Tremaine Neverson (a k a the singer Trey Songz), who graduate with flying limbs in the new, generic sixth installment, “Texas Chainsaw 3D.”

headline: Zipcar Makes S.E.C. Filing After C.E.O.’s Twitter Message
text: Scott Griffith, the chief executive of Zipcar, was still riding high on Friday, two days after Avis announced that it was buying his company for $500 million. He appeared on CNBC to discuss the sale, and showed further enthusiasm for the deal — and the publicity surrounding it — by posting on Twitter:

headline: A New Era’s Filmmakers Find Their Way in Cuba
text: HAVANA — Sebastián Miló barely had enough money to put gasoline in the aged bus that ferried his crew to the set each day, let alone to pay actors a salary.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Gambling Software Arrest and Silicon Valley Dress-Up
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Historians Look Back, and Inward, at Annual Meeting
text: NEW ORLEANS — Some 4,000 historians descended on New Orleans on Thursday for the American Historical Association’s four-day annual meeting, replacing the chants of departing Sugar Bowl revelers with more sober talk of job interviews, departmental politics, and — at least in the official panels — the past itself.

headline: New Rules Let More Beer Flow
text: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J. — When Sean Hanrahan and Nina Sassano, both of Freehold, bought tickets to the River Horse Brewing Company’s oatmeal milk stout release party here last month, they noticed on Facebook that it was the first time the brewery was holding such an event, Ms. Sassano said. But they did not realize that a change in New Jersey law governing microbreweries had made such gatherings possible.

headline: Leaders of Sudan and South Sudan in Ethiopia for Talks
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The presidents of Sudan and South Sudan, two nations that have been locked in a tense dispute over borders, territory and oil since the south split off and became its own country 18 months ago, arrived in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, on Friday for a summit meeting intended to speed up an agreement signed between both sides last September.

text: A six-bedroom stone contemporary colonial in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom colonial built in 1986 in Ardsley, N.Y.

text: A Hell’s Kitchen Studio, a NoHo triplex and a Flatbush town house.

text: Still haven’t found that post-holiday gift for the nostalgic fire buff who has everything? Check out this potential bargain: the door to a surplus vintage 1925 fire alarm box. It’s being auctioned by New York City, with a minimum opening bid of $50.

headline: Fleeing North Korea Is Becoming Harder
text: CHEONAN, South Korea — The Rev. Kim Seung-eun said he could measure the increasing difficulty of smuggling people out of North Korea by the higher cost of bribing North Korean soldiers on the Chinese border to look the other way.
