headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 8
text: A view of the day in sports, which included college and professional basketball games as well as matches in the Gulf Cup soccer tournament in Bahrain.

headline: Conjuring Warmth in Winter’s Kitchen
text: THIS sauce/side dish — a simple combination of fennel, tomatoes and olives — is magical. Not because it’s the best thing you ever ate, but because it’s transportive: you eat it and you’re in the Mediterranean. This is even true with winter tomatoes (though of course it’s better with those of summer, and see my suggestion below), because the dominant flavors are fennel and olives.

headline: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
text: NASHVILLE — Portland knows the feeling. Austin had it once, too. So did Dallas. Even Las Vegas enjoyed a brief moment as the nation’s “it” city.

headline: Costly Medicine
text: The United States spends much more on health care than other advanced nations with public health care systems. By most objective measures, it gets no better results.

headline: Despite Promise, Federal Tax-Refund Debit Cards a No Go
text: Giving consumers who lack accounts at a bank or credit union the option of getting tax refunds on multiuse, prepaid debit cards may help bring them into the financial mainstream, a report from the Urban Institute finds. But the accounts must be low-cost, easy to use and available early in the tax season to encourage their use.

headline: Lobster and Bison After Inauguration
text: WITHOUT a single filibuster or even a cross word, the bipartisan Congressional committee responsible for the lunch after the presidential inaugural on Jan. 21 has agreed on a menu featuring sustainable, artisanal and local ingredients. And many are from New York State.

headline: For 2 Nominees, Vietnam Bred Doubts on War
text: Between them, Senator John Kerry and Chuck Hagel have five Purple Hearts for wounds suffered in Vietnam, shared a harrowing combat experience in the Mekong Delta and responded in different ways to the conflict that tore their generation apart. But in nominating one as secretary of state and the other as defense secretary, President Obama hopes to bring to his administration two veterans with the same sensibility about the futilities of war.

headline: Study Questions Effectiveness of Therapy for Suicidal Teenagers
text: Most adolescents who plan or attempt suicide have already received at least some mental health treatment, raising questions about the effectiveness of current approaches to helping troubled youths, according to the largest in-depth analysis to date of suicidal behaviors in American teenagers.

text: Photos from Lebanon, Pakistan, Greece and Australia.

headline: Off-Duty Correction Officer Shoots and Wounds Man in Brooklyn
text: Updated, 7:15 p.m. | An off-duty correction officer shot and wounded a man in the middle of a Brooklyn street on Tuesday, the police said. A witness said that the two men appeared to know each other and that there appeared to be a woman involved.

headline: Ziel Feldman
text: Mr. Feldman, 54, is the founder and managing partner of the HFZ Capital Group, a real estate development and investment company that he formed in 2005.

headline: Australian Forecasters Add New Colors to Temperature Charts to Capture Record Heat
text: How hot is it in Australia?

headline: Health Care and Profits, a Poor Mix
text: Thirty years ago, Bonnie Svarstad and Chester Bond of the School of Pharmacy at the University of Wisconsin-Madison discovered an interesting pattern in the use of sedatives at nursing homes in the south of the state.

headline: N.R.A. Will Send Representative to Meet with Biden on Guns
text: The National Rifle Association will send a representative to a meeting on guns later this week hosted by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., an official with the gun rights organization said Tuesday.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Winter in Brooklyn

headline: Bloggers Using the Internet to Spread Truth in China
text: Profiling two of China’s so-called citizen reporters, Stephen Maing’s “High Tech, Low Life” offers an inside look at an outsider vocation.

headline: Dish Network Makes Bid for Clearwire, Topping Sprint Offer
text: 8:08 p.m. | Updated Not so fast, Sprint.

headline: A Tale From Gore’s Quest for Current TV
text: I left one out.

headline: Why No One Really Knows If Moderate Drinking Is Safe for Pregnant Women
text: Is moderate drinking (less than one drink a day) safe during pregnancy?

headline: Whoopi Goldberg Plays, but Not Too Much, Working at Cuomo Event
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his staff like to stick to a script.

headline: A Low-Rated Show Gets a Second Shot
text: In the second season of HBO’s “Enlightened,” Amy Jellicoe, a self-involved do-gooder played by Laura Dern, joins Twitter. “Follow me. Follow me,” Amy repeats in the languid voice-over of her internal dialogue.

headline: Christie Lauds New Jersey’s Fortitude and Presses Congress for Storm Funds
text: TRENTON — Gov. Chris Christie opened his re-election year on Tuesday with a speech to the Legislature here that sought to underscore the reputation he earned as “America’s governor” after Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Picking a World XI to Challenge FIFA’s Spain-Only Version
text: Contrary to what FIFA would have us believe, there was soccer played outside of Spain last year. That just did not appear to be the case when the organization named its World XI on Monday at its awards gala in Zurich.

headline: Fuel Leak Is Latest Setback for Boeing’s Dreamliner
text: Boeing’s newest and most sophisticated jet, the 787 Dreamliner, suffered a new mishap on Tuesday when a fuel leak forced an aircraft to return to its gate minutes before taking off from Boston, a day after an electrical fire broke out on another plane.

headline: No Savior Needed for This Old House
text: The producers of the PBS series “Masterpiece” had an office pool going to guess the premiere ratings for Season 3 of “Downton Abbey,” the British period drama that has improbably become one of America’s most-buzzed-about shows.

headline: Free Improvisation at a Memorial Helps Affirm a Saxophonist’s Legacy
text: At one point during the memorial service for David S. Ware, at St. Peter’s Church in Midtown Manhattan on Monday night, a slide show provided a visual record of his commanding presence. It opened with a black-and-white snapshot from when he was 5, sometime in 1955, and ran chronologically up to his final performances, in 2011. Most images showed him with a saxophone, either at the ready or held aloft, in midcry. In almost all of them he looked intensely self-possessed, exuding gravity even in repose.

headline: A Lineup, Soon to Shift, Fills a Hall With Brahms
text: As the cellist David Finckel played a bittersweet melody in the first movement of Brahms’s String Sextet No. 2 in G at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, it was hard not to recall that this is the last season he will perform with the Emerson String Quartet. Mr. Finckel announced last year that he would leave the ensemble, which he joined in 1979, to dedicate more time to his other substantial endeavors, which include the artistic directorship of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center with his wife, the pianist Wu Han.

headline: Ada Louise Huxtable’s New York
text: As a rule, there are few things as stale in literature as yesterday’s news columns anthologized. A 1,000-word essay prepared for immediate consumption usually doesn’t read very well years later.

headline: A Voting Process Overdue for Reform
text: One of the truly refreshing changes in baseball is how open it has been lately to common-sense improvements.

headline: Before Expanding Outside, Market Will Revamp Indoors
text: The owner of Chelsea Market, a popular food marketplace in West Chelsea, recently ignited a public furor when the city approved plans to add office towers to the squat structure. But before construction on the towers begins, the market now plans to expand by adding eight new spaces for vendors — all without changing the exterior of the neighborhood landmark.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: A Curved-Screen TV From LG
text: LG Electronics plans to throw consumers a curve. At the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, the company unveiled an OLED television with a curved screen.

headline: Burned Body on Brooklyn Beach Is 14-Year-Old Girl’s
text: A girl whose burned body was found on a beach in Brooklyn on Sunday has been identified by the police as Shaniesha Forbes, 14.

headline: Cuomo to Press for Wider Curbs on Gun Access
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, pushing New York to become the first state to enact major new gun laws in the wake of the massacre in Newtown, Conn., plans on Wednesday to propose one of the country’s most restrictive bans on assault weapons.

headline: Justice Department and Patent Office Issue Policy Statement on Patents
text: The consensus among policy makers on the perils of using standard patents as competitive weapons continues to build.

headline: Amazon’s Unknown Unknowns
text: Operating the world’s largest public cloud still leaves you with the problem of “unknown unknowns.”

headline: If You Like Carter and Cash. . .
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches artists from her generation with those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Elvis, 1972, Madison Square Garden: The Times Took Note, and How
text: Seventy-eight years ago today, a king was born, in Tupelo, Miss. That, presumably, you knew.

headline: Secret Double Standard
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Governor’s Undercover Mission? Buying His Twins a Car
text: The buyer stood out as unusually inquisitive: in a series of late-night telephone calls and text messages, he kept pressing the sales team about a 1996 Ford Bronco he had spotted on eBay.

headline: Siberia Is Thick With Wolves, and Hunters Are in Demand
text: MOSCOW — Wolf packs are prowling at the edges of villages in the remote Sakha-Yakutia region of Siberia, eating livestock that includes horses and domesticated reindeer.

headline: Justices Rule on Staying Death Row Challenges
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday unanimously ruled that federal courts should not automatically suspend postconviction challenges from death row inmates who are mentally incompetent to help their lawyers. The decision left open the possibility that such suspensions may sometimes be warranted, but it said that they should not be indefinite.

headline: Former SAC Analyst Cooperates in Insider Trading Case
text: A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund owned by the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, has given federal agents the names of about 20 people he said had engaged in insider trading, according to a court filing.

headline: Chuck Hagel, Under Attack Again
text: Washington

headline: Judge Says Harsh Detention Is Not Cause to Drop Charges in WikiLeaks Case
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — A military judge on Tuesday declined to dismiss charges against Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, a former Army intelligence analyst accused of providing archives of military and diplomatic documents to the antisecrecy group WikiLeaks, despite complaints by his defense team that he had been mistreated while being held at the Marines’ brig at Quantico, Va.

headline: France: Budget Minister Faces Inquiry on Foreign Bank Account
text: Budget Minister Jérôme Cahuzac, left, who is leading a crackdown on tax fraud, was told Tuesday that he would face a preliminary investigation into charges that he kept an illegal bank account abroad. Mr. Cahuzac said he welcomed the decision of the Paris prosecutor to open an investigation into what he calls “crazy claims” that he committed tax fraud by holding a Swiss bank account with UBS until 2010, when he then supposedly moved the money to Asia. The accusations were made by Mediapart, a French Web site of investigative journalism, which published a recording of a man it identified as Mr. Cahuzac. He denies that the voice is his and has said he will sue Mediapart.

headline: A Financial Service for People Fed Up With Banks
text: Like many people, Josh Reich got fed up with his bank after it charged him overdraft fees and he endured painful customer service calls to fight them. But unlike most people, Mr. Reich, a software engineer from Australia, decided to come up with a better way to bank.

headline: U.S. Is Open to Withdraw Afghan Force After 2014
text: WASHINGTON — On the eve of a visit by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it was open to a so-called zero option that would involve leaving no American troops in Afghanistan after 2014, when the NATO combat mission there comes to an end.

headline: Musburger Criticized for Remarks About Star’s Girlfriend During Title Game
text: On Tuesday morning, commentary on the broadcast of the Bowl Championship Series national title game between Alabama and Notre Dame included words like “creepy,” “awkward,” “uncomfortable” and “heteronormative.”

headline: Rodriguez to Have Hip Surgery on Jan. 16
text: Alex Rodriguez will have surgery on his injured left hip Jan. 16, and Dr. Bryan Kelly, who will perform the procedure, said he expected Rodriguez to return to full function after the All-Star break.

headline: Next Call to the Bullpen May Be From a Cellphone
text: The reserve clause is dead. And so are wool uniforms. There are no longer eight teams in each league. And the Houston Astros have departed the National League.

headline: Chinese Man Pleads Guilty in Copyright Violation Case
text: Nearly five years ago, a Chinese man named Xiang Li registered several domain names, including www.crack99.com, and embarked on an ambitious, and ultimately illegal, venture.

headline: Another Slap on the Wrist
text: In the face of widespread evidence of illegal foreclosure practices, federal regulators in 2011 told the big banks to investigate themselves.

headline: Menstrual Shame and Superstitions in India
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Spread of Pregnancy Crisis Centers
The Poaching of Elephants and Rhinos
text: To the Editor:

headline: Maine: Medicaid Purge Is Rejected
text: The Obama administration rejected Gov. Paul R. LePage’s request to drop thousands of people from Medicaid rolls. Mr. LePage, a Republican, had sought to eliminate Medicaid coverage for nearly 15,000 parents with incomes between the federal poverty level ($23,050 for a family of four last year) and 133 percent of that level ($30,657 for a family of four). He also wanted to end coverage for more than 6,000 19- and 20-year-olds. Marilyn Tavenner, the acting administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, told Mr. LePage in a letter that the cuts would violate a provision of President Obama’s health care law requiring states to maintain Medicaid eligibility levels. But Ms. Tavenner did approve a separate plan to end Medicaid coverage for Maine parents earning more than 133 percent of the poverty level. Mr. LePage had hoped to save more than $20 million from the cuts.

headline: Justice for India’s Rape Victims
text: Influenced by extraordinary street protests, Indian authorities have moved swiftly to try the men accused of gang-raping a 23-year-old physiotherapy student in New Delhi. Clearly, justice must be served, but there are disturbing aspects to the way the case is being handled.

headline: In Old Taliban Strongholds, Qualms About What Lies Ahead
text: LOY BAGH, Afghanistan — The battle against the Taliban in Helmand Province was so fierce two years ago that farmers here say there were some fields where virtually every ear of corn had a bullet in it.

headline: Facing Ravens and Cold, Manning Keeps Gloves On
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — The gloves are bright orange, and they would be eye-catching even if his hands weren’t of such intense interest.

headline: Arizona: Giffords and Husband Start Campaign Against Gun Violence
text: Former Representative Gabrielle Giffords and her husband, Mark E. Kelly, unveiled a campaign against gun violence on Tuesday, the second anniversary of the shooting in a Tuscon shopping center that killed six people and left Ms. Giffords critically injured. In an op-ed article published in USA Today, Ms. Giffords, a Democrat, and Mr. Kelly, a former astronaut, explained that the effort, called Americans for Responsible Solutions, was intended to counter the influence of the powerful gun lobby. They said they wanted to encourage elected officials “to prevent gun violence and protect responsible gun ownership by communicating directly with the constituents that elect them.” They emphasized that they are strong supporters of the Second Amendment. “We don’t want to take away your guns any more than we want to give up the two guns we have locked in a safe at home,” the couple wrote.

headline: Super Bowl Commercial Time Is a Sellout
text: JUST as the playoff results are making it clearer which teams will play in Super Bowl XLVII, the lineup of advertisers buying commercials in the game is also becoming clearer.

headline: A Mind-Boggling Claim
text: The board of the American International Group will meet on Wednesday to consider joining a misguided lawsuit against the government, which spent $182 billion to save the insurance giant from near certain failure.

headline: The Market and Mother Nature
text: Whenever I hear the word “cliff,” I am reminded of something that President Obama’s science adviser, John Holdren, used to say about how we need to respond to climate change because no one can predict when it might take a disruptive, nonlinear turn. “We are driving toward a cliff in a fog,” said Holdren about the climate, and that’s always a good time “to start tapping on the brakes.” Indeed, when you think about how much financial debt we’ve built up in the market and how much carbon debt we’ve built up in the atmosphere, the wisest thing we could do as a country today is to start tapping on the brakes by both emitting less carbon to bend the emissions curve down and racking up less debt to bend our debt-to-G.D.P. curve down. Unfortunately, we are still doing neither.

headline: Mother’s Newfound Financial Security Benefits Son
text: The only way that Nicholas Beltran has ever been able to communicate verbally with his mother, Wilmarie Dominguez, is with two words. One sound he emits — an “uh uh” — very clearly means “no,” while the other, more commonly vocalized noise expressed as “mahh” — often requires investigation.

headline: Interior Dept. Expedites Review of Arctic Drilling After Accidents
text: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department on Tuesday opened an urgent review of Arctic offshore drilling operations after a series of blunders and accidents involving Shell Oil’s drill ships and support equipment, culminating in the grounding of one of its drilling vessels last week off the coast of Alaska.

headline: Displaying Skill and Composure, Johnson Wins Tournament of Champions Easily
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii — Only someone as athletic and powerful as Dustin Johnson could take the hilly, 7,411-yard, par-73 Plantation Course and turn it into a par-3 contest. And only someone like Johnson, whose personality is as placid as the west Maui winds are not, could describe as “nice” the blustery conditions that delayed the start of the Tournament of Champions for three days.

headline: Q. and A. With Former U.S. Commander in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration weighs how many troops to keep in Afghanistan after 2014, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal cautioned that the United States still needs to keep forces there to help stabilize the country and urged a continued effort to advise the Afghan military that appears to be more extensive than the White House has in mind.

headline: With Children, When Does Religion Go Too Far?
text: When does a religious upbringing cross the line from nurturing to oppressive?

headline: Chávez, Too Ill to Return to Venezuela, Will Be Sworn In Later, Official Says
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Hugo Chávez, Venezuela’s cancer-stricken president, will not return from Cuba this week in time to be sworn in for the start of his new term, a top government official said on Tuesday, adding that the ceremony could legally take place at a later date.

headline: Peru: 5 Americans and 2 Peruvians Die in Copter Crash
text: Five Americans and two Peruvians were killed Monday when the helicopter they were in crashed in the jungle near Pucallpa, in the central part of the country, soon after takeoff. The victims were employees of Columbia Helicopters, an Oregon-based company that operated the cargo helicopter, a two-rotor Boeing Model 234 Chinook. They were on their way to deliver materials to an oil exploration site, the company said. There was no immediate indication of what caused the crash, which is being investigated by Peruvian transportation officials. Witnesses told local news media that the helicopter appeared to have exploded after hitting the ground. Photographs showed the aircraft’s charred and flattened remains in a marshy area. The company said the Americans on board were from Washington, Florida, Utah, Tennessee and Oregon.

headline: An Official Vote, and an Unofficial One
text: The N.H.L. Board of Governors will convene Wednesday in New York to vote on a new collective bargaining agreement with the league’s players’ association. But another important item will be under consideration, even though it will not be on the official agenda: whether Gary Bettman will keep his job as commissioner.

headline: Sudan: Top U.N. Aid Official Warns of Food Crisis in 2 Southern States
text: The director of United Nations emergency relief implored the Security Council on Tuesday to find ways to ensure his aid teams can gain access to two isolated southern states of Sudan. Hundreds of thousands of civilians are trapped there because of a conflict between rebels and the Sudanese government, which has accused the newly independent country of South Sudan of abetting an insurgency. The relief director, John Ging, told reporters afterward that he feared that many residents in the isolated states, South Kordofan and Blue Nile, might be dying of malnutrition and disease, while others were subsisting on roots and leaves. “This is 2013, and to think that tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands of people are living in such desperate and deplorable circumstances, and we can’t get in to help them as humanitarian organizations, it’s just not acceptable,” Mr. Ging said. The United Nations and aid groups have accused Sudan of denying them access to the two states. Sudan’s United Nations ambassador, Daffa-Alla Elhag Ali Osman, told reporters that rebels were responsible for any impediments to aid.

headline: Iran: Ayatollah Discourages Talk of Vote’s Fairness
text: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said its enemies would most likely try to sabotage the presidential election scheduled for June. He warned citizens and prospective candidates to avoid discussion about the fairness of the vote, suggesting that such talk was subversive and would discourage turnout. “Where on earth have elections been so free as in Iran?” he said in a speech in the holy city of Qom, reported by the state-run press. “Watch out for your words not to dissuade people.” His statement, coming five months before the vote for a successor to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, appeared to reflect the ayatollah’s concern about repeating the chaotic aftermath of the 2009 election, in which Mr. Ahmadinejad, his favored candidate, won by a suspiciously lopsided margin that opponents said was fraudulent. Postelection protests escalated into the most serious challenge that the Islamic government had faced since it took power in the 1979 revolution. Mr. Ahmadinejad’s two challengers have remained under house arrest for the past few years.

headline: Richard Ben Cramer, Writer of Big Ambitions, Dies at 62
text: It took time for “What It Takes” to become a classic.

headline: For Drug Users, a Swift Response Is the Best Medicine
text: Ben W. Joseph was a trial judge in the Chittenden County Criminal Court, in Vermont, and he had a problem — one shared by judges across the country that results in billions of dollars of wasteful spending by governments every year. It was 2008, and substance abuse was soaring, particularly among young people whose drugs of choice were pharmaceuticals like OxyContin, a highly addictive pain killer that has an effect similar to heroin but is much easier to obtain. Each month in his Burlington courtroom, Joseph saw defendants who’d been arrested for drug-related offenses — from driving while heavily intoxicated to stealing to feed an OxyContin habit (an 80-milligram pill can cost $100 on the street).

headline: Contractor Settles Case in Iraq Prison Abuse
text: WASHINGTON — An American contractor hired by the military to provide translation services for interrogators at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq has reached a $5 million settlement with scores of detainees who accused its employees of complicity in abusing them, according to financial disclosure documents.

headline: Analysts Skeptical as Majority Owner Takes Role as Chief Executive of Sears
text: Just hours after a board discussion on Monday, a note went out to Sears Holdings employees from Edward S. Lampert, the company’s majority owner and chairman, that he would now be its chief executive.

headline: He Who Knew Not
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Title Game Draws Second Biggest Cable Audience
text: Alabama’s 42-14 win over Notre Dame in the B.C.S. national championship game on Monday night was seen by an average of 26.4 million viewers, the second-biggest audience for a program in cable TV history. The most-viewed program was the 2011 B.C.S. title game, Auburn’s 22-19 win over Oregon, which was seen by 27.3 million viewers.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Jan. 9, 2013
text: The heat was remarkable. It was prolonged. That we beat the record by one degree is quite a big deal.

headline: Record Number of Misconduct Complaints Are Made Against City School Employees
text: A record number of allegations of wrongdoing against teachers and other Department of Education workers were received last year by the office that investigates misconduct in New York City schools, according to a report released on Tuesday.

headline: The Saban Way: That Was Nice, Now Move On
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Early Tuesday morning, the once great Alabama running back stood on the field surrounded by the latest great Alabama team. There was Shaun Alexander, retired from a long N.F.L. career, clad in a Crimson sweatshirt. He brushed confetti from his shoulders. He slapped hands and took pictures and even dropped the d-word.

headline: Texas Budget Surplus Proves as Contentious as a Previous Shortfall
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The last time Texas lawmakers began a legislative session, a cost-cutting fervor filled the marble hallways of the Capitol in January 2011 as the state faced a budget shortfall of as much as $27 billion. Legislators warned of sparing nothing and no one from deep cutbacks — from highways, to prisons, to health care for the poor, to programs for preschool children.

headline: Brooklyn Man Sentenced to 15 Years in Terrorism Case
text: A Brooklyn man who pleaded guilty to supporting a terrorist group after he was arrested trying to board a plane to the Middle East to wage jihad was sentenced to 15 years in prison on Tuesday.

headline: Bank Hacking Was the Work of Iranians, Officials Say
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The attackers hit one American bank after the next. As in so many previous attacks, dozens of online banking sites slowed, hiccupped or ground to a halt before recovering several minutes later.

headline: A Layered Detective Yarn or Another Animal Entirely?
text: In an interview a few years back, Richard Maxwell described the experience of reading a script by his fellow playwright and director Julia Jarcho: “It has density and yet it still feels ephemeral.”

headline: An Extended Family, Sharing Extended Pain
text: Trouble comes in surging waves for the men and women in “Water by the Spoonful,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Quiara Alegría Hudes that is making its New York premiere at the Second Stage Theater. Almost all the characters in this moving collage of lives in crisis have a grim history — and maybe a grimmer future — of substance abuse. Often their addictions have cost them dearly, leading to poverty, isolation and unbridgeable chasms between once-loving parents and children.

headline: Whirling Water
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Did you solve or did you not? That seems to be the question newcomer David Ben-Merre is asking, and it reminds me of a piece of wisdom uttered by a famous exile to the planet Dagobah: “Do or do not … there is no try.”

headline: Corrections: January 9, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Argument Is Assailed by Justices in Fraud Case
text: WASHINGTON — A Supreme Court argument that started on Tuesday as a routine consideration of the time limits for filing some kinds of securities fraud suits turned by its conclusion into a broad attack from justices across the ideological spectrum on what they said was government overreaching with the potential to do away with statutes of limitations whenever the government seeks civil penalties for any kind of fraud.

headline: In Step on ‘Light Footprint,’ Nominees Reflect a Shift
text: WASHINGTON — With the selection of a new national security team deeply suspicious of the wisdom of American military interventions around the world, President Obama appears to have ended, at least for the moment, many of the internal administration debates that played out in the Situation Room over the past four years.

headline: Hall of Fame Has Always Made Room for Infamy
text: The Baseball Hall of Fame, the most august fraternity of its kind in American sports, unveils its latest induction class Wednesday. For the first time this year, balloters must weigh the fate of two eminent stars, Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens, who are also the most celebrated poster boys for the game’s disgraced steroid era.

headline: A Bold Dissenter at the Fed, Hoping His Doubts Are Wrong
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Jeffrey M. Lacker, the Federal Reserve’s most persistent internal critic, does not much resemble a firebrand. He is personally cheerful, professionally inclined to see both sides of an issue and quick to acknowledge he may not be right. He says he would rather be wrong.

headline: Illinois Tries, and Fails, to Fix Its Pensions
text: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — If ever there was a moment when Illinois’s drastically underfinanced pension systems had a real shot at being repaired, some state leaders thought it would be this week.

headline: Armstrong Set to Appear on Oprah Next Week, as New Allegation Surfaces
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 11:07 a.m. The year before his seventh and final Tour de France victory, Lance Armstrong offered to donate “in excess of $150,000″ to the antidoping agency in charge of keeping American athletes from using performance-enhancing drugs, according to the organization’s chief executive.

headline: Controlling Backboards, Nets Keep Winning
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Nets needed something to readjust their focus from the distraction involving center-forward Andray Blatche on Tuesday, and it came quickly, unexpectedly, as Reggie Evans collected rebound after rebound.

headline: Rhode Island Likely to Lose a House Seat
text: It may seem early to be thinking about the redistribution of House seats that will take place after the Census in 2020, but one state, Rhode Island, is being forced to because its population is declining.

headline: Devils Ready to Go, as Soon as Kovalchuk Returns
text: NEWARK — With one notable exception, the Devils sound thrilled to have a labor agreement with the N.H.L., and they are eager to start training camp in a few days, even though it comes four months later than scheduled.

headline: Claude-Anne Lopez Dies at 92; Told of Franklin’s Private Life
text: He was a postmaster-inventor-diplomat-founding father — just another American revolutionary. She was two centuries younger but plenty worldly as well, with a blend of verve and pragmatism that had helped her escape Nazi-occupied Belgium by taxicab. Their first meetings were hardly memorable.

headline: Landing an Unlikely Role in 'Flight'
text: Melena Ryzik chats with the British actress Kelly Reilly about her first movie role shot in America: a leading part opposite Denzel Washington.

headline: Fred L. Turner, Innovative Chief of McDonald’s, Dies at 80
text: Fred L. Turner, who as chief executive helped transform McDonald’s into a global giant and introduced the world to the Chicken McNugget, the Egg McMuffin and the Happy Meal, died on Monday in Glenview, Ill. He was 80.

headline: Poet’s Kinship With the President
text: WASHINGTON — From the moment Barack Obama burst onto the political scene, the poet Richard Blanco, a son of Cuban exiles, says he felt “a spiritual connection” with the man who would become the nation’s 44th president.

headline: Nationals’ Morse Moves Into the Yankees’ Sights
text: The Yankees have been searching for a right-handed hitter to augment their lineup, with only modest results. But a relatively imposing hitter is now expected to become available.

headline: Parker No Longer With ESPN
text: Rob Parker, a panelist on the “First Take” program who was suspended last month for his racially oriented comments about Robert Griffin III, the rookie Redskins quarterback, did not have his contract renewed, ESPN said in a statement. Parker’s contact expired on Dec. 31. In a “First Take” discussion of Griffin, Parker asked, “Is he a brother, or is he a ‘cornball’ brother?” Parker, who is also African-American, added: “He’s black; he kind of does his thing. But’s not really down with the cause.”

headline: Jackson Has ‘No Intention’ of Coaching
text: Phil Jackson, the No. 1 target in the Nets’ coaching search, told a Web site on Tuesday that he has “no intention” of returning to the bench, although his statement left room for a change of heart.

headline: Transcript of Nate Silver’s ‘Ask Me Anything’ on Reddit
text: Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight took questions Tuesday on the popular social news site Reddit’s “Ask Me Anything” section. What follows is an edited transcript, with the questions and answers sorted into several subject areas.

headline: Do the Brain Benefits of Exercise Last?
text: It is well established that exercise bolsters the structure and function of the brain. Multiple animal and human studies have shown that a few months of moderate exercise can create new neurons, lift mood and hone memory and thinking.

headline: Te’O’s Draft Stock Tumbled When Irish Did
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Manti Te’o’s season, filled emotional highs and lows, ended with a thud Monday night.

headline: Word of the Day | catechism
text: catechism •\ˈka-tə-ˌki-zəm\• noun

headline: Who’s No. 1? Tom Seaver
text: Mets fans can at least say they have this over their Yankees counterparts: the lone player who wears a Mets cap in the Baseball Hall of Fame, Tom Seaver, was elected in 1992 with the highest vote percentage ever, 98.8, which is higher than Babe Ruth, higher than Joe DiMaggio, higher than Mickey Mantle.

headline: Macau’s Gaming Take: Sign of Chinese Emigration?
text: BEIJING — Why did gambling boom in Macau in 2012, even as China’s economy slowed? A Hong Kong online magazine that follows the scene closely has a smart take: emigration.

headline: What Ryan and Johnson Didn’t Say
text: Woody Johnson and Rex Ryan were asked many questions at their news conference Tuesday. Some they did not feel like answering.

headline: Record Heat Fuels Widespread Fires in Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Bush fires raging across some of the most populous parts of Australia — feeding off widespread drought conditions and high winds — pushed firefighters to their limits and residents to their wits’ end on Wednesday as meteorologists tracked the country’s hottest spring and summer on record into uncharted territory.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) NASHVILLE The series resumes as Rayna (Connie Britton, above) suggests taking her daughters on tour, only to discover that Lamar (Powers Boothe) intends to hold her hostage with some family secrets. Juliette (Hayden Panettiere) and Sean (Tilky Montgomery Jones), meanwhile, have eloped, and not everyone is celebrating. And Deacon (Charles Esten) reconnects with an old love.

headline: News Quiz | January 9, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 9
text: NEWS In Helmand Province in southern Afghanistan, places that were once Taliban strongholds have been transformed by the American troop surge that brought tens of thousands of marines three years ago. But there is little faith in the government’s ability to maintain those security gains once the Americans leave, and many assume that the Taliban will return. Alissa J. Rubin reports from Loy Bagh, Afghanistan.

headline: Sons of ’94 Lead Brazil Into South American Youth Championship
text: One of the iconic images of the 1994 World Cup captures Bebeto, Mazinho and Romário celebrating Bebeto’s 62nd-minute goal against the Netherlands at the Cotton Bowl.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 9, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the Economix blog post “Degree Inflation? Jobs That Newly Require B.A.’s.”

headline: Our World on a Sphere
text: In Digital Globes Offer a Dynamic Vision, Mark Vanhoenacker reports on an educational tool that can animate complex phenomena. The questions below are based on the article, but watching the video, above, will give students a good sense of the power of this technology.

headline: Shimon Peres on Obama, Iran and the Path to Peace
text: “This part of the conversation is highly sensitive,” said the spokeswoman for Israel’s president. “I want all cellphones taken out of the room.” It was July 25, 2012, and I was interviewing Shimon Peres in a wood-paneled suite at the King David Hotel in Jerusalem. I handed my phone to one of the guards standing at the door, and Peres swiftly opened a scathing monologue against a potential Israeli attack on Iran’s nuclear sites. “Israel cannot solve the problem alone,” he said. “There is a limit to what we can do.”

headline: How Often Do You Leave Your ‘Comfort Zone’?
text: In a recent column, Frank Bruni suggests choosing a college that will take you out of the comfortable world you have known and “expand your universe.”

headline: An Ambitious Woman From a Delhi Neighborhood of Migrants
text: Groups of women huddled around makeshift fires on a wet mud-lane, surrounded by partially constructed houses on both sides, in Mahavir Enclave Part II in Delhi. They winced as the smoke went in to their eyes, and glanced towards the locked house with a green steel door, a barred window and white brick walls, as they remembered the young woman from their neighborhood, who has suddenly become a symbol of India’s dire treatment of women.

headline: The Labor Market Post-Budget Deal
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Inside DataWind’s India Operations
text: In a nondescript neighborhood of Amritsar known as Ghee Mandi, a nod to the area’s past as a clarified butter wholesale market, a three-story building with blue glass windows has displayed a prominent sign: “DataWind Makers of Aakash Tablets.” Below the sign hangs a portrait of a Sikh saint, Baba Deep Singh, after whom the building has been named.

headline: Iranian Captives Freed in Prisoner Exchange in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than 2,100 people incarcerated by the Syrian authorities were being released on Wednesday in return for 48 Iranians freed by rebels after five months in captivity, Turkish and Iranian officials said, in what appeared to be the biggest prisoner swap since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria began almost two years ago.

headline: Activists Convicted in Vietnam Crackdown on Dissent
text: BANGKOK — A court in central Vietnam convicted 14 bloggers, writers and political and social activists on Wednesday of plotting to overthrow the government and sentenced them to prison terms ranging from 3 to 13 years in what human rights groups said was the largest subversion case to be brought in years.

headline: Higher Taxes? They Make This Owner Want to Hire More Employees
text: Beginning in November, just after the election — and a thorough debate over how higher taxes might affect small businesses — we started inviting readers to share the intimate details of their businesses’ financial conditions. We are particularly interested in exploring the relationship between income taxes and investment.

headline: HSBC Sale of $9.4 Billion Ping An Stake in Jeopardy
text: SHANGHAI — The British bank HSBC’s plan to sell its stake in the Ping An Group is in jeopardy after the China Development Bank decided not to finance a large part of the $9.4 billion deal.

text: The fall 2013 collection offered varied interpretations of pinstriped suits and color-blocking in men’s wear.

headline: Three Accused in Delhi Gang Rape Case to Plead Not Guilty
text: A day before the Delhi gang rape case is likely to be handed over to a new fast-track court for trial, a legal defense team for the accused seemed to be coming together on Wednesday. Two lawyers said they had been retained by some of the suspects and planned offer not guilty pleas for their clients.

headline: Daily Report:  Bank Hackers Used Data Centers to Supercharge Attacks
text: There was something disturbingly different about the wave of online attacks on American banks in recent weeks, report Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy of The New York Times. Security researchers say that instead of exploiting individual computers, the attackers engineered networks of computers in data centers.

headline: Chinese Firm Buys U.S. Solar Start-Up
text: Just a few years ago, Silicon Valley investors were pouring money into solar technologies and talking about how they would bring the same kind of innovation to green energy that they had to the computer chip.

headline: UBS Executives Questioned by Parliament Over Rate-Rigging Case
text: LONDON — Senior executives of the Swiss banking giant UBS faced tough questioning from British politicians on Wednesday over a recent rate-rigging scandal that led the company to pay $1.5 billion in fines to global authorities.

headline: Charging Up (Slowly) After the Next Big Storm
text: Shopping for hardware to tide you through the next hurricane? The Electric Power Research Institute has some advice, none of it encouraging.

headline: India Lodges Protest with Pakistan Over Soldiers’ Deaths
text: India said it summoned Pakistan’s envoy in New Delhi on Wednesday to strongly protest the killing and mutilation of two Indian soldiers in the disputed territory of Kashmir after the second firefight in three days between the nuclear-armed neighbors.

headline: At Peace With the Past
text: DRESDEN, Germany — Seventy years ago this winter, Soviet forces surrounded and crushed Hitler’s Sixth Army at Stalingrad. The Germans’ defeat shattered the myth of an unstoppable Nazi war machine and marked a reversal of fortunes in World War II.

headline: Wednesday Reading: For Travel Savings, Go Retro
text: Going retro for travel savings in 2013, a glimpse at the future of parking, taxpayers can start filing Jan. 30 and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: The Great Dissenters
text: My article about Jeffrey Lacker on Wednesday mentions that he is the third member of the Federal Reserve’s Open Market Committee to dissent at least eight times in a single year.

headline: A Time to Go Solo, at Least Onstage
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Super Bowl Ads and a Bet by HBO on ‘Enlightened’
text: CBS said on Tuesday that it had sold all the available commercial time for the broadcast of Super Bowl XLVII on Feb. 3, unless a marketer wants so much to be included that money is no object. According to estimates by agency executives, CBS has sold most of its Super Bowl spots for an average of $3.7 million to $3.8 million for each 30 seconds. (By comparison, the average for Super Bowl XLVI, broadcast by NBC on Feb. 5, 2012, was $3.5 million.) Leslie Moonves, chairman and chief executive of the CBS Corporation, made the announcement at an event at the CBS Broadcast Center on the West Side of Manhattan that was billed as Super Bowl XLVII Media Day. Mr. Moonves, as Stuart Elliott reports, said room could still be found to include commercials for movie studios — which often wait somewhat longer than other marketers to decide whether to buy Super Bowl commercials — but at a price. “If one of those movie companies wants to come in and pay five or six million,” he said, “we will find room.”

text: OXYGEN bars may be a relic of the late 1990s, but the element is popping up as a beauty-industry buzzword of the early 21st century — no plastic hose necessary.

headline: Former SAC Analyst Assists Insider Trading Crackdown
text: Wesley Wang, a former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors, has given federal agents the names of about 20 people that he said had engaged in insider trading, according to a court filing, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports. Federal prosecutors said the extraordinary assistance was still yielding results, as the government continues to circle SAC, the hedge fund owned by Steven A. Cohen.

headline: Climbing the World’s Highest Mountains to Honor Heroes
text: Our wars hit home for me when my childhood buddy, Capt. Derek Argel, died with four other airmen in a small-plane crash near Diyala, Iraq, on Memorial Day 2005. Derek and his Air Force Academy classmate Jeremy Fresques were promoted to captain just before boarding that airplane.

headline: One on One: John Legere, the Hip New Chief of T-Mobile USA
text: T-Mobile USA wants to be the cool wireless carrier for hip people. Its new chief executive, John J. Legere, who wears a T-shirt under his sports coat, seems suited for the job.

headline: Thinking of Planting Some Grapes? Get in Line
text: PARIS—Across many of the wine-producing countries of Europe, growers had special reason to celebrate the New Year. A hated European Union initiative had been defeated.

headline: Several Dozen Injured in Ferry Crash in Lower Manhattan
text: One by one, the passengers shuffled toward the exits — bags in hand, music in their ears — gathering in a neat crowd to step off their New Jersey commuter ferry and into the frosty Lower Manhattan morning.

headline: Accused Picasso Vandal Surrenders at U.S.-Mexico Border
text: A Houston man accused of vandalizing a Picasso painting has surrendered to federal marshals after having fled to Mexico for several months, The Associated Press reported. The man, Uriel Landeros, 22, turned himself in on Tuesday at a bridge between the United States and Mexico, near McAllen, Tex.

headline: For Cornell Wrestling, a Promising Start to Season
text: Cornell’s wrestling team began the season with a lot of injuries (senior Steve Bosak had to have surgery on his wrist), a number of promising new wrestlers, and their biggest star in a compelling new role.

headline: A Gala of Stars and Bleeps
text: 10:26 a.m. | Updated  The beauty of untelevised award shows, even in this social media age, is simple: swearing. The National Board of Review gala on Tuesday got off to an unexpectedly raunchy start when the host, Meredith Vieira, borrowed a line from “Zero Dark Thirty’s” Maya and said, “I’m the” — boss lady, though she used another word — “that’s running this show.”

text: Culinate: Luck has run out for the potluck dinner, increasingly the victim of our crammed schedules and balkanized food politics. – Patrick Farrell

headline: Anti-Leak
text: Before hurtling deeper into the maw of the new year, let’s note an important victory for the First Amendment from the end of 2012.

headline: The Explaining Season
text: The sports calendar tells us it is football playoff season, the time of year we get to focus on only the good teams, the teams that won important games and comported themselves in a relatively professional fashion, at least well enough to escape the regular season with Super Bowl dreams intact. In reality, January is football news conference season, with barely a day going by when a coach or an owner is not sitting in front of some backdrop sponsored by a doughnut company or a health care clinic (fine bedfellows at that), explaining how his championship season morphed into something that resembled the remake of a Three Stooges movie. There are hirings and firings, coordinators axed, fresh starts and do-overs, mediocrity and calamity all cued up for the cameras.

headline: I.R.S.’s Taxpayer Advocate Calls for a Tax Code Overhaul
text: Lawmakers need to overhaul the tax code completely to reduce the “significant, even unconscionable, burden” placed on taxpayers just to file a tax return, the Internal Revenue Service’s ombudsman told Congress on Wednesday.

headline: Sol Yurick, 87, Author of ‘The Warriors’ Gang Novel
text: Sol Yurick, a writer whose best-known work, the 1965 novel “The Warriors,” recast an ancient Greek battle as a tale of warring New York street gangs and earned a cult following in print, on film and eventually in a video game, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: The Black Keys, Fun. and Mumford & Sons to Perform at Grammys
text: The Grammy Awards show next month will include performances from three nominees for album of the year: the Black Keys, Fun. and Mumford & Sons, the Recording Academy announced on Wednesday.

headline: Cuomo Pushes for Action on Guns
text: TimesCast: The governor is set to propose a restrictive ban on assault weapons. | A recent hacking attack is linked to Iran.

headline: Barbarous Relics
text: I feel comfortable in my understanding of the economics of the platinum coin, but don’t claim any legal expertise. However, Laurence Tribe knows whereof he speaks — and he says that it’s quite legal. And so there you have it: if we have a crisis over the debt ceiling, it will be only because the Treasury department would rather see economic devastation than look silly for a couple of minutes.

headline: A Deposit by Credit Card That’s Returned by Paper Check
text: Sometimes, it’s the little things that annoy you.

headline: A Lone Yank Takes Joy in Togetherness
text: LONDON

headline: 36 Hours in Naples, Italy
text: THE southern Italian city of Naples, capital of the Campania region, has a reputation sullied by corruption and crime, both petty and organized. But change is afoot. A new mayor has ushered in initiatives to clean up the city, beginning with the unclogging of streets by disposing of uncollected trash and redirecting chaotic traffic flows. A thriving contemporary art scene — in museums, galleries, and even metro stations — is propelling the city’s cultural revival. Make no mistake: problems persist, but those who remain aware of the vices in this spirited, ancient city will be rewarded by its virtues.

headline: Wall Street’s Elite, Including Ina Drew, Honors JPMorgan’s Former Leader
text: Ina Drew has kept a low profile since she left JPMorgan Chase last year after the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss.

headline: Video: Kelly Reilly, ‘Flight’ Newcomer
text: It has been a banner year for some actors, even if they’re not Oscar hopefuls. Kelly Reilly, a British actress, made her first appearance in a movie shot on these shores, and opposite Denzel Washington, no less. Here, Ms. Reilly talks about securing her breakout role in Robert Zemeckis’s “Flight.”

headline: Talkin’ ’bout Stimulus
text: Somehow Brad DeLong has managed to produce a pretty good transcript of Sunday’s panel discussion. It’s inaccurate in one respect: I can’t believe that I was actually that grammatical. But I think it give you a very good idea of what I at least said.

headline: Obama Will Take Oath to Sounds of Beyoncé, Kelly Clarkson and James Taylor
text: It would not be an Obama inaugural without a little celebrity pizazz.

headline: Court Seeks More Public Input on Nuclear Safety
text: A federal appeals court has ruled that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission must either allow more public participation in its decisions about fire safety at the Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor or to show why such input is impractical or inappropriate.

headline: Across Borders of Memory and Photography
text: In Guayaquil’s Parque Seminario, iguanas are everywhere. Karen Miranda-Rivadeneira grew up terrified of them.

headline: Feeling Bullied by Parents About Weight
text: Nancy Keefe Rhodes, a therapist and writer in Syracuse, N.Y., has struggled with weight all her life. So when the uncle she idolized asked her, at age 10, if she went to “Omar the tentmaker” for her clothes, she was devastated. “When I begged him to stop, he said he was just trying to help,” she said.

headline: In Your Face(book)
text: A friend’s son got married a while back, and because of an unfortunate rift with my friend, I was not invited. I did, however, have the pleasure of looking at the Facebook pictures and seeing how old my friend had become.

headline: Cuomo Looks to Curb Assault Weapons
text: The Times’s Clifford J. Levy discusses Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s push for a restrictive ban on assault weapons in New York.

headline: Obama’s Pick for Treasury Is Said to Be His Chief of Staff
text: WASHINGTON — With his choice of Jacob J. Lew to be the secretary of Treasury, President Obama on Thursday will complete the transformation of his economic team from the big-name economists and financial firefighters hired four years ago to budget negotiators ready for the next fiscal fights in Congress.

headline: Hackers Target American Banks
text: The Times's Quentin Hardy discusses a recent computer hacking attack, which American officials have linked to Iran, that targeted banks in the United States.

headline: New Target in Finger-Pointing Over Housing Bubble
text: No matter how many times people debunk the notion that government policy created the housing bubble, it doesn’t die. It’s part of what the blogger Barry Ritholtz has called the “big lie” of the financial crisis. Now, we are having another argument about whether the government is creating a new housing disaster for taxpayers.

headline: James M. Buchanan, Economic Scholar and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 93
text: James M. Buchanan, a scholar and author whose analyses of economic and political decision-making won the 1986 Nobel in economic sciences and shaped a generation of conservative thinking about deficits, taxes and the size of government, died on Wednesday in Blacksburg, Va. He was 93.

headline: Have a Good Day
text: A new year, a new day. For very young children, there really isn’t much difference. Each morning seems to bring a whirlwind of emotion and possibility, hope and disappointment. And it takes a good long while to get to bedtime. Three new picture books honor the boundaries, as so many picture books do, of the 24-hour lifetimes of young children.

headline: G.M. Chief Expects To Regain Market Share
text: DETROIT — Despite steady profits, last year was a rocky one for General Motors, raising questions about the strength of the company’s comeback from its bankruptcy and government bailout.

headline: PATH Trains to Resume 24-Hour Service
text: Seventy-two days after Hurricane Sandy devastated the PATH system, PATH trains are resuming some round-the-clock service Wednesday night, Governors Chris Christie of New Jersey and Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: After Delays, Pebble Wristwatch Will Ship Jan. 23
text: Pebble, the much-hyped wristwatch designed to connect wirelessly to smartphones to display information like text messages, whipped the Web into a frenzy last May when the project raised more than $10 million through Kickstarter, one of the crowdfunding platform’s largest campaigns to date.

headline: Are There Really No Good Job Applicants Out There?
text: The latest Small Business Optimism Index data from the National Federation of Independent Business — a major industry group for small businesses that surveys a sample of its members each month — is very disappointing. The report, issued Tuesday, showed business optimism to be near recessionary levels in December. Hiring plans in particular weakened substantially.

headline: Cash for Hay Driving Thieves to Move Bundles
text: DENVER — Across the West, ranchers, farmers and county sheriffs are grappling with a new scourge: hay rustling.

headline: Ada Louise Huxtable Leaves Estate to Getty Trust
text: Along with the legacy of first-rate criticism she left to the world, the pioneering architectural critic and historian Ada Louise Huxtable, who died at the age of 91 on Monday, has bequeathed her estate to the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles. The bequest followed the trust’s purchase of her archives in December; at the same time, she donated to the trust the archives of her husband, Garth Huxtable, an industrial designer. The archives will be housed at the Getty Research Institute.

headline: For Americans Under 50, Stark Findings on Health
text: Younger Americans die earlier and live in poorer health than their counterparts in other developed countries, with far higher rates of death from guns, car accidents and drug addiction, according to a new analysis of health and longevity in the United States.

headline: In India, Solar Ambitions Are Suddenly Outsize
text: After years of lagging behind China and the West in the adoption of solar power, some states in India are proposing to build solar farms at a galloping pace that leaves them at risk of falling short of electricity (a familiar problem here) or of paying higher prices for it.

headline: Barry Manilow’s Return to Broadway Is Extended
text: Barry Manilow’s return to Broadway for a limited engagement at the St. James Theater has been extended for an additional 10 nights because of a strong demand for tickets, the producers have announced.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 9
text: A protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Even Fewer Geriatricians in Training
text: Toward the end of each year, Christopher Langston, program director of the Hartford Foundation, undertakes a discouraging task. He wades through the statistics on graduate medical education, published annually in The Journal of the American Medical Association, and digs out the bad news about geriatrics.

headline: Seems Warm?  Expect a Record High (for the Year So Far)
text: Just think: If the forecast is right, Wednesday will be the warmest day of the year.

headline: Continuity on Obama’s Economic Team
text: After President Obama took office in 2009, Jacob J. Lew became a deputy secretary of state within days. Gene Sperling was serving as an adviser to the Treasury secretary. Austan Goolsbee, a longtime Obama adviser, was serving on Mr. Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers. Alan B. Krueger would become an assistant secretary of the Treasury within a few months.

headline: On Budget Deficits, CO2 Binges and Wise Investments
text: Here’s a post, once again, on the human habit of kicking the can down the road — sometimes very different cans, depending on the person and the problem at hand.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: In a Compact Container, a Terabyte of Storage
text: Kingston Digital, a company that makes flash drives, is at the Consumer Electronics Show promoting a new flash drive that can hold a terabyte of data.

headline: Lawmakers in New York Move Toward New Limits on Guns
text: ALBANY – Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders believe they are close to an agreement on a package of gun laws that includes a restrictive ban on assault weapons, and lawmakers hope to vote on it as soon as next week.

headline: Pack Up Your Christmas Trees: Recycling Program Ends Saturday
text: Here’s an urban version of the tree-falling-in-the-forest question: If you don’t leave your Christmas tree at the curb by Saturday, will it be recycled?

headline: Khuzami, S.E.C. Enforcement Chief Who Reinvigorated Unit, to Step Down
text: After becoming the public face of Wall Street oversight and reining in firms like Goldman Sachs, Robert S. Khuzami is walking away from the spotlight.

headline: Why the Founder of a Start-Up Chose to Give Up Control
text: Last week, we published a case study about a start-up founded by a young Australian expatriate who faced a difficult choice — just how difficult was revealed by the scores of conflicting reader comments that poured in to this blog. The choice belonged to Jacqui Rosshandler, who was about to run out of money: she could mothball her breath freshener business, Eatwhatever, and find a job, or she could accept the financial lifeline offered by Arthur Shorin, longtime owner of the Topps Company, who had sold his company and was nurturing start-ups.

headline: ‘Cotton Club Parade’ Will March Onto Broadway
text: After two popular engagements at City Center, “Cotton Club Parade” – a musical revue celebrating the Harlem nightclub during the Duke Ellington era – will move to Broadway this fall, its producers announced on Wednesday. With minimal spoken text, this 90-minute show recreates many of the big-band swing and blues numbers of the Cotton Club during the 1920s and ‘30s, with the score including works by Jimmy McHugh and Dorothy Fields (“I Can’t Give You Anything but Love”), Harold Arlen (“Stormy Weather,” “I’ve Got the World on a String”) and Ellington (“Rockin’ in Rhythm,” “Cotton Club Stomp”).

headline: A Family Circle Spins Around the Oval Office
text: There is something funny about “1600 Penn,” but mostly in the sense of odd. It’s an NBC sitcom on Thursday about a fictional first family that the network is promoting as a blend of “Modern Family” and “The West Wing.” Actually “1600 Penn” seems more like a time capsule of the presidencies of Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan and period sitcoms like “Growing Pains.”

headline: Far From the Spotlight, Parenthetical History Made
text: While the elites of tennis gather in Melbourne to compete for a record first-place prize of $2.5 million at the 2013 Australian Open, a different sort of record excess was created on the opposite sides of the globe and the tennis pantheon, at a Futures tournament in Plantation, Fla., with a total prize pool of just $10,000 to be divvied up amongst all competitors.

headline: On the Floor at the Consumer Electronics Show
text: Televisions are always big news at the Consumer Electronics Show, but cars, wearable computers and even a smart fork are also on display in Las Vegas.

headline: Below the Line: The Light and Dark of ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
text: One of the many challenges  of making  “Zero Dark Thirty,” Kathryn Bigelow’s drama about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, involved  how to shoot one of the  climactic scenes: the SEAL team raid on Osama Bin Laden’s compound. The moment would be low in light, yet high in tension, so securing a cinematographer who could effectively shoot in near darkness was essential for Ms. Bigelow. She decided on Greig Fraser, an Australian director of photography who shot two other 2012 releases: “Snow White and the Huntsman” and “Killing Them Softly.” Those films also used darkness and light in interesting ways but were  more stylized in their approach. Mr. Fraser was recently honored by the New York Film Critics Circle  for his work on “Zero Dark Thirty.”

headline: Keeping Score: Pacers Lead Central Despite Offensive Woes
text: The 2011-12 N.B.A. season was an unqualified success for the Indiana Pacers, who finished with the third best record in the Eastern Conference and put a scare into the Miami Heat before bowing out of the conference semifinals in six games.

headline: Video: Cuomo’s State of the State Address
text: Updated, 4:08 p.m. | Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, rewriting his agenda in the wake of Hurricane Sandy and the Newtown, Conn., school massacre, proposed measures in his State of the State address on Wednesday intended to limit the damage from future storms and to reduce the scourge of gun violence. (Mr. Cuomo begins his speech about 34 minutes into the video.)

headline: Rare Box Stolen From Oakland Museum
text: A box created from gold and quartz at the time of the California Gold Rush was stolen early Monday morning from the Oakland Museum, in the second theft from the museum in two months, according to reports in California newspapers.

headline: Away from Headlines, Boston’s Bradley Makes an Impression
text: Monday night’s game between the Knicks and the Celtics will be remembered for several reasons: its playoff atmosphere; Paul Pierce’s vintage Knicks-felling performance; and a dispute between Kevin Garnett and Carmelo Anthony that has dominated headlines since Boston’s victory.

headline: If Marlon Wayans Asks You to His House, Think Twice
text: “A Haunted House,” a film that opens Friday and stars Marlon Wayans, is ostensibly a parody of the “Paranormal Activity” franchise, down to the found-footage style and the setting in a generic Western tract house. Mr. Wayans’s character buys a video camera to document his girlfriend’s move into his bachelor pad, only to discover she’s brought a demon with her.

headline: Planning Summer (Already!) Amid Winter’s Chill
text: Unbelievably, it is time to plan for summer.

headline: Look of The Moment | Rachel Weisz
text: The Look: Dainty as a Daisy. A dusty floral on a prim, bow-tied dress hints strongly at vintage, but opulent accessories — gilded platforms and a glossy croc clutch — keep the effect from feeling old.

headline: The Scent of Supreme Leadership
text: We are a bit late to this, but, as our fellow news bloggers Max Fisher and Andrew Sullivan have both noted, the Washington Post’s man in Tehran, Jason Rezaian, reported on Twitter this week that he had discovered the perfect gift for pious Iranians who like to smoke in their cars: an air freshener in the image of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

headline: Excerpt: '1600 Penn'
text: Bill Pullman is the President of the United States in this NBC sitcom.

headline: Hagelian Dialectic
text: David: Gail, between 2004 and 2006 I did some preliminary work on an idea I had for a book. It was a group biography of senators who had offices on the second floor of the Russell Senate Office Building, along with selected friends. The senators were John McCain, Chuck Hagel, Joe Biden, Lindsey Graham, plus Hillary Clinton and Joe Lieberman.

headline: A New Scribble on Your Dollar Bill
text: Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s reported pick for Treasury secretary, has a ridiculous signature, as the blogosphere learned from a widely circulated White House memo he signed in 2011.

headline: Censored Newspaper Returns to Publication Amid Struggles
text: GUANGZHOU, China — Propaganda officials in the southern province of Guangdong have agreed to loosen some controls over an embattled newspaper whose struggle against censorship has galvanized free-speech advocates across China, according to journalists at the newspaper. But the paper’s weekly Thursday edition went to press late partly because of internal disputes over content, one senior editor said.

headline: Public Goals, Private Interests in Debt Campaign
text: When Jim McCrery, a former Louisiana congressman, urged lawmakers last month to pursue entitlement cuts and tax reform, he was introduced on television as a leader of Fix the Debt, a group of business executives and onetime legislators who have become Washington’s most visible and best-financed advocates for reining in the federal deficit.

headline: Anti-Semitism Charge Provokes Furor in Germany
text: LONDON — The Simon Wiesenthal Center has prompted an outraged debate in Germany after it included a prominent German journalist’s remarks in its annual top 10 list of anti-Semitic and anti-Israel slurs.

headline: Debate Continues Over Public Library Plan
text: The $300 million renovation of the Fifth Avenue flagship building of the New York Public Library continues to be divisive.

headline: Bonds (and Everyone) Strikes Out
text: In the most resounding referendum yet on the legacy of steroids in baseball, voters for the Hall of Fame emphatically rejected the candidacies of Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens in balloting results announced on Wednesday.

headline: On Our Radar: Fires in Australia and Snow in Damascus
text: Daunting wildfires continue in the Australian state of New South Wales, but the consuming inferno that officials had feared does not fully materialize. Still, officials warn that the danger is not over and that hot conditions have moved further north. On Tuesday, Australia recorded its highest average temperature yet: 104.59 degrees Fahrenheit. [CNN]

headline: Stargazing: Kerry Washington
text: Ms. Washington’s red carpet looks from “Django Unchained” premieres around the world.

headline: Loeb Explains His Herbalife Bet
text: Daniel S. Loeb took many by surprise on Wednesday when he unveiled an 8.2 percent stake in Herbalife, countering a big negative bet by his friend William A. Ackman.

headline: Most States Keep Gun Permit Data Under Wraps
text: In the extended national conversation about guns that has unfolded since the shootings in Newtown, Conn., the decision by The Journal News, a newspaper based in White Plains, to publish the names and addresses of handgun permit holders in two suburban New York counties last month has emerged as a flash point.

headline: Biden, Meeting Gun Control Advocates, Vows Action
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is planning a comprehensive effort to pass legislation and use executive orders to prevent gun violence, representatives of about a dozen gun control organizations were told Wednesday at a White House meeting.

headline: Lego Updates Its Mindstorms Robotics Kit
text: Lego Mindstorms EV3 ($350) is a long-awaited update to the Lego robotics kits used by many schools. The idea, Lego says, is to bring snap-together robots into every home.

headline: Before Aurora Slaughter, Self-Portraits, Court Hears
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — The ghostly self portraits, taken with a cellphone hours before he opened fire at an Aurora movie theater, show James E. Holmes in the final sprint of his deadly plan, prosecutors believe.

headline: Marlon Wayans Talks ‘A Haunted House’
text: TimesCast Media+Tech: Trend spotting at the Consumer Electronics Show. | David Pogue reviews calendar apps. | Marlon Wayans, the actor and screenwriter, returns to spoofing horror films.

headline: Academy Award Memories
text: Academy Award winners share memories of their first Oscar experience.

headline: Local Ties of Obama’s Choice to Lead Treasury
text: The news on Wednesday that President Obama planned to elevate his chief of staff, Jacob J. Lew, to be his next secretary of Treasury, prompted City Room to recall Mr. Lew’s connection to New York, which was recounted last year in this blog post.

headline: More Options to Dock Your iPhone 5 From Philips
text: Hoping to satisfy iPhone 5 users, the Dutch electronics maker Philips has introduced an array of docking speakers with Apple Lightning connectors.

headline: Split Decisions and That Fork in the Road
text: From Jane Eyre and Oliver Twist to Harry Potter, fictional orphans are lonely, misunderstood, often small and markedly different from the people who raise them, and all haunted by the question: Why? Why am I alone in a world where everyone else seems to belong to someone?

headline: Bringing the Calendar Up to Date
text: You know what’s kind of wild? We can identify products by their container designs. You’d know a ketchup bottle, even if it was empty and unlabeled, no matter what the brand. You’d know a pickle jar, or a milk jug, or a bottle of salad dressing, or a cereal box just by their container shapes.

headline: Boeing Says 787 Is Safe Despite Recent Problems
text: Boeing defended the safety of its 787 Dreamliner airplane on Wednesday after three incidents in three days, saying it had “extreme confidence” in the innovative design and technology used in the plane.

headline: Queens Man Dies Just Shy of 111th Birthday
text: Carl Berner, a former toolmaker, toy-maker, factory owner and civic activist who achieved his greatest fame for simply staying alive, died at his home in Middle Village, Queens, on Monday, 20 days shy of his 111th birthday.

headline: A Historic Jazz Label Gets a New Life
text: The major-label landscape hasn’t been hospitable to jazz in recent years, but there’s a bit of good news on the horizon: OKeh Records, the label that released historic early recordings by Louis Armstrong, King Oliver and Duke Ellington, is being revived under the corporate umbrella of Sony Masterworks. The new OKeh roster will feature contemporary artists, including the guitarist Bill Frisell, the saxophonist David Sanborn and the pianist and keyboardist Bob James; its first release will be “A Different Time,” by the pianist John Medeski, on April 9.

headline: Nightmare Week for Dreamliner
text: Glitches on Boeing’s Dreamliner airplanes have surfaced every day since Monday, our colleagues in the Business section report. That includes an All Nippon Airways aircraft at Yamaguchi Ube Airport in Japan whose on-board computer on Wednesday erroneously showed problems with its brakes; a plane operated by Japan Airlines at Boston’s Logan Airport that had a fuel leak on Tuesday; another Japan Airlines plane at Logan that had an electrical fire on Monday. None of the problems occurred in-flight and none caused injuries. “While the problems so far do not point to serious design flaws with the airplane,” Jad Mouawad and Bettina Wassener write, “they represent an embarrassment to Boeing’s manufacturing ability.”

headline: Executive Action on Guns
text: At a White House meeting about gun control this morning, Vice President Joe Biden said his boss was fully prepared to take executive action to reduce gun violence, an important but limited way to bypass the inevitable Congressional roadblocks.

headline: ‘Les Misérables’ Soundtrack Storms to No. 1
text: The soundtrack to the film “Les Misérables” is No. 1 on the latest Billboard album chart, beating out Mumford & Sons by a hair in the sleepy sales week after Christmas.

headline: Islanders Defenseman Doesn’t Want to Be Pushed Back to N.H.L.
text: Lubomir Visnovsky said he has had “enough already” and is tired of being “pushed” by the Islanders and the N.H.L. to return to North America rather than stay with Slovan Bratislava of the K.H.L. until the end of the season.

headline: Marlon Wayans on Spoofing Horror Films
text: Marlon Wayans, the actor and screenwriter, returns to spoofing horror films with his new movie, “A Haunted House.”

headline: Newtown Shooting Dominates Opening of Connecticut Legislative Session
text: HARTFORD — Choking up as he reflected on the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, in a somber State of the State address beginning the legislative session at the State Capitol here, promised to take actions aimed at preventing a similar tragedy from happening again.

headline: A.I.G. Says It Will Not Join Lawsuit Against Government
text: 9:09 p.m. | Updated
