headline: A Cuckoo Kickoff for Men’s in London
text: Men’s wear is in a gray area right now.

headline: Seven Injured After Crane Collapses in Queens
text: A 300-foot crane collapsed on Wednesday, toppling onto a building under construction in Long Island City, Queens, trapping three workers in twisted metal and injuring seven.

headline: Washington Post Ends Its Food Blog
text: The Washington Post announced Wednesday morning that it had ended its food blog, All We Can Eat.

headline: Disney World Gets New President
text: LOS ANGELES – Walt Disney World has a new president: George Kalogridis will take over the top job at the Florida resort on Feb. 1. Disney Made the announcement on Wednesday as part of a broader shuffling of management at its $12.9 billion parks and resorts division.

headline: A Caveat in Creating an Online Social Security Account
text: I wrote this week about expanded online services offered by the Social Security Administration through its My Social Security Web site.

headline: Leno Wins Three-Way Late-Night Race
text: On Jimmy Kimmel’s first night as a new player in the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman, Mr. Leno retained bragging rights — narrowly.

headline: Pap Test Could Help Find Cancers of Uterus and Ovaries
text: The Pap test, which has prevented countless deaths from cervical cancer, may eventually help to detect cancers of the uterus and ovaries as well, a new study suggests.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Calendars
text: David Pogue reviews calendar apps and software.

headline: Are Jokes Something You Have to Work At?
text: Jonah Weiner’s profile of Jerry Seinfeld in our Dec. 23 issue elicited 303 responses from readers, many of whom debated whether the comedian is even funny. Said one: “Jerry is safe, solid, and smooth. . . . he lulls the listener to a laugh.” Said another: “His talent is unparalleled: no curse words, simple everyday observations, turned into exquisite narrative.”

headline: A Way to Put Phones Into Helmets
text: People are loath to give up their mobile phones, even when engaged in sports risky enough to make it wise to use a helmet, like skiing, snowmobiling, motorcycling or bicycling. On top of the safety concerns, there is wind noise to contend with.

headline: A Tricked-Out Bentley at C.E.S. Shows Off Tech’s Capabilities
text: Connected cars and autonomous autos are major draws at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week. But some of the most intriguing car technology is being shown in a customized, obsidian black 2012 Bentley Continental GT.

headline: Idle Talk About Idol
text: Beliebers didn’t want to believe. Last Friday, TMZ posted photos of Justin Bieber holding what the Web site said was marijuana at a party the singer had with friends at a hotel in Newport Beach, Calif. His nearly 33 million Twitter followers were stunned. How could their squeaky-clean idol let them down? Others were less charitable.

headline: Leading Indian Tennis Players Agitate for Better Support
text: CHENNAI, India — In a reprise of the operatic bickering last summer over the Olympics, India’s top tennis players are once again locked in a bitter dispute with the national tennis association.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Trend Spotting at C.E.S.
text: TimesCast Media+Tech: Trend spotting at the Consumer Electronics Show. David Pogue reviews calendar apps. Marlon Wayans, the actor and screenwriter, returns to spoofing horror films.

headline: Washington National Cathedral Announces It Will Hold Same-Sex Weddings
text: The Washington National Cathedral, the nation’s traditional host of prayer services for presidents and memorial services for national tragedies, announced on Wednesday that it would now also hold weddings for same-sex couples.

headline: Generation LGBTQIA
text: STEPHEN IRA, a junior at Sarah Lawrence College, uploaded a video last March on We Happy Trans, a site that shares “positive perspectives” on being transgender.

headline: Stage Scenes: Ethan Hawke
text: A look at some of the actor’s past stage performances.

headline: New Year Begins With Flurry of Ad Industry Deals
text: 4:25 p.m. | Updated The new year has barely begun, but it looks as if it may be a busy one for deal-making on Madison Avenue.

headline: Tip of the Week: Finding Flights Fast
text: Now that the holiday travel season has wound down, many people are starting to look ahead to a spring vacation. Services like Kayak let you efficiently compare multiple flights to find the best fares — as well as hotels and rental cars. The experimental Google Flight Explorer page now lets travelers compare potential trips with multiple destinations and varying lengths all at once — and also shows baggage fees and which flights have Wi-Fi service.

headline: Q&A: Making the Mac Take Dictation
text: Q.

headline: Q&A: Returning to Windows 7
text: Q.

headline: Owners Give Approval and Offer an Apology
text: Amid apologies from the leaders who called for the lockout that shut down the N.H.L. for almost four months, the N.H.L. Board of Governors approved a tentative collective bargaining agreement with the players union Wednesday.

headline: Where Modernity Frames Tradition
text: LONDON — The other day I caught up with New Court, the London headquarters for Rothschild Bank, designed by Ellen van Loon and Rem Koolhaas of OMA. Opulent, context friendly, almost stealthy, it’s an “adult building,” as one of the architects who worked on the project half-jokingly put it.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 10
text: ASAP Rocky, What I’m Wearing Now; Marcelo Burlon’s T-shirts available; not just for the pool: do-Paris swimsuits; and Givenchy sneakers to order now.

headline: Aerial Autos
text: A look at Matthew Porter’s photographs of muscle cars in flight.

headline: S.E.C. Opens Investigation Into Herbalife
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is adding to the scrutiny of Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company that has been a favorite target of prominent hedge fund short-sellers.

headline: Tell Us, if You Were a Tree ...
text: RED is Marc Jacobs’s favorite color, and, for what it’s worth, his favorite former porn star is named Eddie.

headline: More Votes of Confidence for ‘Skyfall’ and an Obstacle for ‘Lincoln’
text: The American Society of Cinematographers keeps giving accolades to Roger Deakins. Mr. Deakins earned his 11th nomination today, for the cinematography in “Skyfall,” alongside another veteran nominee, five-timer Janusz Kaminski (“Lincoln”). Seamus McGarvey (“Anna Karenina”), Danny Cohen (“Les Misérables”) and Claudio Miranda (“Life of Pi”) round out their picks.

headline: TV Puppeteer at Center of Controversy Quits in Puerto Rico
text: 8:35 p.m. | Updated

headline: Saudi Arabia Executes Sri Lankan Maid
text: A Sri Lankan woman who was employed as a domestic worker in Saudi Arabia was beheaded by the Saudi authorities on Wednesday after she was accused of murdering an infant in her charge and then sentenced to death in a case that the Sri Lankan government and human rights groups said was flawed.

headline: A Touch of Autumn
text: Looks from Stella McCartney, Nina Ricci, Céline, Chloé, Lanvin and Philosophy’s prefall collections.

headline: Do People Actually Shop on Phones? The Answer Is Decidedly Yes
text: In e-commerce, the mobile revolution is here.

headline: Scene City: Alber Elbaz Takes the Stage
text: The YMA FSF Geoffrey Beene National Scholarship Awards holds its annual dinner.

headline: Starting the Year With a Bon Mot
text: THE social calendar roared back to life on Tuesday night, when the YMA FSF Geoffrey Beene National Scholarship Awards held its annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

headline: It’s Anybody’s Guess Now, So Whom Would You Nominate?
text: With only hours to go until the Academy bigwigs, telecast host Seth MacFarlane and actress Emma Stone announce the nominees, the race is still not settled. Even veteran prognosticators are split on what will make the cut for best picture – “Lincoln”? “Argo”? “Zero Dark Thirty”? “Les Miz”? “Life of Pi” is creeping up in the game too, with its DGA nomination for Ang Lee, and the Bagger keeps hearing raves for “Silver Linings Playbook.” Other indicators, like the cinematography society nominations, are only muddying the field, at least when it comes to handicapping. If you’ve got money in the game on the nominations tomorrow, check some of the round-up sites here and here, and otherwise, prepare to be surprised. Who do you want to see on the list of nominees tomorrow morning?

headline: Easygoing Tailoring and Tweeds in Prefall Collections
text: THE prefall collections resumed this week after a holiday break (we heard about people’s trips to St. Barth and the Bahamas), with presentations by European brands. A sign of how important these showings are, creative directors were in attendance: Peter Copping of Nina Ricci, Clare Waight Keller of Chloé, Alber Elbaz of Lanvin. Store chiefs turned up as well, along with editors and a few celebrities.

headline: A Closer Look at a Shift in Britain’s Near-Term Global Warming Forecast
text: 7:22 p.m. | Updates below |Quite a few professional climate skeptics have been crowing in the last few days about a 20-percent downward shift in the short-term forecast for global temperature (through 2017) from Britain’s weather and climate agency, best know as the Met Office. Here are the graphs showing the change, with the first published in 2011 (see the related release here, thanks to Leo Hickman of the Guardian) and the next one from late last month:

headline: The Library at the Public
text: AS part of the Public Theater’s renovation, a cocktail lounge called the Library was added that harkens back to the building’s bookish past as the Astor Library. Tucked into the new mezzanine level, the Library looks as if it has been there for years but is, in fact, an entirely new space designed by David Rockwell.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 9
text: A view of the day in sports, which included regional soccer tournaments and Australian Open qualifying matches.

headline: Crossing the Line Online: Sexual Harassment and Violence in the Age of Social Media
text: Overview | How widespread are sexual harassment and sexual violence among teenagers today, and what role is social media playing? In this lesson, students take an anonymous survey about their own experiences. They then examine several recent articles, from The New York Times and elsewhere, about sexual harassment and assault in the age of social media. Finally, they discuss the issues that arise and consider ways to take action.

headline: Scouting Report
text: FASHION SHOW

headline: The Politics of the Platinum Coin
text: I don’t feel qualified to comment definitively on the technical legality or constitutionality of the widely-bruited proposal that President Obama should respond to House Republicans’ debt ceiling brinksmanship by threatening to mint a $1 trillion platinum coin. But I do feel qualified to raise some questions about the political consequences that proponents of “minting the coin” (a group that includes some very smart people not normally given to flights of ideological fancy) seem to think will follow from such a gambit. Here is Matt Yglesias, speaking for a multitude of would-be minters:

headline: Weather Channel Takes a Galactic Leap
text: We are forced to ask: Will the Weather Channel now start naming storms on other planets?

headline: Taking a Deep Look at Tools for Scuba Divers
text: In the middle of winter there can be few more spine-chilling thoughts than the idea of slipping into the ocean for a dip. But at least one group of people are attracted to the idea of year-round: scuba divers.

headline: Minister’s Comments on Gay Rights Raise Questions on Role in Inauguration
text: 9:11 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.5:45 p.m. | Updated The minister President Obama picked to deliver the benediction at his inauguration this month delivered a sermon the 1990s in which he called on fellow Christians to fight the ”aggressive agenda” of the gay rights movement, and advocated “the healing power of Jesus’’ as “the only way out of a homosexual lifestyle.’’

headline: The New Mantra: Replacing ‘Om’ With ‘Glam’
text: ROLL over, $800 yoga mat.

headline: Taking in Paris Any Day, Any Century
text: PARIS — In a 1789 painting of the Bastille, the French artist Hubert Robert portrayed that Paris fortress as a huge, seemingly impregnable structure and the Parisian revolutionaries who razed it as small, vulnerable human beings. More than two centuries later, thanks to 3-D modeling software, a different picture of the Bastille emerges. In its recreated setting it is the Bastille that seems small, even vulnerable.

headline: FM Radio on Cellphones, Long Sought by Broadcasters, Comes to Sprint
text: For years, the radio industry has watched with worry as consumers snap up all kinds of electronic gadgets — from cellphones to tablets to set-top TV boxes — that deliver seemingly every kind of media but that old standby, terrestrial radio.

headline: Mobile Chargers Ease That Feeling of Powerlessness
text: You undoubtedly know people so smitten with their smartphones and tablets that they experience separation anxiety when asked to put them away, even if it’s just long enough to get through dinner. But that is nothing compared with the angst they feel when their devices’ batteries are getting low. Think tremors and rending of garments.

headline: A.I.G. Rejects Shareholder Suit
text: The American International Group has wisely chosen to avoid joining a shareholder lawsuit against government agencies that bailed it out with $182 billion in loans and capital. In an unequivocal statement released Wednesday afternoon, the company said its board would not join a case brought by Starr International, the investment vehicle controlled by A.I.G.’s former top executive Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, in courts in New York and Washington.

headline: Solis Stepping Down as Labor Secretary
text: WASHINGTON – Secretary of Labor Hilda L. Solis announced on Wednesday that she was stepping down, becoming the latest woman to leave President Obama’s cabinet at a time when his personnel choices are drawing scrutiny for their lack of female candidates.

headline: A Late-Night Show Where Cage Holds Sway
text: For anyone confronted constantly with gloomy prognostications about the decline and demise of classical music, high art, Western culture or whatever, the sight of a capacity audience assembled at 10 p.m. on a Tuesday to hear a program of modern American string-quartet music is a powerful shot in the arm.

headline: Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan
text: Peter Clark and Jess Jurkovic of New York City tied for the Greater New York Bridge Association Flight B Player of the Year award.

headline: No Caution in the Eye of the Storm
text: “I’m in love again!” To watch Linda Lavin, wearing a rapturous smile, toss back her head, throw out her arms and shiver with delight while delivering the title phrase from a sexy Cy Coleman-Peggy Lee ballad was to observe a singer deliriously consumed by the lyrics’ celebration of second and third romantic chances. Her performance on Tuesday evening at 54 Below made you ponder what the term “in love” means in the 21st century, when in the 20th it was assumed to be the divine state to which everybody aspired with an implied happy ending.

headline: Dish’s Potemkin Offer for Clearwire
text: Sprint and Softbank are being forced into tactical warfare. U.S. satellite-TV company Dish Network, run by the enigmatic Charlie Ergen, put forward a highly conditional offer for Clearwire, a spectrum owner integral to the ambitions of Sprint and its Japanese buyer. Though the bid is unlikely to go far, it could pressure Sprint to pay more — or strike a deal with Dish.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Steve Ballmer’s N.B.A. Plans and Why C.E.S. Matters
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: Driving Directions With a Human Touch
text: One of the problems facing GPS makers is how to make maps that drivers can use while paying attention to the road rather than the screen.

headline: Behind the Bedroom Door
text: The no-longer secret life of teenagers.

headline: Chronicles of a Bed Unmade
text: A GOOD way to find out if you should enter a teenager’s bedroom is to ask yourself a single, unsparing question: Am I a teenager?

headline: Where Cats Run Free
text: In Pittsboro, N.C., Siglinda Scarpa has turned her home into an animal sanctuary.

headline: 300 Cats, Yes. Craziness, No.
text: PITTSBORO, N.C.

headline: Oscar Memories of the Last, or First, Time
text: On Thursday morning the Oscar nominees will at last be revealed, giving shape to what has been an unusually multidimensional race. The stars and directors of contenders like “Lincoln,” “Argo,” “Zero Dark Thirty,” “Silver Linings Playbook” and “Django Unchained” have been making the rounds to drum up support. For some of them by Thursday afternoon it will be time to pack up the borrowed finery and the studio-approved talking points, and go home. For others it will be the next leg of the race: a six-week sprint to a finish line that involves potentially hefting a gold statuette on Feb. 24 and delivering an embarrassing (or sweet, or funny, or ideally, all three) acceptance speech. As a primer for those left standing — and entertainment for those following along — here are some memories of Oscar experiences from previous winners and nominees, excerpted from interviews at premieres and galas this season.

headline: Flat Roofs, Mountain Views and Really Close Neighbors
text: A modern house in Boulder is unconventional in a number of ways.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photos from New York, Jordan, South Africa and Ivory Coast.

headline: The Semi-Detached Solution
text: GOOD design is often defined as an elegant solution (or a series of elegant solutions) to a complex equation whose variables include space, money, time and human behavior. Also personal biography, history, taste and municipal law.

headline: Where Pills and Crime Collide
text: LOS ANGELES — Important safety information: Adverse reactions associated with this product include dry mouth, nausea, headaches, anxiety, insomnia.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. The bedroom in my apartment has very small windows. Should I try to do something to make them look bigger?

headline: Remembering Richard Ben Cramer
text: The first time I met Richard Ben Cramer, who died this week at 62, I was seeking his advice about a book I wanted to write, and so I called and invited myself down to Maryland’s Eastern Shore. That’s where Richard lived, about a two-hour drive from Washington, in a couple of weathered farmhouses – one for living with his companion at the time and later his wife, Joan, and one for writing. He said sure, come anytime and we would get lunch, he wasn’t doing much of anything, which of course was never true.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,395,000
text: BLUE HILL, ME.

headline: Homes for $1,395,000
text: Properties in Los Angeles, Maine and Denver.

headline: Creature Feature
text: A meeting of a Swiss Surrealist and a British rock band in the imagination of an Italian designer was the genesis for Pig on the Wings. The cloven-hoof stool by Michael Breschi, founder of the Milan-based (and soon to be Miami-based) studio Gentle Giants, pays homage to Meret Oppenheim’s 1939 Traccia table, whose legs terminate in a pair of bird feet. And the name is a slightly scrambled reference to “Pigs on the Wing,” a two-part love song on Pink Floyd’s 1977 “Animals” album. (Mr. Breschi listened to “Animals” a lot while designing the piece.)

headline: Casting Off the Yolk
text: Quirky, the online developer of household products, has introduced a new way to separate raw eggs. Pluck (about $13) is a silicone bulb with a removable plastic nozzle. Crack an egg into a bowl, position the nozzle over the yolk and give a little squeeze. The yolk slithers up into the bulb, ready to be released with another squeeze.

headline: A Deadpan Gaze at the Down and Out in China
text: “I regret eating glass,” San Bao, the depressed young hero of Zhang Yuan’s “Beijing Flickers,” says in a voice-over, the bottom half of his face covered in a white bandage. More things he regrets: checking into a hospital, where he can’t pay the bill, and also checking out of the hospital. After all, life in the big city isn’t going so well. His girlfriend has left him (for a richer man), he’s lost his job, and his dog — Lucky, no less — has run away. He can’t even kill himself properly — a suicide attempt on a train track turns into a Buster Keaton gag.

headline: Less Is Not in Store
text: Can modernist design be dreamy? A show that runs Tuesday through April 21 at MAKK, the Museum of Applied Art in Cologne, Germany, makes a strong case for the affirmative. “Isn’t It Romantic: Contemporary Design Balancing Between Poetry and Provocation” focuses on what its curator, Tulga Beyerle, considers the softer side of a rigorous aesthetic movement. “Design is escaping from functionalism,” Ms. Beyerle said. “Young designers are critical of industrial production.” Included are projects by newcomers like Julien Carretero from France (his ladder, above right, which is made from oak excavated from a medieval Dutch city wall, will appear in a section devoted to concepts), but also work by established designers who have turned away from modernist strictures. Among the veteran offerings are Maurizio Galante’s Cactus sofa for Cerruti Baleri (above left) and Studio Makkink & Bey’s Birdwatch cabinet (above center). The catalog (about $32) is available at dermuseumsshop.de. Information: 011-49-221-2212-3860.

headline: Drapery Through the Ages
text: “If it had not been for the Parisian designer, we in the West would be hanging rags in our windows,” said the design historian Gail Caskey Winkler, author of “Capricious Fancy: Draping and Curtaining the Historic Interior, 1800-1930” (University of Pennsylvania Press, $85). French design ideas fired up the English and spread from there, leading to tented beds, swagged windows and portieres.

headline: A Strong Thread in a Torn Union
text: When Elizabeth Keckley, a former slave turned professional dressmaker and confidante of Mary Todd Lincoln, published her memoir, “Behind the Scenes,” in 1868, the response was vitriolic. One Washington reviewer called Mrs. Keckley “treacherous” and asked: “What family of eminence that employs a Negro is safe from such desecration? Where will it end?”

headline: Sales at Robert Martin Designs, John Robshaw and Others
text: Tomorrow through Sunday, Robert Martin Designs will discount all showroom samples up to 50 percent (a glass-and-cherry wood coffee table, regularly $5,000, is $3,600), Brooklyn Navy Yard Building 280, Suite 223, 63 Flushing Avenue (Navy and Sand Streets), Brooklyn, (917) 603-0644, robertmartindesigns.com.

headline: House Hunting in ... France
text: 19th-CENTURY CASTLE IN NORMANDY

headline: A 19th-Century Castle Outside Rouen
text: An elaborate brick and limestone structure on 92 acres, with its own chapel, is on the market for $2.7 million.

headline: Four Tips for Better Sunrise Photos
text: While fireworks make for spectacular pictures, they show up only so many times a year, whereas nature’s fireworks — sunrises and sunsets — are available daily.

headline: A Send-Off for a Harlem Funeral Director
text: As a funeral director in Harlem for more than six decades, George Bernard Benta delivered his personal brand of service for luminaries like Langston Hughes, James Baldwin, Paul Robeson, Etta Jones, Coleman Hawkins, Gil Noble and Alvin Ailey.

headline: Israeli Election Ads Ruled Too Offensive for Broadcast Rack Up Views on YouTube
text: Efforts to introduce some drama, or comedy, into the somewhat lackluster Israeli election campaign, in the form of satirical television ads for two parties at opposite ends of the political spectrum, have been stifled by the country’s Central Election Committee, which deemed them too offensive to broadcast. Despite those rulings, however, both ads have attracted tens of thousands of views online this week.

headline: Questions of Strategy as Griffin Has Surgery
text: Washington Redskins quarterback Robert Griffin III had two knee ligaments surgically repaired Wednesday — including a reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament and a repair of a tear in the lateral collateral ligament — the result of a knee injury he sustained during Sunday’s playoff loss to the Seattle Seahawks.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Wish List
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo vowed on Wednesday that New York would soon enact the “toughest gun assault weapon ban in the nation. Period.” New Yorkers should hold him to that promise. He made stronger gun laws an urgent priority in his annual State of the State address, but he will need to present the specifics quickly to a divided Legislature and push lawmakers to act. The supporting documents for his speech suggest that he plans to tighten the ban on large magazines and require all gun owners to reapply for a permit every few years, replacing the lifetime permits allowed in some counties. He also wants mental health professionals to be able to report if someone is dangerous, allowing law enforcement to confiscate the individual’s firearms. And he would make the process of licensing guns more efficient while increasing penalties for use of guns illegally.

headline: Restoring Iran’s Heritage of Magnificent Homes in an Age of High Rises
text: KASHAN, Iran — A petite woman in gray boots and a checkered scarf, Shanaz Nader had spent much of her adult life abroad, with long stretches in Tokyo, London and New York. But here she was braving a cold wind in this desert city three hours south of Tehran, making her way through a maze of high mud-brick walls.

headline: The Scene of an Accident at Pier 11
text: A ferry bound from Atlantic Highlands, N.J., to Manhattan ran into a pier Wednesday, injuring scores of people.

headline: The Debt Ceiling’s Escape Hatch
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Frenchman Dreams of Russia
text: RETURNING home from a visit to Russia in 1774, the philosophe Denis Diderot wrote that in France, he could not “help but think that I’ve the soul of a slave in a country where men are called free,” whereas in Russia he “had the soul of a free man in a country where men are called slaves.”

headline: Borrowed Hearing Aid Opens New World to Teenager
text: He thought he was the only one.

text: To the Editor:

headline: New Evidence Expected in WikiLeaks Case
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — Military prosecutors preparing to try Pfc. Bradley Manning said on Wednesday that they would introduce evidence that Osama bin Laden requested and received from a Qaeda member some of the State Department cables and military reports that Private Manning is accused of passing to WikiLeaks.

headline: Abbas and Hamas Leader Meet at Egypt’s Invitation
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority met on Wednesday in Cairo with Khaled Meshal, the political chief of Mr. Abbas’s rival, Hamas, but it was unclear if they were able to overcome any of the differences that have fueled a bitter five-year feud.

headline: A Trillion-Dollar Coin Brings a Jackpot of Jests
text: WASHINGTON — A bizarre but seemingly legal idea to get around the country’s debt ceiling using a trillion-dollar coin is having its day in Washington.

headline: Rodgers’s Homecoming Calls Up a Slight
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — By the time the Packers-49ers game kicks off Saturday night, it will have been 7 years, 8 months, 20 days and a little more than 3 hours.

headline: When Burglary Is Not Burglary
text: Matthew Descamps was convicted in 2008 of being a felon in possession of a handgun and ammunition under federal law, which usually leads to a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. But a federal trial judge in Washington State more than doubled that sentence to 21 years and 10 months under the Armed Career Criminal Act.

headline: A Step Backward in Bank Regulations
text: A committee of central bankers and regulators from more than two dozen countries, including the United States, has disappointingly given in to lobbying by big banks and watered down important rules meant to strengthen the global financial system. The change will let banks include risky financial instruments like corporate bonds and mortgage-backed securities as part of their liquid asset reserves, which are meant to cover up to 30 days of cash outflows during crises. And the banks have until 2019, not 2015, to comply fully with the easier standards. Each nation will decide when and how to implement the rules.

headline: Mexico: Killer Dog Case Widens
text: A pack of feral dogs may be responsible for the deaths of as many as five people in a Mexico City park, the authorities said Wednesday. Last week, the police said dogs had killed four people, including a woman and a baby boy, whose mutilated bodies were found in the park in December. Now, prosecutors are investigating if the wounds found on a fifth person, a 15-year-old girl who died in December, are consistent with dog bites. The authorities have captured several dogs, spurring an online campaign to save them, but it is not clear if any are the culprits.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Penalize 2 Auditors in Bank Case
text: In its first case against auditors stemming from the financial crisis, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday took action against two KPMG employees who had given a clean audit opinion to a Nebraska-based bank holding company that later failed because of bad loans it had made to real estate developers in Nevada and Florida.

headline: Brazil: Prosecutor to Analyze Testimony by Suspect About Former President
text: The prosecutor general, Roberto Gurgel, said Wednesday that he would analyze testimony in which a businessman convicted in an embezzlement and vote-buying scheme tied Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, to the scandal. The businessman, Marcos Valério de Souza, received a 40-year sentence in October after he was found to have operated much of the scheme, the mensalão, or “big monthly allowance,” named after payments received by legislators. The Supreme Court’s trial of suspects in the scheme resulted in the conviction of senior figures, including Mr. da Silva’s former chief of staff, who was sentenced to nearly 11 years in prison. In testimony, Mr. de Souza said he deposited funds in 2003 for Mr. da Silva’s “personal spending,” in an account controlled by another aide to the former president. After Mr. de Souza’s assertion, Mr. da Silva said he could not “respond to a lie.” Mr. Gurgel said no decision had been made on a formal investigation.

headline: Democracy in the House
text: The only reason that income taxes on 99 percent of Americans did not go up this month was that Speaker John Boehner briefly broke with an iron rule of Republican control over the House. He allowed the fiscal-cliff deal to be put to a full vote of the House even though a strong majority of Republicans opposed it.

headline: Probation for Ex-SAC Analyst Who Cooperated in Insider Trading Inquiries
text: A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors who has become a crucial informant in the government’s insider trading investigations avoided prison on Wednesday after a judge sentenced him to probation.

headline: Lipton Goes Back to Basics With a Tea Bag
text: BACK in the “Mad Men” days, a trade organization known as the Tea Council of the U.S.A. celebrated the beverage its members sold with ads that carried the theme “Take tea and see.”

headline: Despite No Direct Tie to Steroids, Piazza Falls Short
text: Voters roundly rejected some of the most accomplished baseball players in the history of the game Wednesday, denying them entry into the Hall of Fame because of their documented association with performance-enhancing drugs. Caught in the middle was Mike Piazza, who hit 396 home runs as a catcher, more than any other player at the position, but who was never directly linked to steroids or human growth hormone.

headline: The Woes of Roe
text: Forty years ago this month, the Supreme Court handed down the great abortion rights decision Roe v. Wade. To be honest, you’re not going to be seeing a whole lot of cake and Champagne. Time magazine recognized the occasion with a downbeat cover story. (“They’ve Been Losing Ever Since.”) Gallup polls suggest support for abortion rights is fading, particularly among young Americans, and that more people now regard themselves as “pro-life” than “pro-choice.”

headline: The Obama Coalition vs. Corporate America
text: The slow implosion of the Republican Party — along with the growing strength of a Democratic coalition dominated by low-to-middle-income voters — threatens the power of the corporate establishment and will force big business to find new ways to reassert control of the policy-making process.

headline: Big Teachers’ Fund to Sell Its Gun Shares
text: One of America’s largest pension funds began on Wednesday to divest itself of firearms holdings, a response to the schoolhouse shooting in Newtown, Conn., that other pension funds could follow.

headline: Benefits of College Degree in Recession Are Outlined
text: Young adults have long faced a rough job market, but in the last recession and its aftermath, college graduates did not lose nearly as much ground as their less-educated peers, according to a new study.

headline: Postgame Confrontation Will Cost Anthony a Game
text: Soon after the Knicks landed in Indianapolis on Wednesday, they learned the N.B.A. had suspended Carmelo Anthony for one game without pay for confronting Kevin Garnett on Monday night.

headline: Deep Cuts Raise Questions About Morgan Stanley
text: When Morgan Stanley’s top executives gathered in mid-September at the Gramercy Park Hotel in Manhattan to discuss strategy, some participants complained that the room was too small.

headline: Robert Bork’s Tragedy
text: Even before Robert Bork died last month, he had achieved something close to martyrdom. In the quarter-century since the Senate rejected his Supreme Court nomination, successive generations of conservative lawyers and activists have carried the torch, depicting his defeat as an injustice of historic proportion. Following his death at the age of 85, liberals mostly maintained a respectful silence while conservatives dusted off old complaints about the conduct of the confirmation hearing and the unfairness, in their view, of the “borking” the nominee received. Clearly, the Bork Battle survives Bork.

headline: Chávez, or at Least His Sash, Is Set for Venezuela Inauguration
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez’s supporters have not ruled out swearing him in from his hospital in Havana. His detractors are calling for government investigators to go check his pulse themselves. The justices whom Mr. Chávez’s allies have named to the Supreme Court have decided that he can continue to govern in absentia.

headline: Justices Look at Legality of Drunken-Driving Test
text: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors in Missouri, supported by the federal government, came to the Supreme Court on Wednesday with a big request: They wanted the justices to rule that the police do not need warrants to obtain blood samples in drunken-driving investigations.

headline: Power for the Women of India
text: How can Indian women gain power so they would not only be safe, but also have more say in their nation's future?

headline: U.S. to Press Fight of Detainee’s Appeal
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, after a high-level debate among its legal team, told a federal appeals court on Wednesday that the conviction of a Guantánamo Bay prisoner by a military commission in 2008 was valid even though the charges against him — including “conspiracy” and “material support for terrorism” — were not recognized as war crimes in international law.

headline: Reframing the Gun Debate
text: This time things are different.

headline: Pastor Chosen for Inaugural Was Criticized as Antigay
text: WASHINGTON — The pastor whom President Obama has chosen to deliver the benediction at his inauguration this month delivered a sermon in the 1990s in which he called on fellow Christians to fight the “aggressive agenda” of the gay rights movement and advocated “the healing power of Jesus” as “the only way out of a homosexual lifestyle.”

headline: In Defense of Hagel for Defense
text: Critics are pounding President Obama’s choice for defense secretary, Chuck Hagel, as soft on Iran, anti-military and even anti-Semitic. This is a grotesque caricature of a man who would make a terrific defense secretary.

headline: State Department Official Urges Britain Not to Loosen Ties With European Union
text: LONDON — The United States entered Britain’s debate over its relationship with the European Union on Wednesday, when a senior diplomat implicitly warned the British government not to do anything that might endanger its membership in the 27-nation union.

headline: Afghan Amnesty Program Falls Short, Leaving Ex-Insurgents Regretful and Angry
text: MEHTAR LAM, Afghanistan — Eidi Mohammed, a former Taliban commander who recently renounced violence and sought amnesty under the Afghan government’s reconciliation program, has had another change of heart. Now he is thinking about rejoining his old comrades. Jobless and losing hope he will ever find work, Mr. Mohammed, 38, took his frustrations to provincial officials. They told him there was nothing they could do.

headline: Flu Widespread, Leading a Range of Winter’s Ills
text: It is not your imagination — more people you know are sick this winter, even people who have had flu shots.

headline: Shopping With Rita Ora
text: Bee-Shyuan Chang goes shopping with Rita Ora at Opening Ceremony, where the singer reveals her style evolution and inspirations.

headline: The ‘It’ Girl
text: At 22, Rita Ora, the prized protégée of Jay-Z, has been rapidly winning over designers with her carefree style.

text: NEW year, new girl.

text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: At Once Catholic and Secular, France Debates Gay Marriage
text: PARIS — Frigide Barjot has made a career of mocking the establishment of France, dressing in fluorescent pink sweaters, playing in a band called the Dead Pompidous and hosting a philosophy soirée at which she handed out T-shirts with the logo, “Kierkegaard is my homeboy.”

headline: Teenage Bedrooms: The Forbidden Frontier
text: Emily Cohn and Emma Orlow, seniors in high school, spent a year interviewing their fellow teens about everything from collages to carpets. The result: The Do Not Enter Diaries.

headline: New York Is Moving Quickly to Enact Tough Curbs on Guns
text: New York State is nearing agreement on a proposal to put what would be some of the nation’s strictest gun-control laws into effect, including what Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vowed on Wednesday would be an ironclad ban on assault weapons and large-capacity magazines, and new measures to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and mentally ill people.

headline: Something to Fill In
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a slight trick to getting the theme of today’s puzzle by Kevan Choset, and it’s not that the theme material is a bit more scattered than usual.

headline: Editors’ Note: January 10, 2013
text: A picture on Monday with an article about a new MagicBand technology that Walt Disney World plans to introduce in the coming months showed people wearing rubber bracelets that will be used with the technology. The people in the picture, which was provided by Disney, are actually models posing to demonstrate the new system, not Disney World customers. Such a posed picture should not have been used to illustrate the article.

headline: Lawmaking Maverick Resumes Course in Nebraska
text: LINCOLN, Neb. — They came to him with hugs and elbow bumps (he rarely shakes hands), wide grins and hearty backslaps.

headline: Hall Vote Puts a Damper on Cooperstown’s Party
text: While many who live in and work in Cooperstown were braced for a blow to the town’s annual Hall of Fame weekend, it took Wednesday’s depressing election announcement to land the actual punch. The traditional induction party will go on as it always does in late July, but because it won’t involve a single living honoree, it’s unclear just who exactly will be inclined to show up.

headline: Trial Begins in Death of 2-Month-Old Girl
text: For almost five years, Li Hangbin, 28, has been jailed on Rikers Island, awaiting trial in the 2007 death of his 2-month-old daughter, Annie.

headline: Woman Is Shot in Brooklyn
text: A woman in her 90s was shot twice by a gunman in a moving car around sunset on Wednesday in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

headline: Cuomo Calls for State to Return to Progressive Ideals
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who spent his first two years in office establishing himself as a fiscal conservative, turned left in his third annual address to the Legislature, and sought to reclaim the state’s progressive mantle.

headline: Lewis Follows in Fancy Footsteps, but Few Can Follow in His
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — With the fog machine on full blast before Sunday’s A.F.C. wild-card game at M&T Bank Stadium, Ray Lewis made his way onto the field to the symphonic renderings of the hip-hop artist Nelly. He reached down to grab a thick slab of sod and smashed it into his face.

headline: Atop New York Senate, an Odd Couple With Some Issues
text: ALBANY — As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo talked state of the state on Tuesday, the alternating presidents pro tem of the New York State Senate sat on the dais listening — two men who could not hide their I-swallowed-the-canary smiles.

headline: Who Is Jack Lew?
text: NAME Jacob Joseph Lew, known as Jack

headline: Police Say Suspect Planned to Blow Up Washington Arch
text: A man who was arrested last month on a charge of possession of a chemical explosive in his Greenwich Village apartment recently told acquaintances that he was busy “making bombs” to “blow up” Washington Arch, a police official said Wednesday.

headline: Ailing on Court and Off, Lakers Lose Fifth Straight
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Los Angeles Lakers flew into Texas for two nights with a wounded lineup, forced to start a player who joined the team from the Development League.

headline: In Harlem, a Nightspot So Iconic They’ll Reopen It. Twice.
text: A few short weeks ago, people in Harlem were wondering how the neighborhood would cope with the loss of the Lenox Lounge, where Dizzy Gillespie, John Coltrane and Billie Holiday once graced the stage, an authentic vestige of a bygone era.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Isner Withdraws From Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The top-ranked American John Isner pulled out of the Australian Open  on Thursday, citing a bone bruise in his right knee.

headline: Obama to Use King and Lincoln Bibles for Inaugural
text: When President Obama takes the public oath of office on Monday, Jan. 21 – the federal holiday commemorating the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. – he will use a Bible that belonged to the slain civil rights leader.

headline: U.S. Consumer Watchdog to Issue Mortgage Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Banks and other lenders will be prohibited from making home loans that offer deceptive teaser rates or require no documentation from borrowers, and will be required to take more steps to ensure that borrowers can repay, under new consumer protections to be announced on Thursday.

headline: Rescuing China’s Bears From Bile Farms, One by One
text: BEIJING — Some had wounded faces and bloodied paws. Some were angry after years of mistreatment.

headline: Philanthropist Abandons Plan for Velodrome in Brooklyn Park
text: Eight months after it was first announced to the surprise and bewilderment of many New Yorkers, an improbable but well-financed plan to bring a bicycle racing track to Brooklyn Bridge Park has collapsed.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK Jack (Alec Baldwin) forms an alliance with his rival Devin Banks (Will Arnett) in a scheme to discredit Kaylie Hooper (Chloë Grace Moretz), his teenage nemesis and the future chief executive of KableTown. Liz (Tina Fey) explores her options to become a mother. And Tracy (Tracy Morgan) tries to direct Octavia Spencer in his new movie. In “The Office,” at 9, Pam (Jenna Fischer) accidentally infects the office with lice but allows Meredith (Kate Flannery) to take the blame. Jim (John Krasinski) is having a great day in Philadelphia as he woos a possible business associate (Julius Erving). Phyllis (Phyllis Smith), Nellie (Catherine Tate) and Kevin (Brian Baumgartner) involve themselves in the love life of Darryl (Craig Robinson).

headline: News Quiz | January 10, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 10
text: NEWS Bush fires raging across some of the most populous parts of Australia — feeding off widespread drought conditions and high winds — pushed firefighters to their limits and residents to their wits’ end on Wednesday as meteorologists tracked the country’s hottest spring and summer on record into uncharted territory. Months of record-breaking temperatures have produced what the government calls “catastrophic” conditions. Matt Siegel reports from Sydney.

headline: In India’s Ancient Khajuraho, Eroticism Mingles With International Commerce
text: When you pass the sign that says “Welcome to Khajuraho,” you enter a different land. The roads become broad and smooth. Lush lawns and tall green trees line up on both sides of the street.

headline: 3 Kurds Are Killed in Paris, in Locked-Door Mystery
text: PARIS — The three Kurdish women were murdered, two with bullets to the head, the third with a shot to the stomach. It was a carefully planned killing in a nondescript building in central Paris.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 10, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Even a Drive in the Suburbs Feels Like a ’60s Vacation.”

headline: 2012 Was the Hottest Year on Record
text: In “Not Even Close: 2012 Was Hottest Ever in U.S.,” Justin Gillis reports on the climate records set in the United States in 2012.

headline: Echoes of Prayer and People
text: How do we live? How do we die? What do we think? Those are the questions that occupy Kenro Izu.

headline: Betrayed by Basel
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Do Adults Who Are ‘Only Trying to Help’ Sometimes Make Things Worse?
text: A recent study in the journal Pediatrics revealed that many overweight children felt bullied about their weight — not just by peers, but also by trusted adults, including coaches and parents.

headline: Private Equity in China: Which Way Out?
text: HONG KONG — Welcome to the private equity game in China: you can buy in anytime you like, but you can never leave.

headline: Ask a Financial Aid Expert About the Fafsa
text: As admission officers review the college applications that have flooded in by the Jan. 1 deadline, it’s time for those student applicants (and their parents) to submit what may be the most vital piece of their financial aid plans: the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

headline: Help for Planning End-of-Life Care
text: If your 2013 resolution is to get your family to embark, finally, on advance care planning, you will find a valuable guide in a new Web site called Prepare.

headline: Jets Widen Search for General Manager
text: The Jets, no closer to selecting their next general manager, have widened their search. Their latest pool of candidates, according to a person briefed on the search, includes Jerry Angelo, the former general manager of the Chicago Bears; Omar Khan, the Steelers’ director of business and football administration; and Brian Gaine, the Dolphins’ assistant general manager. Interviews will resume Thursday.

headline: Visit by Google Chairman May Benefit North Korea
text: BEIJING — As a work of propaganda, the images that North Korea circulated this week showing Google’s executive chairman, Eric E. Schmidt, touring a high-tech incubation center are hard to beat.

headline: What to See on the London Stage in 2013
text: LONDON — With the new year come renewed theatrical hopes, which, in the case of London 2013, means having to equal the especially strong theater year just gone— both for the classics (Shakespeare especially) and for new plays (the 2012 place to be on that front was the Royal Court).

headline: Where Is the Indian Economy Headed?
text: Is India’s economy bottoming out, or getting worse?

text: Q.

headline: Pound for Pound
text: CAIRO — The crisis over the rushed adoption of Egypt’s new Constitution is costing President Mohamed Morsi. His popularity is down, and the country is more polarized than ever. Yet he should be even more worried about another crisis, largely of his own making: the recent run on the Egyptian pound, which is rapidly degrading an already precarious economic situation.

headline: Two Very Different Stories of Murder, Faith and Forgiveness
text: This week the magazine features a story, “Can Forgiveness Play a Role in Criminal Justice?” about parents whose deeply held religious faith leads them to forgive — and seek a lesser sentence for — their daughter’s murderer. The killer was no stranger to Kate and Andy Grosmaire; he was their daughter’s boyfriend and they loved him, which made forgiveness both difficult and necessary.

headline: Divisional Round Probabilities: Atlanta-Seattle Coin Toss Game
text: As seasons come to an end, the conventional assessments of team strength and some of the more advanced rankings tend to converge. That’s the case with the Seattle Seahawks this season. My model had them ranked sixth in the league midway through the season, even as the Seahawks fell to a 4-4 record.

headline: Selling a Business? It’s the Details That Count
text: When we last left Holly Hunter, she had sold her business. She had received her down payment but the following payments had stopped after about a year. And it was obvious she had made some mistakes.

headline: With Laos Disappearance, Signs of a Liberalization in Backslide
text: VIENTIANE, Laos — He was last seen driving home in his old, rusty jeep. And then he vanished.

headline: The Delhi Gang Rape Accused: Vinay Sharma, a ‘Quiet and Simple’ Boy
text: To keep her children warm on Wednesday night, Champa Devi tried to get a small fire going by puffing air into four pieces of wood outside their home in a South Delhi slum.

headline: Returns at Hedge Funds Run by Women Beat the Industry, Report Says
text: Last year was fairly dismal for the hedge fund industry, almost any way you slice it.

headline: ‘Lincoln’ Leads Oscar Field With 12 Nominations
text: Start your Oscar Ballot here.

headline: At Last, the Straw Bale House Is a … Home
text: The night we finished building it, we all sat on the floor of Allison Vanlonkhuyzen’s straw bale home and ate chili with her.  Our four months of hard work volunteering for the nonprofit group Community Rebuilds  were  over.

headline: The Last Man Asian Literary Prize
text: HONG KONG — The five shortlisted novels of what will be the last Man Asian Literary Prize were announced last evening at the Man Group’s offices here. The British investment firm will end its support of Asia’s most prominent literary prize after the final award is given at a black-tie dinner in March.

headline: European Central Bank Leaves Key Rate Unchanged
text: FRANKFURT — The euro zone economy shows signs of stabilizing and may even be in a period of “positive contagion,” Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday after the bank left its main interest rate at a record low.

headline: Quasi Inauguration for Chávez in Venezuela
text: Venzuela’s presidential inauguration is missing a president.

headline: In His Comfort Zone
text: SEEING Ethan Hawke perched on a folding chair in a grungy Midtown rehearsal space leading actors through a reading is a bit of a shock. Not that he is there: Mr. Hawke is a steady presence in the New York theater scene, and he is rehearsing “Clive,” a play about a ’90s-era New York rocker gone very, very bad, in which he stars and directs.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Late-Night Ratings Race, and a Controversial Puppeteer Resigns
text: It was Jimmy Kimmel who joined the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman on Tuesday, but it was Mr. Leno who won the night’s ratings race. Mr. Leno on NBC pulled in 3.27 million viewers, edging Mr. Kimmel on ABC, who had 3.1 million. The total for Mr. Kimmel was his second highest. It also put him in second place, ahead of David Letterman on CBS, who had 2.88 million viewers. As Bill Carter reports, Mr. Leno was also the winner in the audience of most interest to late-night advertisers — viewers between the ages of 18 and 49. Mr. Leno had 1.084 million viewers in that group to 887,000 for Mr. Kimmel and 683,000 for Mr. Letterman.

headline: The 2012 Patent Rankings: IBM on Top (Again), Google and Apple Surging
text: In the yearly count of patents granted in the United States, the corporate front-runner for 2012 is scarcely a surprise.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Options for Divers
text: Diving apps were this week’s subject for the App Smart column. If that seems a little unseasonal then you should remember that some great diving locations are in sunny spots, and a winter getaway vacation doesn’t have to be about skiing!

headline: Reversing Greece’s free fall
text: Regarding “Greece’s rotten oligarchy” (Views, Jan. 7): In citing the mendacity, corruption and avarice overrunning Athens, Kostas Vaxevanis describes a country whose political establishment has betrayed its citizenry. But the notion that modern-day Hellas can be revivified by a return to “Greece’s ancient democratic heritage” is a chimera.

headline: Here Is What Happens When You Cast Lindsay Lohan in Your Movie
text: Lindsay Lohan moves through the Chateau Marmont as if she owns the place, but in a debtor-prison kind of way. She’ll soon owe the hotel $46,000. Heads turn subtly as she slinks toward a table to meet a young producer and an old director. The actress’s mother, Dina Lohan, sits at the next table. Mom sweeps blond hair behind her ear and tries to eavesdrop. A few tables away, a distinguished-looking middle-aged man patiently waits for the actress. He has a stack of presents for her.

headline: Battle Lines Drawn Over Herbalife
text: BATTLE LINES DRAWN OVER HERBALIFE  |  The clash of the hedge fund titans has been set, and the financial world is eagerly watching. William A. Ackman and Daniel S. Loeb, two of the most prominent hedge fund managers in Manhattan, became business rivals on Wednesday, with hundreds of millions of dollars in play over Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company.
