headline: Theories Link Paris Murders to Kurdish Peace Moves
text: LONDON — The overnight discovery in Paris of the  bodies of three Kurdish women activists prompted instant speculation that the execution-style triple killing was linked to an attempt to disrupt peace talks between Turkey and a jailed Kurdish guerrilla leader.

headline: Herbalife Responds to Accusations From Hedge Fund
text: Herbalife found itself in a public relations nightmare in December when the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman called the company a pyramid scheme, announcing he was short-selling its shares. Since then, the stock has rebounded somewhat, and it got a lift on Wednesday when another hedge fund manager, Daniel S. Loeb, said he was bullish on Herbalife, which sells nutritional supplements and skin-care products through a network of independent distributors.

headline: The Early Word: Fight Prep
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Vain Glorious | Laura Mercier’s Caviar Stick Eye Color
text: For those of us who didn’t snare any rose gold jewelry for the holidays, consider Laura Mercier’s new Caviar Stick Eye Color in rose gold as a consolation prize. Called “Caviar” because it glides on and is easy to use, the eyeliner has warm tones that seem to work on any skin color. I’ve been wearing it during the day (it’s a total mood lifter) and when the sun goes down, adding a little extra, for a soft golden glow at cocktail hour. A luxe treat for $24.

headline: In the Spirit of Ada Louise Huxtable, a Times Critic Reinvents His Role
text: Michael Kimmelman’s piece on Ada Louise Huxtable, who died this week at age 91, in Tuesday’s Arts section is tagged “An Appraisal,” but it could easily have been called something more enthusiastic: an appreciation. For by his own eager admission, Mr. Kimmelman – who took over as architecture critic in September 2011 — owes much to Ms. Huxtable, whom he calls a role model.

headline: ‘Lincoln’ Leads Academy Award Nominations
text: “Lincoln,” Steven Spielberg’s film starring Daniel Day-Lewis as the president of the United States who grappled with the scourge of slavery and the Civil War, was nominated for 12 Academy Awards on Thursday morning, including best picture, best director (for Mr. Spielberg) and best actor (for Mr. Day-Lewis). The other films nominated for best picture were “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” “Silver Linings Playbook,” “Zero Dark Thirty,” “Les Misérables,” “Life of Pi,” “Amour,” “Django Unchained” and “Argo.”

headline: Cerberus to Buy Albertsons Grocery Chain From Supervalu
text: An investor group led by Cerberus Capital Management agreed on Thursday to buy a number of grocery chains from Supervalu, including Albertsons, for about $3.3 billion.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Esquire: McDonald’s versus Italian pizza: is this war? — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Director Snubs Point to a Threeway Race: ‘Lincoln’ vs. ‘Playbook’ and ‘Pi’
text: An Oscar race that could have gone in almost any direction suddenly has a shape, and it’s not one that anyone was expecting. The shutout of Kathryn Bigelow and Ben Affleck for best director – though their movies, “Zero Dark Thirty” and “Argo,” were nominees for best picture and screenplay as well as for performances – will cause much hand-wringing around Hollywood, where both were considered locks, especially after they earned nods from the Directors Guild. Tom Hooper, the director of “Les Misérables,” was skipped over too, though his film had a high number of nominations.

headline: Edward St. Aubyn: By the Book
text: If the author of the Patrick Melrose novels could meet any character from literature, he would choose Isabel Archer. And then he’d propose marriage.

headline: What Chris Christie Didn’t Say
text: All three tri-state area governors gave their annual state of the state speeches this week. Two of them – Democrats Andrew Cuomo of New York and Dannel Malloy of Connecticut – discussed the weapons epidemic that was brought into such ghastly focus by the shootings in Newtown, Conn. Mr. Cuomo actually called for major legislation –to restrict ownership of assault-style weapons and high-capacity magazines.

headline: Drug Agency Recommends Lower Doses of Sleep Aids for Women
text: WASHINGTON — For two decades, millions of Americans have taken Ambien to help them sleep at night. But for years, the Food and Drug Administration has gotten complaints that people felt drowsy the morning after taking the medicine or its successors, and sometimes got into car accidents.

headline: Seau Suffered From Brain Disease
text: The former N.F.L. linebacker Junior Seau had a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head trauma when he committed suicide in the spring, the National Institutes of Health said Thursday.

headline: I Don’t Want My Preschooler to Be a ‘Gentleman’
text: My 4-year-old son, Emmett, swallows a spoonful of cereal and asks me if I know what a gentleman is. Surprised, I tell him I have some idea; then I ask what the word means to him.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Bleak Weather’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “Bleak Weather,” a poem by Ella Wheeler Wilcox with “A Cool Glide Through Maine” by Eric Hansen.

headline: Photos of The Moment | E. Tautz
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Statement on Steroids, but What Does It Say?
text: Perhaps the most remarkable thing about the great Hall of Fame shutout of 2013 is, no matter which way the election voting had gone on Wednesday, the outrage would have sounded remarkably similar. Today’s injustice — that the Hall of Fame path of some of the game’s greatest players, led by Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens, was blocked at least for now in the name of protesting the steroids era — would have been replaced by the injustice of ignoring the steroids era. The Hall’s credibility, now under attack for omitting such obvious superstars, would have been assailed for welcoming players everyone believes cheated the game on a massive scale.

headline: Daily Report: Google Chief Urges North Korea to Embrace Web
text: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, returned from a four-day visit to North Korea on Thursday with a message for the reclusive nation’s young new leader: embrace the Web or else, reports Andrew Jacobs of The New York Times.

headline: Celeste Bartos, New York Philanthropist, Dies at 99
text: Celeste Bartos, a philanthropist who supported some of New York City’s most esteemed cultural institutions, in particular the New York Public Library and the Museum of Modern Art, died last Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 99.

headline: Every ’Wich Way
text: For something that has almost unlimited potential, the sandwich has become staid and unimaginative. In part this is because we don’t have as many leftovers as we once did (we don’t cook as much), so a meatloaf sandwich is nowhere near as common as it once was. But it’s mostly because we’ve allowed sandwich-making to become something that is either done by someone else or a task to be squeezed in between breakfast and taking the kids to the bus.

headline: Sally Field, on Texting With Abraham Lincoln
text: Sally Field has been reluctant to say goodbye to Mary Todd Lincoln. “She won’t leave, not for a long time,” Ms. Field said this morning, from a hotel in Los Angeles. But as a newly minted best supporting actress nominee, playing the wife to Daniel Day-Lewis’s Lincoln, she can relive her performance for weeks to come.

headline: British Panel Castigates Ex-UBS Officials at Hearing
text: LONDON — Several former senior executives at UBS were labeled negligent and incompetent on Thursday for failing to detect illegal activity that caused the Swiss bank to pay a $1.5 billion fine to global regulators.

headline: Worrying About Electronic Benefits Deadline? Don’t
text: March 1 is the deadline set by the federal government for converting all benefits payments — including Social Security — to electronic deposits.

headline: France Considers a Gay Marriage Bill as Marriage Itself Is in Decline
text: PARIS— French President François Hollande campaigned on a pledge to legalize gay marriage, though it drew little attention at the time, and he now has the votes in Parliament to do it.

headline: California Suggests Mobile App Privacy Guidelines
text: Make your privacy policy readable. Avoid collecting data that you don’t need for the app to function normally. Alert users with “enhanced measures” if third parties are collecting information, including for advertising.

headline: From Homeless Teen to Oscar-Nominated Film Subject
text: 4:35 p.m. | Updated  Sean Fine was preparing a film for Sundance when he learned on Thursday that the documentary short he and his wife, Andrea Fine, had directed — “Inocente,” which was shown on MTV this summer — had been nominated for an Oscar.

headline: Syria Denounces U.N. Envoy as ‘Biased’
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s government appeared to distance itself from further engagement with the special peace envoy of the United Nations and the Arab League on Thursday, declaring him “flagrantly biased” even as his efforts aimed at a political transition to end the nearly two-year-old Syrian conflict were accelerating.

headline: The Choice Blogger Graduates
text: I have been fortunate to work as a journalist at The New York Times for more than 24 years, beginning just after I graduated from college.

headline: No Words Says It All
text: A lot has been written about the absence of words on the front page of The New York Times’s sports section today in its coverage of the Hall of Fame vote. For those readers who have not seen the print edition, we thought we would present a copy of the page here.

headline: Chávez Illness Delays Inauguration
text: TimesCast: The swearing-in of Hugo Chávez is delayed. | Baseball Hall of Fame voters reject steroid-tainted candidacies.

headline: A Bit of Relief on Food Prices
text: World food prices ended the year with a slight decline, and for 2012 as a whole they were 7 percent below prices of 2011, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reported on Thursday.

headline: Hagel’s Confirmation Proceedings Will Be Short on Old Senate Allies
text: WASHINGTON — For a man who spent 12 years in the Senate, Chuck Hagel will find himself with few close allies when the Armed Services Committee takes up his nomination to be secretary of defense this month.

headline: The Geopolitics of Soap Operas
text: KARACHI — With news in Pakistan seemingly going from bad to worse, no wonder people here are increasingly turning to the frivolous and titillating world of soap operas. The more foreign the better.

headline: Thursday Reading: Flu Is Widespread This Year
text: Flu is widespread this year, Boeing says 787 is safe, a survey of mobile chargers and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Minister Backs Out of Speech at Inaugural
text: WASHINGTON — The minister selected by President Obama to deliver the benediction at his inaugural withdrew Thursday from the program, putting a quick end to a developing controversy over a sermon he gave in the 1990s in which he called on Christians to fight the “aggressive agenda” of the gay-rights movement.

headline: Finding Hope After Miscarriage
text: One year I was pregnant four times. I was 38 and newly married. I got pregnant the first time in January. A few weeks later, I miscarried.

headline: Honda to Assemble 2014 Accord Hybrid in Ohio
text: Honda says it will begin assembling a new 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid at a plant in Marysville, Ohio, later this year.

headline: 2013 Academy Awards — The Nominees
text: A look at the Oscar nominations in top categories.

headline: With Apologies to John Hawkes and Marion Cotillard
text: Pity poor John Hawkes. Mr. Hawkes endured weeks of discomfort – and perhaps permanent back damage – to play the polio-stricken writer Mark O’Brien in “The Sessions,” only to be snubbed by the Academy for best actor. His co-star Helen Hunt, playing a sex therapist in a deeply felt performance that has her frequently naked, did earn the attention of the Academy, though. (Mr. Hawkes may get a chance to go to the ceremony though: he appears in “Lincoln”; then again so do hundreds of other actors.)

headline: Sifting Out Sandy
text: In the Rockaways, truckloads of sand containing debris from Hurricane Sandy are emptied into huge sand-sifting machines. The sand is filtered, then returned to build up damaged seafronts.

headline: Columbus Circle Subway Station, 10:48 A.M.
text: Photo: Even silver-plated human statues need their beauty rest.

headline: Forced Entry
text: The only time in my life I’ve ever participated in a break-in was a few years ago, when my wife and I were still living in Dupont Circle. The safely gentrified D.C. neighborhood was hardly a felonious hive. But there were pockets of criminality in that garden of yuppie complacency, and our unloved, rent-controlled building was one of them.

headline: A Great Year in Film
text: Melena Ryzik discusses this year's biggest successes and themes in her preview of the Academy Awards.

headline: Ben Horowitz on the Impact of Software Everywhere
text: Ben Horowitz may have the skeleton key to the decimation – sorry, transformation – of our economic and political lives. What he doesn’t have is a good sense of what we will look like when we get to the other side.

headline: Look of The Moment | Taylor Swift
text: The Look: White Out. A plunging neckline turns a borderline bridal look into a ravishing red-carpet statement. With hair swept up and earrings dangling low, all eyes go straight to the face.

headline: Lawyer Says Indian Gang Rape Suspect Was Tortured by Police
text: NEW DELHI — A lawyer defending one of the six young men accused in a gang rape case that has gripped India claimed on Thursday that his client had been tortured by the police and that his confession had been coerced.

headline: A Boy's Silence Is Broken
text: Vladimir Gongora, a deaf teen from rural El Salvador, came to New York in May. Since then, he has begun learning to sign, read and write, and has started to make friends for the first time.

headline: Simon Rattle to Leave Berlin Philharmonic in 2018
text: BERLIN – Simon Rattle will step down as chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic when his contract expires in 2018, the orchestra said on Thursday. Mr. Rattle, who came to Berlin in 2002 after 18 years spent conducting the City of Birmingham Orchestra in England, made the announcement so far in advance, he said, to give the orchestra time to find a new conductor.

headline: F.C.C. Says Failure of 911 in Storm Was Preventable
text: WASHINGTON — Two days before a fast-moving, powerful windstorm swept across the mid-Atlantic last June, Verizon tested the backup power generator at its central office in Arlington, Va., and it failed.

headline: The Spectacular Rise and Fall of Fitz John Porter
text: On Jan. 10, 1863, a military tribunal of nine Union generals found Maj. Gen. Fitz John Porter guilty of two charges stemming from his actions at the Second Battle of Manassas the previous August. Eleven days later, Porter was dismissed from the Army and “forever disqualified from holding any office or trust or profit under the Government of the United States.” After signing the order cashiering Porter, President Lincoln remarked, “In any other country but this, the man would have been shot.” His uncharacteristically harsh assessment reveals the controversy and political machinations that surrounded Porter’s court martial as well as the lingering drama accompanying the recent removal of his friend and patron, George McClellan, from command of the Union armies.

headline: Swearing In Postponed for Ill Chávez
text: The Times’s William Neuman reports on the quasi-presidential inauguration in Venezuela that President Hugo Chávez is unable to attend.

headline: A Loss in the Family
text: SPECIAL POST — It is with great sadness that Wordplay announces the death of George Bredehorn, long-time constructor of the Split Decisions Variety puzzles. Mr. Bredehorn was 85 years old.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week Fall 2013 Accessories
text: Highlights from the men’s collections, from face masks to over-sized earmuffs.

headline: Ang Lee on the Digital Characters Who Can’t Argue Back
text: “Life of Pi,” the sweeping 3-D fantasy based on the 2001 international best-selling novel, defied many Oscar predictions by netting 11 nominations, second only to Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln.” In addition to the expected showing of “Pi” in the technical categories and a best picture nod, the film about shipwreck survival, religious wonder and a ferocious digital tiger named Richard Parker also drew a best directing nomination for Ang Lee.

headline: Baseball Writers Select No One for Hall
text: Voters for the Hall of Fame emphatically rejected the candidacies of Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens in balloting results announced Wednesday.

headline: Tough Path Seen by Obama on Ban of Assault Weapons
text: WASHINGTON — While President Obama pledged to crack down on access to what he called “weapons of war” in the aftermath of last month’s schoolhouse massacre, the White House has calculated that a ban on military-style assault weapons will be exceedingly difficult to pass through Congress and is focusing on other measures it deems more politically achievable.

headline: Justin Timberlake Signals That He’s ‘Ready.’ Just Not Yet.
text: What’s the best way for a pop star to get a quick tide of digital ink about a new album?

headline: Amy Adams, Scared by Her Own Character
text: By now, you’d think that Oscar nominations would be all in a good night’s sleep for Amy Adams. After earning best supporting actress nods for “Junebug” (2005), “Doubt” (2008) and “The Fighter” (2010), Ms. Adams has received another shout-out, this time for Paul Thomas Anderson’s film “The Master,” playing Peggy Dodd, the submissive wife of a charismatic religious leader (Philip Seymour Hoffman) who eventually shows her husband who’s boss with a rather steely hand.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 10
text: Pilgrims on their way to the Gangasagar mela in West Bengal.

headline: With ‘Daisy,’ Beats Electronics Bets on Digital Music
text: Memo to Spotify: Beats Electronics is coming for you.

headline: Toronto Shows Faith in Nelsen
text: Ryan Nelsen has become accustomed to overcoming adversity. The New Zealand native encountered a major hurdle early in his collegiate playing days before landing at D.C. United in Major League Soccer and subsequently progressing to England’s Premier League.

headline: Nokia Has Some Good News After Two Years of Gloom
text: Nearly two years ago, Stephen A. Elop, Nokia’s new chief executive, spoke of flaming ocean platforms and shark-infested waters to describe the problems he inherited as the company teetered on the brink of irrelevance.

headline: A Persistent Foreign Predator, Dangerous but Delicious
text: Luiz Rocha, the curator of ichthyology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Belize, where he conducts research on the social wrasse, one of the world’s most endangered fish.

headline: Baseball to Expand Drug-Testing Program
text: WASHINGTON — A day after suffering through the embarrassment of seeing no new players selected to the Hall of Fame, Major League Baseball and its players union moved ahead Thursday by announcing that they had reached an agreement to expand their drug-testing program.

headline: When the Doctor Returns to Doctoring
text: Several years ago, a highly respected medical expert I had just met shared a little-known detail of his illustrious career: as a young doctor, he had stopped practicing medicine for a few years to homeschool his son.

headline: The Extent of the Fires
text:
A map of the wildfires and an update of the status of the firefighting efforts.
Some small fires may not appear on the map due to the limitations of satellite sensors.

headline: The People’s Love for Chávez Continues
text: While President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela lies ill in Cuba, his many fans still flock to the streets at home in support.

headline: Theater Talkback:  Familiar Faces in Two Dimensions
text: Between Al Pacino and Frankenstein’s monster, my life was a theater-free zone. In the last month of last year, I saw Mr. Pacino chomping up the Schoenfeld Theater on Broadway in David Mamet’s “Glengarry Glen Ross”; and in the first month of this year, I watched several versions of Mary Shelley’s big man-made galoot chomping up the Kitchen, the performance space in Chelsea, in Radiohole’s “Inflatable Frankenstein.”

headline: Obama’s Chief of Staff Pick Is Said to Be Down to 2
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday publicly acknowledged the big problem that he has created for himself by picking for the next Treasury secretary Jacob J. Lew, his trusted White House chief of staff. The shift left a vacancy in one of his administration’s, and Washington’s, most powerful if least understood jobs.

headline: For Anne Hathaway and Hugh Jackman, a Bittersweet Day
text: Anne Hathaway was humming. There was a brief, unexpected lull in her retinue of press calls this morning, and Ms. Hathaway was on hold, with a tune stuck in her head. And it was not exactly musical theater.

headline: How Are You Warding Off the Flu?
text: Sure, you could go out and get a flu shot like everyone keeps telling you to do. It’s relatively cheap, and available just about everywhere.

headline: Britney Spears Said to Be Leaving ‘The X Factor’
text: Britney Spears will not return for another season of “The X Factor,” TMZ and The Hollywood Reporter said Thursday, opening up another chair at the judges’ table on the Fox singing competition.

headline: What’s at the Center of the Debate Over Herbalife
text: In the wake of the bombshell announcement that Daniel S. Loeb’s Third Point has taken an 8.9 percent stake in Herbalife after the company’s shares were shorted by William A. Ackman of Pershing Square, the question is: Which very rich hedge fund manager is right?

headline: Before Rebuilding Beaches, Plucking Debris From Storm-Tossed Sand
text: Hurricane Sandy’s toll — already well-documented in power failures, forced evacuations and insurance losses — can also be measured in grains of sand.

headline: Strike on Broadway
text:
Members of Local One, the stagehands' union, were on strike, closing many Broadway shows.
Hear from the people affected by the strike.

headline: London Top 5
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Undocumented Reformers
text: Despite the risk of deportation, undocumented immigrants in Arizona are organizing to influence the pending debate on immigration reform in Washington, D.C.

headline: Candidates in a Box
text: A subjective look at the gifts and deficits of the 2008 presidential hopefuls. By David Brooks and Ben Schott.

headline: State of the Union
text: Interactive video and transcript of President Bush's State of the Union address.

headline: Clouds Seen in Regulators’ Crystal Ball for Banks
text: Five years ago, the financial regulators of the United States — and more broadly the world — didn’t see the storm coming.

headline: How the Pentagon Spread Its Message
text: Audio, video and documents that show how the military’s talking points were disseminated.

headline: Fed Profit of $88.9 Billion Sent to Treasury in 2012
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said on Thursday that it sent $88.9 billion in profit to the Treasury Department in 2012, a record that reflected the vast expansion of the central bank’s investment portfolio.

headline: Judge Blocks Restaurant Plan for Union Square Park
text: What is the purpose of a park? To eat? To eat $18 eggs and potatoes? Or is it to play? To leave space open for the public to gather in protest or celebration?

headline: Despite Recent Losses, India Has an Edge in Upcoming Cricket Series
text: The mood is somewhat despondent in the Indian camp on the eve of the much-awaited cricket series of five One-Day Internationals against England, the first of which will be played in Rajkot on Friday.

headline: Cyberstalkers Threaten Pipeline Security
text: In a recent  annual review, a team at the Department of Homeland Security that works to counter  the threat of attacks  on critical computer infrastructure counted 198 incidents in fiscal 2012. The events reported ranged from the use of malware to sabotage systems to phishing attacks for retrieving  sensitive information. In roughly 40 percent of those cases, the target was the energy sector – “an alarming rate,” the report said.

headline: Did Zeitlin Take Bigelow’s Spot?
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood is rarely surprised by Oscar nominations any more. All of the prognostication machinery that has grown up around the race has made sure of that. Even when a dark horse slips into the mix, the bumped contender is almost always a vulnerable one.

headline: Carbon Emissions Across the United States
text: There are big differences in emissions between companies, and from state to state, that may make it harder to reach agreements on cuts.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Other Place'
text: Laurie Metcalf and Zoe Perry in a scene from Sharr White’s play, which opened on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Downturn Still Squeezes Colleges and Universities
text: An annual survey of colleges and universities found that a growing number of schools face declining enrollment and less revenue from tuition.

headline: New School Show Tunes
text: Listen to excerpts from “In the Heights,” “Passing Strange,” “Adding Machine” and “A Catered Affair.”

headline: From Sketch to Stage: Dressing Dickens
text: David Zinn talks about the costumes he designed for “A Tale of Two Cities.”

headline: Milestones: W. Mark Felt
text: An interactive timeline of W. Mark Felt’s career.

headline: New Mortgage Rules Left Out Down Payments
text: New rules announced Thursday by the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau aim to shield borrowers from the risky sorts of mortgages that helped cause the recent financial crisis.

headline: A ‘Genre Boy’ Returns to Television
text: Cult favorite writer and director Joss Whedon answered reader questions about past projects and his new Fox series, “Dollhouse.”

headline: On Second Night in New Slot, a Ratings Slide for Kimmel
text: Not that anyone should have expected Jimmy Kimmel to stage an immediate late-night ratings coup, but on his second night in a head-to-head-to-head contest with Jay Leno and David Letterman, Mr. Kimmel fell slightly in the ratings, while both other hosts added viewers.

headline: David O. Russell’s Pre-Emptive Thank-You
text: The usually loquacious David O. Russell was rendered speechless, he said, by his nomination for best director and best adapted screenplay, not to mention the best picture nod, for “Silver Linings Playbook.”

headline: Scene City: ‘Girls’ Premieres Second Season
text: Cast members and fans of “Girls” fete the show’s second season with a touch of (imported) Brooklyn.

headline: The Sell: ‘Reasons to Be Pretty’
text: A closer look at the evolution of the poster art for Neil LaBute’s Broadway play.

headline: Plenty of Guts, Little Glory
text: Many stars have had residencies on “ER,” but it’s the off-camera veterans who have kept the hospital humming throughout the show’s 15-year run.

headline: A Closer Look at Immigration Reform
text: TimesCast Politics: Activists speak out in Arizona. | An interview with a conservative voice. | Can legislation actually pass the House?

headline: What Is a Guy?
text: An interactive look at craps, Automats and other references in the revival of “Guys and Dolls.”

headline: Protesters From Afar
text: Political awakening in Russia has reached the immigrant population in the United States. New York activists organized a series of protests in the community not known for political activism.

headline: Where Are They Now?
text: A look at Bush administration lawyers who advised the government on interrogation and national security.

headline: Terrorists No Match for Single City Cop
text: Early in “The Intercept,” the serviceable debut thriller from the “Law & Order” creator Dick Wolf, Osama Bin Laden appears, reproaching his followers for recent failures. “Bomb this. Bomb that,” he scolds the men, sounding like an ad executive in a branding meeting. “Nothing original, nothing intelligent,” adding, “We have failed to innovate.”

headline: The End Is Near!
text: Previews of eight of the season’s most anticipated finales, with an eye to which questions they’ll answer — and which ones they probably won’t.

headline: There Was Even a Snub in the Foreign Language Category
text: This was a very, very good day for everyone associated with “Amour,” Austria’s submission for the best foreign-language film Oscar. “Amour” was a lock for one of the five nominations in that category, but it also won four other nominations, in categories where the presence of foreign-language films is not common: best picture, best director (for Michael Haneke), best actress (for Emmanuelle Riva) and best original screenplay (for Mr. Haneke).

headline: The Motor City Though the Camera Lens
text: The most publicized photographs of Detroit over the last few years have tended to be those of ancient factories and empty lots. Alternately celebrated as elegiac images of lost culture or derided as “ruin porn,” such images have obscured more subtle visions of the Motor City.

headline: A Day of ‘Conquests’
text: Audio and photos from the all-day marathon of “The Norman Conquests.”

headline: Clothes Make the Show
text: Costume designers for some of the most visually striking series on television discuss their work.

headline: A History of Hall of Fame Shutouts
text: When the Hall of Fame voting for 2013 ended up in a big zero on Wednesday, it sparked a debate over how the stars of baseball’s steroid era should be handled when it comes to enshrining them.

headline: In Performance: TV’s Best
text: Ginia Bellafante discusses some of the most notable performances of the year.

headline: Pacific Tuna Stocks Have Plummeted, Scientists Warn
text: The Pacific bluefin tuna, fished relentlessly for decades, is in trouble.

headline: Untangling ‘Top Girls’
text: Audience members share their thoughts on the Broadway production of “Top Girls.”

headline: Emmanuelle Riva’s Very Good Morning
text: “Amour’s” strong showing — five Oscar nominations for Michael Haneke’s film about an elderly French couple facing death — included a best actress nod for Emmanuelle Riva, at 85 the oldest actress nominee in Academy history.

headline: Competing Stimulus Bills
text: Key differences between the $838 billion economic recovery plan outlined by the Senate and the $820 billion version that passed the House.

headline: More On a Quest for Common Ground on Climate Change
text: In 2011, I wrote about efforts by two scientists with different political orientations to identify common ground in weighing risks posed by global warming driven by greenhouse gases. The scientists were Peter C. Frumhoff, an ecologist who directs science and policy for the Union of Concerned Scientists, and Kerry Emanuel, a veteran climate and hurricane researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. (Emanuel has a new edition of his short everyman’s guide to global warming, by the way.)

headline: And in This Corner, the Boys of ‘Girls’
text: FOR a show that is, down to its title, about women, “Girls” pays a lot of attention to its boys. The male characters — boyfriends, exes, bosses, frenemies — are fleshed out in a way that’s unusual for an ensemble comedy, especially one aimed at the other gender. (How long did audiences have to wait for Mr. Big’s mere name on “Sex and the City”?)

headline: A ‘New Normal’ Star Thrives in the TV Ensemble
text: NOT all of the boys of “Girls” fit in with the Brooklyn crew. Andrew Rannells, a longtime New York theater actor, plays Elijah, Hannah’s gay ex-boyfriend. Mr. Rannells, 34, who lives in the East Village, also stars in “The New Normal,” the NBC sitcom about a gay couple trying to have a child via surrogate. He saw his career blossom after he appeared on Broadway in “The Book of Mormon.” These are excerpts from his conversation with Melena Ryzik.

headline: The Edges Are Still Sharp in Brooklyn
text: Back when networks reigned supreme, cable television was the place to go for sex and violence. Now it’s also a safe house for pessimism, an alternate universe where problems fester or deepen, friends let one another down, and love doesn’t conquer anything.

headline: Points for Every (Bumpy) Lap
text: ROLLER skating was as big a part of local culture as bowling in New Jersey, where Elizabeth Schwartz grew up. She laughs when she says she is not the most athletic person in the world, though she is game for pretty much any sport. And now that includes roller derby.

headline: Cuomo’s State of the State Address
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo delivered his State of the State address in Albany on Wednesday.

headline: Creative Use of White Space in Sports … Discuss
text: Readers who picked up Thursday’s print edition and turned to the Sports section could be forgiven if they did a double-take or choked on their morning coffee. For what they saw on the front page of the section was … well, nothing. Or actually, almost nothing: The page was more than three-quarters blank, topped with a headline, in most editions, that read “And the Inductees Are …”

headline: Art House | Wendell Castle
text: The American designer Wendell Castle is known for his idiosyncratic, organic and slightly surreal furniture, which he has been producing in laminated wood, plastic and other materials since the 1960s, and which is highly collectible. Castle, who turned 80 in 2012, showed his work at Design Miami last month, and today his exhibition “A New Environment” opens at Friedman Benda in Chelsea. (Another Castle show, “Volumes and Voids,” is on view just upstairs from Friedman Benda at the Barry Friedman Gallery through Jan. 26.)

headline: ‘Flight’s’ Screenwriter Is Just Thrilled His Name Was Pronounced Right
text: Sure, John Gatins managed to somehow turn a grim script he’d repeatedly abandoned over more than a decade into an acclaimed studio film, “Flight,” that netted him his first Oscar nomination. But the improbable part of the whole thing, for Mr. Gatins, was that Emma Stone managed to pronounce his name correctly when she announced his Oscar nomination early Thursday morning.

headline: To Counter China, Japan and Philippines Will Bolster Maritime Cooperation
text: TOKYO — In a telling sign of how China’s rise has helped turn former wartime foes into allies, Japan and the Philippines agreed on Thursday to cooperate more closely on maritime security.

headline: Thinking About the Brink
text: The platinum coin discussion has moved with startling speed, from an idea nobody took seriously (and which, as I’ve mentioned, senior officials were unaware of just last month), to assertions that it’s ridiculous and illegal, to grudging acknowledgment that it’s almost surely legal coupled with strained attempts to dismiss it as an option nonetheless.

headline: Visions and Voices of a Nation Divided
text: WASHINGTON — In the pursuit of justice, what is unjustified? Are there limits to what may be done in service to a righteous cause? Abstract philosophical questions, perhaps, but also political ones. And in thinking about the Civil War, the answers affect our understanding of that bloody conflict.

headline: Student Shot at California High School
text: LOS ANGELES — One student was shot at a California high school Thursday morning and another student was taken into custody, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Microsoft’s Surface Pro Tablet Changes the Game
text: A few months back, Microsoft raised a lot of eyebrows by selling its first computer: the Surface tablet. For the same $500 that gets you an iPad, it offers better hardware and more jacks. It has only one drawback: it can’t run any PC software.

text: THE LIVES THEY LIVED

headline: A Storm Victim’s Luck Changes
text: For Walter Connolly, whose home in Queens was battered by Hurricane Sandy, a chance encounter in Brooklyn provided a dose of good fortune.

headline: Video: Russian Protesters in New York City
text: A political awakening in Russia, set off by disputed elections and a crackdown on the opposition, has reached the immigrant community in New York. A video by Natalia V. Osipova takes a look at activists who are planning to stage their next anti-Kremlin protest here on Sunday.

headline: Zizi Limona
text: Inside the Middle Eastern restaurant in Williamsburg that is free of culinary or geographic limitation.

headline: A Cruise Across the Mediterranean
text: THE oxtail is in a state of beautiful disarray, all tangled, velvety strands, the tough guy turned moony poet. It has been sluiced with silan (dates boiled down into honey), barraged with cinnamon sticks and braised for five hours until utterly undone.

text: History rhymes, even in the capital markets.

headline: New York Legislators Debate Details of Gun Law
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers have agreed they want to ban military-style weapons and high-capacity magazines, but continue to negotiate over the fine print of a broad gun-control package that would include such a ban, state officials said Thursday.

text: On the HBO comedy about a group of young women, the male characters play significant roles as well.

text: The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has a graph:

headline: Carter Family Songs in Red Hook
text: On Aug. 1, 1927, a Virginian named A. P. Carter, along with his wife, Sara, and sister-in-law Maybelle, entered a makeshift studio in Bristol, Tenn. There they recorded a handful of the songs Mr. Carter had collected in his travels across Appalachia, and in the process more or less gave birth to modern country music.

headline: Judge Postpones Sentencing for Wells Fargo Broker
text: A California federal judge has delayed the sentencing of Philip Horn, a Wells Fargo broker who pleaded guilty to defrauding more than a dozen clients.

headline: Blasts in Pakistan Kill Scores and Stir Fears on Elections
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Bomb blasts in two Pakistani cities killed at least 115 people on Thursday and wounded more than 270, offering harrowing evidence of how the country’s myriad internal conflicts could destabilize it as elections approach.

headline: Launching a Fragrance Line (In a Manner of Speaking)
text: BRANDS often give away trips like a weekend in New York, but now Axe, the men’s grooming brand, has a giveaway that it can say, without hyperbole, is out of this world.

headline: A God in Pursuit of a Redemption
text: It’s not often that you go to the theater these days and find yourself excitedly questioning and rethinking your reactions. Self-examining art, after all, has become such a cozy genre in itself that it rarely startles.

headline: Friends Without Benefits
text: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress Taissa Farmiga, followed by a conversation with the writer, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below.

headline: Herbalife Shares Fall After Company Defends Itself
text: Herbalife  sought on Thursday to counter accusations that the company was a fraud, but it appeared that investors were still trying to decide.

headline: Jacki Weaver and the Lord of Greenwich Village
text: At her last go-around with the Oscars, in 2011, as supporting actress for “Animal Kingdom,” Jacki Weaver said she felt like “a stunned mullet.” Now, as a two-time supporting actress nominee, she’s moving up in the sea. “Maybe like a grouper,” she mused, on the phone from Los Angeles. “One of those things with the big puffy lips. I still haven’t done that to my lips.” She laughed. “Now that I’m going so Hollywood, maybe that’s the next thing.”

headline: A Debate, to and Fro
text: I was looking at old photos with some tennis buddies. We all laughed at the mullet I sported in my teens. But my comment that another pal had “an amazing Jew-fro back then” was met with uncomfortable silence. A colleague told me that the term is racist and insensitive. But if Afro is not racist, why is Jew-fro? Dan

headline: An Old Magician’s Ploy Adds a Bit of Flair to a Show That’s Not Exactly About Race
text: At the start of “Tar Baby,” Desiree Burch, an African-American comic and actress, says she doesn’t want to do a show about race and then tells the audience members that they don’t really want to see one. “You want to say you saw a really important show about race,” she says, a sneaky smile emerging, “And I want to say I did that show.”

headline: Drilling Down: Andrew Sullivan Decides to Start His Own Business
text: This week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to a news article about Andrew Sullivan’s decision to leave The Daily Beast and move his popular blog, The Dish, to his own, subscription-based site. Mr. Sullivan writes about politics, the economy, business and culture, but is he ready to be a small-business owner? It seems he’s off to a good start, with more than 16,000 subscribers already signed up — delivering almost half a million dollars in revenue almost instantly. We decided to ask him a few questions as he enters the world of entrepreneurship.

headline: In Cyprus Bailout, Questions of Whether Depositors Should Shoulder the Bill
text: LONDON — On their Web sites, the largest of Cyprus’s failing banks brag that their client representatives are fluent in Russian. No indication, though, whether strizhka — Russian for haircut — is part of their lexicon.

headline: Sharp Words From European Minister for Countries in North
text: BRUSSELS — Jean-Claude Juncker, the departing leader of the group of ministers who oversee the euro currency, sharply criticized Northern Europeans on Thursday for demanding austerity budgets from their southern neighbors.

headline: Ask Well: Exercises for Tennis Elbow
text: Question:

headline: In Saudi Town, Women Protest Detentions, Leading to Their Own
text: Last weekend, Saudi security forces encircled and arrested a small group of women who were protesting the long-term detention of relatives without charges on suspicion of terrorism, and the event has touched off nearly a week of unrest in the Saudi town of Buraida.

headline: Citadel Posted 25% Return Last Year, Beating Industry Again
text: It was another good year for Kenneth C. Griffin.

headline: A Wide-Awake Bradley Cooper; a Sleepy Jennifer Lawrence
text: Bradley Cooper was so busy cheering on his “Silver Linings Playbook” colleagues Robert De Niro, Jacki Weaver, Jennifer Lawrence and, especially, the director David O. Russell that he apparently failed to notice that he’d been nominated for an Oscar himself.

headline: Turn Off That TV and Go Outside and Play
text: For many of us, it’s the most indoorsy time of the year. It’s cold, blustery and wet in much of the United States (we are ignoring my friend in the South, who posted to her Facebook page this morning complaining about the mosquitoes impeding her ability to get into her garden). Going outside is complicated, particularly if you have young children. When my four were small, I once calculated that I had to put a minimum of 28 extra items of clothing on them to get them outside in the snow — and, of course, when they came back in, they came in with all 28 items (one hoped), dripping.

headline: Q&A: Dealing With Duplicate Work on Dropbox
text: Q.

headline: Boy, 16, Charged With Murder in Death of Another 16-Year-Old
text: The police on Wednesday charged a teenager with murder in connection with the killing of a 16-year-old last week on the Lower East Side, following a confrontation between two groups of young men.

headline: Homicide Tracking Site Expanding to Chicago
text: Homicide Watch, the Washington, D.C., Web site that tracks murders, has found another crime-ridden city to cover.

headline: Film to Present Iran’s View of ‘Argo’ Events
text: TEHRAN — A tough week for Ben Affleck just got tougher.

headline: Tribal Lessons
text: The custom among the Pirahã Indians of Brazil is that women give birth alone. The linguist Steve Sheldon once saw a Pirahã woman giving birth on a beach, while members of her tribe waited nearby. It was a breech birth, however, and the woman started crying in agony. “Help me, please! The baby will not come.” Sheldon went to help her, but the other Pirahã stopped him, saying that she didn’t want his help. The woman kept up her screams. The next morning both mother and baby were found dead.

headline: One Screen, Two Points of View
text: It would be hard to find another work of contemporary art that protests war with such soulful grace and understated wit as Meiro Koizumi’s “Defect in Vision” (2011), the main attraction of a small show at the Museum of Modern Art. Projected in somewhat different versions on opposite sides of a single screen in lustrous black and white, Mr. Koizumi’s 12-minute video meditates on the doomed, myth-saturated mind of Japan’s warrior class in the last days of World War II.

headline: American Eden, After the Fall
text: WASHINGTON — “It is a beautiful country. I never had the pleasure of seeing it before.” So said the abolitionist John Brown gazing out over the Shenandoah Valley in Virginia, on a December morning in 1859. Americans have always reacted that way to their native land. It was their great possession. Europe had history stretching back into time. America had earth, here and now all potential, paradisally green.

headline: Portable Navigation Learns Some New Moves at C.E.S.
text: Portable navigation devices aren’t dead yet — at least not at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Several makers are promoting their wares this week, including one company that is taking a page from built-in car systems to appeal to smartphone-addicted buyers.

headline: A Google+ Hangout on Modern Slavery
text: Today I participated in a Google+ Hangout with two of my heroes, Somaly Mam of the Somaly Mam Foundation, and Rachel Lloyd of GEMS Girls. Both have devoted their life’s work to fighting sex trafficking, and here’s our discussion. Let me know what you think in the comments section.

headline: Chinese Newspaper Protests End, but Battle Over Censorship Is Unresolved
text: GUANGZHOU, China — The demonstrations have died down, and the reporters and editors are back to work at China’s most prominent weekly newspaper. Its latest issue was published more or less on schedule. But the paper, Southern Weekend, is sure to remain a crucial battleground over Communist Party censorship.

headline: Wet Wrinkled Fingers Evolved for Better Grip
text: The prunelike wrinkles that result from a long, hot bath may have an evolutionary purpose, researchers say.

headline: Richard Nixon’s Legacy
text: Yesterday, on the occasion of what would have been Richard Nixon’s 100th birthday, many journalists rehearsed an argument that goes something like this: To one generation of Americans (who grew up, as I did, in the 60s and 70s), Nixon was the personification of political evil. But his achievements, and his liberalism by the standards of today’s Republican Party, may ultimately prove more significant than his failings.

headline: Making Scrimshaw a Sea Companion
text: Sailors on 19th-century whale ships faced oppressive boredom, interrupted by occasional life-threatening storms and hunting expeditions. As a kind of distracting therapy, they carved whale teeth and bones into everything from dominoes to bird cages, pieces that are collectively known as scrimshaw.

headline: Low Lights, Good Drink and Welcoming Soundtracks
text: It seems to have been something of a stealth invasion. The Gnarly Vine in New Rochelle, which opened in 2007, was the first of the wine bars in southern Westchester County, followed by the rather luxe Vintage 1891  in Larchmont, the cozy Crush on the other side of that town, and then, last month, Bar’Lees in Mamaroneck on the increasingly lively Mamaroneck Avenue.

headline: Jan. 10 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
text: The Lede is following the intensified debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web.

headline: Where the Flippers Still Flap
text: Long eclipsed by video games, pinball machines can still be played in bars, cafes and some truly odd outposts across New York.

headline: For Some Dead Brands, a Tortuous Path to Resurrection
text: At a time when bankruptcy auctions are filled with sad tales of beleaguered brands, snagging a well-known name for pennies on the dollar can seem like a sure bet for ambitious investors.

headline: Where the Flippers Still Flap
text: MOST of the patrons at Mission Dolores in the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn go for craft beers like Dark Horse Scotty Karate Scotch Ale or the house pour, Narragansett Lager. But some do not make it as far as the bar.

headline: These Law Enforcers Will Stop at Nothing
text: “Gangster Squad” is less a movie than a costume party run amok. Set in a late-’40s Los Angeles painted in cartoon colors rather than noir shadows, it is a hectic jumble of fedoras and zoot suits, stockings and cigarettes, and red femme-fatale dresses. The accessories of choice are guns of various calibers and styles, deployed to drown out — or perhaps to emphasize — knucklehead dialogue and inept storytelling.

headline: Children’s Flu Medicine in Short Supply
text: As influenza cases surge around the country, health officials say they are trying to stem a shortage of treatments for children.

headline: Come Together, Bruch and Bruckner
text: Despite the many decades that their lives overlapped and the consonance of their names, like the setup of a joke, Bruch and Bruckner have little in common.

headline: ‘The Civil War and American Art’
text: Works from a new exhibition at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington.

headline: The Healing Power of Yoga Controversy
text: Adapted from the Afterword to “The Science of Yoga,” paperback edition.

headline: Daulerio Is Leaving as Gawker Editor
text: 5:49 p.m. | Updated Gawker Media is getting a change in leadership. A.J. Daulerio, who became the editor of Gawker just over a year ago, is leaving and will be replaced by the writer John Cook.

headline: Raised by Political Activists in a Dictatorship’s Shadow
text: In “Clandestine Childhood” a 12-year-old Argentine boy is forced into playing a dangerous game of pretend. It’s 1979, three years after a military coup d’état at home and exile in Cuba with his family. Now the boy, Juan (Teo Gutiérrez Moreno), who will go by Ernesto, is returning to Argentina with his parents, Charo (Natalia Oreiro) and Daniel (César Troncoso), and his baby sister, Victoria. “We think,” Charo tells Juan, “it’s the right time to carry on fighting.” In between changing diapers she and Daniel will soon be fighting Argentina’s right-wing military dictatorship in the name of freedom and country — and saluting fallen compañeros with rousing cries of “Perón or death!”

headline: No Exit for Returning Son Who Upsets His Family’s Expectation of Vengeance
text: It took more than four years for “Sumeida’s Song,” the first opera by the young Arab-American composer Mohammed Fairouz, to have a staged production. He finished the score in 2008, when he was 22, having been possessed by its source, the play “Song of Death” by the prominent Egyptian writer Tawfiq al-Hakim, who died in 1987. On Wednesday night at Here Arts Center “Sumeida’s Song” inaugurated Prototype, a new festival of boundary-blurring musical-theater works produced by Here and Beth Morrison Projects.

headline: Cigarette Taxes vs. Cigarette Smuggling
text: Three of every five cigarettes consumed in New York State were smuggled in from lower-tax states in 2011, according to new estimates from the Mackinac Center for Public Policy, a free-market research organization in Michigan. That is the highest smuggling rate in the country.

headline: For Wetter or for Worse
text: LIKE expectant parents marveling at a sonogram, Christine Dennison and Tim Taylor gazed at a grainy black-and-white image made by sound waves ricocheting through water, and knew their lives would be forever changed. This was two months before the couple, professional adventurers, were married at the Explorers Club in New York in December 2010. And the image was not of an embryo but of the R-12, a Navy submarine that had been lost for nearly 70 years.

headline: Man in Plastic Ball Dies on Russian Ski Slope
text: MOSCOW — It is called a zorb, an outsize inflatable ball in which people strap themselves, then bounce down a ski slope and, presumably, have a good time doing so. But when a zorb veered off a ski run high in Russia’s Caucasus Mountains earlier this month, there was little anyone could do but watch as the two men inside careened along a jagged ridge and then plunged over a precipice.

headline: As Sea Gulls Hover, Three Old Friends Reunite for a Funeral
text: There isn’t a dishonest moment in “Fairhaven,” Tom O’Brien’s piercing, wistful portrait of three longtime buddies in their mid-30s who reunite around a funeral in a southeastern Massachusetts fishing community. It is the dead of winter, and Peter Simonite’s exquisite cinematography captures the bluish snow light with such acute sensitivity to atmosphere that even in the warmth of a theater you may shiver. A line of sea gulls hovers above a red-gold ribbon of a sunset on the horizon, signaling the distant promise of spring. But for now Fairhaven (a town of about 15,000 near New Bedford) is a place of hibernation.

headline: A ‘Rigoletto’ Reunion Just Might Save the Day
text: In a charming, only somewhat condescending scene in “Quartet,” Reginald Paget (Tom Courtenay), a retired opera singer, lectures a room full of hip-hop-loving teenagers about the similarities and differences between his favorite music and theirs. Opera, he explains, is about the expression of intense emotion through song. Rap, he surmises, sort of does the same thing. There is more to it than that, of course, but Reginald is distracted before he can finish the lesson. Perhaps he might have pointed out that singing opera (and rapping, for that matter) also demands a great deal of discipline and attention to technique.

headline: Digital Notes: Amazon ‘Rips’ CDs Into the Cloud
text: Amazon is turning to an unlikely old friend to step up its competition in digital music: CD’s.

headline: Heavily Armed and Not All That Bright
text: Billy Bob Thornton and Eva Longoria may be the marquee names in “The Baytown Outlaws,” a splattering action comedy set in the Deep South. But the movie’s caffeinated juice is supplied by the actors playing the three Oodie brothers: cretinous, tattooed, muscle-bound hit men who are the ruling outlaws of this modern-day Wild West.

headline: Appeals Court Rules for Warner Bros. in Superman Suit
text: LOS ANGELES – A quest by Warner Brothers to rid its Superman character of legal entanglements just took a major leap forward.

text: What place does pleasure have in a good life?  Should we, following Epicurus and John Stuart Mill, take maximal pleasure as our overriding goal? Or are there higher moral values that trump pleasure?

text: Photos from Kenya, South Africa, Brazil and Venezuela.

headline: First He Is Killed, and Then He Tells His Tale
text: It is usually not a smart idea to kill off a movie’s central character in its opening scene. But that’s what happens in “Struck by Lightning,” a rancid comic satire whose 17-year-old protagonist, Carson Phillips (Chris Colfer of “Glee”), is felled by a bolt from the blue in his high school parking lot.

text: Art

headline: Out of Prison With Little Time to Waste
text: “Banshee,” the latest action-and-attitude series from Cinemax, comes on strong — almost comically so. In the first few minutes the show’s unnamed hero walks out of prison and down some mood-setting railroad tracks, has sex with a waitress and steals a muscle car. Having checked those items off the hard-boiled mystery man’s to-do list, he branches out, tracking down an Asian hairdresser-drag queen from his past, getting shot at and chased through the streets of Lower Manhattan and narrowly avoiding death by a sliding double-decker bus.

headline: Warmly Renovated in Homage to Blue
text: A STATELY six-story Upper East Side town house, carefully renovated with both family and entertaining in mind, is about to come on the market for $29.99 million.

headline: Washington’s Economic Boom, Financed by You
text: One damp morning this winter, Jim Abdo was looking through architectural renderings at his office in Logan Circle, one of the many leafy Washington neighborhoods anchored by a statue of a long-dead guy riding a horse. Abdo got his start as a property developer by buying decrepit buildings and modernizing them, and his headquarters shows off the trick. The adjoining storefronts had been stripped bare and rebuilt, all warm wood and cold glass with exposed brick and beams. It looked like a Brooklyn design studio or a Silicon Valley start-up, or at least how those offices might look in a Nancy Meyers movie. But Abdo has built his business in the unstylish land of think tanks and tepid salmon lunches and boxy women’s suits.

headline: A Judaica Collection Heads to Auction
text: Michael Steinhardt, the New York hedge fund manager, and Judy, his wife, have long supported Jewish causes. They are also known as passionate collectors, particularly of antiquities, though their holdings are far broader than most people realize. For decades the couple have quietly collected Judaica: illuminated manuscripts, elaborate silver vessels, candelabra and menorahs, as well as simple boxes used to collect money for charity.

text: For Syrian refugees in the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan, winter has brought bitter new hardship and at least one death.

headline: A Flip Side to the Attack on Fracking
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: NBC Hockey Announcer Calls Girls’ 12-and-Under Game
text: Mike Emrick’s vacation, otherwise known as the 113-day N.H.L. lockout, is about to end. Unable to call National Hockey League games, Emrick has not been fully idle. He has called some college hockey games for the NBC Sports Network and dabbled in calling figure skating for NBC. But his most unusual assignment came last month: play-by-play of a girls’ 12-and-under league game.

headline: Citizen Foment That Fed Egypt’s Arab Spring
text: It has been almost two years since Egypt’s astonishing revolution began at Tahrir Square in Cairo, the Arab Spring’s biggest moment. As Fredrik Stanton’s documentary “Uprising” makes clear, though, what may have seemed a spontaneous protest by millions against the oppressive 30-year rule of President Hosni Mubarak actually capped years of growing unrest.

headline: The New ‘Old-Money’ Upper East Side
text: IN the TV series “Gossip Girl,” the Brooklyn-bred character Dan Humphrey is the self-described Lonely Boy, who, realizing he can never fit into the wealthy world of the Upper East Side of New York City, starts his “Gossip Girl” Web site, devoted to the “scandalous lives” of the privileged set.

headline: Avoiding Loan-Modification Hoaxes
text: HOMEOWNERS wary of being taken in by bogus “loan modification specialists” should not assume that a law office is the safest conduit to their lender. Consumer advocates say a growing number of fraudulent modification services involve lawyers, or people who say they are lawyers.

headline: SAP Steps on the Gas
text: SAP is betting that a product that brought in 1.5 percent of its 2011 revenue is ready to scatter the competition, maybe even revolutionize SAP itself.

headline: Even Before Oath, Reminders That Being a Police Officer Isn’t Easy
text: Hair buzzed or in buns, hands pressed to knees, backs as ramrod straight as the cushioned burgundy seats of the Queens College auditorium would allow, more than 800 new recruits sat waiting Thursday to be sworn in to the New York Police Department.

headline: New York Examines Over 800 Rape Cases for Possible Mishandling of Evidence
text: The New York City medical examiner’s office is undertaking an unusual review of more than 800 rape cases in which critical DNA evidence may have been mishandled or overlooked by a lab technician, resulting in incorrect reports being given to criminal investigators.

headline: Richard McWilliam, Trading Card Innovator, Dies at 59
text: Richard McWilliam, whose innovative leadership of the trading card company Upper Deck helped make it an industry powerhouse at a time when baseball and other sports cards were increasingly coveted by adult collectors, died on Jan. 5 at his home in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 59.

headline: Windows 8 Failed to Reverse PC Slump During Holidays
text: For weeks, there have been signs that the public was not buying new PCs over the holidays in the numbers many had hoped. Now add to them new figures from IDC, one of the best-known scorekeepers for the market, showing that worldwide PC shipments declined 6.4 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier.

headline: A Bad Budget Estimate Fit Nicely With Prevailing Politics
text: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: An Urban Standard, Coolly Reimagined
text: INTERNATIONAL-STYLE Modernism was supposed to have a purifying effect on architecture — out with the dowdy old, in with the austere elegance of the new!

headline: The Clincher: It Matches My Knitting!
text: CHRISTINE LAVIN spent most of her adult life in the city, migrating north from the East Village to a series of apartments on the Upper West Side.

headline: For International Students, College Checklists for January
text: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: Make the Cabinet More Effective
text: EVERY four years the cabinet briefly becomes the focus of national attention in December and January — only to fade from view again after Inauguration Day. True, individual cabinet secretaries will be in the news from time to time, but the cabinet as an institution will be all but forgotten. Yet the United States could benefit greatly by strengthening its scope and role.

headline: Patriots’ Tight End Tandem Set to Play
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Barring an unforeseen calamity, Tom Brady will have his two young, productive tight ends available Sunday when the New England Patriots host the Houston Texans in an A.F.C. playoff game.

headline: His Job Safe, Straus’s Next Challenge Is the G.O.P.
text: With the latest threat to his leadership easily dispatched, the speaker of the House, Joe Straus, Republican of San Antonio, has proved once again that he can hold onto the third most powerful post in state government despite a vocal contingent of critics in his party’s conservative wing.

headline: Russia to Let a Few U.S. Adoptions Go On
text: MOSCOW — In what could be good news for a few prospective American parents, a top Kremlin official said Thursday that Russian children whose adoptions had already been approved by a court would be allowed to join their adoptive families in the United States and would not be affected by a ban on such adoptions that President Vladimir V. Putin signed into law last month.
