text: Montreal

headline: A Patron With Passion in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Obama and Karzai Meet in Washington
text: President Obama and President Hamid Karzai meet to discuss the future of the American commitment in Afghanistan.

headline: Fallout From Match Fixing in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The recent global lifetime ban of 41 South Korean players for match-fixing does not do the soccer scene in the East Asian country any favors. It perpetuates the perception that the practice is ongoing when it all stems from the one, admittedly serious, outbreak in 2011 that is still moving slowly through the system at home and abroad, both at a soccer and legal level.

headline: Explanations and Advice for Those Hit Hardest by New Tax Increases
text: WHILE the affluent will pay more in taxes this year, that is probably not the case for the very wealthiest — those worth hundreds of millions or more. They may still be paying a lower tax rate than Warren Buffett’s secretary.

headline: Young Tops Blake in Surprising Qualifying Match
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – The first time James Blake played Donald Young was in Arthur Ashe Stadium, in a first-round night match during the 2008 United States Open ). Blake won in five sets, 6-1, 3-6, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4.

headline: City Council to Examine Possible Mishandling of Rape Cases
text: Following a  report in The New York Times on Friday that the city’s medical examiner’s office was reviewing 800 rape cases in which critical DNA evidence may have been mishandled or overlooked by a lab technician, the City Council announced that it would hold an emergency hearing to look into the problem.

headline: A Remote Control for Your Life
text: Dozens of companies at the Consumer Electronics Show showed off connected accessories that communicate with smartphones.

headline: Jan. 13 — 20
text: SINCE opening in 2008 LE POISSON ROUGE has provided a home for some of New York’s most groundbreaking new-music composers and performers. But over time the club has come to host the full range of classical music’s history. Just the first half of this week offers an expansive overview.

headline: Jan. 11 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
text: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web.

headline: Etiquette Lessons for the Braggart: Step 1, Don’t Pretend to Be Humble
text: MOST of you are probably not aware that, in the last month, many seniors in high school have learned whether they have been accepted to their top-choice college.

headline: Highlights From Obama’s News Conference With Karzai
text: President Obama, after meeting with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, said Friday that the United States would be able to accelerate the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan in coming months because of gains made by Afghan security forces.

headline: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
text: Paul Hunt still remembers the dilemma that he and his wife, Lynn, faced in early January 2010 at their home in rural north-central Minnesota. The couple had just moved into their ultra-efficient house, on the outskirts of Pine River, population 944, but still lacked a thermostat and were about to go out of town for more than two days. It was bitterly cold, and an exterior sensor, one of the many dotting their house, suggested that the nighttime temperature would dip far below zero. Should they leave the heat on or turn it off?

headline: Republican Says Akin Was ‘Partially Right’ About Rape
text: Two months after the incendiary issues of rape and abortion helped defeat two Republican Senate candidates, a veteran House Republican from Georgia reopened the subjects on Friday, telling a group in suburban Atlanta that the former Republican senatorial candidate Todd Akin of Missouri was “partially right” when he said that women do not become pregnant when raped.

headline: Toasting and Grinding Spices
text: Is grinding your own spices really worth the effort? Melissa Clark explains why the answer is yes.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 10 P.M. (TMC) MY WEEK WITH MARILYN (2011) Michelle Williams, above, in an Oscar-nominated role, steps into the pumps and pencil skirts of Marilyn Monroe, and Eddie Redmayne plays Colin Clark, a documentary filmmaker who claimed to have spent an intimate interlude with her in 1956 while they were making “The Prince and the Showgirl.” This film, an adaptation of his diaries, also features Kenneth Branagh, in another nominated role, as Laurence Olivier, Monroe’s co-star and director, whose infatuation and ego clashes with Monroe caused him to call her “the stupidest, most self-indulgent little tart I’ve ever come across.” When the shoot went from bad to worse, he told her: “Just be sexy. Isn’t that what you do?” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, “He didn’t get Monroe, and she is similarly out of the grasp of this movie,” adding: “Ms. Williams tries her best, and sometimes that’s almost enough. She’s too thin for the role, more colorlessly complected than creamy, but she whispers and wobbles nicely.” Still, Ms. Dargis said: “The problem isn’t Ms. Williams or the serviceable work of the director, Simon Curtis, but a script by Adrian Hodges that hews faithfully to Clark’s clichés. Instead of the complex woman familiar from the better books about her, the film offers a catalog of Monroe stereotypes: child, woman, smiling exhibitionist, shrieking neurotic, the barefooted free spirit and, lamentably, the martyr teetering in heels toward her doom. The tragic Monroe is obviously dramatic, but the intimations of disaster don’t fit a movie that works so hard to be breezily, easily likable.”

headline: The Divided Influence of Gnosticism
text: In the latest First Things, David Bentley Hart has an interesting essay on Carl Jung’s eccentric, esoteric, solipsistic and impenetrable “Red Book,” which includes some perceptive remarks on the difference between the modern manifestations of Gnosticism and the more ancient variety:

headline: Blood Oranges Add a Ruby Hue to Dishes and Desserts
text: THE last bottle of holiday wine has been drunk, the discarded Christmas trees have been pulped to mulch and my local farmers’ market has shrunk to a few crates of muddy roots and yellowing kale. It’s time to celebrate something new: the arrival of blood oranges.

headline: The Changing Newsroom Environment
text: | Several updates below |There’s been a flurry of blog, Facebook and Twitter shock and anger following Katherine Bagley’s exclusive report for Inside Climate News on the decision by The New York Times to shut down its standalone environment “pod” and redistribute that able team of reporters and editors to other desks (not necessarily other duties).

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Peter Dale, the chef of The National in Athens, GA, will cook up Southern food with a Mediterranean twist in two dinners at City Grit, 38 Prince Street, in SoHo, on Friday at 7:30 p.m. and Saturday at 7 p.m. A five-course meal will be served. Tickets are $75 per person, with wine and beer extra.

headline: Off the Charts: High Tech, High Dividends
text: The information technology sector, which once disdained paying dividends to shareholders, now pays more dividends than any other sector in the Standard & Poor’s 500.

headline: Band’s Name Punches Its Ticket to Russia
text: Sometimes a witty name can take you places. Just ask the American indie pop band Someone Still Loves You Boris Yeltsin. On Sunday, the quartet will headline the Old New Rock Festival in Yekaterinburg, Russia. Boris Yeltsin, the former Russian president, was a native of the region around Yekaterinburg.

headline: Milk Group Opts for Bigger Super Bowl Ad Presence
text: A marketer that until now has had a low-key Super Bowl presence is going all in this time around.

headline: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler Will Be Giving Sondheim His Big Break
text: Seth MacFarlane may not be allowed to drink at the Oscars, but Tina Fey and Amy Poehler have invented a Golden Globes drinking game.

headline: Chief Keef and Cultural Tourism
text: A minor Twitter dispute about a new rap album recently led to some larger discussions about how black pop is understood or misunderstood in the media. Host Ben Ratliff and Times pop critic Jon Caramanica talk about the young Chicago rapper Chief Keef, the original spark for the debate. Later they are later joined by Brian “B.Dot” Miller, content director of the hip-hop blog Rap Radar, for a conversation about age, class, race, memory, and music criticism.

headline: Information Technology Dividends Outpace All Others
text: FOR what appears to be the first time ever, information technology companies in the Standard & Poor’s index of 500 stocks are paying more in dividends than companies in any other sector, S.&P. reported this week.

headline: Smartphones Become Life’s Remote Control
text: LAS VEGAS — The smartphone is no longer just a portable computer in your pocket. It has become the remote control for your life.

headline: After Deadly Fire, a Man Is Charged With Murder
text: The police charged a 45-year-old man with murder, arson and attempted assault on Friday, after a fire in Manhattan that left one person dead and several others injured on Thursday night.

headline: Palestinians Set Up Tents Where Israel Plans Homes
text: JERUSALEM — Adopting a tactic more commonly employed by Jewish settlers who establish wildcat outposts in the West Bank, scores of Palestinian activists erected tents on Friday in a hotly contested piece of Israeli-occupied West Bank territory known as E1, and they said they intended to stay put.

headline: Get Your Finances Together
text: The ”Your Money” columnist Ron Lieber profiles a Seattle woman whose Web site helps individuals and families prepare their financial lives for the unexpected.

headline: Calling All Cauliflower
text: At my house we eat cauliflower like popcorn. Using a simple recipe from Alice Waters, we slice it thin, toss in olive oil and salt, and roast. One head of cauliflower is never enough.

headline: Popcast: Chief Keef and Cultural Tourism
text: This week: Chief Keef, hip-hop journalism and “cultural tourism.”

headline: Street Style From Pitti Uomo
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: C.E.S. 2013: The Voice-Controlled Home, With a Catch
text: The annual International Consumer Electronics show in Las Vegas is always filled with astonishing prototypes for products that don’t exist and may never exist, although you hope they will someday.

headline: Uncertainty Hangs Over Wall Street in 2013
text: Big American banks have plenty to prove in 2013. Wells Fargo aside, their valuations have languished below book value. After a strong 2012 for stock markets and with fourth-quarter earnings reports imminent, JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs are again near that level. But when they get there, it will be a relief rather than anything to crow over.

headline: A Strange Sail
text: As the year 1862 ended, Union naval forces had consolidated effective control of much of the Texas Gulf Coast. From Sabine Pass in the North to the mouth of the Rio Grande, almost all of the roughly 450 miles of Texas coastline were safely in their hands. During that year, minor engagements at Corpus Christi, Galveston and Sabine Pass had effectively secured the coastline from most Confederate shipping.

headline: The Generator Is the Machine of the Moment
text: IN the days that followed Hurricane Sandy, the developer of the luxury condominium 150 Charles Street hunkered down with his team of architects and engineers to rethink the building’s design.

headline: Not an Exotic Mushroom, but a Satisfying One
text: I ENJOY wild mushrooms, but I happen to like ordinary white button mushrooms, too; the cultivated kind, the ones that are also called champignons de Paris (especially by the French). Simply sautéed in a little butter or olive oil and finished with garlic and parsley, or sliced raw for a salad with a lemony dressing — what could be better? They’re completely satisfying.

headline: A Sundance Offshoot in Brooklyn?
text: 1:36 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES – The Sundance Film Festival, having started a London offshoot last year, may be coming to New York next. Such a move would put the venerable movie bazaar in more direct competition with the Tribeca Film Festival, which is overseen in part by Geoffrey Gilmore, Sundance’s former director.

headline: The Dicey Parent-Teacher Duet
text: The teacher-parent relationship is a lot like an arranged marriage. Neither side gets a lot of say in the match. Both parties, however, share great responsibility for a child, which can lead to a deeply rewarding partnership or the kind of conflict found in some joint-custody arrangements.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘We’re Hiring’ Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: The Sweet Spot | Free Speech and Guns
text: A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about free speech and the gun issue — and when violence veers “too close to what is real.”

headline: Red Bulls Release Preseason Plans
text: The Red Bulls have no coach (yet) and one not-so super pick (No. 22 over all) in Thursday’s Major League Soccer draft, and now players’ frequent-flyer accounts are about to take a hit after the club on Friday announced its preseason training plans.

headline: Kimmel Gains in Coveted 18-49 Age Group
text: On his third day as an 11:35 p.m. late night host, Jimmy Kimmel took his biggest step yet to separate himself from the two titans of that time period, David Letterman and Jay Leno. He started pulling away, at least for one night, among the most important audience in late night.

headline: Wells Fargo Awash in Mortgage Gains
text: The Federal Reserve’s extraordinary efforts to stimulate the housing market and the wider economy continues to benefit banks’ bottom lines.

headline: The View from Baylor: Back at No. 1
text: The Baylor Lady Bears are back in familiar territory, reclaiming the No. 1 spot in The Associated Press poll after seven weeks out of it.

headline: Putting Myself Out There, and Waiting for a College to Accept
text: A college application is an individual’s proposition about why he or she would best fit in a particular school. The same goes for the interview process. It really is an opportunity to show who you were then, who you are now, and who you want to be in the future.

headline: A Trail of Bullet Casings Leads From Africa’s Wars Back to Iran
text: The first clues appeared in Kenya, Uganda and what is now South Sudan. A British arms researcher surveying ammunition used by government forces and civilian militias in 2006 found Kalashnikov rifle cartridges he had not seen before. The ammunition bore no factory code, suggesting that its manufacturer hoped to avoid detection.

headline: A Shocking Death, a Financial Lesson and Help for Others
text: SEATTLE

headline: Opera Meets Philosophy
text: It has the makings of an extremely high-brow reality show: find four composers, give them a set of philosophical questions and see what kind of opera each comes up with. The Royal Opera in London has presented the challenge to Kaija Saariaho of Finland, Mark-Anthony Turnage of Britain, Luca Francesconi of Italy and Jörg Widmann of Germany. In a statement on Thursday the company said it had come up with the questions “in collaboration with” the philosopher Slavoj Zizek, and will ask the composers to write works responding to them. The questions are: “What preoccupies us today? How can we today stage ourselves? What are the collective myths of our present and future?” The operas are expected to be presented in 2020.

headline: Getting Your Will and Estate Plans Together
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I pay a visit to Chanel Reynolds, a widow who has built a site whose name cannot be mentioned here (though I can give you a link to it). It encourages you to get your will, living will and power of attorney done. And it urges you to collect all of your financial and other account information in one place and let a few trusted people know where to find it.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Jan. 11
text: This week, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about free speech and the gun issue — and when violence veers “too close to what is real.”

headline: Affleck Can Joke but Hollywood’s Puzzled by Snubs
text: Ben Affleck continued his roll of giving funny and pointed (yet classy) awards speeches. At the Critics’ Choice ceremony on Thursday night, where “Argo” won the best picture and best director trophy just hours after Mr. Affleck had been snubbed by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, he began his speech the only way feasible.

headline: In a Wartime Telegram, a Look at a Frustrated Lincoln
text: One way to think of it is this: It is a page from the script for the script for “Lincoln.”

headline: So Much for the Growing Class War
text: Despite all the talk of the lazy 47 percenters, the scruffy 99 percent versus the entitled top 1 percent, contentious proposals to raise taxes on the rich, and the uncapped political donations of billionaires, the “class war” apparently abated last year, if you believe the American public.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $24,750,000
text: A century-old Upper East Side town house — a landmark with an off-again-on-again relationship to the market since 2008, when it was offered for $32.75 million, finding no takers — was yet another beneficiary of the December dash to seal the deal on luxury properties before onerous tax implications kicked in. At $24.75 million it was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Baseball’s Hit King Finds a New Team, and Queen
text: Already banned from baseball for betting on games, Pete Rose now has another infraction on his record: His new reality show, “Pete Rose: Hits & Mrs.,” tests positive for tedium.

headline: Flu Season Deaths Reach Epidemic Level but May Be at Peak, C.D.C. Says
text: Deaths in the current flu season have officially crossed the line into “epidemic” territory, federal health officials said Friday, adding that, on the bright side, there were also early signs that the caseloads could be peaking.

headline: Giants, Jets, Broncos: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: Christa Justus and Mark Linn-Baker
text: EVEN those who spend their lives in the limelight can feel star-crossed when confronted by the harsh reality of the New York City dating scene.

headline: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
text: MEXICO CITY — This megacity of more than 20 million rang in the New Year with a pleasant revelation: the region registered 248 days in 2012 in which the air quality considered good.

headline: Keeping Environmental Reporting Strong Won’t Be Easy
text: Those who care deeply about environmental issues were understandably concerned Friday after learning that The Times was dismantling its special team – or “pod” – of seven reporters and two editors.

headline: Shell Violated Air Permits for Arctic Ships, E.P.A. Says
text: The Environmental Protection Agency says that Shell committed numerous violations of the air pollution permits for its two Arctic drill ships, adding to the company’s catalog of Alaskan offshore woes.

headline: My Travel Wish List
text: WE travel for pleasure, for a door-slamming sense of “I’m outta here,” for a change of air, for edification, for the big vulgar boast of being distant, for the possibility of being transformed, for the voyeuristic romance of gawping at the exotic; and sometimes we travel because we have been banished. I was banished once, and it fortified me.

headline: Guns, Abortion and Mistrust
text: Before his closed-door meeting with gun-control advocates on Wednesday, Vice President Joe Biden chatted briefly with reporters. What he told them incensed right-wing news sources. The Drudge Report splashed headshots of Hitler and Stalin. The Examiner  ran a story claiming that President Obama would “ban guns” and “act like a dictator” by taking legally owned firearms from “nonviolent Americans.”

headline: Obama Accelerates Transition of Security to Afghans
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, eager to turn the page after more than a decade of war, said Friday that beginning this spring American forces would play only a supporting role in Afghanistan, which opens the way for a more rapid withdrawal of the troops.

headline: Unions Back Revisions of Labor Law in France
text: PARIS — French labor unions and business leaders struck a deal on Friday to overhaul swaths of France’s notoriously rigid labor market, moving to tame some of the most confounding rules in the 3,200-page labor code as the country tries to increase its competitiveness and curb unemployment.

headline: Understanding the Home Appraisal Process
text: BEFORE anyone can buy a house with a loan from a bank or refinance a mortgage, the lender needs an objective assessment of the property’s value — after all, the home is the bank’s collateral for the loan. Assessing the value is the job of the appraiser.

headline: Feeling For | Gerard Tully’s Snake Ring
text: It’s the year of the snake (the Chinese New Year begins on Feb. 10) and in honor of that, the Gerard Tully designer Ryan Kearney is adding an 18-karat solid yellow gold snake to his menagerie of diamond-eyed animal rings. Since they’re made to order, no two rings are exactly alike (wait time: three weeks). “Snakes can be hypnotic, and I’ve been told that this ring is, too,” Kearney says. “Charming is the name of the game.” Hissssss.

headline: Newark Mayor Takes First Official Step Toward a Senate Run
text: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark has taken his first official step toward running for the United States Senate in 2014.

headline: A Scene From ‘Luv’
text: A scene from "Luv," directed by Sheldon Candis and starring Common and Michael Rainey Jr.

headline: Just Cry Uncle: Write, and Direct, What You Know
text: IN the film “Luv,” opening Jan. 18, an 11-year old boy learns some not-always-lovely life lessons from his paroled uncle on the streets of Baltimore. Its director, Sheldon Candis, 33, has learned a few lessons himself on the way to making his first feature, which had its premiere at last year’s Sundance Film Festival. A Baltimore native, Mr. Candis loosely based the film’s story, which he wrote with Justin Wilson, on childhood experiences with his own uncle: riding around late at night in his car and listening to his advice on how to be a man. His possible criminal connections weren’t an issue. The fictionalized version goes deeper, exploring what happens when role models exhibit less than model behavior.

headline: New Women’s League Allocates Players
text: The National Women’s Soccer League on Friday divvied up 55 national team players from the United States, Mexico and Canada among the eight clubs scheduled to begin play in the league’s inaugural season in the spring.

headline: State of the Union Date Is Set
text: President Obama will deliver the first State of the Union address of his second term on February 12, having received a formal invitation from House Speaker John A. Boehner on Friday to address a joint session of Congress on that date.

headline: Obama and Karzai Hold Press Conference
text: President Obama and President Hamid Karzai spoke about postwar Afghanistan at the White House on Friday.

headline: Low-Cost Shelters for Feral Cats
text: A display of cat shelters from eight New York City architects and designers.

headline: For Feral Cats, a Few New Places to Call Home
text: EIGHT New York City architects and designers proudly displayed their new low-cost houses at a show in Manhattan on Thursday, and not a single client was present. Feral cats are like that.

headline: A Mixed Start for the Winter TV Season
text: The flipping of the calendar to the new year also signals the arrival of television’s winter season, with many new and returning TV shows vying for attention.

headline: 50-Year Term for Burning a Woman to Death in an Elevator
text: Calling the crime one of the most brutal he had seen in his judicial career, a judge in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Friday sentenced a man who burned a woman to death in an elevator to 50 years in prison.

headline: The Tax Code and the Very Rich
text: Almost anyone who receives a paycheck will pay higher taxes this year. But as Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week, the very wealthiest Americans — those worth hundreds of millions or more — usually don’t get paychecks. These people, generally partners in private equity firms or hedge fund managers, earn much of their money as a share of their funds’ earnings. And those earnings are taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income.

headline: Would Exporting the Natural Gas Surplus Help The Economy, or Hurt?
text: Natural gas exports are turning into Washington’s hottest energy question.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The State of the Nuclear World
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Bill Keller reviews three new books that address the current thinking about nuclear weapons. Mr. Keller writes:

headline: Taking In the Winter Jazzfest (Or Trying to, Anyhow)
text: The Winter Jazzfest heaved into being in 2005, subsuming all three floors of what was then the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa. Over the last eight years the festival has expanded and relocated — its geographical center, since 2009, has been the Bleecker Street bar district, in and around Le Poisson Rouge — but its core function hasn’t changed at all.

headline: Spokesman for Cuomo to Become Chief of Staff
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who is known for his careful, if aggressive, cultivation of the news media, is promoting his press spokesman to serve as his chief of staff.

headline: On the Market | Second Homes in Miami
text: A beachfront contemporary, a waterfront Mediterranean, a South of Fifth condo, a Venetian Islands waterfront and a Downtown condo.

headline: Butler’s Next Challenge: The Atlantic 10
text: The Butler men’s basketball team had one of the toughest nonconference schedules in the country. They played three teams that were in the top 25 at the time of their games, as well as six teams from last year’s N.C.A.A. tournament. That schedule included Xavier, Marquette, North Carolina, Illinois, Northwestern, Indiana and Vanderbilt. On Jan. 19, Butler plays Gonzaga, ranked No. 9.

headline: Designing for Calm
text: IT should come as no surprise that violence in mental health facilities causes psychological and often physical harm to health care workers and patients. What’s shocking is how prevalent it is.

headline: Teacher’s Grade Hinges on Student’s Playoff Test
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In his only planned meeting with local reporters before Saturday’s playoff game against Green Bay, 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick was asked 23 questions in five minutes.

headline: Spices: When to Grind, When to Toast
text: This week’s video shows how to toast and then grind whole spices, a worthy endeavor.

headline: Sundance Makes a Family of the Denied
text: THE first-time feature-film director Stacy Sherman was on the edge of her seat in a Los Angeles movie theater, watching “Silver Linings Playbook,” when she received the e-mail she’d been waiting for. Ms. Sherman had been repeatedly checking her BlackBerry in those days leading up to Thanksgiving, and at last she scanned the words: “Sundance,” “ ‘Claire’s Cambodia’ ” (the name of her movie) and, finally, “we are sorry.”

headline: Screams and Curses: A ‘Beast’ Nominee Gets the News
text: The screenwriter Lucy Alibar based parts of “Beasts of the Southern Wild” on her own relationship with her father, who lives in the rural South and never saw her one-act play, from which the indie hit and best-picture nominee was adapted. So it was particularly gratifying to have him and her mother be a part of her Oscar morning on Thursday. “I didn’t think they had a TV that worked,” she said, “but I guess they did, they were watching it.”

headline: Q&A: Resetting a Kindle’s Automatic Bookmark
text: Q.

headline: Q & A
text: Landlady Demands Half of Rent in Cash

headline: ‘Any Lawful Steps’ Urged to Avert Default
text: WASHINGTON — The Democratic leadership in the Senate asked President Obama on Friday to take “any lawful steps” available to avoid a default on the nation’s debt if Republicans continue to press their demand that an increase in the government’s borrowing limit be accompanied by spending cuts of the same magnitude.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 11
text: Subjects include performances by Ethan Hawke and Tamar Shelef, and the recently refurbished King’s Cross Station.

headline: In Defense of Child Bribery
text: I’m an unabashed briber of my children.

headline: The Messy Work of Examining Disorganizations
text: THE Brooklyn documentarians Audrey Ewell and Aaron Aites were watching live online as Occupy Wall Street started its ill-fated march over the Brooklyn Bridge. It was October 2011, and “there was this crazy drama unfolding,” Ms. Ewell said. “All of a sudden everybody is being arrested — and then the guy who was filming it said his batteries were running low, and the screen went black.”

headline: Train a Parent, Spare a Child
Week in Review: When Hedge Fund Managers Clash
text: DealBook analyzed new loan rules and examined cuts at Morgan Stanley. Andrew Ross Sorkin said the easing of rules for banks acknowledges reality. A.I.G. weighs whether to sue the U.S. but decides against it; two hedge fund managers clashed; an ex-SAC analyst cooperated on an insider case; Bank of America made a deal to extend a retreat from mortgages; and banks agreed to pay $8.5 Billion to speed up foreclosure relief.

headline: King of the Hill, Indeed, With a Price to Match
text: TROY, N.C.

headline: Listing of Films of 2012 by Female Directors
text: Of the 250 top films at the box office last year, 9 percent were made by female filmmakers. Most were working on their own, a few had partners. Here are their films, in alphabetical order:

headline: The Rear-Engine Corvette That Was Never to Be
text: ON Sunday evening, just ahead of two press preview days for the 2013 North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Chevrolet will unveil the seventh generation of the Corvette. While the two-seat sports car accounts for a small fraction of Chevy’s total sales, it is a vital element of the brand’s image — and, in fact, its longest-running passenger-car nameplate.

headline: Female Directors Gain Ground, Slowly
text: FOR those rooting for women to make strides in Hollywood the news that Brenda Chapman, a screenwriter and director of “Brave,” had been replaced at the helm midway through production of that animated film about the flame-haired archer came as a blow last year. The happy ending is that the movie on which Ms. Chapman shares directing credit (with Mark Andrews) ranks eighth at the box office in 2012.

headline: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
text: Biomimetic is a popular term among designers and engineers. Imitating nature’s shapes promises more efficient as well as more elegant buildings and vehicles. Now get ready to hear “morphogenesis.” Not content with adopting the forms of nature, engineers are looking to adapt the processes of nature to design.

headline: Yoko Ono Takes Fight Against Gas Drilling to Albany
text: ALBANY — For months they have been descending on Albany: farmers, environmentalists, latter-day hippies and placard-bearing parents.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 11
text: More photographs.

headline: Reviving a Dream ’Vette
text: The XP-819, a storied Corvette engineering prototype, is progressing toward the final phases of a restoration at a shop in Long Island.

headline: How to Shoot a Viper
text: For this week’s Look, we sent Brett Beyer to photograph the Chrysler auto plant in Detroit where the Dodge Viper is manufactured. Recently I spoke to Beyer about how he made his pictures.

headline: The End of Courtship?
text: MAYBE it was because they had met on OkCupid. But when the dark-eyed musician with artfully disheveled hair asked Shani Silver, a social media and blog manager in Philadelphia, out on a “date” Friday night, she was expecting at least a drink, one on one.

headline: A Nuclear Post-Mortem for Sandy
text: The operators of the Oyster Creek nuclear plant, the reactor that declared an “alert” during Hurricane Sandy, made several small errors, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Friday. But an inspection team has concluded that “performance was acceptable and that emergency action level declarations were timely.”

headline: Manufacturing a Viper
text: Inside a newly reopened Chrysler plant in Detroit, a car revs to life.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: Alexandros Pissourios captures the calm chaos of backstage beauty at the Meadham Kirchhoff men’s-wear show in London in a fashion film. The man behind the coifs? James Pecis, who was also responsible for the models’ neon tresses from last season.

headline: The Week in Pictures for the New York Region, Jan. 11
text: Subjects include the effort to create a High Line in Queens, the State of the State address from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, and the final days of the Long Beach Boardwalk.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Strange Hiring Questions and Curved Controls
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Whispered Lyrics, Spooky Snippets, Old Frontiers Anew
text: Dom La Nena

headline: Tending to Veterans’ Afflictions of the Soul
text: FORT WORTH — On a drizzly Saturday afternoon in September 2005, the Rev. Rita Nakashima Brock awaited her instructions at a vast Washington rally against the Iraq war. The protest march, numbering more than 100,000, was the latest and among the largest events in her nearly 40 years of pacifist activism.

headline: A Cold Case of Cold-Blooded Murder
text: ON a hot July day in 1977, one of New York’s ugliest summers, my 23-year-old cousin, Ellen Hover, left her Third Avenue apartment. She had an appointment with a young photographer who had asked to take pictures of her. His name, he’d told her, was John Berger.

headline: Graphic Design: What a Trip
text: O.K., kids and curators: it’s official.

headline: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
text: Photos from China, Pakistan, India and Spain.

headline: Nam June-Paik at the Smithsonian
text: The exhibit “Nam June-Paik: Global Visionary,” on view at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, D.C.

headline: Shows Go On, Under New Proprietors
text: CULVER CITY, Calif.

headline: A Generation Gap? Not on This Web Site
text: YOUNG, stylish women may spend thousands of hours and hundreds of dollars trolling the Web for everything from naughty to nice at sites like Shopbop, Net-a-Porter and Rue La La. But what about their mothers?

headline: Doctors Recommend Flu Shot for Children With Egg Allergies
text: Amid an unusually widespread outbreak of the flu, a medical association of allergy specialists said Friday that even children with severe egg allergies should get flu shots.

headline: A Rugged Benz That Still Rides Smooth
text: The Mercedes-Benz GL350 is a unique beast, offering vanlike capaciousness, an interior worthy of the S-Class and a helping of legitimate old-school S.U.V. abilities.

headline: More Emergency Visits Linked to Energy Drinks
text: A rising number of patients, many of them young people, are being treated in emergency rooms for complications related to highly caffeinated energy drinks like Red Bull, Monster Energy and 5-Hour Energy, new federal data shows.

headline: Industry’s New Year Buffet: Entrees and a Few Desserts
text: THE annual North American International Auto Show, which opens in Detroit on Monday with two days of press previews, is off life support after a few touch-and-go years when various automakers pulled out and some threatened to go elsewhere.

headline: Palestinians Rally Support Online for West Bank Protest Camp
text: About 200 Palestinian activists set up camp, and a Twitter feed, on Friday in a part of the Israeli-occupied West Bank just east of Jerusalem known as E1, where Israel plans to build homes for thousands of new settlers. The activists described their encampment as the start of “a new Palestinian village named Bab al-Shams,” Arabic for “Gate of the Sun,” after a book by the Lebanese novelist Elias Khoury.

headline: Living In | Richmond Hill
text: A diverse part of Queens, made up of single- and multifamily homes with a smattering of apartment buildings.

headline: Indo-Caribbean Content, Victorian Style
text: RICHMOND HILL, in southeastern Queens, is the ultimate study in New York diversity. It is a place to eat Caribbean cuisine, shop for Bollywood movies, worship at a Sikh temple and stroll through streets lined with Victorian-era houses, a slice of pure Americana.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: A Genuinely Novel Gadget, the Self-Driving Car
text: Most of what’s on display at this year’s Consumer Electronics Show is the same as what was on display at last year’s Consumer Electronics Show. Phones, TV sets, accessories. Minus Microsoft, of course.

headline: A Conversation With Bill Moyers
text: I taped a long talk with Bill Moyers yesterday. Here’s the link. It should also be aired on most PBS stations this weekend; listings at the Moyers site.

headline: As Flu Rages, Caregiving Suffers
text: The flu started in the personal care center at Masonic Village in Elizabethtown, Pa., then moved to the nursing home. Within a few days, seven older adults had taken ill.

headline: Discolored Slopes Mar Debut of Snow-Making Effort
text: After a decade of legal battles, a ski resort in Northern Arizona recently became the first in the world to make artificial snow totally out of sewage effluent. On Dec. 24, Arizona Snowbowl fired up its snow guns for the first time, and to everyone’s surprise, the snow that blasted onto the mountain was yellow.

headline: Is That A Backbone I See?
text: Senate Democrats give Obama full backing in any unilateral action he might take on the debt ceiling. Reports say that Harry Reid is still partial to the 14th amendment; but there’s also the coin and the coupons.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Pakistanis Protest the Killing of 86 Shiites
text: ISLAMABAD — Protesters and distraught family members of 86 Shiites from the Hazara ethnic group killed in two bomb blasts on Thursday in the southwestern city of Quetta braved biting cold to stage a sit-in on Friday, refusing to bury their dead till the Pakistani Army took control of the city to provide them with security.

headline: A Crash Course in Mandarin, With No Books or Interpreters
text: Ready to learn a little Mandarin? Head down to the Public Theater for the next week or so, where “C’est du Chinois,” a language lesson in the lively form of an interactive theater piece, is being presented as part of the Under the Radar festival.

headline: Friday Night Music: More The Head and the Heart
text: Still listening to this band a lot:

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Get the Media Out of the Honoring Business
text: It is no great sacrifice for me to say that those who regularly cover major league baseball should get the heck out of the business of Hall of Fame voting. That’s because I work for a newspaper, The New York Times, that doesn’t allow its reporters to participate in the business — and that’s exactly what it is — of electing ballplayers to a club that will not only elevate their historic standing, but will enhance their earning power.

headline: Don’t Own It? Still Make Money on Land Sale Near Brooklyn Bridge
text: Hipsters are not the only ones reaping benefits from the soaring value of real estate in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn. All of Consolidated Edison’s customers could soon share in a minor windfall from the sale of the next piece of Brooklyn Bridge Park.

headline: Wearing Gray, Breathing Hard and Repeating Themselves
text: Performed by two people wearing combinations of leotards and medieval attire, “Sacre,” by the French choreographer David Wampach, is fairly silly, slightly boring and very peculiar. The boring and the peculiar aspects actually work to the piece’s advantage. What little happens keeps happening again and again — but it is so sheerly odd that the repetitions encourage you to slap on meanings, making it more interesting than it is. Still, despite its bizarre sides, the work is ultimately both flimsy and fatuous.

headline: Moving Back in Time and Nearer to Nature
text: So much care has gone into making Emily Johnson’s “Niicugni” that you can almost smell it. At the Baryshnikov Arts Center, where this dance installation had its New York premiere on Wednesday as part of Performance Space 122’s Coil Festival, 51 lanterns hand-sewn from fish skins hang over the stage and audience. A map inserted in the program specifies not just which of the many volunteers made which lamp but also how many thousands of miles the fish might have traveled in its migrations.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Sri Lankan Parliament Impeaches Chief Justice
text: NEW DELHI — Defying a court order, Sri Lanka’s Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Friday to impeach the nation’s chief justice, a significant step in a worsening showdown between the legislature and the judiciary that has alarmed democracy advocates and many foreign governments.

headline: For Golden Globes, It’s a Good Time
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — It is awfully easy to make fun of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

headline: Lawyers Say Police Confused Bomb Suspect’s ‘Doodle’ With Nazi Symbol
text: Lawyers for Aaron Greene, the man charged with keeping an explosive chemical in his Greenwich Village apartment, criticized investigators on Friday for linking what they said was a “mere doodle” by their client to a Nazi symbol.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 11
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the effort to create a park in Queens like the High Line; Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s State of the State address; and the final days of the Long Beach Boardwalk.

headline: Judge Settles Dispute Over Rare Gem Collection
text: A legal dispute over a rare collection of 295 naturally colored diamonds currently on display at a London museum was recently settled in favor of a New Jersey diamond dealer who had spent years assembling the collection.

headline: Lessons Learned, and Put on a Plate
text: When I first moved to New Jersey in 1987, residents of downtown Jersey City who cared about the latest trends in food did their dining in Hoboken. In 2001, Marco & Pepe opened to accommodate the growing influx of urban homesteaders, and now there are Madame Claude Cafe, the Light Horse Tavern and Thirty Acres, among other notable restaurants. There is also Satis.

headline: Mortality Rate by Year
text: Last week, the percentage of deaths from pneumonia and influenza moved slightly above the epidemic threshold, to 7.3 percent. In recent years, though, this figure has risen much higher.

headline: Voices as an Instrument
text: A 50-year-old shower crooner takes a turn with the nation’s oldest a cappella group, the Whiffenpoofs of Yale.

headline: Singing for Their Supper
text: DURING my brief tenure as a member of one of the nation’s oldest a cappella groups, the Whiffenpoofs of Yale, I learned a shortcut. I call it fakeappella. You keep your mouth very liquid, and when you get to a note and lyric that you are entirely sure of, you do to that note and lyric what a flame thrower would do to a piece of Kleenex.

headline: Options for Protecting Social Security
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Remark by Hagel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Picking a College
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tobacco and the Stars
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Came First? The Sack
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Von Miller is happy to show off the shiny, white, personalized high-tops he will wear in Saturday’s playoff game against the Baltimore Ravens.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Legs of Manhattan
text: The gothic and medieval eras are casting their spells over fashion. Today's look of black leggings and abbreviated coats suggests men in the 1400s.

headline: Inside a Greek Poet’s Work, a Reflection of Her Country’s Hard Times
text: ATHENS

headline: A Homey Style That Is All Italian-American
text: In search of an antidote to the jet-fueled pace of holiday entertaining, we landed the Friday before New Year’s at Sophia’s Ristorante Italiano, a casual and accommodating eatery on Route 1 in Westbrook. This unassuming space has housed three other restaurants during the past several years, but longtime locals will probably remember Marty’s Seafood Restaurant, where beachgoers fortified themselves with fried fish and hot dogs after a day in the sun. Sophia’s is the third Connecticut restaurant for owner Mauricio Salgar, who also owns the Black Seal in Essex and Gabrielle’s in Centerbrook.

headline: Bollywood Laughs at Corruption
text: Opened on Friday nationwide.

headline: Greece Votes to Raise Tax on Higher Earners
text: ATHENS — Greek lawmakers voted late Friday to increase taxes on middle- to high-income earners, self-employed professionals and businesses despite vehement objections by the political opposition and several ruling coalition deputies who said austerity-weary citizens should not be subjected to further pain.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s King Allows Women to Join National Advisory Council
text: Women are not allowed to drive and cannot yet vote in Saudi Arabia, but on Friday they were given a voice in an advisory council that debates the kingdom’s legislation.

headline: Activists Document Sit-In by Families of Bombing Victims in Pakistan
text: Last Updated, 8:31 p.m. Hours after it started on Friday night, Pakistani television began to report on a protest in the city of Quetta, where relatives of scores of people killed in bomb attacks one day earlier sat beside coffins in the street, refusing to bury their loved ones until they received assurance that the state would protect them.

headline: Trouble in Russia Over Ban of Adoptions by Americans
text: MOSCOW — The moratorium on the adoption of Russian children by Americans, which began as a fight between two countries, began this week to look like a fight between Russians and themselves.

headline: A Horror Movie Parody
text: Opened on Friday nationwide.

headline: Motorcycle Auction Brings Unexpected Results
text: 3:42 p.m. | Updated LAS VEGAS – The Bonhams Las Vegas Motorcycle Auction on Thursday produced some upsets and surprises as some of the most highly anticipated lots did not sell, others sold for unexpected prices and a 1954 BMW Rennsport RS54 Sidecar was a top seller.

headline: Seeking Truth; Finding Fear
text: “Bluebeard” is about wanting to know the unknowable. The rich old man of the title entrusts his young wife with the keys to his castle, warning of a single room she must not enter.

headline: Taste of Adventure, With Hint of Familiarity
text: Italian-Kitchen, a new, shoe-box-size trattoria in Ardsley that taps into the “ode to nonna” and rustic-modern vein, is the perfect sort of place to eat on a cold night. The muscular, full-flavored food — thick slices of roasted eggplant layered with mousse-like ricotta and bold tomato sauce; pink-centered slabs of hanger steak punched up with Gorgonzola dolce; tortellini stuffed with duck liver and dusted with fennel pollen; rich dark-chocolate bread pudding thick with golden raisins — is packed with lots of calories, and lots of simple pleasures.

headline: Tipsy Corporate Intrigues That Fill Billable Hours
text: There aren’t enough church services to cleanse Sunday of what Showtime does to it with the return of its iniquitous triumvirate, “Shameless,” “House of Lies” and “Californication.”

headline: Warming and Weighty Reds
text: When winter’s chill sets in and menus tend toward hearty fare, a weighty red wine lends a warmth of its own.

headline: Death of a Daughter
text: The death of a young woman who was raped by several men in New Delhi in December has shattered the dreams of her father.

headline: Winter Jazzfest: Pretty Postbop From a Comfy Seat
text: Bryan and the Aardvarks, led by the bassist Bryan Copeland, specializes in an unabashedly pretty strain of postbop, chamberlike and euphonious. At the Culture Project theater on Bleecker Street, early in the going at Winter Jazzfest on Friday night, they sounded ready for a bigger stage, or at least an indie film soundtrack.

headline: From French Roots, a Multicultural Menu
text: Both the food and the décor at Bistro Etcetera, on Main Street in Port Washington, are as eclectic as the name suggests. There is nothing haphazard about the cooking, though: the chef and owner, Karen Melanie LaRocco, clearly knows what she is doing.

headline: A Cancer Cycle, From Here to China
text: MORE than one million people in the Chinese city of Handan awoke last week to the alarming news that an essential source of their drinking water, the Zhouzhang River, had been dangerously contaminated by a 39-ton chemical spill in the nearby city of Changzhi. What made the news even more shocking was that the leak, from a factory pipe, had started at least five days earlier but had been kept secret by government officials, who allowed millions of their neighbors to keep drinking.

headline: Claude Nobs, Founder of Montreux Jazz Festival, Dies at 76
text: Claude Nobs, who founded the Montreux Jazz Festival in 1967 and built it into an international phenomenon far more famous than the small Swiss resort town where it was held — and far more musically inclusive than the term “jazz festival” would suggest — died on Thursday in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 76.

headline: How to Shoot a Gun
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.

headline: New Jersey Symphony President Quits After Questions on His Past
text: Richard Dare made a splash last year as an outspoken entrepreneur turned arts administrator and started work on Jan. 2 as the president and chief executive of the New Jersey Symphony, with the promise that his business acumen would bring it new luster.

headline: Cinematic Polish for an Evolving Shore Town
text: ASBURY PARK, N.J.

headline: Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
text: The most successful players at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last month were Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York City, and Hemant Lall of Dallas and his son, Justin Lall of Las Vegas.

headline: For India Rape Victim’s Family, Many Layers of Loss
text: MEDAWARA KALAN, India — The village of Medawara Kalan lies down a one-lane dirt track, past mustard fields, thatched-roof huts and piles of neatly stacked cow dung patties, dried to use for fuel.

headline: Hostess Names Flowers as Lead Bidder for Bread Brands
text: Hostess Brands said on Friday that it has picked Flowers Foods as the lead bidder for most of its bread brands, a group of names that includes onetime staples like Wonder Bread.

headline: 1908 Courthouse Reborn as a Museum
text: GLEN COVE, N.Y.

headline: When Rangers Roamed the Halls
text: Barry Beck’s tomato-red perm stopped me in my tracks as I rounded the corner on the second floor of the Ramada Inn in Armonk, N.Y. It was mid-September 1983, and I had been in the hotel’s employ for two weeks. It was only then that I noticed the squirming mummy being carried by Beck, the Rangers’ captain, and Nick Fotiu, the team’s resident brawler.

headline: ‘Twelfth Night’ Twit Gets a Turn in the Spotlight
text: Even the most audacious actors rarely play a suicide attempt for laughs. But in his acclaimed one-man show “I, Malvolio,” the British performer Tim Crouch flings a noose over a ceiling pipe, slides a chair underneath and blames everyone for his lot in life — audience members included. So will they muster compassion for this character, a puritanical blowhard who has just spent 30 minutes attacking them for a variety of sins, or will they indulge baser instincts and mock him in kind?

headline: A Big Exhibition About an Even Bigger War
text: NEW ORLEANS— The project has already taken almost as long as the war it chronicles, and the most difficult part is yet to come. But on Sunday, when the National World War II Museum opens its third building here, it will be just midway through a strategic expansion, creating a $325 million campus of six buildings, extending along three square blocks near the Pontchartrain Expressway. What is promised by 2016 is an epic survey of the American experience during the war.

headline: The Flu. Who Knew?
text: Everybody is talking about the flu. Never have I seen so many people trying to open doorknobs with their elbows. “Epidemic spurs rush to hospitals,” announced The New York Post under a “Flu York” front-page headline. A financial Web site offered a list of undervalued stocks in the funeral service industry. The mayor of Boston declared a public health emergency. Google Flu Trends painted a map of the country in deep red and inspired a raft of terrifying predictions. (“Outbreak could be the worst on record.”)

headline: China: Landslide Buries a Rural Village
text: A rescue operation was under way in a rural part of western China after a landslide buried a village in Yunnan Province, killing at least 42 people and injuring two others, the authorities said Friday. Officials in Beijing ordered an “all-out rescue” effort to search for survivors after reports said that 19 children were among the missing, according to Xinhua, the official state news agency. The landslide, which took place in a mountainous region about 340 miles northeast of Kunming, the provincial capital, was said to have been set off by heavy rain and snow.

headline: Sony Defends ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ After Oscar Voter Speaks Out
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s official: “Zero Dark Thirty” is now a political football not just in the United States Senate, where several senators have been challenging its portrayal of torture in the hunt for Osama bin Laden, but also within the voting ranks of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

headline: Bolivia: Morales Wins Victory as U.N. Agrees to Define Some Coca Use as Legal
text: Traditional uses of the coca leaf in Bolivia will no longer be considered illegal under a United Nations antidrug convention, the organization said Friday. Coca is the plant used to make cocaine, but many people in Bolivia, which has a majority indigenous population, chew it as a mild stimulant, a use that has continued since pre-Colombian times. Bolivians also use the plant as a tea, in medicines and in religious or social rituals. The government of President Evo Morales withdrew from the international agreement a year ago as it sought an exception for traditional uses of the plant within its borders. The change was a diplomatic victory for Mr. Morales, above. To block the change, 62 United Nations members would have had to object; only 15 did, including the United States. Bolivia will now rejoin the convention, which could help it receive aid in fighting drug trafficking.

headline: Russia: Ex-Defense Chief Faces Accusers
text: State investigators on Friday accused the former defense minister, Anatoly E. Serdyukov, of obstructing a corruption investigation into real estate dealings by the Defense Ministry, and suggested that he might soon face criminal charges. Mr. Serdyukov, who was dismissed by President Vladimir V. Putin in November, invoked his constitutional right not to incriminate himself during an interrogation, a spokesman for the state Investigative Committee said. Several of his former aides have already been charged in the case.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business, Jan. 11
text: President Obama nominated Jacob J. Lew to be the Treasury secretary, the Consumer Electronics Show took over Las Vegas and Boeing ran into more problems with its 787 Dreamliner.

headline: Senator Reid Takes Fresh Aim
text: During a tight re-election campaign in 2010, when the vote of gun owners was crucial, Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader of the Senate, not only showed his prowess with a 12-gauge shotgun — hitting two clay pigeons from the air — but also invited Wayne LaPierre, chief executive officer of the National Rifle Association, as his guest for the opening of a new shooting range in Searchlight, Nev. Mr. Reid, a former policeman, eagerly displayed his sportsman’s enthusiasm to the voters.

headline: Horse Deaths at Aqueduct Stir Action by State Board
text: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board announced Friday that it would order necropsies for all horses that sustain deadly racing injuries on Aqueduct’s inner dirt track after four fatalities at the racetrack’s meet, which opened Dec. 12.

headline: Little Hope Seen for Iran Nuclear Talks
text: The top United Nations nuclear monitoring official expressed renewed pessimism on Friday about negotiations with Iran, set for next week. The talks are aimed at gaining access to a restricted military area, which his inspectors suspect may have been used for atomic bomb-trigger testing work. The official, Yukiya Amano, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, said that “the outlook is not bright” for obtaining permission from Iran to visit the site, Parchin, which is about 20 miles south of Tehran. Mr. Amano’s remarks contrasted with a more optimistic tone from the agency less than a month ago, when his deputy, Herman Nackaerts, expressed hope that the negotiations this Wednesday would lead to final agreement on an inspection plan.

headline: Makers of Violent Video Games Marshal Support to Fend Off Regulation
text: WASHINGTON — With the Newtown, Conn., massacre spurring concern over violent video games, makers of popular games like Call of Duty and Mortal Kombat are rallying Congressional support to try to fend off their biggest regulatory threat in two decades.

headline: New York’s Pension Muscle
text: When the United States Supreme Court issued its flawed 2010 decision in the Citizens United case, unleashing millions of dollars in corporate spending on political campaigns, there seemed to be one small prescription for relief. Justice Anthony Kennedy, writing for the majority, noted that prompt disclosure of political expenditures would allow stockholders and citizens to hold corporations accountable. Shareholders, he said, could determine whether the corporation’s financing of campaigns “advances the corporation’s interest in making profits.”

headline: Rebel Coalition in Central African Republic Agrees to a Short Cease-Fire
text: Bringing a tentative close to an uprising that brought the Central African Republic to the brink of civil war, the government and rebel fighters seeking to oust the president signed a deal on Friday for a weeklong cease-fire that could mature into a peace plan.

headline: Back When I Was Packing
text: I know what it feels like to be a gun lover.

headline: Squidolatry
text: Two points about the giant squid, Architeuthis dux, recently caught on video by Japanese scientists and now writhing all over the Internet. It is not a colossal squid, Mesonychoteuthis hamiltoni, which is even larger. And this is not the first deep-water image of a giant squid. In 2004, Japanese scientists photographed one taking their bait nearly 3,000 feet underwater in roughly the same location, some 600 miles south of Japan.

headline: The Corvette XP-819
text: In 1964 General Motors engineers built an experimental Corvette called the XP-819. Now it is being restored by a team of automotive craftsmen in Valley Stream, N.Y.

headline: Florida Record Store Goes the Way of the 8-Track
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — South Florida, a place forged by people from elsewhere — another state, another country — has always been quick to discard yesterday for tomorrow.

headline: Theories and Motives Abound in the Killing of 3 Kurds in Paris
text: PARIS — With her signature long hennaed hair, fiery resolve and olive-green military fatigues, Sakine Cansiz was a feminist, guerrilla fighter and former political prisoner as adept at wielding a machine gun as organizing political protests from a jail cell.

headline: Baltimore Fullback Is Dangerous Player in Endangered Role
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Vonta Leach sat at his locker inside the Baltimore Ravens’ training facility this week, grabbed a pair of scissors and began the painstaking process of cutting through the thick bandages that encased his sprained right knee. He groaned. He grimaced. He stared at a swollen mess.

headline: The Afghan War’s Last Chapter?
text: President Obama said on Friday that the United States is moving toward a “responsible end” to the war in Afghanistan that has lasted for 12 years. At a news conference, he and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan filled in some details on how they would get there, but there are still many questions that must be addressed.

headline: Revolutionary Language
text: Listen closely.

headline: Mariangela Melato, Italian Actress, Dies at 71
text: Mariangela Melato, an Italian actress who achieved fame alongside Giancarlo Giannini portraying complicated relationships in the provocative films of Lina Wertmüller, including “The Seduction of Mimi” and “Swept Away (by an Unusual Destiny in the Blue Sea of August),” died on Friday in Rome. She was 71.

headline: Portrait of Duchess Is Unveiled, and the Criticism Is Withering
text: LONDON — They did not necessarily know much about art, but they knew they did not like the way the Duchess of Cambridge looked in her new portrait.

headline: Goalie Arrives in Vancouver but May Not Stay Long
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The resolution of the lockout might have wiped the slate clean for most N.H.L. players, but for Vancouver goaltender Roberto Luongo, the end of one wait was the beginning of a new one.

headline: New York City Ties Doctors’ Income to Quality of Care
text: In a bold experiment in performance pay, complaints from patients at New York City’s public hospitals and other measures of their care — like how long before they are discharged and how they fare afterward — will be reflected in doctors’ paychecks under a plan being negotiated by the physicians and their hospitals.

headline: After 65 Years, Spec’s Records of Florida Closes
text: At Spec’s Records and Tapes in Coral Gables, the music didn’t stop and neither did the memories.

headline: Man Taking Generic Drug Can Sue Branded Maker
text: The Alabama Supreme Court ruled on Friday that a patient could sue a brand-name company for failing to warn about a drug’s risks even though he had taken a generic version of the product that the company did not make.

headline: A Gathering of Banjo Masters
text: When Béla Fleck was growing up and walking the streets of New York City with his banjo in tow, he found that his instrument was often a magnet for derision. “What I would hear from people was: ‘Squeal like a pig!’ ” a reference to an infamous scene in the John Boorman film “Deliverance,” “or ‘Yee-haw!’ ”

headline: In Hershey, an Original A.H.L. Team Plays On Uninterrupted
text: HERSHEY, Pa. — Ken Hatt came to town in 1933 to attend what was then known as the Hershey Industrial School, Milton Hershey’s boarding school for orphans. After graduating in 1941, he worked in the ticket office at the arena where the Hershey Bears played hockey. He loved the sport, and so, it turned out, did the co-worker who became his wife. They bought their first season tickets in 1946.

headline: Winter Jazzfest: Nine-Man Band Fleshes Out a One-Man Show
text: The trombonist and composer-arranger Jacob Garchik released one of the odder (and better) jazz recordings of last year: “The Heavens: The Atheist Gospel Trombone Album.” The ethical/religious connotations of the album are probably best left to another forum; what’s germane here is the fact that the Heavens, on record, is a one-man show, a product of shrewd overdubbing and self-sufficient conviction.

headline: In the Wrong Business
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Doug Peterson and Brad Wilber are two of the nicest people I know in the field of crossword puzzle construction. Lovely men they both are, with an air of gentility about them, and decent table manners for the most part. So I don’t understand why they insist on beating me silly with their crosswords.

headline: Corrections: January 12, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Officer Held in Plot to Kidnap Women Balks at Jail Transfer
text: Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer charged with plotting to kidnap, kill and eat women, had been held in a special unit of the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, separated from other prisoners, apparently for his own protection.

headline: A Collection of Sculpture All About the Artists
text: A hundred years after Pablo Picasso shaped a guitar from cardboard, and nearly a century since Marcel Duchamp signed a urinal and called it art, it’s easy to forget that these were huge transgressions against the lineage of Western sculpture. Previously, sculpture consisted of objects in stone, bronze or wood. But as “Once Removed: Sculpture’s Changing Frame of Reference” at the Yale University Art Gallery shows, sculpture can be made of anything now, from feathers and video to Vaseline.

headline: Forcing Turnovers Is the Patriots’ Way
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — They don’t dominate or intimidate. All they do is give you a little wiggle room — and then make you look bad. Sometimes really, really bad.

headline: After Immigration Arrests, Online Outcry, and Release
text: PHOENIX — Immigration agents arrested the mother and brother of a prominent activist during a raid at her home here late Thursday, unleashing a vigorous response on social media and focusing new attention on one of the most controversial aspects of the Obama administration’s policies on deportation.

headline: With Skullcandy, Look Stylish While Playing Video Games
text: Skullcandy is known for adding youthful flair to audio gear. So when the company acquired Astro Gaming, a maker of premium gaming accessories, it made sense that it would introduce a line of stylish, less-expensive gaming headsets with the Skullcandy brand.

headline: No Jail Time for Ex-Doctor, 85, Convicted of Drug Charge
text: The former doctor sat in courton Friday waiting to be sentenced for a crime that breached every tenet of his professional code. He had run his house in Staten Island like a drug mill, selling the prescription painkiller oxycodone to all comers — including undercover federal agents. The guideline sentence for his crimes was up to six years.

headline: On Subway Platforms, More Warnings for Riders
text: The audible nudge, wafting above the tracks, is probably familiar to any New York City subway rider: “Please stand away from the platform edge.”

headline: Camby Adds Foot Injury to Knicks’ List of Woes
text: The Knicks found themselves short-handed again Friday night when they announced that Marcus Camby would be out two to four weeks with a foot injury, a painful reminder of just how fragile the oldest team in the N.B.A. can be.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: A Scary Street

headline: Cornell Withdraws Recognition of a Fraternity After a Report of Hazing
text: Two years after one of its students died after a fraternity drinking ritual, Cornell University has withdrawn its recognition of another fraternity after a pledging episode in which prospective members were said to have been served alcohol and stripped naked.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Tusks of Whimsical-Looking Whales Lead to Charges for 2 in a Maine Courtroom
text: BANGOR, Me. — Two Americans on Friday pleaded not guilty to charges that they participated in a decade-long international smuggling operation that, according to federal officials, brought narwhal tusks — the long, tapered tooth that makes the elusive Arctic creature look a bit like a floating unicorn — into the United States.

headline: For Nets, Third Quarter’s the Charm Again
text: Nets Coach P. J. Carlesimo did not say much to his team at halftime, but he thought this might be a game to throw in the towel early. The Nets trailed the Phoenix Suns by 7 points, and they looked lifeless. He implored his players for more energy.

headline: He Snips, He Flirts, He Stays
text: ASTOR PLACE HAIRSTYLISTS has gone through many changes since it became, in the early 1980s, the renowned East Village hip haircut factory, but one constant has been Valentino Gogu, 65, who has been cutting hair at the shop for nearly three decades.

headline: Fund-Raising Is Lagging, So Far, for Inaugural Plans
text: President Obama’s inaugural committee is at least $10 million short of its $50 million fund-raising goal, officials have told top donors, with just over a week before Mr. Obama is sworn in for his second term.

headline: Local Stop: South Street Seaport
text: The South Street Seaport was once the bustling, raucous, polyglot center for maritime trade in the Port of New York.

headline: Winter Jazzfest: Worth the Wait for a Marquee Duo
text: I encountered my first line — the first of many, if past precedent counts for anything — outside the Bitter End, for a duo set by the guitarists Nels Cline and Julian Lage. I eventually made it inside, and was glad that I did.

headline: Veterans and Senate Buddies, Until Another War Split Them
text: WASHINGTON — In the old days it was like a Senate buddy movie.

headline: A Sinner Holds Tight to Faith and a Second Chance
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md.

headline: Water and Land, Past and Present
text: The South Street Seaport was once the bustling, raucous, polyglot center for maritime trade in the Port of New York. During its peak years, in the half century after the War of 1812, ships from all over the world docked here, with their bowsprits pointing west over South Street. But the area’s proximity to the East River led to terrible flooding during Hurricane Sandy, and the historic neighborhood, much of it built on 19th-century landfill, is only beginning to recover.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Jan. 12, 2013
text: If I had 1,000 AR-15’s I could sell them in a week.

headline: Ruth Carter Stevenson of the Amon Carter Museum Dies at 89
text: Ruth Carter Stevenson, who followed her father’s last wishes in creating the Amon Carter Museum in Fort Worth, one of the nation’s pre-eminent collections of American art, died on Jan. 6 at her home in Fort Worth. She was 89.

headline: Media Towers; Old Letters; and War Stories
text: A newspaper reporter once complimented Renzo Piano, the architect of The New York Times Building on Eighth Avenue, on his design, noting that the building reminded him of a sheet of newsprint. “It does?” Mr. Piano replied.

headline: A Booster for Brooklyn, 7 Days a Week
text: After waking his parakeet, going out with his wife to walk and buy food, and eating breakfast, Marty Markowitz, the borough president, spends most Sundays appearing at events, in churches and before organizations.

headline: In 2010 Portland Bomb Plot, a Question of Manipulation or Violent Extremism
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — A defense lawyer for a 21-year-old Somali-American told a federal jury here on Friday that his client did in fact push a cellphone button on a night in late November 2010 believing he was detonating a truck bomb that would kill hundreds or thousands of people who had gathered to watch downtown Portland’s Christmas lights come on.

headline: Jeanne Vertefeuille, C.I.A. Official Who Helped Catch a Notorious Mole, Dies at 80
text: Jeanne Vertefeuille joined the Central Intelligence Agency as a typist in 1954 and then began inching up through the ranks, obtaining postings overseas. By 1986 she had become a midlevel expert on the Soviet Union and counterintelligence. She remained a quiet agency soldier, however — purposefully nondescript and selflessly dedicated. She lived alone and walked to work.

headline: Being Brooklyn, Aided by Cheesecake
text: Officially, Marty Markowitz may be Brooklyn’s borough president, but others know him as its booster-in-chief. Born three blocks from Ebbets Field and becalmed in the borough ever since, he spends every day — Sundays included — at ribbon cuttings, street renamings and political dinners, learning his constituents’ problems, doing whatever his City Charter-limited powers allow, and, always, cheering the borough. After 23 years as a state senator, he was elected to “the job I always wanted” in 2001. Now 67, he lives in a brick house in Windsor Terrace with his wife, Jamie, 54, a graphic artist; they have an African gray parrot named Beep (as in B.P.) that he calls his son.

headline: Ex-Technician Denies Faulty DNA Work
text: A former New York City laboratory technician whose work on rape cases is now being scrutinized for serious mistakes said on Friday that she had been unaware there were problems in her work and, disputing an earlier report, denied she had resigned under pressure.

headline: Rockefeller Will Leave Senate After Five Terms
text: WASHINGTON — Senator John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia, a longtime liberal voice in Congress, announced on Friday that he would not seek a sixth term in 2014, providing an opening for Republicans to cut into the Democratic Senate majority.

headline: A Seemingly Familial Unit Visits Boutiques, Looking for New Jeans
text: Kate Johnson was helping a customer in the back of an Olive and Bette’s boutique in SoHo when the front door opened on a recent Sunday afternoon. She looked up.

headline: Sales of Guns Soar in U.S. as Nation Weighs Tougher Limits
text: As Washington focuses on what Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will propose next week to curb gun violence, gun and ammunition sales are spiking in the rest of the country as people rush to expand their arsenals in advance of any restrictions that might be imposed.

headline: Rejected Disability Claims in Queens May Be Reheard
text: Thousands of poor Queens residents with debilitating conditions who were denied federal disability benefits would have their cases reconsidered, under a settlement proposal in a class-action lawsuit that accused judges of bias.

headline: Mother Learns a New Skill and How to Calm Her Child
text: All of her hours practicing on a stenograph keyboard have brought Stephanie VanBuren equal amounts of insight and frustration, reassurance and doubt.

headline: The Unaffordable Luxury of Food
text: Sometime around 1990 and not too long out of college, I held what memory tells me was my first true dinner party, in a three-bedroom brownstone duplex in Brooklyn, where the rent was approximately $1,200 a month. The menu revolved around a pork loin stuffed with sausage and dried apricots, a recipe that came from “The New Basics,” which along with “The Silver Palate Cookbook,” its predecessor, and the various musings of Laurie E. Colwin would have made up the near entirety of any young aspiring cook’s kitchen library. That evening, we were paying tribute to a friend who had recently begun working as a writer for David Letterman, and in that spirit my roommate and I purchased several bottles of Kendall-Jackson chardonnay for $11 each, feeling very grand about it.

headline: Out of Sorts Once Again, Knicks Fall to the Bulls
text: The Chicago Bulls did not need to bully the Knicks. They did not need to slow the game down, either. In the third meeting of the season between the teams, the Bulls were dominant.

headline: Lawmaker Seeks Public Reply on Guns
text: SANTA ROSA, Calif. — A California congressman leading a House Democratic task force on gun violence wrapped up a series of heated and packed town hall meetings on gun control here Thursday night, providing a glimpse into how the debate is resonating beyond Washington after last month’s massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Antique Cannon in Central Park Found Loaded
text: The cannons of the British warship H.M.S. Hussar were last fired in anger during the Revolutionary War. But when Central Park Conservancy workers arrived to clean one on Friday, the police said, they found it was still loaded with gunpowder and a cannonball, ready to fire.

headline: Justices to Hear Case on Groups’ Free Speech
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide cases on the First Amendment rights of groups fighting AIDS and the Fifth Amendment rights of people who refuse to answer questions from the police.

headline: Kenojuak Ashevak, Artist From the Canadian Arctic, Dies at 85
text: OTTAWA — Kenojuak Ashevak, a once-nomadic artist from Canada’s Arctic regions whose prints and drawings helped introduce Inuit art to much of the world, died on Tuesday at her home in Cape Dorset on West Baffin Island in the northern territory of Nunavut. She was 85.

headline: Louisiana: New Orleans Rethinks Deal on Police
text: A federal judge in New Orleans on Friday approved a sweeping consent decree with the city’s Police Department, one of the most ambitious blueprints for a police overhaul in the country in years. The agreement was announced last summer by officials from the city, the Police Department and the Justice Department, after two years of investigations and negotiations. But in a sign that the matter may be far from settled, Judge Susie Morgan of Federal District Court acknowledged in her order that the city intended to file a motion to withdraw from the deal. In a statement, Mayor Mitchell J. Landrieu said he wanted to hold off on the pact because he objected to the millions of dollars the city may have to spend under a separate agreement pertaining to the city jail, which is currently being negotiated. “We asked the judge to hold off on executing the police consent decree until the price tag of the prison consent decree is clear,” Mr. Landrieu said.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 11
text: A view of the day in sports, from bobsledding to a friendly soccer match at a prison.

headline: Ford Plans to Hire 2,200 Salaried Workers in U.S.
text: The Ford Motor Company said on Friday that it planned to hire 2,200 salaried workers in the United States this year, its largest increase in new salaried workers in more than a decade, to support new Ford product introductions. The hiring is in addition to the more than 8,100 combined hourly and salaried jobs Ford created in the United States in 2012, as the company increased production capacity and expanded engineering, manufacturing and other areas to meet the growing demand for its vehicles, the company said.
