About 1,000 of the positions are hourly jobs brought back to Ford plants in the United States from other locations, including Japan and Mexico.  Ford said it was more than halfway to the 12,000 new jobs it committed to deliver in the United States by 2015 as part of its 2011 contract with the United Automobile Workers. “As we expand our product lineup of fuel-efficient vehicles, we need more people in critical areas, such as in a range of engineering activities, vehicle production, computer software and other I.T. functions, to ensure we deliver the vehicles people want and value,” Joseph R. Hinrichs, Ford’s president for the Americas, said in a news release.

headline: Advanced Systems Are on the Move
text: New technologies are changing the way cars are driven. — John Markoff

headline: Drivers With Hands Full Get a Backup: The Car
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Driving around a college campus can be treacherous. Bikes and scooters zip out of nowhere, distracted students wander into traffic, and stopped cars and speed bumps suddenly appear. It takes a vigilant driver to avoid catastrophe.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Showtime) THE TWILIGHT SAGA: BREAKING DAWN — PART 1 (2011) Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) weds her vampire, Edward (Robert Pattinson, above, with Ms. Stewart), enjoys a rollicking honeymoon and then suffers through a horrendous pregnancy in this fourth installment in the franchise, directed by Bill Condon. Mr. Pattinson’s portrayal of a passionate, potentially dangerous husband capable of sexual rough play “shifts the story into another world,” said Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times. “Mr. Condon works in that world fluidly, gilding it with a necessary sense of humor — Bella and Edward’s white honeymoon bed glows as portentously as an altar for a sacrificial virgin — and imbuing it with a love and a gift for melodrama. He slathers on the music (‘melodrama’ comes from song or music drama), lets Ms. Stewart rock and the emotions roil. He resurrects the awkward teenage yearning that enlivened the first ‘Twilight’ movie, but also transforms that initial, crude hunger into something deeper. Mostly, he brings Bella toward her happily-ever-after by giving this movie over to her, her dreams and her desires, as in a cosmic montage sequence worthy of ‘The Tree of Life,’ but, you know, shorter. Edward may finally change Bella, but it’s Mr. Condon who resurrects her.”

headline: Are They Gifted? Or Segregated?
text: The city says the testing for accelerated programs is fair but critics say it favors pupils who are already privileged, putting them on a fast track to success.

headline: A Major Gap in Gifted Programs
text: Since 2009, the number of schools offering gifted programs has fallen, especially in minority areas of the city like central Brooklyn, southeast Queens and the Bronx.

headline: Gifted, Talented and Separated
text: IT is just a metal door with three windows, the kind meant to keep the clamor of an elementary school hallway from piercing a classroom’s quiet. Other than paint the color of bubble gum, it is unremarkable.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 12
text: New source for Africa’s arms trade; France intervenes in Mali fighting; abuse by British television host detailed; examinations of new Boeing jets planned.

headline: A Clear View of an Unfamiliar City
text: The street photographer Steven Siegel has captured a historical record of New York’s battered past: its lunar beaches and junked appliances and citizens as shadows on the wall.

headline: New Focus on Village of Delhi Rape Victim’s Father
text: MEDAWARA, Uttar Pradesh — A makeshift helipad was being built this week in this remote dusty village in eastern Uttar Pradesh. The potholed single-lane road that leads the village was under repair, and journalists, district officials and local politicians had come to call.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Rajasthan: On Thursday, an additional district court in Rajasthan sentenced a man to capital punishment for the rape and murder of a minor, the Deccan Herald reported. The accused, a 28-year-old named Sohanlal, raped a 15-year-old girl in his neighborhood and then strangled her.

headline: As Formula One Hibernates, Some Puzzlers to Ponder
text: PARIS— It’s the winter season, when nothing happens in Formula One. The last race of 2012 was on Nov. 25, in Brazil, and the first race of the 2013 season will take place on March 17, in Australia. But the presentation of the new cars starts later this month. Winter testing starts on Feb. 5 in Spain. And actually, a lot has been happening, some of it puzzling, or open to interpretation. I’d like to take a break from the break and make short list of the principal such head-scratchers, and ask readers what they make of it all. In most cases, I am not quite sure what I make of it, but have some ideas, too.

headline: Missing School for a Stint at the Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Nicole Gibbs, a 19-year-old college junior who is an economics major at Stanford, wasn’t about to make any financial decision without researching market conditions and past trends.

headline: The Weekend Word: Political Divorce
text: Today’s Times

headline: French Soldier Killed in Somalia Commando Raid
text: PARIS — French special forces failed early Saturday in a hostage rescue mission in southern Somalia.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Jil Sander
text: The show was one of the first during Milan Men’s Fashion Week.

headline: Project Basement: The Receiver
text: My search for a receiver is over.

headline: Hostages Caught Up in France’s African Intervention
text: LONDON — The widespread satisfaction expressed in France at the government’s decision to intervene militarily against Islamic militants in Mali was tempered on Saturday by news of a failed overnight French hostage rescue mission on the other side of Africa.

headline: Credibility
text: Ah. Charles Plosser of the Philadelphia Fed is against the platinum coin, which he says “doesn’t solve any real problem” and would hurt our credibility.

headline: Why Am I a Challenge for Charities?
text: From top-notch schools to groups like Heifer International, charities want the same thing from baby boomers that they wanted from your parents and grandparents: money. The trouble is figuring out how to get it. There’s gold in them thar boomers, but how do you mine it?

headline: Worthwhile Japanese Initiative
text: Shinzo Abe has taken Japan off in a surprisingly Keynesian direction. Noah Smith points out, again, that he’s probably doing it for disreputable reasons, mainly old-fashioned LDP pork-barrel (katsu barrel? tofu barrel?) politics. But this may not matter.

headline: Over 50, and Under No Illusions
text: IT’S a baby boomer’s nightmare. One moment you’re 40-ish and moving up, the next you’re 50-plus and suddenly, shockingly, moving out — jobless in a tough economy.

headline: Recalibrating a Directing Brotherhood
text: IN “Broken City,” a crime thriller by the director Allen Hughes, Mark Wahlberg plays Billy Taggart, a former New York policeman who suspects that his girlfriend (Natalie Martinez) is having an affair. Enraged, Billy gets so drunk that he hears the chorus of DMX’s “Party Up” thumping in his ears, then goes completely bananas on the streets of the East Village.

headline: Jil Sander: The Complexity of the Simple
text: MILAN — Steve Jobs once remarked that simple can be harder than complex. The thought was not particularly original or even original to him but, like pretty much everything else Jobs did, it had wide applications to a culture he helped define. According to the Apple calculus, simple equals idiot-proof and that equals success.

headline: On Winfrey’s Show, Armstrong Is Planning to Confess Drug Use
text: After nearly 15 years of vehement denials, Lance Armstrong will admit that he used performance-enhancing drugs during his cycling career when he is interviewed by Oprah Winfrey, two people with knowledge of the situation said.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: In Cooperstown, a Crowded Waiting Room
text: The failure of the writers to pick Barry Bonds or Roger Clemens was not a surprise given the low vote totals received in the past by Mark McGwire and Rafael Palmeiro, other players associated with the use performance-enhancing drugs. But the vote totals for Bonds and Clemens, just 36 and 38 percent, were lower than expected.

headline: Journalists in Greece Are Becoming Targets
text: The Greek police on Saturday were looking for the people responsible for detonating makeshift bombs at the homes of five journalists in Athens, the latest in a series of actions taken against reporters in Greece that have raised questions about a deteriorating climate for media freedom.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: With Elusive Victory in Sight, Retirement Talk Must Wait
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — For Michael Palmer, breakfast consists of oatmeal with blueberries and cinnamon. Why not a higher-calorie meal for a strapping, energy-burning N.F.L. tight end?

headline: In Fantasy Football, Refining the Search for Points
text: After finishing near the top of standard fantasy football scoring in each of the past four seasons, Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers appeared more than worthy of his No. 2 average draft position (fantasypros.com) in this past season’s fantasy drafts.

headline: A Desert Cold and Wet Multiplies the Misery of Syrian Refugees
text: ZAATARI, Jordan — The water has mostly been removed from hundreds of flooded tents and the dirt paths that run between them here in the region’s vastest camp of Syrian refugees. The clotheslines are laden with soggy sweaters and socks, waiting for the sun after a week of harsh wind, rain and snow.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic With Personality
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Here’s another book to add to your reading list: “THE MUSIC OF CHANCE,” by PAUL AUSTER, a novel about the supposed meaninglessness of the universe. Published in 1990, it has since become a film starring Mandy Patinkin and James Spader, but Mr. Auster’s writing is so charming, you’ll want to read the book. Here is the New York Times review of the novel.

headline: French Airstrikes in Mali Deter Islamist Rebels
text: PARIS — French airstrikes in Mali appeared to halt an Islamist rebel advance, France said Saturday, as West African nations authorized what they said would be a fast deployment of troops in support of the weak Malian government.

headline: Sides Sign Agreement; Training Camps to Open
text: It took four months, and one more delay Saturday, but the N.H.L. and the players union put the final details in place to lift the lockout, allowing the league to reopen and prepare for its first games of the 2012-13 season this coming Saturday.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana
text: Milan

headline: Our Economic Pickle
text: FEDERAL income tax rates will rise for the wealthiest Americans, and certain tax loopholes might get closed this year. But these developments, and whatever else happens in Washington in the coming debt-ceiling debate, are unlikely to do much to alter one major factor contributing to income inequality: stagnant wages. For millions of workers, wages have flatlined. Take Caterpillar, long a symbol of American industry: while it reported record profits last year, it insisted on a six-year wage freeze for many of its blue-collar workers.

headline: The Low Politics of Low Growth
text: WE typically blame Washington for not doing more to help the economy grow. But what if we have it backward: What if it is the weak economy that is driving the failures in Washington?

headline: Dolce & Gabbana, Part 2
text: Milan men’s fashion week, 2013.

headline: Why Pixel Counts Don’t Count in Cameras
text: With the coming of the Consumer Electronics Show, camera manufacturers will be trotting out scads of new products, but many are unfortunately falling back on an old marketing strategy.

headline: Russian Lawmakers Aim at Foreign Cars, Films and Schooling in Patriotic Purge
text: MOSCOW — The members of Russia’s lower house of Parliament — which last year passed so many harsh new laws with so little debate that commentators compared it to a “rabid printer” — returned to work last week as the standard-bearers for President Vladimir V. Putin’s brand of patriotism.

headline: For Patriots’ Coach and Quarterback, Wins, Not Words, Add Up
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Bill Belichick is excited. Really, he is. Or rather, he says he is. The sentiment must be qualified because anyone observing Belichick’s news conference Friday — attended by a few dozen reporters and filmed by a row of cameras — can attest that he expressed it with all the emotion of a rutabaga.

headline: Knicks and Anthony Remain Vulnerable to Self-Sabotage
text: It was almost half past 11 Friday night when Carmelo Anthony strolled into the public part of the locker room, about an hour after the Knicks’ third straight defeat to an Eastern Conference rival. This is now one of the defining measures of 21st-century N.B.A. stardom — the longer deadline-besieged reporters are kept waiting, the more important the player apparently must be.

headline: Burberry Prorsum: Fall 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Burberry
text: The changing demands of war — or the military, anyway — have generated almost all the major evolution in menswear.

headline: As Texas Bakes in a Long Drought, Water Becomes a Focus for Legislators
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — There is usually no shortage of controversial and politically divisive issues for lawmakers to address in the opening days of a state legislative session, from abortion to immigration to gun rights.

headline: Australian Open: Players to Watch
text: A look at some of the more intriguing players in this year’s Australian Open.

headline: Two Men, One Sky
text: As they pursued a hang gliding record over hundreds of miles, Jonny Durand and Dustin Martin were often within shouting distance of each other.

headline: A Hunter’s Education in the Class of ’13
text: The environmental conservation officer stood in front of my hunter-education class and said he had never seen one so big, so early in the year. Normally in January he would be speaking to about a dozen people, maybe 20, most of them Boy Scouts. Our group numbered at least 70, most of them solitary men, from young to grizzled, but also a family with children and a handful of fathers with young daughters.

headline: Salvagers in Italy Say Costa Concordia Wreck May Be Gone by Summer’s End
text: GIGLIO, Italy — One year after the luxury liner Costa Concordia ran aground off the Tuscan coast, taking 32 lives, its wreck still lies there, a lumbering hulk of metal enclosed by floating salvage platforms, creating an incongruous industrial landscape amid the pristine waters of a marine sanctuary.

headline: Is Delhi So Different From Steubenville?
text: IN India, a 23-year-old student takes a bus home from a movie and is gang-raped and assaulted so viciously that she dies two weeks later.

headline: Forget the Oscars — It’s the Teachies!
text: After months of speculation, the nominations have finally been announced for the Teachies, the biggest, glitziest, most media-crazed pedagogical awards ceremony of the year, judged by the renowned American Federation of Teachers and presented in the legendary Student Drama Theater. Who will win Teacher of the Year? Or Best School? And don’t forget the smaller awards, like Most Supportive Teaching Assistant. Read on for predictions to use for your office pool!

headline: Fight for the Housing Trust Fund
text: Despite the Obama administration’s best efforts, the lack of affordable housing remains one of America’s most vexing problems.

headline: Syrian Camp Faces Storm’s Aftermath
text: Syrian refugees face harsh conditions at camp in Jordan.

headline: Darwin Was Wrong About Dating
text: A COUPLE of evolutionary psychologists recently published a book about human sexual behavior in prehistory called “Sex at Dawn.” Upon hearing of the project, one colleague, dubious that a modern scholar could hope to know anything about that period, asked them, “So what do you do, close your eyes and dream?”

headline: We Offer More Than Ankles, Gentlemen
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Collaborate vs. Collaborate
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: Restoring Due Process
text: The Supreme Court this week will consider whether to reverse a troubling 2002 decision that allowed judges greater sentencing power in certain circumstances. For the sake of fairness and consistency, it should overturn that 10-year-old ruling.

headline: Misguided Social Security ‘Reform’
text: At the end of last year, just shy of the 11th hour in the fiscal cliff negotiations, President Obama made an offer that included a Republican-backed idea to cut spending by lowering the cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security benefits. The move shocked Congressional Democrats and dismayed Mr. Obama’s liberal base.

headline: Democrats Behaving Badly
text: FOR the textbook definition of not knowing enough to quit while you’re ahead, please turn your attention to Harry Reid, he of the scabrous tongue and rotten temper, a boxer in his youth and a pugilist to this day, throwing mud along with punches and invariably soiling himself.

headline: Venezuela Warns Opposition Against Vocal Dissent
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Top government officials are threatening to take action against opposition governors and issuing dark warnings about conspiracies against the government of President Hugo Chávez, who is ailing and remains incommunicado in Cuba.

headline: A Pedophile in Plain Sight
text: JUST after Christmas, Poly Prep Country Day School, the venerable Brooklyn institution, settled a lawsuit alleging a more than 40-year cover-up of the predatory pedophilia of its legendary football coach, Philip Foglietta. The terms of the settlement have not been disclosed, but the lawsuit charged that school administrators were repeatedly informed from the 1960s until his forced retirement in 1991 that Mr. Foglietta was sexually abusing boys — on campus, in his apartment and during trips. Mr. Foglietta, who died in 1998, fondled and raped dozens, if not hundreds, of children.

headline: 12-Year-Old Is Commentator, Would-Be G.M. and N.F.L. Trend
text: BALTIMORE — As the Ravens were losing three consecutive games in December, Cullen Little told his radio audience that the team should let quarterback Joe Flacco leave as a free agent.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Is a Bigger House Better?
text: Readers debate how to make Congress less dysfunctional.

headline: The Obama Synthesis
text: AS both his critics and admirers argue, the nomination of Chuck Hagel as secretary of defense last week tells us something important about Barack Obama’s approach to foreign policy. But so does the man who was nominated alongside Hagel, to far less controversy and attention: John Brennan, now head of the White House’s counterterrorism efforts, and soon to be the director of the C.I.A.

headline: Jeffrey Sprecher
text: Jeffrey Sprecher is the founder and chief executive of IntercontinentalExchange, or ICE, an Atlanta-based operator of futures exchanges, credit markets and clearinghouses. He is currently awaiting regulatory approval to acquire the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Cuomo Declares Public Health Emergency Over Flu Outbreak
text: With the nation in the grip of a severe influenza outbreak that has seen deaths reach epidemic levels, New York State declared a public health emergency on Saturday, making access to vaccines more easily available.

headline: When Markets Rise Above Politics
text: ECONOMIC growth remained sluggish and politics often intruded on the markets, yet stocks achieved solid returns last year all the same. It wasn’t the first time that investors scaled a wall of worry, but it might be the only instance when the main source of concern, at least in the fourth quarter, was thought to be a cliff.

headline: Internet Activist, a Creator of RSS, Is Dead at 26, Apparently a Suicide
text: Aaron Swartz, a wizardly programmer who as a teenager helped develop code that delivered ever-changing Web content to users and who later became a steadfast crusader to make that information freely available, was found dead on Friday in his New York apartment.

headline: Burberry’s Martial Menswear
text: “War, huh, yeah, what is it good for?” asked the lyrics to a 1970s hit by Edwin Starr. The answer: “Absolutely nothing, uh huh!” That’s not entirely true, though. The changing demands of war — or the military, anyway — have generated almost all the major evolution in menswear, particularly when it comes to the longest and most successful of male uniforms, the suit.

headline: The Thinking Person’s Entertainment
text: SOME of television’s most compelling shows start up again this month — and thank heaven for that. “Downton Abbey,” “The Good Wife” and “Girls” will happily draw viewers — like me — back into their characters and their plot-heavy story lines.

headline: Speaking Like a Shaman, Running Like the Wind
text: HOUSTON — The question made Arian Foster think, which to him is precisely the point. “Understand the universe, you’ll understand me,” reads part of the profile on his Twitter account, so when Foster was asked whether he loves winning or hates losing, he answered like a shaman in search of spiritual balance.

headline: Remembering Aaron Swartz
text: Last Updated, 9:02 p.m. Friends, colleagues and admirers of Aaron Swartz, a digital activist and innovator, posted tributes to him online on Saturday, after an early-morning report of his death by The Tech, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology student newspaper. An uncle, Michael Wolf, told The Times that Mr. Swartz, 26, had apparently committed suicide in New York on Friday.

headline: Bryant Now Deals With Mediocrity
text: Albert Camus once wrote, “There is scarcely any passion without struggle.” Anyone who has watched Kobe Bryant play basketball might beg to differ.

headline: As ‘Bodega Clinicas’ Fill Void, Health Officials Are Torn
text: HUNTINGTON PARK, Calif. — The “bodega clinicas” that line the bustling commercial streets of immigrant neighborhoods around Los Angeles are wedged between money order kiosks and pawnshops. These storefront offices, staffed with Spanish-speaking medical providers, treat ailments for cash: a doctor’s visit is $20 to $40; a cardiology exam is $120; and at one bustling clinic, a colonoscopy is advertised on an erasable board for $700.

headline: Investing Abroad This Year? Remember a Good Map
text: AT the start of 2012, stock investors braced themselves for what seemed to be shaping up as a difficult year abroad.

headline: Lazy Jon Stewart
text: Oh, dear. Jon Stewart took on the platinum coin, and made a hash of it — he faceplanted, as Ryan Cooper says.

headline: Hypochondria: An Inside Look
text: WHEN The New York Times called, inquiring if I might pen a few words “from the horse’s mouth” about hypochondria, I confess I was taken aback. What light could I possibly shed on this type of crackpot behavior since, contrary to popular belief, I am not a hypochondriac but a totally different genus of crackpot?

headline: A Record Hang Gliding Ride on the Texas Wind
text: To set a hang gliding distance record, Jonny Durand and Dustin Martin set out last July from Zapata, Tex., and headed north as far as the warm winds would take them.

headline: Can’t Save? Here’s Why
text: THE odds are good that you haven’t yet given up on your New Year’s resolutions and that one of them is to swear off those expensive cappuccinos and save money for your old age. That’s a typical suggestion from finance gurus, who say we can add thousands of dollars annually to our nest eggs by eliminating such wasteful spending.

headline: Japan’s Teachable Moment
text: Whatever else you can say about the new turn in Japanese policy, it’s offering a great demonstration of the peculiarities of zero-lower-bound economics. (JGBs meet the ZLB, OK!)

headline: After Foster Care Years, a Woman Becomes a Role Model for Her Sisters
text: Precious Perry shares a few things in common with the fictional protagonist in the 2009 film “Precious.”

headline: Selling Out by Selling Off
text: IT might be time for me to sell out.

headline: Writing About What Haunts Us
text: I’ve been trying to lie about this story for years. As a fiction writer, I feel an almost righteous obligation to the untruth. Fabrication is my livelihood, and so telling something straight, for me, is the mark of failure. Yet in many attempts over the years I’ve not been able to make out of this tiny — but weirdly soul-defining — episode in my life anything more than a plain recounting of the facts, as best as I can remember them. Dressing them up into fiction, in this case, wrecked what is essentially a long overdue confession.

headline: Pressing On for the Children
text: As part of the 2012-13 Neediest Cases campaign, The New York Times is catching up with some of the people who were profiled in recent campaigns.

headline: Descending Into a State of Nature
text: SURPRISINGLY, Joseph Conrad’s novella “Heart of Darkness” has only been filmed once under its own name — as a 1993 made-for-television movie directed by Nicolas Roeg. But with its richly metaphorical plot and tight dramatic structure — leaving the trappings of Western civilization behind, a cultured man embarks on a journey into a strange territory, where he is forced to confront the savagery (“the horror, the horror”) that survives beneath the surface of polite human behavior — the tale has served as a template for countless works of art (William Faulkner’s “Sanctuary,” for example), and perhaps even greater quantities of schlock (Ruggero Deodato’s “Cannibal Holocaust”).

headline: Someone’s Knocking at My Door
text: The editors of Anxiety recently asked the Hungarian novelist Laszlo Krasznahorkai to contribute to the series. Below, in the author’s words, is “a lyrical essay about the terrible meeting between boorishness and aggressiveness,” a meditation on a type of violent person who produces in him “the deepest personal anxiety.” It was translated by George Szirtes from the Hungarian.

headline: Mubarak Is Asked About Media Gifts
text: CAIRO — Prosecutors questioned former President Hosni Mubarak on Saturday about $1 million worth of personal gifts he received from a state news organization over his last six years in office, the organization’s Web site reported.

headline: N.C. State Announces Its Relevance, Beating No. 1 Duke
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — North Carolina State’s athletic program has a catchy marketing campaign these days: “This is our state.” When it comes to men’s basketball, that may finally be true.

headline: Rivals in Czech Presidential Runoff Support Warmer Ties With Europe
text: PARIS — An outspoken former prime minister and the current foreign minister will face each other in the Czech Republic’s presidential runoff in two weeks, according to the results of the first round of voting released Saturday.

headline: Free-Range Fund Managers, in a Pickle
text: MUTUAL fund managers tend to be held on a short investing leash, but a small subset of funds lets managers run free and place bets on just about any asset class from any part of the world. As liberating as this go-anywhere mandate is, however, managers of some of the largest of these world allocation funds say that no amount of freedom is helping them today — because they aren’t finding many great opportunities.

headline: Two Men, One Sky: A Flight to the Finish
text: T HE CLOUDS stretched across the Texas sky like a highway. And soaring along those lanes, lofted nearly 8,000 feet by the hot air rising from the earth, two hang gliders raced in tight pursuit of the most prized feat in this high adrenaline niche sport: farthest ever flown.

headline: Funds That Add Spices to the Stock-and-Bond Mix
text: A PORTFOLIO balanced between stocks and bonds, in a roughly 60-40 split, is a staple diet of investing. These two asset classes often move to different rhythms, so overall returns tend to have milder swings than either one experiences on its own.

headline: Strategic Advice, Long Before You Invest
text: TWO market veterans have new books out, offering thoughts about how to invest. But their suggestions come with a twist.

headline: Good Economy or Bad, Hurdles for Junk Bonds
text: WHEN the financial crisis erupted several years ago, its victims included lenders to the weakest and most debt-laden companies. Investors in junk-bond mutual funds suffered a negative return of roughly 25 percent in 2008.

headline: Versace: Fall 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Versace
text: Donatella Versace offered a delirious and invigorating show in Milan.

headline: Their Specialty Was to Find Strong Returns
text: MODERN economies often reward specialists — surgeons who operate only on knees, scholars who study a single author or era, money managers who buy only South Korean or clean-technology stocks. But in the fourth quarter of 2012, old-school generalists led three of the better-performing stock mutual funds.

headline: Funds Aren’t Wielding Much Power Over Executive Pay
text: THE stock market swings up and down, yet executive pay seems to go only higher. Rising executive compensation has been something of a constant in modern capitalism — and so far, at least, managers of mutual funds haven’t had much of an effect on it.

headline: So What Will You Do, Mr. President?
text: If I’d spent the past five years living in a monastery or something, I would take the Treasury Department’s declaration that the coin option is out as a sign that there’s some other plan ready to go. Maybe 14th Amendment, maybe moral obligation coupons or some other form of scrip, something.

headline: A Show That Only Versace Could Give
text: MILAN — There were suits in steroidal Al Capone proportions (and accessories: spectator shoes!). There was graffiti print double-denim. There were wide ties lopped so short Emmett Kelly could have worn them. There were studded Stormtrooper boots as well as glossy puffed bombers in the house’s trademark neo-Romanesque prints.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 13
text: As lawmakers take to the Sunday shows to express their opinions on President Obama’s cabinet nominations, Colin L. Powell, the retired general and former secretary of state, will join NBC’s “Meet the Press” to voice his support for Chuck Hagel as the next secretary of defense.

headline: Follow Two Hang Gliders on Their Record Ride
text: Follow the paths of two hang gliders as they set a new distance record of over 475 miles.

headline: Paying the Price, but Often Deducting It
text: THE numbers seem eye-popping. So many billions here for supposed mortgage abuses, so many billions there for questionable foreclosures.

headline: Trying to Stop Office Politics in Its Tracks
text: This interview with  Dinesh C. Paliwal, the chairman, president and chief executive of Harman International Industries, the audio and infotainment equipment company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: I’m Losing Money. So Why Do I Feel So Good?
text: STEP into a casino and chances are good that slot machines are filling much of the space, as far as the eye can see. That dominant presence reflects the preference of many customers for machine gambling over human-mediated table games. Not surprisingly, electronic game machines contribute a clear majority of casino revenue in the states that permit them.

headline: The Auto Loan That Went Haywire
text: SOMETIMES, the Haggler gets the depressing sense that corporations are not reading this column and taking every single word to heart. Crazy, right? The ideas and recommendations offered here are avidly implemented by executives and their underlings across this country. That is a given.

headline: Above the Debt Ceiling, Boehner Might Find a Blue Sky
text: ALTHOUGH he has been re-elected as House speaker, John Boehner is in danger of becoming irrelevant to the crucial economics discussions that must occur over the next few months.

headline: In Investing, No Need for Sudden Death
text: “AMERICA loves a winner,” Gen. George S. Patton Jr. told the troops in 1944, and he was surely right. The general also declared, “America will not tolerate a loser.” He was wrong on that one, but how could he have known about the Mets?

headline: To Keep Your Office Resolutions, Start Small
text: Q. It’s two weeks into the new year, and you can already see your work-related resolutions start to fall by the wayside. This happens every year, so why do you keep setting these kinds of goals?

headline: Costs and Carbon Dioxide
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Targets for Future Taxes
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Path to Publishing
text: I GREW up in Middletown in southwestern Ohio. My mother took care of my brother and me. My father had several businesses, including a trucking company. I had a paper delivery route and worked as a candy striper at the local hospital.

headline: League May Require Teams to Re-Sod Fields
text: DENVER — Commissioner Roger Goodell said Saturday the league will look into whether it should require teams to re-sod parts of their natural grass fields after extensive criticism of the field conditions at FedEx Field in Landover, Md., last weekend. Goodell said there was no complaint after the Redskins’ regular-season finale against the Cowboys, but one week later, the Seahawks complained at length about the choppy field, which was blamed for the torn knee ligament sustained by Seahawks defensive end Chris Clemons.

headline: Magic Square
text: Administrivial Grid Numbering Alert! Due to the unusual nature of Elizabeth C. Gorski’s Sunday puzzle, the clue numbering is different in the print and electronic versions.

headline: Despite Protests, Gun Show in Upstate New York Goes On
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The line to enter the Saratoga Arms Fair at the City Center here had never been so long, and David Petronis, its organizer, said he had never shaken so many hands in one morning.

headline: A Car That Takes the Controls
text: Carnegie Mellon's Autonomous Cadillac SRX can drive itself on public roads, detect and stop for pedestrians, and communicate with traffic signals--among other things--all while looking very normal.

headline: After Run of Losses, Knicks Lose Day of Rest
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks used the word urgency several times after practice Saturday. A three-game losing streak has made them concerned about a lot of things, particularly their defense and their poor starts.

headline: Dried Out and Title-Scrubbed, Flooded Cars Lure the Unwary
text: BORDENTOWN, N.J. — At the far end of an enormous hangar, used cars rolled up one by one to the auction block. They had been buffed to a shine, but some carried telltale signs of damage. Puckered leather seats, a hint of mildew, headlights beaded with condensation. Just over two months ago, they had filled with seawater during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: A Fiery Preacher’s Arrival Shakes Pakistani Politics
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Campaign season has begun in Pakistan, with elections widely expected by mid-May that, if they proceed peacefully, would represent a democratic milestone in a country plagued by intermittent military rule.

headline: A Soldier’s Requiem, Never Fading Away
text: WOODBRIDGE, Va. — Each December, Jackie Finken pulls plastic bins from the basement and distributes carefully wrapped Christmas decorations to her three daughters. Each girl has her own ornaments. And each of those ornaments has a story. That is a Finken tradition, one of many.

headline: Six Years Gone
text: Lt. Col. Paul Finken died in Iraq in 2006, leaving behind his wife, Jackie, and their three daughters, Emilie, Caroline and Julia, to figure out which things can heal.

headline: Checking on the Status of State Gun Laws
text: As the Obama administration seeks new federal measures to reduce gun violence, states have also moved to enact new laws. Lawmakers in New York have made the biggest push, following Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s State of the State address on Wednesday, in which he proposed changes in several areas.

headline: Final: 49ers 45, Packers 31
text: Read on for commentary and live analysis from Saturday night’s N.F.C. divisional-round playoff game between the Green Bay Packers and the San Francisco 49ers as it happened. The game was a rematch of the teams’ Week 1 encounter, won by the 49ers, 30-22, but that game offered few clues about what was to come Saturday night.

headline: At Arraignment, Account of a Threat Before a Fatal Fire
text: The suspect in the deadly fire that engulfed a Manhattan apartment building on Thursday night told someone: “You die, I die, everybody dies,” just before igniting two beds in his apartment, a prosecutor said at his arraignment on Saturday.

headline: Pointed in Right Direction, Nets Aren’t Interested in Looking Back
text: Brook Lopez had his feet planted in an ice bath, and Deron Williams’s right thigh was wrapped thickly with gauze. Gerald Wallace had X-rays taken of his ribs. There was fear that a flu bug was going around.

headline: Treasury Won’t Mint Coin to Defy Debt Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department said Saturday that it will not mint a trillion-dollar platinum coin to head off an imminent battle with Congress over raising the government’s borrowing limit.

headline: On Scale of 0 to 500, Beijing’s Air Quality Tops ‘Crazy Bad’ at 755
text: BEIJING — One Friday more than two years ago, an air-quality monitoring device atop the United States Embassy in Beijing recorded data so horrifying that someone in the embassy called the level of pollution “Crazy Bad” in an infamous Twitter post. That day the Air Quality Index, which uses standards set by the United States Environmental Protection Agency, had crept above 500, which was supposed to be the top of the scale.

headline: Taking Violence Against Women Seriously….
text: My Sunday column grew out of the rape/murder in Delhi. At the time I was in China, reporting there, and so I didn’t weigh in. But this is of course an issue that I’ve covered in one way or another for decades and that Sheryl and I tried to call attention to in Half the Sky, and friends began emailing me about other incidents of sexual violence or gender violence that deserved attention. An American woman raped in India, whom the authorities weren’t interested in. A 13-year-old girl dying of injuries caused by rape in Liberia. A separate incident in which an 8-year-old girl is kidnapped by a pimp in Liberia. A woman in San Francisco allegedly doused with gasoline by her boyfriend and set on fire. A girl in Nepal burned alive because she refused a marriage offer. And so on and so on.

headline: Hawks on Iraq Prepare for War Again, Against Hagel
text: In the bitter debate that led up to the American invasion of Iraq in 2003, Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska said that some of his fellow Republicans, in their zest for war, lacked the perspective of veterans like him, who have “sat in jungles or foxholes and watched their friends get their heads blown off.”

headline: Winter Jazzfest: A New-World Meshing of Pop and Folk
text: Day 2 of Winter Jazzfest began, for me, with Claudia Acuña at the Bitter End, reharmonizing “You Are My Sunshine” for a standing-room crowd. I feel as if I’m still digesting last night’s offerings, including a brilliantly indeterminate set by the bassist Eric Revis, the pianist Kris Davis and the drummer Andrew Cyrille; and a midnight set by Nasheet Waits’s Equality, featuring the pianist Vijay Iyer. I tumbled into bed this morning at 3:30, and spent most of the day looking forward to more of the same.

headline: Despite Taliban Threat, Afghanistan Manages to Entice Some Tourists
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have a message for foreign tourists who come to Afghanistan, especially if they are from any of the 50 countries that are part of the NATO-led coalition supporting the government: Big mistake.

headline: Obama Will Seek Citizenship Path in One Fast Push
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to push Congress to move quickly in the coming months on an ambitious overhaul of the immigration system that would include a path to citizenship for most of the 11 million illegal immigrants in the country, senior administration officials and lawmakers said last week.

headline: Accommodating an Old Honky-Tonk in New Austin
text: Old Austin clashes with New Austin nearly every day, causing much worry among the city’s natives: Will these new condos and luxury hotels rub out everything that makes their weird city great? Will the shows for hipster musicians dry up? Is $10 guacamole really worth it?

headline: Energy Industry Awaits U.S. Ruling on Prairie Chicken
text: In a few months, a grouse known as the lesser prairie chicken will emerge from its West Texas winter hideaway. Males will do a loud and elaborate mating dance, delighting females — and bird-watchers.

headline: India’s New Focus on Rape Shows Only the Surface of Women’s Perils
text: NEW DELHI — Harassed for years by her husband and his relatives, an Indian woman was finally kidnapped, raped, strangled and tossed into a ditch.

headline: In Double Overtime Drama, Ravens Stun Broncos
text: DENVER — In Peyton Manning’s 15-year career, there has been a lone dent in his legacy. For all of his regular-season brilliance, Manning has, in all but one season, been unable to propel his team to the championship. Manning’s teams have gone to the postseason 12 times, but in 7 of the previous 11 trips, Manning’s team has lost in its first playoff game.

headline: Winter Jazzfest: Saxophone Whiz, Inspired by a Whale
text: The saxophonist Colin Stetson, who performed a scarily proficient solo set at the Bitter End tonight, is a one-man astonishment engine. This isn’t news to anyone who has seen him live — a substantial number of people, given his indie-rock cachet — but this was my first time hearing him in person, and I won’t forget it soon.

headline: Some State Legislators Blur Line Between Public and Private Interests
text: On the presidential campaign trail, Gov. Rick Perry waxed eloquent about the merits of Texas’ part-time Legislature, saying that Congress would be more effective if its members had “real jobs back at home.”

headline: In Wyoming, Many Jobs but No Place to Call Home
text: CASPER, Wyo. — After losing everything last year to Southern California’s soured economy, Tiffany Kipp and her family packed up three boxes and a diaper bag and caught a Greyhound bus to Wyoming, their best chance at a fresh start.

headline: Wyoming’s Boom Economy Offers Jobs, but Little Chance for Housing
text: There is a surprising downside to Wyoming’s economic resilience and its 5.1 percent unemployment rate: a sharp rise in homelessness.

headline: Shortest Bronco Sets Two N.F.L. Records
text: DENVER — At 5 feet 5 inches, Trindon Holliday of the Denver Broncos is the N.F.L.’s shortest player and its biggest good-luck charm.

headline: A Quandary for the Game in a High-Tech Era
text: A third-place finish at a tournament last month by a formerly obscure player was so startling that organizers searched his clothing and took apart his pen looking for evidence that he had outside help. They found nothing.

headline: Israelis Evict Palestinians From a Site for Housing
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli security forces evicted scores of Palestinian activists before dawn on Sunday from a tent encampment they had set up set up two days earlier in a strategic piece of Israeli-occupied West Bank territory known as E1, east of Jerusalem, where Israel says it plans to build settler homes.

headline: Corrections: January 13, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Winter Jazzfest: A Happy Audience, for Whatever the Genre
text: There isn’t a handy term of genre for the music that Kneebody creates. It’s a band thoroughly acquainted with 1960s free-bop, 1970s jazz rock, 1990s hip-hop and postmillennial indie rock; along with classical postminimalism. (I’m leaving something out, I’m sure.) Whatever the terminology, this group has an audience: it’s set at Culture Project theater is packed beyond capacity, and the crowd has been vocal in its enthusiasm.

headline: Kaepernick Passes and Runs and Dominates in 49ers’ Victory
text: SAN FRANCISCO — There were 22 players on the field, dozens more on the sideline, 69,732 fans at Candlestick Park and millions watching from home.

headline: Bess Greenbaum, Andrew Seewald
text: Bess Gail Greenbaum and Andrew Eric Seewald were married Saturday evening at Guastavino’s, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi David Ingber officiated.

headline: Katherine Bedingfield and David Kieve
text: Katherine Joan Bedingfield and David Kelley Kieve were married Saturday evening at St. John’s Episcopal Church Lafayette Square in Washington. The Rev. Dr. Luis León, the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Matthew Birkhold and Jordan Elkind
text: Matthew Hoover Birkhold, a son of Lee Stephenson Birkhold and Richard A. Birkhold of Stillwater, Minn., was married Saturday to Jordan Michael Elkind, the son of Kerry J. Weiner and Andrew E. Elkind of San Francisco. Rabbi Lev Baesh officiated at St. Paul’s Chapel of Columbia University in Manhattan, with assistance from the Rev. Richard A. Nelson, a Lutheran minister.

headline: Cameron Bierce and Jonathan Hume
text: Cameron Higgins Bierce and Jonathan Matthew Hume were married Saturday evening at the Yale Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Edwin Cromey, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Janhavi Kirtane and Oliver Fritz III
text: Janhavi Mohan Kirtane and Oliver Harvey Fritz III were married Saturday at Houston Station, an event space in Nashville. Pandit Koteswaran K. Gurukkal, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Amy Eisen, Harrie Bakst
text: Amy Eisen and Harrie H. Bakst were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Steven A. Exler at the Central Park Boathouse in Manhattan.

headline: Reyzl Geselowitz, Michael Pershan
text: Reyzl Reba Geselowitz, a daughter of Emily M. Schneider and Michael N. Geselowitz of Cedarhurst, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Michael Brandon Pershan, a son of Debbie A. Pershan and Marc H. Pershan of Skokie, Ill. Rabbi Ben Greenberg is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Kneseth Israel in Far Rockaway, Queens.

headline: Claire Freedman and David Kusnetz
text: Claire Olla Freedman, the daughter of Debra O. Freedman and Robert J. Freedman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to David Matthew Kusnetz, a son of Marcia E. Kusnetz and Dan A. Kusnetz, both of White Plains. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

headline: Elizabeth Gonzalez and Bradford Sussman
text: Elizabeth Ruth Gonzalez and Bradford Jay Sussman are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Ari Fridkis at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for Contemporary Art in Manhattan.

headline: Michaella Dooley, Douglas Kurdziel
text: Michaella Gabrielle Dooley and Douglas Hall Kurdziel were married Saturday at St. Joseph’s Church Yorkville in New York. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Cautious Calls, and a Calamitous Finish
text: DENVER — The Denver Broncos had this one. With a 7-point lead late in the game, possession of the ball and Peyton Manning running the offense, Broncos fans had every reason to believe their team would still be playing next weekend.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 70TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Tina Fey and Amy Poehler (above, from left) host these awards — considered predictors of the Oscars — sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live from the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles. In the motion picture drama division, nominees include “Argo,” “Django Unchained,” “Life of Pi,” “Lincoln” and “Zero Dark Thirty” for best picture; Jessica Chastain, Marion Cotillard, Helen Mirren, Naomi Watts and Rachel Weisz for best actress; and Daniel Day-Lewis, Richard Gere, John Hawkes, Joaquin Phoenix and Denzel Washington for best actor. In the comedy or musical division, the nominees are “The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” “Les Misérables,” “Moonrise Kingdom,” “Salmon Fishing in the Yemen” and “Silver Linings Playbook” for best picture; Emily Blunt, Judi Dench, Jennifer Lawrence, Maggie Smith and Meryl Streep for best actress; and Jack Black, Bradley Cooper, Hugh Jackman, Ewan McGregor and Bill Murray for best actor. Jodie Foster will receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award. Awards will also be handed out for television work. Coverage from the red carpet begins at 6 on E! and at 7 on NBC; E! will visit after-parties at 11.

headline: Eugene C. Patterson, Editor and Civil Rights Crusader, Dies at 89
text: Eugene C. Patterson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning editor of The Atlanta Constitution during the civil rights conflicts of the 1960s and later the managing editor of The Washington Post and editor of The St. Petersburg Times in Florida, died on Saturday in St. Petersburg. He was 89.

headline: Breathing in Beijing: Coping With China’s Smog
text: BEIJING — With Beijing’s air pollution soaring to seemingly new, awful records this weekend, the classic parenting dilemma of “What shall we do with the kids?” had a grimly obvious answer: Slap on the antipollution face masks and go shopping for another air purifier.

headline: Big Payoff in Harbaugh’s Gamble With Kaepernick
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Jim Harbaugh has spent his entire coaching career as nothing short of a football alchemist, a mad genius in a mock turtleneck and a scowl. Most recently he has been responsible for turning the chronically dysfunctional San Francisco 49ers into one of league’s best teams — a ranking that improved with a 45-31 victory over the Green Bay Packers on Saturday in an N.F.C. divisional playoff game.

text: The censor at the wheel.

headline: Russians Rally Against Adoption Ban in a Revival of Anti-Kremlin Protests
text: MOSCOW — Thousands of Russians marched Sunday to condemn the Parliament’s move to ban the adoption of Russian children by American families, an event called a “March Against Scoundrels.” The protesters chanted, “Take your hands off children,” and carried posters showing the faces of lawmakers stamped with the word “shame.”

headline: Egyptian Court Rejects Verdict Against Mubarak
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian appeals court on Sunday threw out the guilty verdict and life sentence against former President Hosni Mubarak on charges that he allowed the killing of protesters. The court ordered a new trial, which would once again send the ailing autocrat rolling on a stretcher into the steel defendant’s cage in an Egyptian criminal court.

headline: By George

headline: Indian Woman Is Gang-Raped After Bus Ride
text: NEW DELHI — A 29-year-old woman was raped over the weekend by a bus driver, a conductor and five other men in the northern Indian state of Punjab, the police said Sunday, in an episode that recalls the recent attack in Delhi that has caused widespread outrage.

headline: Afghans Killed After Allies Target Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An explosion in a mountain village in eastern Afghanistan on Sunday killed at least seven civilians after a joint American-Afghan military raid killed four Taliban fighters there, Afghan officials said. But villagers said 16 civilians had been killed.

headline: A Son Risks His Life on the Highway
text: My 21-year-old son, Sam, pulled a guy out of a burning car on Interstate 95 in Connecticut a week ago, and despite my having four children, I’ve never said that before. I’m hoping it’s a once-in-a-lifetime kind of thing.

headline: China Again Is Growing, More Slowly
text: GUANGZHOU, China — After a sharp economic slowdown through much of last year, China’s economy is growing again — but not at its previous double-digit pace, and with signs that inflation might become a problem again.

headline: Times Square ‘Bow Tie’ Is to Get Belts of Steel and Granite
text: Times Square, one the most free-flowing public spaces in the world, will be constrained a bit by the addition of dozens of stainless-steel bollards and granite barriers that are intended to prevent terrorists — and drunks — from driving vehicles on to the pedestrian plazas that have been created between West 42nd and West 47th Streets.

headline: Disruptions: Design Rivals Technology in Importance
text: Last year, at Apple’s event to announce the iPad Mini, I was wandering around the gadget petting zoo the company sets up after each product unveiling. As I turned a corner, I bumped into Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, who immediately wanted to show me something.

headline: Bomb Kills 14 Pakistani Soldiers as Attacks Shake Up Provincial Government
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A powerful roadside bomb in the militant hub of North Waziristan killed at least 14 Pakistani soldiers and wounded at least 25 on Sunday, a senior military official and local tribesmen said.

headline: ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ in Wider Release, Captures Box-Office Crown
text: Controversy about its torture scenes certainly didn’t hurt “Zero Dark Thirty” as it expanded nationwide over the weekend. The dramatic thriller about the hunt for Osama bin Laden took in a strong $24 million, easily enough for No. 1. “Zero Dark Thirty,” a Sony-distributed film that cost about $45 million to make, has grossed an estimated $29.5 million since arriving in limited release on Dec. 19, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Foxconn Begins Bribery Investigation
text: SHANGHAI — Foxconn Technology, the huge contract electronics manufacturer that makes the Apple iPhone and other popular products, said that it was investigating whether its employees had accepted bribes from supply-chain partners.

headline: U.S. Debate on Gun Laws Is Put to a Test in Colorado
text: DENVER — With politicians in Washington deeply divided over new gun regulations, an urgent national debate ignited by the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School is storming into state legislatures across the country. And nowhere is that debate more emotionally charged or politically consequential than here in Colorado, a reluctant crucible for the battle over guns.

headline: Ed Asner Adds His Voice to ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ Protest
text: LOS ANGELES — Sunday dawned crisp and clear here, with wintry (for Southern California) temperatures lingering in the 40s and 50s. But the rhetoric was already hot, as Hollywood got ready for a Golden Globes ceremony at which the table talk — if not the stage banter — almost inevitably will turn to the political flare-up around “Zero Dark Thirty.”

headline: Seeking Fresh Start, Knicks Dispatch Hornets With Ease
text: The Knicks called it a must-win game, a first for them this season. They vowed to be the more aggressive, more physical team on their home court. And they said they were going to use this game, a Sunday matinee against the New Orleans Hornets, as a way to start a new winning streak after their first three-game skid.

headline: Applause at Missoni, but an Empty Stage
text: MILAN — Rising for a standing ovation at the end of the Missoni show, as much in respectful sympathy as praise, the crowd here this afternoon found itself clapping for no one.

headline: The Very Model of a Modern Major Lyricist
text: Try to imagine how American musical comedy might have evolved without the precedent of Gilbert and Sullivan, and be thankful for the elevated standard of satirical nonsense this British team’s delirious patter songs established for the 20th century. In the words of Alan J. Lerner, W. S. Gilbert raised lyric writing “from a serviceable craft to a legitimate popular art form.” Johnny Mercer bluntly declared, “We all come from Gilbert.” Would it be stretching a point to suggest that rap songs’ fusillades of rhyme also owe something to Gilbert?

headline: At a Temple of Electronica, Drumming Up Lights to Carry the Rest
text: Gaping holes and deliberate convolutions define the songs of Purity Ring, the Canadian duo that performed at Webster Hall on Saturday night, the second of two nights. Megan James is the singer and occasional percussionist; Corin Roddick controls the electronics and keeps busy in real time with drumsticks, tapping on lanterns that light up as they trigger individual notes. Purity Ring combines programmed tracks that are overtly artificial with idiosyncratic content, creating a carnal presence in a digital environment.

headline: Real-World Killings Pressure TV Fiction
text: LOS ANGELES — When Kevin Reilly, the chairman for entertainment at the Fox network, commissioned an ambitious thriller series called “The Following,” about a Hannibal Lecter-like serial killer who inspires a legion of deranged followers, his intention was to challenge the cable business, not the culture.

headline: A Met Debut Helps Elevate Puccini’s Stepchild of an Opera
text: Often when a young singer makes a Metropolitan Opera debut, the engagement is in effect a tryout for potential future assignments. Not so with the Latvian soprano Kristine Opolais, who made her Met debut on Friday night as Magda in Puccini’s “Rondine,” a return of Nicolas Joël’s stylish 2008 production. Without releasing the details a Met official made it clear before her debut that the company has some big plans for Ms. Opolais in coming seasons

headline: In a Work From the Dawn of Opera, Daniel Avoids Becoming Some Lions’ Lunch
text: The point of opera’s origins, the moment when various age-old combinations of music and drama came together in a newly integrated way, keeps being pushed further back.

headline: To Tell a Story, You Have to Have the Right Moves
text: Dance is an oral tradition in which roles and works are passed one from one generation to the next. But what happens to the personal stories? On Thursday evening at the Theater at the 14th Street Y the dancer Todd Allen shared a good one in honor of “The Men Dancers: From the Horse’s Mouth.” At the age of 5, while growing up in Salt Lake City, he planted a tree with Martha Graham, who was traveling through the city. As the only boy in his dance program, Mr. Allen was chosen to appear at the ceremony. Graham was “a pyramid of purple with a head in a bun,” as he put it. “I don’t remember any arms.”

headline: A Deadpan Look at Life Before and After a Stroke
text: “I found myself praying,” Peggy Shaw says in her new solo show “Ruff,” recalling the day she suffered a stroke. It seemed the natural thing to do, since she had already fallen to her knees. “If you get me through this I will stop wearing suits,” she remembers thinking. “I will get married. I will pay market rent in Manhattan. I will not wear skinny jeans. I’ll take antidepressants.”

headline: Photos of The Moment | Calvin Klein
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: An Effort to Untangle Scientology’s Mysteries
text: Lawrence Wright’s avowed purpose in writing “Going Clear” is to understand why Scientology, a religion known for its bizarre creation myth, mining of church members’ secrets and draconian punishment system, has appeal. “What do its adherents get out of it?” he asks. “How can seemingly rational people subscribe to beliefs that others find incomprehensible? Why do public personalities” — he’s talking to you, Tom Cruise — “associate themselves with a faith that is likely to create a kind of public relations martyrdom?”

headline: Before Carrie Graduated to Those Manolos
text: Seen outside the long shadow cast by “Sex and the City,” “The Carrie Diaries” is relatively inoffensive (based on its pilot episode): a fair to middling CW teenage soap opera with some nice performances, particularly by Matt Letscher as the father of the 16-year-old Carrie Bradshaw and Austin Butler as her first crush. It’s not relationship material, but you wouldn’t feel guilty about spending a night with it.

headline: What Is On Your Tennis Wish List for 2013?
text: The Australian Open begins in a few hours, and with the season’s first Grand Slam tournament comes contemplation about the year ahead. The Times’ Christopher Clarey lays out what he hopes to see during the 2013 season. Among his wishes are a run at a Grand Slam, better rivalries in women’s tennis, accurate speed guns, a better antidoping program, and breakthroughs for Chinese men and South American women. He would also like to see players take a break from towel breaks:

headline: Years of Frustration to Tears of Joy
text: ATLANTA — Through more than 250 games with two teams in 16 N.F.L. seasons, Tony Gonzalez never cried tears of joy. He saw players on other teams do it, of course, watching with envy as his opponents were so overwhelmed by the emotion of a victory that they wept on their shoulder pads. But for Gonzalez, those tears never came.

headline: Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan
text: The second most successful team at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last month was Justine Cushing, Melih Ozdil and Joel Wooldridge of New York City, and Adam Kaplan of New Port Richey, Fla. In five events they had three wins, one second and one fourth.

headline: After Rocky Year for Start-Ups, Investors Are Pickier
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Call it the Facebook effect. Until recently, investors had been all too eager to pour millions into any Web start-up with rapid growth, regardless of whether it made money or even had plans to do so down the road. But after Facebook’s rocky initial public offering and flameouts at Zynga and Groupon, venture capitalists are entering a picky phase.

headline: They Left Their Hearts at Coogan’s Bluff
text: Once they were the darlings of Coogan’s Bluff, but now the San Francisco Giants are the darlings of a bar in New York’s East Village as well as thousands of passionate baseball fans back East who stay up late to root.

headline: ‘Argo,’ ‘Les Miz,’ Homeland’ and ‘Girls’ Win Big at the Golden Globes
text: Tonight the Hollywood Foreign Press Association handed out its Golden Globe awards at the Beverly Hilton Hotel.

headline: Taylor Dance Company Offers a Bargain
text: The Paul Taylor Dance Company is to announce on Monday that it will commemorate the 25th anniversary of Mr. Taylor’s “Brandenburgs” (above) and “Speaking in Tongues” by selling $5 tickets to the March 6 performance of the two dances in four separate pop-up shops across Manhattan. Every seat at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center will be sold at the discounted price, and tickets will be distributed equally among all pop-up locations. Tickets must be purchased in person, with a limit of two per buyer. More information including participating sites, on-sale times and dates can be obtained by calling (212) 431-5562.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data scheduled to be released includes retail sales for December, the Producer Price Index for December, and business inventories for November (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for December, industrial production for December and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for December and the Philadelphia Fed index for January (Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for January (Friday).

headline: Serious Flaw in Java Software Is Found, Then Patched
text: 6:53 p.m. | Updated Oracle fixed a security flaw in its Java software on Sunday, after the Department of Homeland Security warned users to disable Java software completely, citing a security hole that allows hackers to take control of their machines.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Winter Jazz Festival Packs in the Bands, Ideas and Crowds
text: The ninth annual Winter Jazzfest reached capacity at around 7:30 on Saturday night, which meant that a lot of bands that aren’t completely hot in New York became so by the laws of supply and demand. It was right around that time that I heard the owner of the Zinc Bar, Alex Kay, use this-inbox-is-full tones to deliver the following sentence to a line of disappointed faces on West Third Street in Greenwich Village: “You will not get in to see Tigran tonight.”

headline: Winter Jazzfest 2013
text: Scenes from the ninth annual music festival.

headline: What Speeding Cars Do
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Steve Salmon must have what recording engineers call Golden EARS. His third time out in The New York Times as a crossword constructor is no different than his first two times: cleverly punny and sure to cause a guffaw or two. Some people can just hear where the puns are, and apparently Mr. Salmon is one of them.

headline: More Modest Growth for China
text: Consumer-price inflation is rising in China and producer-price declines have eased. Those trends are a sign that the economy’s maximum sustainable growth rate may not rebound to its previous double-digit levels.

headline: Documenting a Generation’s Fall
text: One of the lasting effects of the Great Recession has been the economic spiral downward of the American middle class, and no group has been harder hit than the boomer generation, men and women in the prime of their working lives.

headline: A Hilton Web Site Prescribes Vacations for Workers’ Ills
text: HILTON HOTELS AND RESORTS, the flagship brand of Hilton Worldwide, has joined forces with The Onion, the satirical news Web site, to attract leisure travelers to its hotels, following in the footsteps of other advertisers who are using humor to lure younger customers.

headline: President of Sri Lanka Dismisses Chief Justice
text: NEW DELHI — President Mahinda Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka removed the nation’s chief justice from office on Sunday in the culmination of a widely criticized impeachment process that has crippled the nation’s courts and may precipitate a constitutional crisis.

headline: In Beleaguered Detroit, a Media-Wise Group Shows Reporters the Brighter Side
text: In September, a group of nearly 40 journalists and bloggers, some from well-known news organizations like Forbes, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal and Reuters, boarded a bus in downtown Detroit and headed for one of the most run-down neighborhoods in the city. As they peered through the windows at block after block of dilapidated, abandoned homes, a young community organizer spoke eloquently about the area’s revitalization efforts.

headline: Katherine Sarafian and Mark Andrews
text: An interview with Katherine Sarafian and Mark Andrews, the producer and the director of the animated film “Brave.”

headline: The Seventh-Generation Corvette Is Unveiled in Detroit
text: DETROIT — The Stingray is back, in name and in spirit.

headline: Google Gains From Creating Apps for the Opposition
text: For many people, smartphone shopping comes down to a choice of Apple’s iPhone or one powered by Google’s Android software.

headline: Questioning Greek Growth
text: Suzanne Daley, a Times correspondent, reports from Greece on efforts to raise revenue with gold mining despite worries about environmental dangers and lax oversight.

headline: First Rangers Practice Finds Tortorella in Midseason Form
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The N.H.L. got back to business Sunday, which for the Rangers meant that John Tortorella, their ingenious and volatile coach, was back in charge, damning by faint praise and praising by faint damns.

headline: Guns, Maps and Data That Disturb
text: Should data have a conscience?

headline: Jason Clarke at the Golden Globes
text: A chat with the actor Jason Clarke, appearing in “Zero Dark Thirty.”

headline: Hagel to Meet Schumer to Discuss Policy Issues
text: WASHINGTON — In what could be a crucial moment in the Obama administration’s efforts to advance the nomination of former Senator Chuck Hagel as secretary of defense, he will meet this week with Senator Charles E. Schumer, the most influential Jewish member of the Senate, who is expected to press Mr. Hagel on issues concerning Iran and Israel.

headline: The Myth of Nuclear Necessity
text: TRENTON

headline: The Red Carpet at the Golden Globes
text: Style from the red carpet of the 70th Golden Globes.

headline: Greece Sees Gold Boom, but at a Price
text: IERISSOS, Greece — In the forest near here, bulldozers have already begun flattening hundreds of acres for an open pit gold mine and a processing plant, which Canada’s Eldorado Gold Corporation hopes to open within two years. Eldorado has reopened other mining operations around here, too, digging for gold, copper, zinc and lead from nearby hills.

headline: Invasion of the Data Snatchers
text: YOU are the editor of a local newspaper. A reporter on your staff comes to you having obtained (by legal means) one of the following:
