headline: Skirmishes Threaten Pakistan-India Thaw
text: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Tuesday made what may be one of his most aggressive public statements ever about Pakistan, saying that renewed hostilities between the countries in the disputed Kashmir region had made a continued thaw in relations impossible.

headline: The Atlantic Apologizes for Scientology Ad
text: The Atlantic on Tuesday issued a simple three-word apology for publishing an advertisement by the Church of Scientology that resembled a normal article from the acclaimed magazine: “We screwed up.”

headline: Learn How Calipash Differs From Calipee
text: The excuse for buying a dictionary of culinary terms, even if you already have one, is that the vocabulary keeps growing. “Umami,” for example, which “The Diner’s Dictionary: Word Origins of Food & Drink” says was coined in 1908, is still relatively new to the English-speaking world. And “dulce de leche,” the Argentine milk caramel, first appeared in English in 1923 but was not more commonly used until a good 80 years later. These are just two of more than 2,000 words or terms crammed into this compact volume. There are some surprising gaps, like “acai,” the popular Amazonian berry; or “vadouvan,” a kind of curry that’s showing up on menus more often; or “guanciale,” the Italian cured pork cheeks. The perspective is more British than American, but what is offered is useful and fascinating. For example, who knew that there were not one but two terms for turtle meat: calipash and calipee, which refer to different parts of the animal? And that lamb’s wool was a warmed spiced beer with apple that Samuel Pepys mentioned as a nightcap in 1666?

headline: For Indiana’s George, a Breakout Season
text: In an N.B.A. season with a long list of teams learning to cope with sidelined superstars, perhaps no player has made more of his opportunity than Indiana’s Paul George.

headline: From Japan, a New Approach to Fine Chocolates
text: Steps from the Belgian chocolate giants Neuhaus and Leonidas on Madison Avenue is a new Japanese rival, Royce’, with a very different approach to chocolate-making. Instead of filled bonbons, its signature is a small flavored square, the Nama, vaguely truffle-like and alluringly creamy. Green tea, bitter dark, mild milk and white are some of the options, all made with fresh cream from farms near the factory in Hokkaido, Japan’s northernmost region. The sliver of a boutique sells less than half of the varieties Royce’ makes, but they include novelties like potato chips covered with fromage blanc, cocoa-dipped marshmallows and flat chocolate squares called Prafeuille with gooey fillings of honey, berries and caramel. Ken Romaniszyn, the company’s American partner and an owner of Lady M Cake Boutique uptown, said Royce’, which was founded in 1983 and has stores all over Asia, is poised to add two more shops in New York in the spring, on 40th Street opposite Bryant Park and on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.

headline: Italian Tomatoes Ripe for the Picking
text: The race to one-up Heinz continues. And the latest contender, from Italy, should at least get a silver medal. Mutti Tomato Ketchup is properly sweet, tart and a trifle spicy, and if anything, more robustly tomatoey than the iconic brand. It’s also made without the high-fructose corn syrup that is in most Heinz ketchup. Mutti, with headquarters in the Parma area, is an Italian giant that makes only canned tomato products. Its line has just been introduced in the United States and includes tins of juicy baby plum tomatoes, cherry tomatoes, tomato purée and rich, crushed tomato pulp — all worth having in the pantry, especially in winter. Tomato vinegar could easily replace commercial balsamic. There are also several sauces. The ingredient lists on these items are mercifully brief.

headline: New York’s Gun Bill
text: Governor Andrew Cuomo is trying to lead the nation in gun control, but he’s picked a peculiar way of doing it. Mr. Cuomo negotiated in secret with a few other powerful politicians on a dog’s breakfast of legislation that got no public discussion at all and was passed by state senators who had not even read it—because they were not given a chance to do so.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Kill Palestinian at Barrier
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian teenager during a confrontation along the West Bank barrier on Tuesday, underscoring the potential for spiraling violence after weeks of simmering unrest in the area.

headline: Freeing the Plum Book
text: The federal government produces reams of publications, ranging from the useful to the esoteric. Pick a topic, and in most cases you’ll find a relevant government publication: for example, recent Times articles about presidential appointments draw on the Plum Book. Published annually by either the House or the Senate (the task alternates between committees), the Plum Book is a snapshot of appointments throughout the federal government.

headline: Elizabeth Keckley Takes to the Stage, Again
text: Pop culture’s recent fascination with Elizabeth Keckley, the former slave who became a successful dressmaker and confidante of Mary Todd Lincoln, continues with a new play scheduled to open in March at the Mead Center for American Theater in Washington.

headline: PS: A Little NRA Mystery
text: This morning I blogged about a new target-shooting app – NRA: Target Practice – that has gotten a ton of media attention because it is advertised as being for ages 4 and up. I suggested that this was, even by NRA standards, so tasteless that it must be a hoax.

headline: Another First for Barclays Center: A Concert of Jewish Music
text: The arena he built in Brooklyn has hosted concerts of hip-hop, Latin salsa and reggae, not to mention performances by Dylan, Streisand and the Rolling Stones, but when the genre chosen was Jewish music, Bruce C. Ratner decided to take charge himself.

headline: An Herbed Cheese With Roots in Corsica
text: Fleur du Maquis, better known as Brin d’Amour, is a popular Corsican sheep milk cheese with great character, thanks to its generous coating of brambly dried herbs, notably rosemary. Now, Murray’s Cheese is taking young, fat wheels of sheep’s milk cheese from Old Chatham Sheepherding in the Hudson Valley and giving them a Corsican accent, with a coating of rosemary, lemon thyme, marjoram, elderberries and hop flowers. The cheeses, called Hudson Flower, then age for about a month in Murray’s caves. The smooth, tangy interior acquires a mellow, satiny rim, which is flattered by the edible, fragrantly piney herb-dusted rind. And just as the Hudson Valley is a gentler place than volcanic Corsica, the herbs are not quite as aggressive as on the original.

headline: Investigation Into Fund Misses Mark
text: The trail runs cold in the investigation of Steven A. Cohen, the hedge fund billionaire who runs SAC Capital.

headline: Momentum Seems to Build for Gargantuan Buyout of Dell

headline: Sunni Lawmaker in Iraq Is Killed in a Suicide Bombing

headline: Who Was That Masked Kia?
text: What should a masked superhero drive on the way to dispensing vigilante justice? Comic book fans probably don’t see their heroes racing to the scene in a Kia, but that isn’t keeping the automaker from making a play for the caped-crusader market.

headline: A Holding Pattern at Tesla
text: Tesla Motors threw out a lot of numbers at its news conference Tuesday at the Detroit auto show — about new Supercharger locations, about store and service center openings — but it did not directly address production or delivery numbers for the Model S sedan, and it wasn’t saying very much about reported cash-flow problems as production of the car ramps up.

headline: Police to Use Fake Pill Bottles to Track Drugstore Thieves
text: Seeking to catch and eventually deter addicts who steal painkillers, the New York Police Department will stock pharmacy shelves with decoy pill bottles that contain tracking devices.

headline: Restricting Guns in New York State
text: The Times’s Michael Paulson on how New York State is set to enact tougher gun restrictions.

headline: Raising an Interest in Food, Naturally
text: CHLOE VONGERICHTEN, 12, is the horseback riding, hip-hop dancing, trapeze swinging daughter of Jean-Georges Vongerichten, 55, and his wife, Marja, 36. He has eight restaurants in New York, including the one bearing his name at 1 Central Park West, and 27 more around the world. She was the host of “Kimchi Chronicles,” a food and travelogue show that ran for 13 episodes on PBS beginning in 2011, and is the author of the accompanying cookbook. The question arises: Is an obsession with food a genetic trait? And if so, does Chloe have it?

headline: Parents’ Financial Support Could Hurt College Grades
text: Parents beware: The money you contribute to your child’s college education may lead to lower grades.

headline: Readers React: TripAdvisor Feedback and Other Ways to Save on Travel
text: Reader responses to my last two columns — on how to use TripAdvisor and finding retro ways to save on travel — were often thoughtful, original and occasionally hilarious. Here is a selection.

headline: It’s Bonus Week on Wall Street
text: This is bonus week on Wall Street, and it’s shaping up to be a tale of two firms.

headline: My Dark Materials: The Music of Depression
text: “A grief without a pang, void, dark, and drear,” wrote Coleridge in “Dejection: An Ode,” a poem about the paralyzing melancholy he suffered most of his life, which might be diagnosed today as depression. “A stifled, drowsy, unimpassioned grief,/Which finds no natural outlet, no relief,/In word, or sigh, or tear….” The irony of these lines about a poet who is too unhappy to write is, of course, that we find them in a long, sustained poem. A friend shared these lines with me because a similar paradox is at play in many of my compositions, distant as they are from the work of the Romantics.

text: Question:

headline: What Helps a Film More: a Globe or an Oscar?
text: The millions that studios spend on Oscar campaigns are often worth it in the reflected “nominations bump,” the extra tickets sold at the box office when films become Oscar nominees. But over at Reuters, Edmund Helmer made a surprising discovery: The Golden Globes bump may be more lucrative.

headline: Making Do: Learning and Growing Through Adversity
text: Overview | How do people manage when the going gets tough? What traits help some people, or whole societies, succeed where others fail?

headline: Picturehouse, Small Film Distributor, Is Returning
text: LOS ANGELES — Picturehouse is back.

headline: It May Float, but a Home Isn’t a Boat, Justices Rule
text: WASHINGTON — A floating home is not a vessel to be regulated under federal admiralty law, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a colorful decision that featured photographs and the first dissenting opinion in an argued case since the term started in October.

headline: How Is Microsoft’s Surface Tablet Doing?

headline: Bandages Not Included
text: OF the many primal noises to emanate from the modern kitchen — crackle, sizzle, “mmm” and so forth — “AAAGGGHHH!” is not one anybody wants to hear. But that’s what shattered the uneasy peace last July 4 at the white clapboard house my in-laws rent every year in Annisquam, Mass.

headline: Adding Convenience and Danger
text: COOKS have been cutting their fingers since the invention of metal. But with the recent boom in cooking shows and food blogs, chefs and would-be chefs alike have been discovering new ways to hurt themselves.

headline: White House Plots Approach on Guns
text: The Times's Michael D. Shear discusses President Obama's strategy on gun control reform.

headline: Logging Miles (and Miles!) With Clinton
text: HAS anyone in the world traveled as widely in recent years as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and the aides who accompany her? Philippe Reines, her chief spokesman and “the deputy assistant secretary for Doing Hillary’s Bidding,” as The Washington Post once called him, logged 111 countries with Mrs. Clinton in four years (the one country he missed was Hungary) before she was grounded with a health scare.

headline: Arlington Club
text: Inside the steakhouse with a menu that strays far from the steakhouse roster.

headline: Panetta Says U.S. Still in Talks With French Over Mali Aid
text: MADRID — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Tuesday that France faced a difficult task in trying to rout extremists from a vast area in northern Mali and that the Pentagon remained in talks with the French over what kind of military aid the United States would provide.

headline: One Man’s Shakespeare Is Another’s Kick in the Pants
text: The boy from the audience has been instructed to aim for “the nirvana somewhere between comedy and pain.” So the boy, who looks to be about 10, delivers a swift kick to the rear end of the scowling fellow in soiled long johns. Pretty much everybody at the Duke on 42nd Street laughs, as people are expected to at this basic bit of slapstick.

headline: The Designer’s Night 2013 Party
text: DETROIT— A wicked flat black and silver customized Ford GT stood behind a velvet rope at the annual Designer’s Night 2013 Party at the Bankle Building.

headline: Bending the Steakhouse Rules
text: AS soon as you settle on your order at Arlington Club, which can take time because the menu sprawls out like a reclining lawn chair, a basket will land on your table. The basket will hold popovers. The popovers will be huge, steaming hot inside and bronze on top, with a crown of baked Gruyère, Emmental and fontina.

headline: Flu Activity and Norovirus on the Rise in Europe
text: Americans are not the only ones under siege by influenza. The flu is now widespread in at least 10 European countries, and a growing number are reporting an increase in cases.

headline: A Fight Over Historic Preservation Brews in Art Deco Country

headline: Marionettes That Dare Leave the Handlers Behind
text: You think blank-faced marionettes are creepy? Try taking the puppeteers out of the picture and, instead, show filmed footage of puppets seemingly acting of their own accord. Without the animating artist on the premises, all comforting assumptions about what these dapper figures are capable of go right out the window.

headline: ‘The Killing’ to Live Again on AMC
text: In one of the more surprising turns of events for a show known for outlandish plot twists, the cable network AMC announced Tuesday that it had made a deal with Fox Television Studios to produce a third season of “The Killing,” which the channel had said last summer it was canceling.

headline: U.S.-Costa Rica Qualifier in Colorado

text: Republican lawmakers are threatening to put the nation’s financial health at risk over a ritual vote to raise the debt ceiling, but they don’t actually object to throwing away money. Case in point: they seem to relish spending taxpayer dollars on the plainly unconstitutional Defense of Marriage Act.

headline: A Swinging Party With Old Friends
text: Eddie Palmieri was eager to share the glory when he accepted his 2013 National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters award, at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Monday night. Taking the podium, he recalled the first time he heard his fellow pianist McCoy Tyner, at Birdland in the mid-1960s with the John Coltrane Quartet. Mr. Palmieri, whose band was then in residence just up the block at the Palladium Ballroom, described being transfixed.

headline: 8 Things That Don’t Belong In the Kitchen (Yet Somehow Do)
text: Earlier this week I noticed that one of the most bizarre things that lives on my kitchen counter is also one of my favorites: my earmuffs. No, not to drown out the squabbling children or the incessant drone of the several hours of Disney “sitcoms” they subject us to every weekend, but for my blender. I like making smoothies; the blender is old and horribly loud, and after months of blending with my hands over my ears, I indulged myself in $7 worth of noise reduction. They’re red. They even go with my kitchen. Blending is now a joy.

headline: The Honoree Would’ve Felt at Home
text: In an inspired gesture, a group of exemplary musicians presented a memorial concert for the composer Elliott Carter on Sunday night not at a prestigious performing arts center but at Le Poisson Rouge, the lively, informal Greenwich Village club that caters to all kinds of contemporary music. Carter died in November, a month shy of his 104th birthday, and he was composing and collaborating with performers almost to the end.

text: Midwives, it seems, are having a moment. Not only is the number of midwife-assisted births increasing in the United States, but “Call the Midwife,” the spectacularly saccharin British import about 1950s midwives in the East End of London, will also soon start its second season on PBS.

headline: Global Economy Brightens With Modest Growth Ahead, World Bank Says

text: Chief Keef, a Chicago rapper, was jailed on Tuesday afternoon after a judge ruled that he had violated his probation on a previous gun conviction when he held a gun during a videotaped interview with the Pitchfork music site, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Australian Open Chronicles: What Makes Melbourne Special
text: Irina Falconi, an American who is playing at the Australian Open, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets as she did during the United States Open last year. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

headline: Walmart Plans to Buy American More Often
text: The manufacturer 1888 Mills produces most of its sheets and towels overseas, in part to keep costs low for retailers like Walmart. But after Walmart gave 1888 Mills a long-term contract for towels made in the United States, 1888’s chief executive said the company expected to produce more goods here.

headline: At a Climate Protest, Science and Religion
text: Science and religion went hand-in-hand on Tuesday as leaders from both worlds gathered in front of the White House to protest what they cast as government inaction on climate change.

headline: For a Thief in This Office, Paper Clips Wouldn’t Do
text: In just about any office in the city, it is not uncommon for everyday items to disappear from the supply cabinet. Most of the time, it is relatively harmless — a pen here or a notepad there, tucked into a backpack and taken home.

headline: Slowdown in Germany Worries Euro Zone
text: BERLIN — Despite a drumbeat of optimistic forecasts from economists and upbeat statements from various European leaders, the actual news on the economy continues to be grim, with figures released Tuesday showing that Germany, the Continent’s flagship economy, contracted by about 0.5 percent in the final months of last year. Combined with a flurry of disappointing results recently in other major economies, the stumble raised questions about Europe’s ability to escape recession.

text: WASHINGTON — After fierce lobbying by political leaders in states across the Northeast, the House of Representatives on Tuesday night approved a long-awaited $50.7 billion emergency bill to provide help to victims of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: David T. Ennis
text: Mr. Ennis, 44, is the founder and president of the Daten Group, a real estate development and consulting company based in New York. Before starting the company in 2001, he worked as a financial analyst for the Blumenfeld Development Group.

headline: Meeting in Cuba Angers Venezuelan Opposition
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — With the president absent and ailing, the country on edge and the government eager to portray a sturdy sense of continuity, there might be nothing unusual about the most powerful officials in Venezuela meeting over the weekend, except for the location they chose for the sit-down: Havana.

headline: Seattle Rookie Wins by Losing
text: For a player, a loss in the postseason is not necessarily a bad thing. There are times when, even in defeat, a player can make his presence known to a wider audience and polish his star.

headline: Cuomo Raises $22.5 Million for Re-election Bid
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s campaign reported nearly $22.5 million in the bank on Tuesday, a formidable war chest that could scare off potential rivals when he seeks re-election next year.

headline: A New Line in the Sand Against Terror?

headline: Amazon Drives Seattle Office Market Surge
text: If the strength of Seattle’s office market could be chalked up to one company, it would be Amazon.

headline: Wal-Mart Reaches Out to Veterans
text: Wal-Mart, the nation’s largest private employer, says it plans to offer jobs to any recent veterans who want one and hire more than 100,000 of them in the next five years. Other companies should follow Wal-Mart’s lead in this welcome effort to help reduce high unemployment among those who served in recent wars.

headline: Behind Double-Digit Premium Increases
text: National health care spending has been rising at an unusually low rate for three consecutive years. Yet health insurance companies in some states with lax regulations are requesting and winning double-digit premium increases for some customers. That jarring discrepancy suggests that both the federal government and the states need more power to reject premium increases that can’t be justified.

headline: In Russia, Ban on U.S. Adoptions Creates Rancor and Confusion
text: MOSCOW — Despite the adoption ban that has roiled the Russian public and deeply splintered the country’s political and intellectual establishment, Rebecca and Brian Preece arrived here from Idaho on Monday expecting to pick up their new child, a 4-year-old boy with Down syndrome. They plan to call him Gabriel.

headline: President Morsi’s Repulsive Comments
text: When Mohamed Morsi became Egypt’s president in June, he rose, unknown and untested, from the Muslim Brotherhood to the leader of the most important Arab country. He has made missteps and some truly alarming decisions, but there was still reason to hope that he might grow into the job and become the kind of leader that could benefit Egypt and the region.

headline: Record Taxpayer Cost Is Seen for Crop Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — The worst drought in 50 years could leave taxpayers with a record bill of nearly $16 billion in crop insurance costs because of poor yields.

headline: Already Wooing Tenants in Hudson Yards
text: Plans for an athletic stadium fit for the Olympic Games are long gone, but there is no shortage of fierce competition taking shape in the area known as Hudson Yards. Instead of gold medals, though, these players will measure their success in billions of dollars in rent from commercial and residential tenants, and hotel guests. They also hope for bragging rights as the pioneers of a 60-block district that will be transformed by new infrastructure, commercial buildings and public spaces.

headline: 2 Makers Press the Case for Electric Cars
text: DETROIT — The greenest cars on the market — electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids — have attracted very few buyers so far.

headline: Noah Matches His Game to His Bravado
text: DEERFIELD, Ill. — Of all the taunts he has heard, and there have been plenty, Joakim Noah has a favorite. It came when he was in college at the University of Florida, playing in Kentucky’s Rupp Arena. During a timeout late in the game, with his Gators handily beating the Wildcats, Noah looked into the crowd, which was a sea of blue, and screamed at the top of his lungs, “It’s quiet in here!”

headline: Paris University Scandal Clouds Esteemed Past
text: PARIS — Sciences Po was a renowned place of learning well before Richard Descoings became director, an exacting Paris university and among the most prestigious points of entry into the French political, intellectual and economic elite. President François Hollande is an alumnus, for instance, as are the three men who preceded him as chief of state, along with at least a dozen French prime ministers from recent decades.

headline: Redden and Gomez Are Close to Buyouts
text: The N.H.L. and the players’ association have agreed to accelerated compliance buyouts that could enable Wade Redden and Scott Gomez to resume their N.H.L. careers as soon as Saturday.

headline: Burning Fuel Particles Do More Damage to Climate Than Thought, Study Says
text: The tiny black particles released into the atmosphere by burning fuels are far more powerful agents of global warming than had previously been estimated, some of the world’s most prominent atmospheric scientists reported in a study issued on Tuesday.

headline: Fighting Back as Mexican Churches Are Looted
text: CHOLULA, Mexico — Three men, field laborers by day, huddle on a bench as night descends, a mess of empty bottles of hard liquor strewn nearby. Another man gets a refresher on how to ring the bell in case of emergency. One listens attentively to orders from their leader.

headline: On 49ers, Moss Reinvents Himself as Role Model
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — About two weeks ago, 49ers staff members affixed placards to the nameplates above each locker at the team’s practice site. The signs are laminated sheets of paper bearing players’ college recruiting information from their days as prep standouts — intended, perhaps, to remind them of where they began, the success they have enjoyed, and maybe even the idea that a sport that may now seem unduly complicated was not always that way.

headline: Legislature Restricts Access to Gun Permit Data
text: New York State’s new gun law seeks to restrict ownership of certain weapons. But it also restricts something else: access to previously public information about gun permits.

headline: U.S. Criticizes Egypt’s Leader for Anti-Semitic Remarks
text: CAIRO — A White House spokesman on Tuesday condemned anti-Semitic comments made by President Mohamed Morsi before he took office, calling on him to “make clear this kind of rhetoric is not acceptable or productive in a democratic Egypt.”

headline: Facing the French, Mali Rebels Dig In and Blend In
text: BAMAKO, Mali — In the face of fierce, all-night bombardment by the French military, Mali’s Islamist insurgents have hunkered down to fight again.

headline: Takes One to Tango
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Obama’s 1-2 Punch?
text: If election campaigns are supposed to be an exercise in coming to grips with our biggest problems, then the one we just went through was a dismal failure. Our only real solution — a strategy to reignite consistent growth so we can narrow our income gaps and lift the middle class — never got a serious airing. Instead, each side was focused on how to secure a bigger slice of a shrinking pie for its own base. This lousy campaign produced the worst of all outcomes: President Obama won on a platform that had little to do with our core problems and is only a small part of the solution — raising taxes on the wealthy — so he has little incentive to rethink his strategy. And the Republicans did not lose badly enough — they held the House — to have to fully rethink their strategy. It does not bode well.

headline: Nagisa Oshima, Iconoclastic Filmmaker, Dies at 80
text: Nagisa Oshima, the iconoclastic filmmaker who challenged and subverted the pieties of Japanese society and the conventions of Japanese cinema and who gained international notoriety in 1976 for the sexually explicit “In the Realm of the Senses,” died on Tuesday at a hospital near Tokyo. He was 80.

headline: New York Leads on Gun Control
text: The broad gun control bill approved Tuesday by the New York Legislature substantially strengthens the state’s gun control laws and, if vigorously enforced, could make New York one of the toughest places in the country to buy, sell or own dangerous weapons. But the bill also contains troubling provisions involving mental health and public access to important records that should be revisited and reworked.

headline: Syrian Rebels Find Hearts and Minds Elusive
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As the Syrian civil war nears the two-year mark, the opponents of President Bashar al-Assad and their international backers have failed to win the backing of many government supporters, including minorities, a slice of the population whose help is essential not only to resolve the conflict, but also to keep Syria from becoming a failed state, analysts say.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week Fall 2013 Accessories
text: Notable accessories from the Milanese runways.

headline: Warning Signs of Violent Acts Often Unclear
text: No one but a deeply disturbed individual marches into an elementary school or a movie theater and guns down random, innocent people.

headline: On Print’s Turf, Google Wins for Creativity
text: THE winner of a contest to encourage creativity in print advertising, with a grand prize of $1 million worth of full-page ad space in USA Today, is a company that, it can be said, is a reason there are contests to encourage creativity in print advertising with prizes like $1 million worth of full-page newspaper ad space.

headline: Obama Gun Proposal to Look Beyond Mass Shootings
text: A new federal assault weapons ban and background checks of all gun buyers, which President Obama is expected to propose on Wednesday, might have done little to prevent the massacre in Newtown, Conn., last month. The semiautomatic rifle that Adam Lanza used to shoot 20 schoolchildren and 6 adults complied with Connecticut’s assault weapons ban, the police said, and he did not buy the gun himself.

headline: Looking Upstream in Doping Cases
text: The case against Lance Armstrong by antidoping officials detailed how Armstrong, as the leader of his professional cycling team, used performance-enhancing drugs over many years to fuel his run as a seven-time Tour de France champion. It detailed the lengths that many teammates, trainers, doctors and other associates went to enable him to pull off what was called the most sophisticated doping program in the sport’s history.

headline: Whipping Things Up
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s funny how things work, isn’t it? Yesterday I thought that Peter A. Collins would be offering us one of his signature anniversary puzzles, and he didn’t. Today we have a new puzzle by Michael David, and the theme is — wait for it — TRADITIONAL ANNIVERSARY GIFTS. O.K., so I was only off by one day.

headline: Parents Gird for Disruptions as Bus Drivers’ Strike Looms
text: The last time Sherry Passante had to take all three of her children to their three schools, it ended badly. When she dropped off the younger ones at their schools, Derek, her son who has autism and usually takes a school bus, started biting himself and hitting himself in the head. Then he lunged at her.

headline: Nagisa Oshima, Groundbreaking Director, Dies
text: Mr. Oshima, the iconoclastic filmmaker who challenged both Japanese society and the conventions of Japanese cinema, died on Jan. 16.

headline: An Oil Town Where Men Are Many, and Women Are Hounded

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Gun Debate, Even Language Can Be Loaded
text: WASHINGTON — When the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence wanted to promote more restrictions on firearms after the Connecticut school shootings in December, it turned to a firm to help publicize its position. The firm’s name? Point Blank Public Affairs.

headline: Calculating the Cost of College
text: Federal officials require every college to provide a net-price calculator on its Web site.

headline: Daniel J. Edelman, a Publicity Pioneer, Dies at 92

headline: Nationals Strengthen Bullpen by Adding Soriano
text: The Washington Nationals on Tuesday agreed to terms with relief pitcher Rafael Soriano, strengthening their already formidable bullpen and solidifying their status as legitimate World Series contenders for the 2013 season.

headline: D. Brainerd Holmes, a Leader in Space Race, Dies at 91
text: D. Brainerd Holmes, who led NASA’s manned spaceflight program for two crucial years, 1961 to 1963 — a period that included John Glenn’s historic orbit of Earth and helped set the stage for the first moon landing — died on Friday in Memphis. He was 91.

headline: Bulls See Little Value in Knicks’ Eavesdropping
text: DEERFIELD, Ill. — Joakim Noah has an idea why James L. Dolan and the Knicks would have a keen interest in eavesdropping on the Chicago Bulls.

headline: Clarity and Confusion From Tuition Calculators
text: The annual ritual of college admissions has shifted from the season of applying to the season of waiting. While that means an anxious vigil for millions of teenagers like Zachary Ewell, it goes double for their parents. Heidi and Mike Ewell must wait not only to learn where Zachary will go, but also how many thousands of dollars they will have to pay.

headline: Man Pleads Not Guilty to Murder in Fatal Subway Pushing
text: A suspect charged with pushing another man to his death in front of an oncoming subway train in Midtown Manhattan last month told the police that he knew the victim was too drunk to pose a deadly threat and acknowledged that he could have just “walked away,” a prosecutor said Tuesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Jan. 16, 2013
text: The government is twisting in the wind, and they are just watching it happen.

headline: Young Man Dispossessed by Hurricane Is a Virtual Prisoner in His New Home
text: Facing a life wrought with trials, Jason Celik is also a virtual prisoner in his home.

headline: Knicks Given a Day Off
text: After an overnight flight to London in preparation for their regular-season game against Detroit on Thursday, the jet-lagged Knicks were given the day off by Coach Mike Woodson, who did have enough energy to meet with reporters.

headline: Injury-Plagued American Has Another Setback
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Brian Baker, who in 2012 carried himself from the fringes of the Futures Tour to the second week of a Grand Slam, was felled by yet another injury Wednesday in Melbourne, injuring his right knee in his second-round match against his fellow American Sam Querrey.

headline: Candidates Diverge on Residency for Police
text: Should New York City police officers be required to live in New York City?

headline: White House Rejects Petitions to Secede, but Texans Fight On
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — More than 100,000 people who signed an online petition calling on the Obama administration to allow Texas to secede from the United States and create an independent government received an official 476-word response from the White House last week.

headline: For ‘Party of Business,’ Allegiances Are Shifting
text: WASHINGTON — Not for the first time, the White House made known on Monday that top administration officials had reached out to corporate executives for their help in getting Republicans in Congress to compromise on pending budget issues. But as both President Obama and industry chieftains are finding, today’s Republican Party is hardly so quick to bow to big business.

headline: Rights Group Reports on Abuses of Surveillance and Censorship Technology
text: A Canadian human rights monitoring group has documented the use of American-made Internet surveillance and censorship technology by more than a dozen governments, some with harsh human rights policies like Syria, China and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Boosting Your Flu Shot Response With Exercise
text: As this year’s influenza season continues to take its toll, those procrastinators now hurrying to get a flu shot might wish to know that exercise may amplify the flu vaccine’s effect. For maximal potency, the exercise should be undertaken at the right time and involve the right dosage of sweat, according to several recent reports.

headline: Word of the Day | brunt
text: brunt •\ˈbrənt\• noun

headline: Harsher View of Bombing Suspect Is Revealed on Tapes
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Jurors who may have been studying the defendant in recent days at the federal terrorism trial here of a 21-year-old Somali-American named Mohamed Osman Mohamud have seen a thin, neatly dressed young man at the defense table who sometimes quietly confers with his lawyers. But on Tuesday they got a drastically different view as video and audiotapes secretly recorded by the F.B.I. in 2010 revealed a sometimes bombastic, sometimes swaggering religious militant who said repeatedly he was willing to kill and die as a martyr if need be.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (Sundance) MONSOON WEDDING (2002) An extended Punjabi family works through its issues as it prepares to celebrate the arranged marriage of a daughter (Vasundhara Das, above left, with Shefali Shetty) — who has been carrying on an affair with a television host — and her betrothed (Parvin Dabas), who lives in Houston, in this film directed by Mira Nair. Naseeruddin Shah plays the father determined to pull off a wedding he cannot afford. Vijay Raaz is the wedding planner, who nervously eats marigolds. “ ‘Wedding’ often has the energy of a Bollywood spectacle, with its ingratiatingly incongruous shuffles of genres; we even get a handful of musical numbers, including a warm, offhanded song on the pleasures of married life performed by a group of women,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “The agile handling of the soap opera elements — conventional plotting at best — finally makes ‘Wedding’ a pop, facile take on Capulet versus Montague stuff, likable but square.” He added: “Like the monsoon rains that temper Delhi’s summer heat, this movie offers subtle surprises. When ‘Wedding’ captures the small, hilarious skirmishes of a culture at war with itself, and the families trying to hold their ground against change, it is enchanting.”

headline: In Delhi Gang Rape Case, a Controversial, Outspoken Lawyer for the Defense
text: NEW DELHI: When Manohar Lal Sharma heard that the defendants in one of the most high-profile rape cases in recent years were about to be tried, he was the first to rush to court so he could offer to represent them pro bono.

headline: The Extraordinary Trial of Khmer Rouge Leaders
text: BEIJING — Brother Number Two is ill.

headline: News Quiz | January 16, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Leader Issues Populist Vows in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s embattled chief executive on Wednesday used his first policy address to outline a series of populist proposals to alleviate the severe housing shortages and air pollution that have bedeviled the city.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 16
text: NEWS Despite a drumbeat of optimistic forecasts from economists and upbeat statements from various European leaders, the news on the economy continues to be grim, with figures released Tuesday showing that Germany contracted by about 0.5 percent in the final months of last year. Combined with disappointing results in other major economies, the stumble raised questions about Europe’s ability to escape recession. Nicholas Kulish and Jack Ewing report.

headline: On the Ground in Mali, French and Local Troops Confront Islamist Forces
text: BAMAKO, Mali — French soldiers are battling Islamist militants in direct clashes on the ground in central Mali, Malian and Western officials said on Wednesday, acknowledging for the first time that France’s campaign against the militants who have seized much of the nation has involved more than just airstrikes.

headline: Taliban Escalate Battle With Afghan Spy Agency in Assault on Its Headquarters
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Heavily armed Taliban attackers in minivans packed with explosives struck the headquarters of the Afghan intelligence agency on Wednesday, detonating one of the vehicles in one of the most secure parts of Kabul and escalating a growing conflict between the two entities.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 16, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Ergonomic Seats? Most Pupils Squirm in a Classroom Classic.”

headline: Found: A Legendary Monster of the Deep
text: In “Giant Squids Ready for Small-Screen Debut,” William J. Broad writes about an expedition that has captured video of a legendary monster of the deep.

headline: In the Shadows of Wolves and Man
text: “They say you don’t start living until you step out of your comfort zone,” the photographer Christian Houge said. “Art arises when you let go. It can be in the process, in the darkroom. But it can also be in the concept. The end product is about not having control.”

headline: Obama’s First Term: A Romantic Oral History
text: Four years ago, on the eve of Barack Obama’s inauguration, this magazine devoted nearly an entire issue to a photo essay, “Obama’s People.” The photographs, 52 of them, depicted a team arriving on a wave of hope despite inheriting an economy in trouble, a collapsing auto industry, two wars and a continuing terrorist threat.

headline: What Have Your Parents Taught You About Money?
text: The topic of how to teach your children about money is one that comes up in many different contexts in The New York Times.

headline: Bombings in Iraq Kill More Than 20 and Are Seen as Political
text: BAGHDAD — At least two car bombs shattered a building housing the local headquarters of the Kurdistan Democratic Party in the restive city of Kirkuk on Wednesday, killing at least 19 people and wounding more than 200, according to the police.

headline: Helicopter Crash Leaves 2 Dead in Central London
text: LONDON — A helicopter crashed into a crane atop a residential tower in central London on Wednesday, exploding into flames and hurtling to the ground during the morning rush hour, the police said.

headline: India’s Man Problem
text: As India grapples with what seems like a constant barrage of shocking acts of violence against women, one question is asked again and again: Why is this happening?

headline: Part 3: Answers to Your Questions About the Fafsa
text: Now that most college applications are in, it is time for those student applicants (and their parents) to submit what may be the most vital piece of their financial aid plans: the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

text: Chase Stuart analyzed the Jets’ defense on Monday.

headline: Ex-M.T.A. Chief and Mayoral Candidate Is Unknown to Many Voters, Poll Says
text: Updated, 10:27 a.m. | Despite his leadership in restoring service quickly to the subways after Hurricane Sandy, Joseph J. Lhota, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, still hasn’t made an impression on many New York City voters, according a Quinnipiac University poll released Wednesday.

headline: Tip of the Week: Monitor Your Memory
text: If your computer seems to be running slowly and acting as if it does not have enough memory installed, you can use software that comes with the operating system to see what is going on under the hood.

headline: In Flu Season, Use a Mask. But Which One?
text: Face masks help prevent people from getting the flu. But how much protection do they provide?

headline: Ayasdi: A Big Data Start-Up With a Long History
text: Ayasdi is a data analysis start-up built on the career of one man: Gunnar Carlsson, a professor of mathematics at Stanford.

headline: Ten Hard-Earned Lessons About Selling a Business
text: My last three posts have focused on Holly Hunter and her business sale that went bad. I want to thank Ms. Hunter for allowing her story to be told. Although she made some mistakes, she was willing to talk about them in the hope that others might learn from her experience.

headline: JPMorgan Cuts Dimon’s Pay, Even as Profit Surges
text: Even as profit surged, the board of JPMorgan Chase cut the pay package of its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, by 50 percent, in light of a multibillion-dollar trading loss last year.

headline: Art Basel Enters Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — The dessert served at the Art Basel Hong Kong media luncheon was a large, hollow chocolate globe that self-destructed when hot fudge was poured over it. As expected, in a room filled with art types, everyone had to discuss it instead of just eating it. Did it symbolize the breakdown of global boundaries as Art Basel prepared its first fair in Asia? Or the melting away of a beloved and quirky local event? (Or maybe the Mandarin Oriental’s pastry chefs were just in overdrive).

headline: An American, 17, Shows Her Power and Promise
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Despite being a spectator, Pam Shriver looked flushed Wednesday as she left Show Court 3 at the Australian Open.

headline: India’s Police Force Lags Much of the World
text: A recent spate of violent crimes against women in northern India has led to increased scrutiny of the Indian police force. In Delhi, after the gang rape and subsequent death of a young woman, residents called for the resignation of the city’s chief of police and the retraining of the overwhelmingly male police force.

headline: No Easy Path for Obama’s Gun Safety Agenda
text: WASHINGTON — The fact that President Obama would make an all-out push for new gun restrictions seemed all but inevitable from the moment he delivered tearful yet resolute remarks to the nation in the hours after the Newtown, Conn., school massacre last month.

headline: Bolstered by Investments, Goldman Sachs’s Profit Soars
text: 4:19 p.m. | Updated

headline: Selling Some Old Sparkle From Nights at Studio 54
text: As Steve Rubell saw it, the key to a successful party was populating a room with guests more interesting than you.

headline: A Hospital Network With a Vision
text: As the United States struggles to find new business models for health care, some innovators are looking to other industries, ones that provide high-quality services for low prices. In a recent article in The New Yorker, for example, Atul Gawande suggests that the Cheesecake Factory restaurant chain — with its size, central control and accountability for the customer experience — could be a model of sorts for health care. That’s not as outlandish as it seems. The world’s largest provider of eye care has found success by directly adapting the management practices of another big-box food brand, one that is not often associated with good health: McDonald’s.

headline: Interior Secretary to Step Down in March
text: WASHINGTON — Ken Salazar, the blunt-spoken lawyer and rancher who took over the scandal-ridden Interior Department at the outset of the Obama administration, said Wednesday that he would step down  in March to return to his home in Colorado.

headline: The Road to Bamako
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Mamadou Doumbia was so thrilled that France intervened this weekend to beat back a jihadi offensive in Mali that on Monday he took me to buy a French flag to mount next to the Malian flag on the dashboard in his taxi.

headline: Opinion Report: Jobs for Vets
text: From the editorial page

headline: The Central Park Ducks in Winter
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Stone Links: Dating Made Easy (All Too Easy)
text: Taking off from Dan Slater’s essay in The Atlantic, the philosopher and Stone contributor Peter Ludlow pinpoints the source of the trouble with online dating. In the language of economics (which is probably apt), the most basic cost, of which the ones Slater identifies are just consequences, is that it creates a near frictionless market where transaction costs are all but eliminated. But it is friction, the complications it introduces, Ludlow thinks, that is exactly what we need in love–even if it’s not what we want.

headline: How Aaron Hernandez Opened a Throwing Window for Tom Brady
text: Aaron Hernandez did it all for the Patriots in their 41-28 victory over Houston on Sunday. With tight end Rob Gronkowski out of the game, Hernandez was targeted nine times, finishing with six receptions for 85 yards.

headline: Panetta, at Vatican, Says Pope Thanks Him for Service
text: ROME — On what is probably his last trip as defense secretary, Leon E. Panetta had an audience on Wednesday morning at the Vatican with Pope Benedict XVI, who told him, Mr. Panetta said, “Thank you for helping to protect the world.” Mr. Panetta said he replied, “Pray for me.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Gun Data Under Wraps, and Mixing and Matching Disney Characters
text: New York’s new gun law has a provision that restricts access to data about gun owners in the state, Christine Haughney writes in The Times. That component was included in the legislation in response to the publication of names and addresses of gun permit holders in two suburban New York counties by The Journal News, a newspaper based in White Plains, N.Y. The decision to print that information with an accompanying map outraged gun owners across the nation and prompted a backlash against the paper’s employees. Now some journalists are lamenting the loss of data previously available as a reporting tool.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Improve Your Flu Shot’s Potency With Exercise
text: Exercise can improve your flu shot’s potency, confusion and clarity from tuition calculators, a new awards program for Amtrak riders and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Goldman Profit Blows Through Expectations
text: Goldman Sachs on Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter profit of $2.89 billion, or $5.60 a share, well above results in the period a year earlier and handily beating analysts’ expectations of $3.78 a share. The results were buoyed by strong trading and investment banking results. The firm’s conference call is at 10:30 a.m.

headline: Hong Kong Reconsiders Changes to Corporate Database
text: HONG KONG — The second-highest official in Hong Kong said Wednesday that the government was reviewing a proposed rule change that had prompted a groundswell of worry among global banks, accounting firms, investors and media companies who fear the loss of a powerful tool against corruption in China.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Introduces a New Search Tool
text: Facebook has spent eight years nudging its users to share everything they like and everything they do, reports Somini Sengupta in Wednesday’s New York Times. Now, the company is betting it has enough data so that people can find whatever they want on Facebook. And on Tuesday, it unveiled an ambitious new tool to help them dig for it.

headline: Sexual Myopia
text: Every once in a while a male friend in his 60s tells me that try as he might, he just cannot get turned on by women his own age and naturally I channel Cher in “Moonstruck” and let him have it: Snap out of it, I say! Look in the mirror! We all age! What’s more important to you, a woman 30 years younger whom you can show off on the beach or someone who doesn’t draw a blank when you talk about Bullwinkle and Boris Badenov? Not that I have that many conversations in which I need to reference Bullwinkle and Boris Badenov, but when I do I don’t want to have to get bogged down in the whole back story. This is why I know this whole cougar thing is a myth. I do not know any women in their 60s who want a 30-year-old boyfriend because what would they talk about?

headline: Lumière | The French Fifty Shades
text: When it comes to erotica and pornography, whether hard, soft, sadomasochistic or merely steamy, the French believe they have done it first, done it better and done it all. So the French version of the “Fifty Shades of Grey” trilogy should have flopped.

headline: Lafayette Selects Its First Female President
text: Lafayette College has named Alison R. Byerly as its 17th president, making her the first woman to lead the liberal arts institution in Easton, Pa.

headline: Will Boeing’s Problems Benefit Its European Rival?
text: LONDON — Boeing faced the latest setback for its new 787 Dreamliner on Wednesday and industry-watchers are speculating whether the aircraft’s recent troubles could provide a boost for Airbus, the U.S. company’s European archrival.

headline: Trinkets and Doodads for Those Who Are Just Looking
text: Seeing all the new cars may be the reason automotive journalists from all over the world gather at the Detroit auto show during press days at the Cobo Center, but part of the fun is also seeing what tchotchkes the automakers hand out on the show floor. The new Corvette Stingray is important and all, but wasn’t that a really cool paperweight Chevy handed out along with the press materials about the car? They went fast.

headline: Channeling Armstrong
text: O.K., so you find yourself with another day to kill while frantically searching your on-screen cable TV guide looking for the Oprah Winfrey Network — Honey, you sure it isn’t the Alerta TV network? I found that in the 400s. Halogen TV, maybe? — and you’ve decided to wonder whether you will be sick of Lance Armstrong’s big staged confession before it even starts. This is a distinct possibility. After all, Winfrey has already done interviews about the interview (sigh), let people know Armstrong will not come off as contrite (eye roll) and will quite likely try to paint cycling’s leadership as the truly bad guys (stomach churn). Winfrey’s network helped exactly nothing by deciding to drag the thing over two nights, so you can be doubly preannoyed at the whole sideshow.

headline: JPMorgan Report on Trading Loss Takes Aim at Top Executives
text: The bad bet that cost JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion has already provoked scrutiny from regulators and federal agents.

headline: American Airlines Reports a Thin Profit
text: American Airlines, which is in the final stages of bankruptcy and under pressure from US Airways to merge, on Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter profit mostly because of lower costs and some reorganization credits.

headline: At Strike’s Root, Runaway Costs In Busing Pupils
text: The day before the start of New York City’s first school bus strike in 34 years, a long yellow bus pulled up at Public School 282 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and the little bodies that popped out could be counted on one hand: Three. The big bus had dropped off part of its cargo earlier, at another school, but in all, 10 children had ridden on a bus fit for about 60.

headline: Another Change in the Oscar Rules for Documentaries
text: While everyone was busy prepartying and donating money, the Academy quietly announced a major rule change to its members. As GoldDerby.com reports, an e-mail  on Saturday informed voters that choosing the best documentary, best animated short and best live-action short would no longer be such exclusive affairs.

headline: From Death Strip to Tech Campus
text: BERLIN — Travis Todd, an American tech entrepreneur, pointed at the snow-covered construction site behind his shared office. Twenty-five years ago, East German border guards would have gunned down anyone caught in the restricted zone along the Berlin Wall. Today, Google and other investors are turning an abandoned brewery in the “death strip” into a technology campus.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Food & Wine: Scarlett Johansson wishes she could have raw oysters with Bette Davis. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Jan. 16 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
text: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web. On Wednesday, President Obama announced a push for new laws to restrict the availability of guns and to embrace a series of executive actions that he can take without seeking congressional approval.

headline: Extortion Charges for 29 Tied to Trash-Hauling Industry
text: In the annals of organized crime and extortion, there is no end to the victims and their suffering, from movie stars and Wall Street brokers to truck drivers and small businessmen.

headline: An Insider’s Insider Returns to Politics, This Time as an Outsider
text: ROME — The dark, double-breasted suits have long been a mainstay, but now former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has taken to wearing the occasional fedora. It lends him a rakish, retro air as he embarks on what many Italians, foreign investors and no doubt Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany hoped would never happen: another election campaign.

headline: Second Stage Adds ‘Nobody Loves You’
text: “Nobody Loves You,” a musical satire about reality television and its shameless contestants, will be the final production in the 2012-13 season at Second Stage Theater, the company said on Wednesday. The musical — which features a book by Itamar Moses (the playwright of “The Four of Us” and a writer for television’s “Boardwalk Empire”), music by Gaby Alter, lyrics by Mr. Moses and Mr. Alter and choreography by Mandy Moore (of television’s “So You Think You Can Dance”) — chronicles a young man who competes on a fictional reality show (also called “Nobody Loves You”) in hopes of regaining a lost girlfriend and of exposing the contrivances of the show.

headline: The Mannequin Also Speaks
text: LAST Thursday, a rarefied intersection of the downtown creative set packed the Envoy Enterprises gallery on Rivington Street. Curators from the New Museum and the Clocktower Gallery mingled with musicians like Santigold and the cabaret siren Lady Rizo.

headline: Viva La Villa | Prison-Side Palazzo
text: Adventures in house-hunting: a writer chronicles her attempt to find the perfect home in Italy.

headline: Youth and Experience in Harmony
text: One of the worthy activities of the George London Foundation has been its series of voice recitals at the Morgan Library & Museum, in which an established and an emerging artist share a program.

headline: Militants Seize Americans and Other Hostages in Algeria
text: BAMAKO, Mali — The French military assault on Islamist extremists in Mali escalated into a potentially much broader North African conflict on Wednesday when, in retribution, armed attackers in unmarked trucks seized an internationally managed natural gas field in neighboring Algeria and took at least 20 foreign hostages, including Americans.

headline: The Dalloway
text: LESBIANS tired of the same old bars in Manhattan — Cubbyhole, Henrietta Hudson, the Stonewall Inn — have a new spot to call their own. Opened in November, the Dalloway, named after the Virginia Woolf character, is owned by two reality TV stars: Kim Stolz of “America’s Next Top Model,” and Amanda Leigh Dunn of “The Real L Word.”

headline: Putting Limits on Guns
text: TimesCast: What to expect from President Obama’s gun control proposal. | France begins a ground war against Malian insurgents.

headline: Tell Us Your Candidates for Obama Cinema
text: As the president’s second inauguration approaches, The Times’s chief film critics, A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, are proposing a new genre: Obama Cinema. In a “highly preliminary, wildly speculative thematic guide” — as they put it — they argue that it’s possible to view recent American films as reflections of different aspects of the nation and especially its leader since 2008.

headline: Movies in the Age of Obama
text: FOUR years ago, on the historic occasion of Barack Obama’s first inauguration, we took a look at the good, bad and outrageous movie characters who helped make his election possible. The road to the White House, we wrote, hadn’t just been paved by Mr. Obama’s speeches, innovative campaign strategies and the hopefulness of a majority of voters, but also by decades of African-American men in movies. From the class striving of Sidney Poitier’s everyman in the classic film “A Raisin in the Sun” to Will Smith’s messianic loners in recent titles like “I Am Legend,” the movies have ennobled, consecrated, glorified, immortalized and, most important, normalized the figure of the black man.

headline: Keeping Score: Magic Pay Less Attention to the 3-Point Line
text: The 2012 off-season was tumultuous for the Orlando Magic. From late May to early August they fired Stan Van Gundy, the best coach in franchise history; traded Dwight Howard, the best player in franchise history; and lost the free agent Ryan Anderson, the league’s most improved player last season.

headline: Obama to ‘Put Everything I’ve Got’ Into Gun Control
text: WASHINGTON — Four days before taking the oath of office, President Obama on Wednesday staked the beginning of his second term on an uphill quest to pass the broadest gun control legislation in a generation.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 16
text: A religious procession in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Bronx Zoo Welcomes Baby Gibbon
text: Half a world away from its native habitat, a white-cheeked gibbon was born in the Bronx.

headline: France Battles Rebels in Mali
text: The Times’s Greg Winter talks about the escalating conflict in Mali, where the government and France are fighting Islamist insurgents.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Draw the School Bus Strike
