headline: White House Gun Proposals
text: The White House released a series of documents on Wednesday outlining the president’s plan for reducing gun violence.

headline: A Right of Insurrection?
text: Opponents of gun control often argue that they need firearms for self-defense. Most of them mean that literally – defending themselves and their homes and families against intruders. Others have a more grandiose understanding of self-defense. They find gun control anathema because they believe that firearms safeguard the right to rise up against the American government.

headline: Steve Rubell Memorabilia at Auction
text: Items from Mr. Rubell’s collection of items associated with Studio 54 are up for sale.

headline: Levine Sees More Opportunity Representing Canada
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The United States once seemed to attract defecting tennis champions in droves, with Martina Navratilova, Monica Seles and even Ivan Lendl, late in his career, switching to representing the United States.

headline: In the Round: Chevy Impala LTZ
text: The Chevrolet Impala LTZ at the Detroit auto show. To control the view of the car, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

headline: Photo Replay: January 16
text: The day in sports, including the World Cup downhill and the Australian Open.

headline: White House Denounces Web Video by N.R.A.
text: WASHINGTON — The National Rifle Association provoked a furious response from the White House on Wednesday by releasing a video accusing President Obama of being an “elitist” and a “hypocrite” because he opposes posting armed guards at schools, while his daughters have Secret Service protection.

headline: A Soap Maker Sought Compatibility in a Merger Partner
text: For Eric Ryan and Adam Lowry, the quest began in 2001 in what they call a “dirty little flat” in San Francisco, where the two childhood buddies from Detroit first plotted to disrupt the all-but-impenetrable cleaning products industry long dominated by giants like SC Johnson and Procter & Gamble.

headline: The Fisker Karma With a V-8, Courtesy of Bob Lutz
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: VL Automotive Destino

headline: What Factors Affect Your Credit Score
text: A Web site from an arm of the credit bureau Experian now offers a free tool that can help you see how different financial steps, or missteps, can affect your credit score.

headline: On Our Radar: The Python Hunting Contest
text: Eleven Burmese pythons have been captured in Florida since a hunting contest for the snakes, an invasive species, began in southern Florida on Saturday. [The Miami Herald]

headline: The Fall Line’s Fault
text: The warehouses that once serviced the wharves of Richmond, Va., now house restaurants and stores, including the venerable independent Fountain Bookstore. A heron rookery bustles in the riverside treetops, the nestlings nourished by the fish that crowd the turbulent, oxygen-rich shallows below. The rapids offer the best urban kayaking in the United States.

headline: A Spirited American Tale
text: Today’s booksellers, surrounded by tablets and e-book readers of varying gigabytes and styles, are by all appearances in the throes of a daunting battle. But in 1775, Henry Knox, a bookseller in colonial America, got tangled in a war of a more traditional stripe.

headline: In Effort to Preserve Bedford-Stuyvesant, Some Ask: For Whom?
text: With block after block of crisply handsome 19th-century row houses arrayed in almost military precision, punctuated on the avenues by fantastically turreted schoolhouses and apartment buildings, the area of Bedford-Stuyvesant between Bedford and Tompkins Avenues and Monroe and Fulton Streets is unquestionably a historical district.

headline: Christian Rocker Tops the Chart
text: New albums by a Christian singer-songwriter and a band of masked rap-rockers have taken over the Billboard chart, as the music industry’s post-holiday sales doldrums continue.

headline: Where South Beach Meets the Stage
text: The focus of Focus Dance, the multiprogram festival presented by Gotham Arts Exchange at the Joyce Theater last week, is less on who’s dancing than on who’s in the audience: the potential buyers in town for the annual Association of Performing Arts Presenters conference. Most of the selections had been shown recently in New York, but one company was making a New York debut: Rosie Herrera Dance Theater.

headline: Full Transcript of Biden and Obama’s Remarks on Gun Laws
text: The following is the complete transcript of President Obama’s remarks on gun laws on Wednesday in Washington. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service.)

headline: Ex-Governor, Disgraced in Scandal, Eyes Congress
text: Mark Sanford, the former South Carolina governor whose career and marriage crumbled as he pursued a relationship with an Argentine woman, on Wednesday made official his decision to run for Congress.

headline: Hotel Review: Alfonso XIII in Seville, Spain
text: UPSHOT

headline: Social Search and the Difficulties of Discovery
text: In literature and philosophy, in both West and East, the notion of search refers to expansive, ambitious human pursuits. We have, alternately, searched for the Promised Land and the holy grail. Astronomers have searched for life in outer space. The Buddha searched for truth.

headline: Obama Unveils Plan for Gun Laws
text: President Obama outlined his proposals to reduce gun violence in the United States, urging Congress to approve expanded background checks, a ban on assault weapons and other restrictions.

headline: Has Snowboarding Lost Its Edge?
text: LATE last summer when Shaun White, the two-time Olympic gold medal snowboarder and X-Games superstar, was charged with public intoxication and vandalism, he became at age 26 an accidental metaphor for his sport: a young phenom all grown up, and in a spot of trouble.

headline: Only for Those Who Aren’t Photosensitive
text: Last weekend Japan Society presented its 15th annual contemporary dance showcase and once again opened a window onto the East Asian scene. The series’s artistic director, Yoko Shioya, remarked that the Internet has made that scene more easily accessible. She also said that her focus has shifted from new companies to new works, since so many dancers and choreographers are now freelancers and eager to collaborate with artists outside dance. Sounds like New York.

headline: Pushing France Onto the Digital Stage
text: PARIS — When the most prominent new face in France’s effort to oversee the new economy speaks, her pronouncements may be followed almost as closely in Silicon Valley and Seoul as in Paris.

headline: Forecast: More Sunshine at Sundance (at Least on Screen)
text: The Sundance Film Festival has long had a dual personality. The atmosphere is typically fun and fizzy — Stars! Swag! Hot tub hopping! — while the films are dark and depressing, sometimes to the point of self-parody.

headline: Milan Top 5
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Below the Line: Designing ‘Moonrise Kingdom’
text: While “Moonrise Kingdom,” Wes Anderson’s whimsical feature about young romantics in a small island community, didn’t make the cut for best picture at last week’s Oscar nominations, it did receive a nod for its screenplay and was recognized by the Producers Guild of America, while also making several critics’ top 10 lists.

headline: Introducing Building the Team: Flower Power
text: Three years ago, I knew nothing about flowers.

headline: Rossignol Rentals Introduce Its Technology
text: Memories of ill-performing rental gear — skis with the turning ability of a two-by-four, boots that pinch — are a big deterrent to occasional skiers, especially those who haven’t visited the slopes recently enough to realize that today’s equipment has vastly improved, making it easier to become a better skier.

headline: Knicks Practice in London With Anthony Backing Dolan
text: LONDON — After a trans-Atlantic flight, the Knicks returned to work Wednesday, adjusting to their temporary surroundings with a practice session at O2 Arena and a clinic for children who might have been only vaguely familiar with N.B.A. players.

headline: The Latest in Anti-Politics
text: Gail Collins: David, the House Republicans are going off for their annual retreat this week. As a sign of my good intentions, I am not going to make any jokes involving Custer and Little Bighorn.

headline: What Is Driving Growth in Government Spending?
text: It’s one of the most fundamental political questions of our time: What’s driving the growth in government spending? And it has a relatively straightforward answer: first and foremost, spending on health care through Medicare and Medicaid, and other major social insurance and entitlement programs.

headline: Have an N.B.A. Question? Howard Beck Has Answers
text: 3:56 p.m. | Updated What has happened to the Mavericks? Are the Nets good enough to go beyond the first round of the playoffs? Can the Lakers be repaired? Howard Beck, the N.B.A. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers about the season. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear next week on Off the Dribble.

headline: Still Flying Beyond Gravity’s Pull
text: Nearly a decade has passed since Idina Menzel introduced her signature song, the Stephen Schwartz anthem “Defying Gravity” in the 2003 Broadway smash “Wicked.”

headline: Study Discovers DNA That Tells Mice How to Construct Their Homes
text: The architectural feats of animals — from beaver dams to birds’ nests — not only make for great nature television, but, since the plans for such constructions seem largely inherited, they also offer an opportunity for scientists to tackle the profoundly difficult question of how genes control complicated behavior in animals and humans.

headline: Sandy and the Hastert Rule
text: A quick look at the House vote on $50.7 billion in federal aid to repair the damage from Hurricane Sandy suggests that it passed pretty easily on Tuesday night, 241 to 180. The real news is in how the two parties split: Republicans voted overwhelmingly against it, while all but one Democrat supported it.

headline: Will Gridlock Last?
text: Lately I’ve been arguing that both political parties should probably lower their expectations for what they’re likely to achieve in a divided Washington D.C. This would mean focusing on consolidation (for liberals) and rebuilding (for conservatives), making small-ball deals instead of seeking grand bargains and comprehensive reforms, giving up on the idea that some brilliant legislative gambit will suddenly “break” the House Republicans or “force” the White House to accede to G.O.P. demands, and accepting that the next wave of significant legislating will probably have to await a shift in the balance of power come 2014 or 2016.

headline: Reversing Course, Kelly Leaves Oregon to Become Coach of the Eagles
text: On Saturday evening, the Philadelphia Eagles sent out a curious statement. They explained that they had no regrets about how much time they had spent interviewing the best college coaches for their vacant head coaching spot, despite knowing there was only a remote chance one of them would leave for the N.F.L. The statement was an indication the Eagles were moving on, having failed to land their top choice.

headline: Comparing Wall St. Bonuses? There’s an App for That
text: It’s a ritual as old as Wall Street. Come bonus time, employees furtively compare their pay to see how they measure up.

headline: Oxygen Drops Plans for ‘All My Babies’ Mamas’
text: The cable channel Oxygen has scrapped a show in development called “All My Babies’ Mamas” after the promotion of an online petition that condemned the channel, accusing it of exploiting and stereotyping black children and families.

headline: Incoming Members of Congress Not Exactly Average Joes
text: With the rise of the Tea Party movement, the image of Average Joe Citizen taking over Congress has captured the media’s imagination, from rural northern Florida, which sent a large-animal veterinarian, Ted Yoho, to the House, to eastern Michigan, which elected a reindeer farmer and Santa Claus impersonator, Kerry Bentivolio.

headline: Inaugural Committee Previews Weekend’s Festivities
text: “I love the idea of any show that begins with Chuck Schumer and ends with Beyoncé.” — Brent Colburn, communications director for President Obama’s inaugural committee, describing Monday’s swearing in ceremony on the west front of the Capitol. Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, will make remarks opening the ceremony and Beyoncé will sing the national anthem at the end.

headline: Houston Symphony Chooses New Maestro
text: The Houston Symphony on Wednesday named the Colombian-born Andrés Orozco-Estrada as its next music director. Mr. Orozco-Estrada, 35, will begin conducting the orchestra regularly next season and take over officially with a five-year contract in the 2014-15 season.

headline: A Breath of Florida, Alligators Included
text: Parsons Dance returned to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with works by the choreographer David Parsons, including his new “Dawn to Dusk,” as well as a commission by a former company member, Katarzyna Skarpetowska. Each serve watered-down versions of dances by master choreographers: Mr. Parsons, as usual, draws from Paul Taylor, with whom he danced. Ms. Skarpetowska, at least in her new “Black Flowers,” channels Martha Graham.

headline: Anti-Auto Show Focusing on Alternative Transportation
text: DETROIT — The North American International Anti-Auto Show, an art exhibition timed around the show at the Cobo Center, opens Friday night with a black-tie preview at the Contemporary Art Institute of Detroit. Admission is $1 to the green carpet event, where anti-auto show girls will unveil some of the artwork from 14 artists highlighting alternative transportation-based themes.

headline: Family Art
text: Dieter Roth’s works live on as a family business.

headline: Into Antarctica’s Dark Depths
text: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee, Antarctica.

headline: Could Responsibilities Help Prevent Teenage Suicide?
text: One recent Saturday, a friend of mine drove across town to a gun store. She bought a pistol, went back to her car in the parking lot, and ended her life.

headline: Gun Reform for a Generation
text: We usually cringe when politicians drag ordinary people onstage for their events. But the four children who appeared with their parents and President Obama in the White House on Wednesday at his announcement on gun control proposals drove home the nature of the crisis facing the country. While guns and gun control have been a subject of debate among politicians and lawyers and lobbyists and pollsters and political groups in the center and on the fringes, our children have been living in a free-fire zone for sociopaths with virtually unfettered access to instruments of mass murder.

headline: Lance Armstrong Faces the Media
text: TimesCast Media+Tech: Oprah Winfrey’s network prepares to show the Lance Armstrong interview. | John Green, the author and video blogger, goes from YouTube to Carnegie Hall. | Apps for the ski slopes.

headline: Teaching About the Flu With The New York Times
text: “Flu Attack! How a Virus Invades Your Body,” a video from NPR

headline: Producer Says James Brown Biopic Is Finally a Go
text: The movie producer Brian Grazer says that  he has obtained the rights to James Brown’s music from the singer’s estate and that he is moving ahead with a long-delayed film about Mr. Brown’s life. In an interview with Rolling Stone, Mr. Grazer said that he had brought in Mick Jagger as a producer and that they intended to begin casting the movie soon, using a revised version of a script Mr. Grazer commissioned years ago from the British screenwriters Jez and John-Henry Butterworth.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Lance Armstrong Faces the Media
text: Oprah Winfrey’s network prepares to show the Lance Armstrong interview. John Green, the author and video blogger, goes from YouTube to Carnegie Hall. Apps for the ski slopes.

headline: Owning a Home, Mortgage Free
text: With all the painful foreclosures during the recent economic downturn, it’s easy to forget that some homeowners don’t even have mortgages. Nearly a third of homeowners — 29.3 percent of them — do not, according to a recent analysis by the real estate site Zillow.

headline: Europe Weighs Requiring Firms to Disclose Data Breaches
text: BERLIN — To combat a rise in cybercrime, the European Commission is considering a plan to require companies that store data on the Internet — like Microsoft, Apple, Google and I.B.M. — to report the loss or theft of personal information in the 27-nation bloc or risk sanctions and fines.

headline: An Actor’s Evolution, by Way of Some Famous Scenes
text: Right from the start of his career James DeVita could perform Shakespeare with his hands tied behind his back.

headline: Seven Features Announced for New Directors/New Films Series
text: Sarah Polley’s documentary exploration into her own family and Shane Carruth’s followup to his 2004 debut, “Primer,” are among the features that will be presented at this year’s New Directors/New Films series, the annual program presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the organizations said on Wednesday.

headline: Students’ Letters to Obama
text: Read three student letters, released by the White House to The Associated Press, asking President Obama to change gun laws.

headline: Ask Well: Do I Need a Flu Shot if I’ve Had the Flu?
text: Question:

headline: Spicing Up a Ho-Hum Tech Show
text: Hi boss! I’m back from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. You assigned me to report on what’s new and exciting, but I have some bad news. The answer is: almost nothing.

headline: Winehouse Foundation Gift to Help Brooklyn Conservatory Students
text: The Amy Winehouse Foundation has awarded $25,000 to the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music to finance scholarships for teenage jazz musicians. The parents of Amy Winehouse, Janis and Mitch Winehouse, attended a short ceremony at the nonprofit conservatory in Park Slope on Wednesday morning to hand over a giant facsimile of a check to Karen Geer, the executive director.

headline: Growing Up With Hinsch’s
text: One of the last vestiges of my childhood in Brooklyn will be gone when Hinsch’s, the luncheonette-cum-ice cream parlor in Bay Ridge, closes down as planned in March.

headline: Germany to Move 674 Tons of Gold
text: FRANKFURT — Nearly half of Germany’s gold reserves are held in a vault at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York — billions of dollars worth of postwar geopolitical history squirreled away for safe keeping below the streets of Lower Manhattan.

headline: What’s in Obama’s Gun Control Proposal
text: The initiative to reduce gun violence announced by President Obama includes both legislative proposals that would need to be acted on by Congress and executive actions he can do on his own.

headline: If You Like the Moody Blues, Try Alt-J
text: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Lance Armstrong Opens Up to Oprah
text: On the eve of Lance Armstrong's interview with Oprah Winfrey, The Times's Brian Stelter talks about the fallen athlete as he faces the media.

headline: An Acura MDX Prototype With Front-Wheel Drive
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2014 Acura MDX Prototype

headline: Video Shows Flaming Wreckage After Helicopter Crash in London
text: Video and photographs posted online by witnesses showed smoke and fire on a street in central London after a helicopter crash on Wednesday. The police said the aircraft hit a crane atop a residential tower, exploding into flames and hurtling to the ground during the morning rush, my colleagues Lark Turner and Alan Cowell reported.

headline: Alfa Romeo Returns to America, via China
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2007 Alfa Romeo 166 … check that, it’s now a 2013 Guangzhou Trumpchi

headline: When Scots Cut Loose, They Go All the Way
text: New York seems to be lacking in proper date plays — you know, lively love stories that might lead to dinners in dark places and public make-out sessions. Of course there’s “Once,” the Tony-winning, boy-almost-gets-girl musical on Broadway. But if you’re looking for a less obvious, more affordable show to see with that special someone you slipped your number to last week at Citarella, you could do worse than “Midsummer,” written and directed by David Greig.

headline: Kathryn Bigelow Steps Up Defense of “Zero Dark Thirty”
text: As the political and film industry tensions around “Zero Dark Thirty” rise, Kathryn Bigelow, a naturally reserved woman who dislikes public speaking, has taken more opportunities to defend her film, about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, and its portrayal of torture as a tactic used by the C.I.A. in its manhunt.

headline: Pot Goes to Florida, and Vice Versa
text: Dave Barry has written a comic novel that features lost luggage, beaches, hapless tourists from Michigan, exotic animal life, drugs, wild mix-ups, laughable oldsters and the trademarked zaniness of Florida. Not at all coincidentally Tim Dorsey’s new comic novel features these same ingredients, although Mr. Dorsey’s hapless tourists come from Wisconsin.

headline: H.P. Said to Have Suitors for Two Units
text: Hewlett-Packard has received a number of inquiries from would-be buyers for its Autonomy and Electronic Data Systems units in recent weeks, though the technology company is not interested in selling at the moment, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: By the Fadduh of ’60s Parodies
text: Broadway history is punctuated with failures, but some are more spectacular than others. Surely hopes were high in 1969 when Allan Sherman, he of “Hello Muddah, Hello Fadduh” and the best-selling song-parody album “My Son, the Folk Singer,” delivered a musical about the strains of infidelity then sweeping across suburbia. Despite Dorothy Loudon as its star and George Abbott as its director “The Fig Leaves Are Falling” closed after four performances, leaving behind a memorable pan from Clive Barnes of The New York Times. “There is nothing much wrong” with the show, he wrote, “that a new book, new music, new lyrics, new settings, new direction, new choreography and a partially new cast would not quite possibly put right.”

headline: Counting the Vanishing Bees
text: A new method for monitoring the decline in bee populations may prove a useful tool in much-needed conservation efforts. It requires only a few hundred pan traps: bright shallow bowls partly filled with soapy water or propylene glycol.

headline: Segregation Linked in Study With Lung Cancer Deaths
text: African-Americans who live in highly segregated counties are considerably more likely to die from lung cancer than those in counties that are less segregated, a new study has found.

headline: China Arrests 7 in New Effort to Stop Tibetan Self-Immolations
text: BEIJING — The authorities in northwest China have detained seven people they say organized the fatal self-immolation of a Tibetan villager in October, photographed his burning body and then sent the images abroad.

headline: YouTube to Carnegie Hall
text: Thanks in no small part to a YouTube channel he started with his younger brother, the best-selling author John Green enjoys literary success — and his own concert performance at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Cadillac, Ford, Nissan and Lutz Win Design Awards
text: The annual Eyes on Design Awards for design excellence at the Detroit auto show were presented late Tuesday as the last event of press days.

headline: A First Look at Saint Laurent in the Stores
text: Hedi Slimane’s first designs for Saint Laurent, including his spring men’s wear and a women’s resort collection that had not previously been shown to the news media, began appearing in stores this week, giving customers their first opportunity to see the clothes up close. Barneys New York has a small selection of the men’s designs, including a cotton hoodie that costs nearly $1,000, and some women’s pieces like a minidress in an animal print ($4,490) are now available online.

headline: Different Shades of German Rivalry
text: January does not look like its going to be a good month for Schalke.

headline: Smithsonian and Patent Office Work Together on Expo
text: The Arts and Industries Building on the National Mall has been closed for extensive renovations since 2004. But in anticipation of its reopening next year, the Smithsonian announced on Wednesday that it is starting a programming and exhibition series this summer at the Patent and Trademark Office’s headquarters in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Shelby Focus ST Looks Back to the 1980s
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2013 Shelby Focus ST

headline: Rodriguez Has Hip Surgery; Yankees Expect Six-Month Recovery
text: The last time Alex Rodriguez had hip surgery was 2009. He did not return until May 8 that season, but managed to hit 30 home runs and knock in 100 runs, then went on a remarkable tear in the postseason to lead the Yankees to a World Series title. Four years later, Rodriguez is hoping for a taste of the same formula, although the recovery time could be three times as long.

headline: Lawmaker Weighs In on Gun Issue
text: An interview with Congressman Mike Thompson, chairman of the Congressional Gun Violence Prevention Task Force.

headline: In Italy, a British Outpost
text: MILAN

headline: Suiting Up in Milan
text: There is still a special quality to Italian goods.

headline: Dennis Kucinich Signs as Fox News Contributor
text: Dennis Kucinich, the former Democratic congressman from Ohio, is the Fox News Channel’s newest contributor.

headline: Robert Wolf Said to Hire Goolsbee as Adviser for His Firm
text: One of President Obama’s favorite bankers is teaming up with one of the president’s go-to economists.

headline: A-List Guide to the Inauguration Parties
text: WHEN aides to President Obama announced that there would be only two official inaugural balls this weekend — the fewest in recent memory — Washington insiders and veteran partygoers shrugged.

headline: Audi’s Trackside Diversion in Detroit
text: Having revealed two vehicles with a combined output of 914 horsepower, Audi was feeling particularly racy at this year’s Detroit auto show. Perhaps to drive the point home, the German automaker invited journalists to a night of go-karting, following the first media preview day on Monday.

headline: Tougher Line Needed on Dimon
text: JPMorgan Chase has gone soft on Jamie Dimon over the so-called whale trade.

headline: Models and Actresses Start Makeup Lines
text: The transition from modeling or acting to running a company is not easy.

headline: From Celebrity to Entrepreneur
text: ON an overcast Monday afternoon, while many of her peers were nursing Golden Globes hangovers, Drew Barrymore was greeting members of the press at the TriBeCa headquarters of Maesa, a cosmetics manufacturer that is her partner in a new line, Flower. It began arriving at Walmart stores on Jan 2, with items priced from $4.98 to $13.98.

headline: Morsi Says His Slurs of Jews Were Taken Out of Context
text: CAIRO — A spokesman for President Mohamed Morsi said on Wednesday that inflammatory comments that he made about Jews before taking office had been intended as criticism of Israeli policies toward the Palestinians but had been taken out of context. The spokesman said that Mr. Morsi respected all monotheistic religions and religious freedom.

headline: Memorable Clips
text: Mia Farrow, Linda Evangelista, Grace Coddington and others as examples of a radical change in hairstyle.

headline: The ‘Karlie’ Is Turning Heads
text: THE haircut of the year has arrived. Yes, already. Vogue is calling it the Chop, others have named it the Karlie, after the model Karlie Kloss.

headline: Study Confirms Benefits of Flu Vaccine for Pregnant Women
text: While everyone is being urged to get the flu vaccine as soon as possible, some pregnant women avoid it in the belief that it may harm their babies. A large new study confirms that they should be much more afraid of the flu than the vaccine.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Carven
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Times Communications Executive Is Leaving
text: 1:25 p.m. | Updated Robert Christie, senior vice president of corporate communications for The New York Times Company, is leaving the company and his position is being eliminated, The Times announced Wednesday.

headline: In Thoreau’s Flower Journal, Clues for Climatologists
text: Henry David Thoreau was a peculiar fellow. After his secluded stint at Walden Pond, his fixation with the natural world only grew. Starting in 1852, his journal turned into a two million-word project documenting seasonal observations around his small Massachusetts township, Concord. Over the next six springs he could be seen racing about town like a madman in an effort to spot and record that year’s first elusive blooms, all the while taking notes.

headline: Scouting Report
text: LE SHOPPING

headline: Netanyahu Issues Veiled Barb in Response to Reported Criticism From Obama
text: JERUSALEM — Days before an Israeli election that he is expected to win, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday directed a veiled barb at President Obama, who was quoted this week as denouncing Mr. Netanyahu’s policies.

headline: Moody’s Gives Colleges a Negative Grade
text: The credit reporting agency Moody’s said on Wednesday that it had revised its financial outlook for colleges and universities, giving a negative grade to the entire field.

headline: On Snowy Slopes, Fingers Glide Down the Touch Screen
text: I love skiing: the thrill of racing down a tricky trail, the tingle of icy air in your lungs, the mountaintop views, the sips of mulled wine. Like everyone, I take a tumble now and again, and I am prone to getting lost among the trails and ski lifts, and stuck in the occasional snowdrift. At least my red hair helps my friends find me on the slopes.

headline: Scent of Chekhov May Confuse the Senses
text: Remember those much-parodied Calvin Klein fragrance commercials that Richard Avedon did in the mid-1980s? The ones with glamorous, sexually ambiguous young creatures in stark rooms, striking languorous poses and speaking enigmatic nonsense? Well, that’s kind of what Tina Satter’s “Seagull (Thinking of you),” part of Performance Space 122’s Coil Festival, feels like, at least at first.

headline: App Smart: Ski Trip Apps
text: Kit Eaton reviews apps that could help you out on your weekend ski trip.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iran and Egypt.

headline: Homes for $1.6 Million
text: Properties in Connecticut, Washington, D.C. and Houston.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.6 Million
text: ROXBURY, CONN.

headline: A Snub by Oscars? Affleck Has an Answer
text: Ben Affleck said to ask him anything. “Nothing is off limits,” he said, adding later, “There’s nothing that you can ask me that hasn’t been asked of me before.”

headline: Letting Dance Carry Music: Balanchine Put Tchaikovsky in Perspective
text: Peter Martins will soon reach his 30th anniversary as ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet. The company’s schedule for the whole 2012-13 season reads as a statement of what Mr. Martins believes matters most to its identity. The fall season concentrated on the series of Stravinsky ballets that was the most celebrated and radical part of the founder and choreographer George Balanchine’s work; the current season, through Feb. 24, celebrates Balanchine’s no less important Tchaikovsky ballets (following the six-week season of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” a core ballet for reasons apart from its popularity). And the spring season will focus on Mr. Martins’s own ballets. Premieres by both Justin Peck and Christopher Wheeldon are spaced over months.

headline: Rich Little’s Many Characters
text: A Las Vegas show by the country’s pre-eminent impressionist in the 1970s may be headed to Broadway.

headline: In Choosing a Tablet, First Try It On for Size
text: In the grand scheme of worries, deciding which size tablet to get — they all sit within a roughly three-inch screen range — does not quite rank.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 17
text: Spring fashion is still a few weeks away from stores, but there are stellar pieces in many of the resort collections that can breathe life into your exhausted winter wardrobe.

headline: Make No Mistake, but if You Do, Here’s How to Correct It
text: Newspaper people try to get everything right, but given that they are human beings writing and editing huge amounts of copy on unforgiving deadlines, often they don’t.

headline: Obama Plans to Name Close Aide on National Security as Chief of Staff
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is planning to elevate a key national security deputy, Denis R. McDonough, to White House chief of staff, administration officials said on Wednesday, making perhaps his closest foreign policy adviser the gatekeeper to the Oval Office.

headline: Where Knowing Your Way Around a Song Trumps Youth
text: An awards show without acceptance speeches, only performances by the winners of their best material: that was the considerable enticement of the 11th annual New York Nightlife Awards, presented at Town Hall on Monday evening in a three-hour-plus marathon hosted by the writer and comedian Bruce Vilanch.

headline: A Dream of a Lifetime, Fully Lived in Hours
text: The rhythmic squeak of rotating blades on a windmill outside a rustic country inn; wind rushing through the grass; unsmiling characters viewed sidelong through half-open doors: These are among the repetitive aural and visual motifs in Eduardo Nunes’s “Southwest” that evoke the relentless passing of time and the weight of the world on people struggling to survive.

headline: An Unheralded Muse of Midcentury Fashion
text: FASHION history lesson: At the 1965 inauguration of Lyndon B. Johnson, his wife, Lady Bird, wore a matching coat-and-dress daytime ensemble in a shade of red so vivid that it was described in press reports as “American Beauty.”

headline: Supreme Court Hears Argument on the F.C.C.’s Authority to Rule on Cellphone Towers
text: WASHINGTON — In June, two Texas cities asked the Supreme Court to decide a practical question and an abstract one, both concerning how quickly local zoning authorities have to respond to applications from telecommunications companies to build wireless towers.

headline: The 1.6.13 Issue
text: GEORGE SAUNDERS

headline: A Minimalist House Near Oslo
text: A starkly designed house in Drammen is on the market for $1.6 million (8.7 million Norwegian kroner).

headline: House Hunting in ... Norway
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM MINIMALIST HOUSE NEAR OSLO

headline: Hearings Set on the Gowanus Cleanup
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency plans to hold two public meetings next week on its proposed Superfund cleanup of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The massive job involves dredging contaminated sediment from most of the canal at a cost of up to $504 million. The agency is also proposing that the city control raw sewage discharges by installing holding tanks that would temporarily retain excess sewage and storm water during rains until treatment plants can handle the load.

headline: When Pills Fail, This, er, Option Provides a Cure
text: The treatment may sound appalling, but it works.

headline: Comedy Not Intended for the Squeamish
text: With jolting premieres coming up from shows like “The Following” and “Bates Motel,” the winter television season is going to separate viewers who like their TV strong and unsettling from those who don’t.

headline: In the Post-Pocket-Protector Era, Reigning on Reality TV Contest
text: Reality television’s perennial problem is that many people who are not professional actors are awkward and unappealing on camera. The solution? Make a show about people who by definition are awkward and unappealing.

headline: Prominent Republicans Criticize Obama’s Executive Actions
text: Prominent Republicans are accusing President Obama of abusing his executive power by taking 23 executive actions on gun violence at the same time that he asked Congress to pass legislation.

headline: A Show Makes Friends and History
text: “Scandal,” now in its second season, has been a success for ABC. Last week the show had 3.52 million viewers aged 18 to 49 and 8.4 million total viewers. Among the group aged 18 to 34 it typically ranks first in its 10 p.m. Thursday time slot. A political thriller set in Washington, “Scandal” has attracted some inside-the-beltway fans like the political strategists Donna Brazile and Roland S. Martin, who have both tweeted about the show.

headline: A Defiant ‘Oui’ for ‘Fifty Shades’
text: PARIS

headline: Tweaking Rap’s Rules, but With Respect
text: What are the hallmarks of great rapping in 2013? Lyrical imagination and complexity, sure — those are always on the list. But they’re increasingly sharing space with things like texture, emotion, versatility, experimentation and confidence. Rap has always made room for innovation, eccentricity and dialect, but the range has never been wider.

headline: Last Time Around, Striking Bus Drivers Had Plenty of Company

headline: F.A.A. Grounds U.S.-Operated Boeing 787s
text: The Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday that it was grounding all Boeing 787s operated by United States carriers until it can determine what caused a new type of battery to catch fire on two planes in nine days.

headline: A Novelist and His Brother Sell Out Carnegie Hall
text: Goofy variety shows are not the stock in trade of most authors, especially those who write emotionally wrenching novels about teenagers dying of cancer, but John Green inhabits a multiplatform world with few boundaries. So when he took the stage at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night along with his brother, Hank, to celebrate the one-year anniversary of the release of John’s critically acclaimed book “The Fault in Our Stars,” all of his diverse interests were on display.

headline: Jaime Ortiz-Patiño at the 1982 Bermuda Regional
text: Jaime Ortiz-Patiño, a former president of the World Bridge Federation, died on Jan. 3 in Marbella, Spain. He was 82.

headline: Creatures Small and Great
text: In the world of bio design, tiles are animated and moss is electric.

headline: The Beauty of Bacteria
text: IF we’re to believe half a century of daytime TV commercials, housekeeping is war — a perpetual battle against the sneaky soldiers of nature. For decades, we’ve armed ourselves with cleaning products to slay bacteria, scrape away fungus and torture mites. As our household organisms move up the evolutionary ladder, acquiring wings and faces, we hire mercenaries to drive them out.

headline: Camellias That Can Take the Chill
text: In cold climates, early bloomers make the best choices.

headline: Hoax Is Revealed as Irish Star Says He Was Duped
text: Manti Te’o, Notre Dame’s star linebacker, was one of the feel-good stories of the 2012 college football season, excelling on the field despite the deaths of his grandmother and his girlfriend, he said, within hours of each other.

headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
text: Disney Interactive Studios went to great pains to lay out its new multiplatform gaming initiative, Disney Infinity, and with good reason. Infinity, which is to be released in June, will have a lot of elements at the start, and has the potential to grow into a behemoth.

text: AS anyone who has ever been disappointed by the New York housing market knows, the experience can be something like a bad date: Drawn in by the promise of a handsome exterior, you make your way hopefully down a featureless corridor and persevere up a sagging stair, only to find a “duplex” of spaces that are sloppily renovated, bizarrely configured and so small as to be almost uninhabitable.

headline: Russian Court Rejects Jailed Punk Band Member’s Request to Be With Young Son
text: MOSCOW — A judge in Siberia on Wednesday rejected an appeal by a member of the punk protest band Pussy Riot to be released temporarily so that she could be with her 5-year-old son while he was growing up, telling the courtroom that having a small child “did not prevent her from committing a serious crime.”

headline: Patterned Bedding
text: GABY BASORA breezed into the John Robshaw showroom in Chelsea wearing a yellow coat with black stitching, a black-and-cream jumpsuit in what looked like a tribal print, a velvet blazer and animal print pumps.

headline: Stained Glass, From Churches to Malls
text: Brian Clarke, 59, a stained-glass artist, will present more than 50 works in “Between Extremities,” a show that opens Thursday at one of the Pace galleries in Chelsea. Mr. Clarke’s glass can be found in chapels, mosques and synagogues, but also in corporate headquarters and shopping centers. He has collaborated with architects including Renzo Piano, Zaha Hadid and Norman Foster. Born in the north of England to a coal miner father and a mother who worked in a cotton mill, he lives in London.

headline: In Education, China Takes the Lead
text: China has invested heavily in a huge expansion of higher education.

headline: Sit, Inhale, Whatever
text: If you have been searching for a one-of-a-kind piece for home or garden, you might be interested in Mary Jane’s High Chair ($10,000). Originally designed by the Princeton, N.J., artist Peter Stefferson for a licensed California marijuana dispensary, it is, Mr. Stefferson says, a homage to “the positive attributes of an old and respected American Indian medical and recreational herb.” So what happened to the original client?

headline: Illumination, Inspired by Catastrophe
text: Giulio Cappellini, the Italian design entrepreneur who helped start the careers of such luminaries as Jasper Morrison, Tom Dixon and Marcel Wanders, has made another find: a young Swedish designer, Johan Lindsten, whom Mr. Cappellini discovered at the Salone Satellite, a showplace of young talents that is part of the International Furniture Fair in Milan. Their first collaboration is a lamp by Mr. Lindsten made of thin-walled, handblown colored glass. Called Meltdown, the lamp is Mr. Lindsten’s comment on the nuclear catastrophe at Fukushima, Japan. Instead of being suspended within the fixture, the light bulb rests against the bottom of the glass and looks ready to dissolve.

headline: Art Imitates Indianapolis
text: Indianapolis Museum of Art curators have filled a nearby hotel with contemporary art that resonates with and sometimes mocks the region. At the Alexander Hotel, designed by Gensler, which opens Monday, windows here and there are covered with the artist Kim Beck’s vinyl silhouettes of local weeds (above). The sculptor Sonya Clark built a portrait of the Indianapolis hair-care tycoon Madam C. J. Walker out of 3,840 combs (top right). Paul Villinski’s wall-mounted installation is made from vinyl records by musicians including the Gary, Ind., native Michael Jackson (top left). And Mark Fox’s stream-of-consciousness text, cut from reflective stainless steel, notes that John Dillinger is buried about seven and a half miles from the Alexander, and that hotel rooms are zones of “mirrors and copulation.”

headline: Tips From a Backyard on a Dirt Road
text: Margaret Roach, the garden writer and blogger who lived out the fantasy of not only making it to the top (editorial director of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia), but also chucking it for an old house in upstate New York, wrote about her first adventures with snakes and solitude in “And I Shall Have Some Peace There: Trading in the Fast Lane for My Own Dirt Road.” Now, in “The Backyard Parables: Lessons on Gardening, and Life” (Grand Central Publishing, $26), she really digs in. Along with observations of wind, caterpillars and bacteria — Mycobacterium vaccae can elevate the mood and stimulate immune cells — she offers details like shoveling alone, through thigh-high snow, in the dark of night, to hammer a hole in the ice of a frog pond so the frogs didn’t suffocate. For fans who crave her gardening advice, don’t worry. She tells how to protect banana plants in winter, and put up a deer fence, too.

text: In-stock wool rugs are 20 percent off at Angela Adams, through Monday; (800) 255-9454, angelaadams.com.

headline: Megabytes From the Motor Show: The Final Chapter?
text: Manufacturers were still giving out flash drives containing press materials at the 2013 Detroit auto show, but not as many as at past shows. More companies are switching to either paper releases or just telling reporters to go to their media sites for the information. This just builds one’s appreciation for the drives that are handed out.

text: MOSCOW — Not much is known about the underworld kingpin known as Grandpa Hassan, except that somebody really wanted him dead.

text: WASHINGTON — President Obama indicated on Wednesday that along with asking Congress to pass measures like an assault weapons ban, he would be increasing pressure on lawmakers to do something they have refused to do for the past six years: confirm a permanent director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

headline: AT&T Allows FaceTime for Limited Data Users. What About Unlimited?
text: AT&T said on Wednesday that it would allow more of its iPhone customers to use Apple’s videoconferencing app, FaceTime, over its cellular network. But customers with unlimited data plans are still left out.

headline: Pakistan Says Preacher and Crowd at Risk
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Two days after a charismatic preacher swept into the capital surrounded by thousands of supporters, Pakistan’s government responded by rejecting his political agenda and hinting that an operation to dislodge him was imminent.

headline: Candidate’s Stepmother Declines to Endorse Him for Public Advocate
text: Noah E. Gotbaum, a son of the labor leader Victor Gotbaum, can count on his family name for a boost as he runs this year for the office of New York City public advocate.

headline: Democrats in Albany Propose Giving Illegal Immigrants Access to Aid for College
text: Responding to more than two years of lobbying by immigrants’ advocates, the Democratic majority in the New York State Assembly threw its support on Wednesday behind a comprehensive bill that would make state financial aid available to illegal immigrants at colleges and universities.

headline: For Space Station, a Pod That Folds Like a Shirt and Inflates Like a Balloon
text: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. — An inflatable space pod to be attached to the International Space Station in a couple of years will be like no other piece of the station.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American military has suspended the transfer of detainees to some Afghan prisons out of concern over continuing human rights abuses and torture, the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force said Wednesday in response to questions about the subject.

headline: Soldier, Husband, Father, Lost in War
Syrian North Sees Increase in Violence
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least two dozen people, many of them Syrian government soldiers, died Wednesday when three powerful car bombs exploded in Idlib, according to the opposition, and the government announced it was carrying out new operations in and around Idlib and Aleppo.

headline: Vincent Sombrotto, Who Led Postal Strike, Dies at 89
text: Vincent Sombrotto, who as a rank-and-file letter carrier led a wildcat strike that shut down post offices across the country in 1970, prompting President Richard M. Nixon to call out the National Guard, and who went on to lead one of the nation’s most powerful postal workers’ unions for 24 years, died on Jan. 10 at a hospital near his home in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: Former Counsel to Paterson Is Fined on an Ethics Law Violation

headline: An Added Mission for Arizona Sheriff’s Immigration Posse: School Patrols
text: GILA BEND, Ariz. — Dennis Donowick is a retired truck driver who refused to spend the rest of his days “drinking beer and doing nothing,” as he put it. Four years ago, he packed his guns and his urge “to give back to the community” and joined Sheriff Joe Arpaio’s volunteer posse, a group best known for its supporting role in the sheriff’s immigration raids.

headline: Another Face-Off for Nuclear-Armed Rivals
text: One of the likeliest flash points for a nuclear war is the enduring conflict between India and Pakistan, which have scores of nuclear weapons. In recent weeks, several fatal incidents across the disputed Kashmir border have stoked new fears that the firing of bullets could escalate into something even worse.

headline: As Israeli Vote Nears, Arab Apathy Is a Concern
text: BAKA AL-GHARBIYA, Israel — There are two distinct strains of voter apathy here in what is known as the Triangle, home to many of Israel’s 1.5 million Arab citizens.

headline: U.S. Sees Hazy Threat From Mali Militants
text: WASHINGTON — As Islamic militants methodically carved out a base in the desert of northern Mali over the past year, officials in Washington, Paris and African capitals struggling with military plans to drive the Islamists out of the country agreed on one principle: African troops, not European or American soldiers, would fight the battle of Mali.

headline: Report Details Missteps in Trading at JPMorgan
text: Long seen as one of the most careful banks on Wall Street, JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday drew back a curtain on a rare breakdown, showing traders acting on their own and concealing losses while managers seemingly turned a blind eye.

headline: JPMorgan’s Board Uses a Pay Cut as a Message
text: Shortly after the markets closed on Tuesday afternoon, an emissary from JPMorgan Chase’s board of directors walked two flights down to the 48th-floor corner office of the bank’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, to deliver a stark message. The board had voted to slash Mr. Dimon’s annual compensation for 2012 by half.

headline: Now What, Liberalism?

headline: In Britain, Basketball Can Be a Tough Sell
text: LONDON — Our secondary school, a fairly average one in the rural English town of Yeovil, population 40,000, was, like the majority of others in the country, very much a hot spot for soccer as the 1990s unfolded. Soccer was what we played and talked about during morning breaks, at lunchtime and after classes.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Jan. 17, 2013.
text: I know many of us as would rather have had our tooth pulled than use the word ‘recover,’ it was so unscientific. Now we can use it, though I think we need to stress that it’s rare.

headline: Conviction Tossed Out in ’89 Killing in Brooklyn
text: A federal judge tossed out the conviction of a Brooklyn man who has spent 23 years in prison for the murder of a local drug dealer, ruling that the trial prosecutor was “overzealous and deceitful,” the man’s lawyers were “indolent and ill prepared,” and the decisions of the original trial judge were “incomprehensible.”

headline: Given Chance, Raven Gets Into Backfield
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — When Terrell Suggs tore his right Achilles’ tendon over the off-season, his Baltimore Ravens teammates were concerned, and that might be putting it mildly. How would the defense’s pass rush hold up? Suggs seemed almost irreplaceable.

headline: Next Made-in-China Boom: College Graduates

headline: Pakistan Criticizes Obama’s Plan for Turning Over Military Command in Afghanistan
text: Pakistan’s foreign minister on Wednesday issued a biting critique of President Obama’s plan to accelerate the handover of military command in Afghanistan to Afghan forces, declaring that the border with Pakistan has become “less well managed” and that the United States is leaving “without determining whether you have accomplished your objectives.”

headline: Felony Charges for Officer Accused of False Arrest
text: A New York City police officer was charged with 10 felony counts of filing a false document in connection with what prosecutors said was an unwarranted arrest of a man in a Harlem housing project last year.

text: NEWARK — The Devils welcomed back their leading scorer, right wing Ilya Kovalchuk, on Wednesday while securing another of their top threats by signing center Travis Zajac to an eight-year contract worth $46 million.

headline: At Many Top Public Universities, Intercollegiate Sports Come at an Academic Price
text: Public colleges and universities that compete in N.C.A.A. Division I sports spend three to six times as much on each athlete as they do to educate each of their students, according to a new report by the Delta Cost Project at the American Institutes for Research.

headline: Israel: U.S. Immigrant Convicted in Palestinian Deaths
text: A Jerusalem court on Wednesday convicted an American immigrant who lived in a West Bank settlement of killing two Palestinians in 1997. Known as “the Jewish terrorist,” Yaakov (Jack) Teitel was also convicted of other crimes, including bombings in 2008 that wounded a leftist Israeli professor and a teenage boy belonging to a community of Jews who believe in Jesus. Sentencing is planned for February.

headline: About-Face as Slumping Hawks Crush Sizzling Nets
text: ATLANTA — The Nets’ seven-game winning streak came to a thudding end Wednesday night when they were run off the Philips Arena floor, 109-95, by an energetic Hawks team missing its best player.

headline: Even Defining ‘Assault Rifles’ Is Complicated

headline: Bruised by Losses, a Mother’s Heart Soars Anew
text: “I like to dance! I like to sing! I like to do everything!” Maleah Weeks, 5, called out as she twirled around her living room, which was still decorated for Christmas, early this month.

headline: Report Criticizes School Discipline Measures Used in Mississippi
text: Less than three months after the Justice Department sued Meridian, Miss., after finding that school students there were routinely arrested without probable cause, a report by a group of civil rights organizations says that “overly harsh school disciplinary policies” are common throughout the state.

headline: For Resourceful Lawyer, Setback in Soldier’s Case
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — When he was hired in 2010 to defend Pfc. Bradley Manning, David E. Coombs was handed the most daunting of challenges.

headline: Some With Autism Diagnosis Can Overcome Symptoms, Study Finds
text: Doctors have long believed that disabling autistic disorders last a lifetime, but a new study has found that some children who exhibit signature symptoms of the disorder recover completely.

headline: Flooded Businesses Set Goal to Reopen, but Obstacles Emerge
text: Susan Povich, an owner of the Red Hook Lobster Pound, cast a desultory glance around her market and takeout shop on Van Brunt Street, the main strip of a seaside neighborhood in Brooklyn still struggling to its feet after Hurricane Sandy’s pounding.

headline: Inaugural Planners Spotlight Eight Citizens
text: A retired nurse, a 26-year-old who was denied health insurance, a soldier injured in Afghanistan and a laid-off auto worker who got her job back after President Obama moved to rescue the auto industry are among eight “citizen co-chairs’’ of Monday’s inaugural festivities, inaugural planners are to announce Thursday morning.

headline: Coming Back: Red Hook
text: Businesses in Red Hook, Brooklyn, struggled to reopen after Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Trestman Back in N.F.L. as Bears’ Coach After Successful Stay in C.F.L.
text: Marc Trestman was smart enough for Bernie Kosar, Steve Young and Rich Gannon. He was valued enough by the nine N.F.L. teams that hired him as an assistant over nearly two decades. Trestman was seasoned enough, finally, as a head coach, to compile a 64-34 record and consecutive Grey Cup championships in five seasons with the Montreal Alouettes of the C.F.L.

headline: Lottery Numbers
49ers Star Shakes Off Focus on Injury
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — So there was Justin Smith, inside a tent on Wednesday, behind a lectern, clad in gray San Francisco 49ers sweats complete with the requisite lineman stains. His face hinted at neither worry nor concern. That whole thing about a partly torn triceps tendon?

headline: Yuri M. Schmidt, Rights Lawyer in Russia, Dies at 75
text: MOSCOW — Yuri M. Schmidt, a human rights lawyer who represented critics of the Russian government and others accused of political crimes, died on Saturday in St. Petersburg. He was 75.

headline: Courtside Eavesdropping Does Not Flatter the Knicks
text: In a maneuver that owes more to Austin Powers than James Bond, the Knicks’ owner, James L. Dolan, may have tarnished his team’s reputation, and that of his best player, with a stunt involving two microphones and a plan to surreptitiously record on-court comments by Carmelo Anthony. Unfortunately, the plan was carried out in the most conspicuous, ham-handed manner since the 1960s sitcom “Get Smart” featured spies hiding in trees.

headline: Conrad Bain, Father on ‘Diff’rent Strokes’, Dies at 89
text: Conrad Bain, an accomplished stage and film actor who was best known for a late-career role on television as the white adoptive father of two poor black boys on the long-running comedy “Diff’rent Strokes,” died on Monday in Livermore, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Cosmos Unveil Plan for Soccer Stadium Near Belmont Park
text: The New York Cosmos, whose forebears ignited a soccer boom four decades ago, said Wednesday that they hoped to build a stadium near Belmont Park Race Track in Nassau County, just over the border with New York City. The stadium would be part of a new shopping and entertainment district.

headline: What’s On Thursday

(OWN) OPRAH AND LANCE ARMSTRONG In the first installment of a two-part interview recorded on Monday in Austin, Tex., Mr. Armstrong, above, addresses the doping scandal that stripped him of his seven Tour de France titles and resulted in the loss of millions of dollars in endorsement deals. Part 2 will be shown Friday at 9 p.m. The interview will also be streamed at oprah.com.

headline: News Quiz | January 17, 2013

headline: Ram Singh and Mukesh, Delhi Gang Rape Accused, Remembered With Fear
text: NEW DELHI —Ram Singh and Mukesh, the two brothers accused in the Delhi gang rape case, were likened by a neighbor to Gabbar Singh from the Bollywood classic “Sholay.” A particularly cold-hearted Bollywood villain, the character stirred so much fear in viewers that mothers in India sometimes told their children “to stop crying and go to sleep or Gabbar Singh will come.”

headline: Is Something Toxic Buried in China’s Financial System?
text: BEIJING — China’s economy, whizzing ahead as the West struggles, seems quite remarkable. Perhaps a little too remarkable? Like many things too good to be true, is it all a little, well, too good to be true?

headline: For Courtside Officials, a Pay Fight Resonates
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Wearing white straw hats and long-sleeved orange jerseys, they trudge in single file on and off nearly two dozen tennis courts several times each day at the Australian Open.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 17

headline: Algerian Troops Attack Site to End Hostage Standoff

headline: Torrential Rains Paralyze Indonesian Capital
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Torrential rains caused flooding that paralyzed much of the Indonesian capital, Jakarta, on Thursday, resulting in the deaths of at least four people and forcing the evacuations of tens of thousands of others.

headline: French Troops Fight Alongside Mali Army Against Islamist Occupiers
text: In “French and Malian Troops Confront Islamists in Seized Mali Village,” Adam Nossiter, Alan Cowell and Eric Schmitt report on the recent French intervention in the war in Mali.

headline: A Conversation With: Sikkim Chief Minister Pawan Kumar Chamling
text: Tucked away in the Himalayas, India’s Sikkim state has averaged an annual growth of 12.6 percent over the last eight years. The state of 600,000 people is of strategic importance to India, surrounded by China, Nepal and Bhutan on three sides. The former monarchy of Sikkim joined the Indian federation of states in 1975 and has been the most peaceful among India’s strife-torn northeastern states.

headline: Chim: A Vivid Retrospective of Europe
text: History’s fickle nature has given Chim and George Rodger a back seat to their more celebrated colleagues and co-founders of Magnum Photos, Robert Capa and Henri Cartier-Bresson.

headline: If You Could Go Anywhere, Where Would You Want to Travel?
text: Imagine money and logistics are no problem.

headline: Another Hard Day of Trying to Stay Alive
text: Out on patrol with the Afghan National Army, not an American solider in sight.

headline: Which Way Did the Taliban Go?
text: The village was abandoned. Streets deserted. Houses empty. Behind the central mosque rose a steep escarpment. Behind the escarpment mountains upon mountains. Up there — above the timberline, among the peaks — a white Taliban flag whipped in the wind. Several Afghan soldiers were admiring it when a stunted and contorted person emerged from an alley. Dressed in rags, he waved a hennaed fist at them and wailed. Tears streamed down his face. Most of the soldiers ignored him. Some laughed uncomfortably. A few jabbed their rifles at his chest and simulated shooting. The man carried on undeterred — reproaching them in strange tongues.

headline: Pakistani Preacher Ends Protest in Government Deal
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, the preacher turned political activist who led thousands of his supporters to occupy the heart of the Pakistani capital, ended his protest on Thursday night after the government granted his party largely symbolic input into the country’s electoral process.

headline: Jordan Says It Won’t Accept New Refugees if Syria Falls
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the latest sign of the intense pressures Syria’s war has placed on its neighbors, Jordan’s prime minister said Thursday that his country would not accept thousands of new refugees likely to flee Syria if President Bashar al-Assad’s government collapsed.

headline: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions About the Fafsa
text: Now that most college applications are in, it is time for those student applicants (and their parents) to submit what may be the most vital piece of their financial aid plans: the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

headline: A Delicate Mating Game of Partners for Mixed Doubles
text: MELBOURNE, Australia– Shortly before 4 p.m. Wednesday, time was running out to find a partner with whom to saunter into the male-female competition unique to the Grand Slam events.

headline: Keep Kelly Atop Police Department, New Yorkers Say in Poll
text: Whether Democrat or Republican, white or nonwhite, male or female, wealthy or not, New York City voters overwhelmingly like Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and would prefer that he remain in the job under the next mayor, a Quinnipiac University poll released on Thursday found.

headline: Officials Say Checks Won’t Be in the Mail
text: The jig is up.

headline: France Sends Reinforcements to Confront Islamist Forces in Mali
text: BAMAKO, Mali — French soldiers have battled Islamist militants in direct clashes on the ground in central Mali since just after landing last week, according to officials, and fighting continued on Thursday as hundreds of French reinforcements arrived. The ground battles expanded the campaign against the militants, who have seized much of the nation, beyond the airstrikes used initially.

headline: In Thailand, a Broader Definition of Insulting Royalty
text: BANGKOK — It has become almost routine in Thailand for judges to hand down jail sentences to those convicted of offending the country’s king. But an unusual ruling issued on Thursday appears to considerably broaden the interpretation of Thailand’s already restrictive lèse-majesté law.

headline: How Good Does Karaoke Have to Be to Qualify as Art?
text: John Brophy, the mastermind of America’s greatest karaoke night, lives in a well-kept bungalow in a neighborhood of small homes in southeast Portland, Ore. When I visited on a weekday afternoon last spring, Brophy, then 36, wore a ringer T-shirt and dark jeans. His wrist was encircled by a half-dozen bracelets, and his dark hair swooped in front of his face. Like many Portlanders, he’s in a band, called Gingerbread Patriots, although currently the band is on hiatus — the “Shows” section of the Gingerbread Patriots Web site is empty but for the words “2009 will bring shows shows and more shows!”

headline: What I Sang on My Epic Karaoke Odyssey
text: For this weekend’s magazine, I wrote about my epic six-day karaoke odyssey in Portland, Ore., hoping to figure out why this city’s karaoke scene is so ridiculously vibrant. I visited karaoke nights at tiki bars, strip clubs, comedy clubs, honky-tonks and pizza places, interviewing K.J.s (karaoke jocks), fans, strippers and Portland’s mayor. But I also, of course, sang. A lot.

headline: Maybe There Is Such a Thing as Bad Publicity
text: In part because we are a social enterprise with a mission that most people support — keeping waste out of landfills and incinerators — TerraCycle has been blessed with a lot of good publicity. In fact, we talk about having what we call a “negative-cost” media department that in 2012 generated more than 4,500 articles around the world. That’s more than 12 articles per day! (You can see an example of this coverage here.) We call the department negative-cost because we have been able to produce marketing — books, TV shows — that earns us money while also promoting the company.

headline: Louisville Slugger
text: The Pendennis Club in Louisville, Ky., is a big Georgian pile that might have appeared in the Thackeray novel it was named for, full of wealthy afternoon nappers and drawling black-tie gentry. In the early part of the last century, the club’s headwaiter was a black man named Henry Bain. His contribution to the world was at least as important as the newspapers and racehorses, banks and bridges sired by the white club members he served. Bain invented a sauce.

headline: Jan. 17 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
text: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web. On Thursday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called on the nation’s mayors to support the White House gun measures, and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appointed a task force to look beyond gun control at mental illness, addiction and other underlying causes of gun violence

headline: Conference Title Game Probabilities, and the Kaepernick Effect
text: The second-year quarterback Colin Kaepernick has certainly fulfilled the expectations of 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh, who elected to start him over the veteran Alex Smith midway through the season. Kaepernick has proved to be a definite upgrade, bringing two new dimensions to the 49ers’ offense: his ability to run and his ability to throw deep. It’s very difficult to assess the value of a player like Kaepernick, but let’s try anyway.

headline: How We Come Up With Our Big, Important Chart
text: The Big, Important Chart on The One-Page Magazine allows me to fulfill a pretty basic impulse: measure and rate things. Being a comedian in real life, I especially appreciate the opportunity to arbitrarily assign mathematical meaning to material that does not necessarily warrant it, like the length of Gerard Butler’s beard or the heroism of Adam West’s Batman versus Christian Bale’s.

headline: The Countersettlement
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Last Friday 200 Palestinians made their way to the top of the hill east of Al Zaim, a village near Jerusalem, in a zone known as E1, which the Israeli government has designated for Israeli settlements. Setting up 20 tents amid boulders and balding patches of grass, they announced the establishment of the village of Bab al-Shams (Gate of the Sun, in Arabic) “by order of the people, without permission from the occupation, or any other body.”

headline: All Your Base Are Belong To Us: What Is the Question?
text: OK, we are indeed, as Steve Randy Waldman says, all dorks, and so are you if you are reading this. What’s more, we’re inarticulate dorks, or so it seems.

headline: A Mending Spain Finds Willing Bond Buyers
text: MADRID — January is turning out to be a bumper month for Spain and some of the euro zone economies most in need of debt financing, with governments and companies flooding the market with bonds that have sold at significantly lower interest rates than just a few months ago.

headline: Daily Report: Europe Weighs Requiring Firms to Disclose Data Breaches
text: To combat a rise in cybercrime, the European Commission is considering a plan to require companies that store data on the Internet — like Microsoft, Apple, Google and I.B.M. — to report the loss or theft of personal information in the 27-nation bloc or risk sanctions and fines, Kevin J. O’Brien reports Thursday in The International Herald Tribune and The New York Times.

headline: On the Non-equivalence of Greenhouse Gases and Entitlement Spending
text: One fairly common trope in budget discussions – I’m pretty sure I’ve done it myself, somewhere along the line – is to compare attitudes toward fiscal issues and those toward environmental issues. The usual version, which I must have used, is to compare attitudes toward the long run: pointing out how strange it is that many people profess to be deeply concerned about the state of the Social Security trust fund in the year 2037, while being apparently indifferent to the state of the climate around the same time, which is all too likely to involve things like a permanent drought in the southwest and so on.

headline: Profit Drops 63% at Bank of America After Mortgage Settlements
text: 10:12 a.m. | Updated

headline: Test for Tomic After a Year of Tumult
text: MELBOURNE — Despite Bernard Tomic’s impish reminder, Roger Federer did indeed manage to make it to the third round of another Australian Open.

text: Q.

headline: Facebook’s Other Big Disruption
text: Facebook just made a potentially game-changing announcement. It got less fanfare than Tuesday’s announcement that it is going into the social search business, but this other announcement may have bigger long-term implications for the technology industry.

text: From the editorial page

headline: Time and Other Collaborators
text: OVER the last half-century few artists have explored impermanence — in art and life — quite as thoroughly as Dieter Roth, the wildly experimental Swiss-German jack-of-all-trades who died in 1998.

headline: Bat Fungus Spreads in Kentucky
text: Officials have confirmed the presence of a deadly bat fungus in Mammoth Cave National Park in Kentucky. The fungus has already killed millions of bats across the Northeast and in the Midwest.

text: Citigroup, which has been working to cut costs and unload troubled assets, continues to struggle under the weight of its mortgage woes.

headline: New Delhi Gang-Rape Case Is Expected to Move to Fast-Track Court
text: NEW DELHI — Two weeks after court proceedings began against the five men accused in a gang rape that sparked widespread protests in India, the case is scheduled to be moved to a special fast-track court created for rape cases, defense lawyers said Thursday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Levity Gets a Screening at Sundance, and Questions for Armstrong
text: The Sundance Film Festival, which gets under way Thursday in Park City, Utah, has long had a reputation for showcasing dark, sobering films. Now the festival is getting a face-lift, of sorts, Brooks Barnes writes in The Times. The event has nearly tripled the number of comedies appearing in its top three categories, a lineup that should leaven the mood and bring it line with the festive, glitzy atmosphere that pervades the ski town when the festival is in session.

text: Big troubles with the Dreamliner.

headline: Thursday Reading: A Flu Shot, Even if You’ve Had the Flu?
text: Do I need a flu shot if I’ve already had the flu, F.A.A. grounds Boeing 787s, Rossignol rentals introduce new ski technology and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Mortgage Woes Weigh on Bank of America
text: Bank of America continues to work through mortgage woes stemming from its acquisition of Countrywide Financial. The bank reported a widely expected 63 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit after settling claims over its mortgage business. The earnings of $732 million amounted to 3 cents a share, narrowly beating estimates of 2 cents a share, based on analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. The bank’s quarterly revenue was down about 25 percent, to $18.7 billion. The conference call is scheduled for 8:30 a.m.

headline: Breaking the Mold | Takuro Kuwata
text: Takuro Kuwata’s gem-studded vessels, in vivid Pop Art reds and blues, appear far removed from traditional Japanese tea ceremony ware. Similarly, the artist’s sherbet-hued bowls — malleable-looking structures with cracked, milk-white armors of glaze — could only be surreal, even psychedelic renderings of tea ceremony ceramics.

headline: Measuring the Success of Online Education
text: One of the dirty secrets about MOOCs — massive open online courses — is that they are not very effective, at least if you measure effectiveness in terms of completion rates.

headline: Jihadist Kingpin Suspected in Hostage Seizure
text: LONDON — Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the one-eyed smuggler-jihadist said to be behind the seizure of foreign hostages at a gas plant in Algeria, has been a notorious kingpin of the Sahara for more than a decade.

headline: Canada Pension Plan Unit to Join K.K.R. Merchant Banking Venture
text: An arm of the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board said on Thursday that it would be the latest partner in a merchant banking business run by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: New Barclays Chief Tells Staff to Accept Changes or Leave
text: LONDON – Antony P. Jenkins, the new chief executive of Barclays, has told employees who are unwilling to buy into the British bank’s push to rebuild its reputation to leave the bank.

headline: Rick Owens
text: Men’s fall 2013 collections in Paris.

headline: What to See in 2013
text: This time of year, museums around the world herald their major exhibitions. Here is a selection of those opening in the first half of 2013 that promise food for thought and feasts for the eyes, listed in the order in which they will open their doors.

headline: Ken Salazar’s Legacy
text: The Obama administration will soon lose three of its most public-spirited and progressive players on environmental policy. Lisa Jackson made great strides on climate and clean air issues as head of the Environmental Protection Agency. Jane Lubchenco worked tirelessly and creatively to resist the decline in threatened fish populations as boss of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Both announced their wish to return to private life last month. The latest departure is Ken Salazar, who said Wednesday that he will leave his post as interior secretary in a few weeks.

headline: The Cleric in the Container
text: LONDON — Between 25,000 and 50,000 people marched on Islamabad this week to demand the resignation of the government and electoral reforms. At the head of the movement is Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, a cleric who recently returned to Pakistan from Canada.

headline: Republicans May Offer Short-Term Extension of Borrowing Limit
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. — Gathered for a retreat to map out how to manage coming confrontations with President Obama and Congressional Democrats, often combative House Republicans seemed on Thursday to be looking for a quick way out of one imminent fight.

headline: A Spot-On Impression of a Stubborn Survivor
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Knicks’ Wallace Says He’ll Play Again This Season
text: LONDON — Coach Mike Woodson and Rasheed Wallace have played down suggestions that the Knicks forward may miss the rest of the season with a foot injury.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Boston Globe: How to cook in your fireplace: roast peppers or rest a heavy pot of beans in the embers. — Julia Moskin

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Pentatina for Five Vowels’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “Pentatina for Five Vowels,” a poem by Campbell McGrath with an article, “Why You Won’t Be the Person You Expect to Be” by John Tierney, and the related video, above.

headline: Fighting for Light Amid Urban Noir
text: After sundown the familiar, big, beautiful, soul-dirty town in “Broken City” looks as if it were built from shattered glass. That’s especially true from the air, where the director, Allen Hughes, likes to take a god’s-eye measure of what’s below, the camera gliding over the glittering lights and shadows as black as the abyss. This is a place so ominous that the sun never seems to shine, leaving the gray streets and people washed in an icy blue light. One glance and it’s obvious that this is New York, though it’s a city Mr. Hughes has painted a darker shade of noir.

headline: Difficult Choices on Debt if the U.S. Hits the Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — By mid-February or early March, the United States could face an unprecedented default unless it raises its debt ceiling, the Treasury Department said this week.

headline: Outsize Personality Joins, and Jostles, Mayor’s Race
text: To pump himself up for tense negotiations with the City Council, Joseph J. Lhota listened to the soaring theme song to the film “Top Gun,” and, afterward, relaxed to the soothing tones of Gregorian chants.

headline: Lying Becomes an Official Sport
text: Let’s just go ahead and declare this the national day of lying in sports. We have such a spectacular range of them on display, the world of sports lies is starting to look like the cereal aisle at a grocery store. It’s overwhelming. It was enough that we were going to be treated Thursday night to the latest in the Lance Armstrong lie fest — the Oprah talk-show confession — but then we got Chip Kelly’s pivot from “I’m staying at Oregon” to “the Eagles’ money smells so good.” And those are only the hors d’oeuvres before you hit the all-you-can-eat buffet of lies that is the story of Notre Dame linebacker Manti Te’o’s fabricated dead girlfriend.
