headline: Gun Control and Suicide
text: If you’re looking for a reason to be skeptical that the gun control proposals President Obama unveiled yesterday would actually have an impact on violent crime, look no further than the historical examples invoked by gun control advocates praising the White House’s effort:

headline: Excerpt: 'Newsreaders'
text: The newsmagazine parody, a spin-off of "Childrens Hospital," begins Jan. 17 on Adult Swim.

headline: ‘Reporting’ the News for Adult Swim
text: WHENEVER “Childrens Hospital,” the kinetically goofy medical show spoof on Adult Swim, wants to push its satire even further into the meta-sphere, it brings in Louis La Fonda. He’s the inept fake newsman, played by the comic actor Mather Zickel, who “reports” on the show’s shenanigans for the parody-within-a-parody “20/20” knockoff, “Newsreaders.”

headline: Louis Vuitton
text: Men’s fall 2013 collections in Paris.

headline: Flu Season Strikes Again ... and Again
text: The flu comes every year and this year’s strain has hit early and hard. The Times’s Donald G. McNeil Jr. says plenty of people are sick, but don’t just blame influenza.

headline: Ben Affleck, Resurgent Yet Again
text: Early on, “Argo” was seen as a front-runner for awards this season: in August it was shown in a sneak preview at the Telluride Film Festival, where “The King’s Speech” started its journey to best picture, and in September it received a standing ovation at the Toronto International Film Festival, the same response that “Slumdog Millionaire,” another best picture winner, received. But as late arrivals like “Lincoln,” “Les Misérables” and “Zero Dark Thirty” picked up steam, “Argo” began to seem like an underdog, a status more or less solidified when the film received seven Oscar nominations but not one for its director, Ben Affleck, a nod usually necessary for a best-picture win.

headline: Jared Diamond: By the Book
text: The author of “The World Until Yesterday” says that if he had to recommend one book of geography to children, he would suggest his own “Guns, Germs, and Steel.”

headline: The Fallout of a Chance Medical Finding
text: An incidental finding — I was convinced of it. My patient had undergone a CT scan of the abdomen at another hospital because of stomach pains and “incidentally noted” was a 2-centimeter mass in her adrenal gland. She brought in the report for me to see, nervous that she might have cancer.

headline: Why Am I Getting Mellower?
text: You are a member in good standing of an elite group dedicated to the proposition that the pursuit of happiness is for suckers. “Baby Boomers: The Gloomiest Generation,” is how the Pew Research Center put it a few years ago after conducting a survey.

headline: Drinking Like a Poet
text: One chilly evening more than a decade ago, my Glasgow-born-and-bred friend Angus Robertson greeted me at his Brooklyn Heights doorway in his kilt and sporran and welcomed me to my first Burns supper, the Scottish celebration on Jan. 25 that honors the poet Robert Burns. About 20 of us gathered around the haggis (nothing to be afraid of, basically a big mealy sausage), neeps and tatties (that’s turnips and potatoes) and whisky-fortified gravy. Then the time arrived for dessert, poetry, song and whisky. Lots of Scotch whisky, selected with care by our hosts.

headline: The Road to Bamian
text: For the people of Bamian, the roads, paved for the first time in the Afghan province’s history, have brought both opportunity and peril.

text: TimesCast: Policy makers weigh options and appetite for involvement. | Ben Affleck on his inspiration for “Argo.” | Responding to a virulent flu season.

text: Pelicans at the Delhi zoo.

headline: Wheelies: The Booming Business Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: SurveyMonkey Raises Nearly $800 Million While Staying Private
text: SurveyMonkey’s fund-raising success is showing that the business of Internet surveys is worth a lot of money.

headline: An Inquiry Into Discolored Snow
text: As I wrote last Friday, after a decade of legal battles, Arizona Snowbowl recently became the world’s first ski area \to make snow totally out of wastewater, piped directly from the sewage treatment plant in neighboring Flagstaff. That the snow emerging from the snow guns was streaked with a yellow hue raised eyebrows and stirred environmental and health concerns.

headline: U.S. Weighing Policy Options in Mali
text: The Times's Mark Mazzetti talks about the challenges facing Washington in crafting a strategy for dealing with Islamist militants in Mali.

headline: Seth MacFarlane on Hosting: ‘It Could Be a Disaster. Who Knows?’
text: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler pulled in high ratings and good reactions for their debut as hosts of the Golden Globes, which means that Seth MacFarlane, neophyte host of the Oscars, may be sweating.

headline: Monument to a City
text: My wife and I began to unconsciously prepare ourselves for living in Washington, D.C., long before we actually moved to the city. Over the course of three years and half a dozen trips from our apartment in Paris to my parents’ home deep in the Virginia suburbs, we imagined hypothetical versions of our life there. We wandered through Georgetown and pictured ourselves living in a colonial-style mansion on a cobblestone road. We went out to eat in Columbia Heights and imagined life on a not-too-quiet street near our favorite strip of restaurants and bars.

headline: Young People Paying Off Card Debt More Slowly
text: Younger Americans not only borrow heavily on their credit cards, but they repay the debt at slower rates than previous generations, new research from Ohio State University finds.

headline: Philadelphia Vandalism of Quaker Building Is Seen by Some as Union Intimidation
text: PHILADELPHIA — It was several weeks ago when vandals struck the building site, setting fire to a crane, cutting deep gashes in steel columns and loosening the bolts that anchored them. The episode resulted in about $500,000 in damage and was, the authorities believe, apparently an attempt to halt the construction of a Quaker meeting house.

headline: Memories of a Kid on a Hot Tin Roof
text: A NEW Broadway production of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” like the one scheduled to open on Jan. 17, will always ring with a certain importance in the theater world, but for me it brings on an additional spell of nostalgia. In 1974, at 10 years old, I landed a thrill of a summer job as one of the kids in “Cat” — those “no-neck monsters” as Tennessee Williams so memorably called them. My parents had responded to an ad for open auditions at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn. I was offered the role, the production turned out to be a hit, and we transferred to New York the following fall.

headline: Ratings for “American Idol” Premiere Are Down Again
text: It looks like those who predicted “American Idol” would be down another 20 percent this year — despite Fox’s best efforts to pump it up with new judges like Mariah Carey and Nicky Minaj – could get jobs posting betting lines in Las Vegas.

headline: Solving Bus Strike’s Impact on Special Needs Students Isn’t Simple
text: New York City’s bus strike is disproportionately affecting one of its most vulnerable populations: children with special needs, whose symptoms or travel limitations can make it extremely challenging for their parents to get them to school using other methods of transportation. Marie Myung-Ok Lee, who has written for about the challenges and joys of raising a child with developmental disabilities, including autism, in New York City, reminded me yesterday that children like her son depend on continuity and predictability in ways that children without his symptoms do not. And many children in the city’s special education programs present particular challenges for bus drivers and their aides. They may be prone to violent tantrums, or need physical help. It’s a different job, and a different relationship, than the phrase “bus driver” immediately suggests.

headline: A Gentle Giant of a Catfish Fades From Sight
text: The captain leaned heavily into his pole, nudging the boat’s nose off the sandy bank.  As the boat swung into the swift current of the Mekong, he scrambled back behind the wheel, the engine roared, and we resumed our downstream journey toward Luang Prabang, Laos.

headline: Arizona Congresswoman Hires Immigrant Activist After She Details Raid
text: PHOENIX — Erika Andiola, the young immigrant activist who prompted outrage on social media last week after her messages and tearful video chronicled the arrests of her mother and brother during an immigration raid here, is the new outreach director for Representative Kyrsten Sinema, the freshman congresswoman known for her staunch opposition to Arizona’s stance on illegal immigration.

headline: From Sketch to Stage: ‘The House of von Macramé'
text: A look at Tristan Raines’s costume design for the new pop musical at the Bushwick Starr.

headline: Armstrong Stripped of 2000 Olympic Medal
text: On the eve of Lance Armstrong’s public admission that he used performance-enhancing drugs during his cycling career, he was stripped of yet another prize: his bronze medal from the 2000 Sydney Olympics.

headline: Officials Seek Energy Drink Information
text: Three Democratic lawmakers sent letters to 14 marketers of highly caffeinated energy drinks on Thursday requesting information about the products’ ingredients and any company studies showing their risks and benefits to children and young people.

headline: Double Duty Tests Serena Williams’s Ankle, And it Holds Up
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — There may never have been so much doubt about how a player would respond after a 6-0, 6-0 victory.

headline: Museum of Arts and Design Director Announces Departure
text: After 16 years as the director of the Museum of Arts and Design, Holly Hotchner, 61, has announced that she will step down from her position at the end of April.

text: The filmmaker Jason DaSilva reveals the challenges for the disabled in navigating New York City’s public transportation system.

text: The travel booking site Orbitz is looking to inspire you with more than good deals.

text: Via Salon

headline: Russian Comforts on Antarctic Ice
text: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee, Antarctica.

headline: Gun Violence Is a Topic of Discussion at Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah — “Gun” is a short film about a man who buys a handgun for protection and becomes obsessed with the newfound sense of power it gives him. “Valentine Road,” a documentary, looks at a school shooting in California. “Blue Caprice” was inspired by the 2002 Beltway sniper attacks.

headline: MoMA Names Winner of 14th Young Architects Program
text: Starting in late June, the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, will feature a tall steel frame that is balanced in place with large fabric containers filled with water. The project was designed by Caroline O’Donnell of Ithaca, N.Y., whose firm, CODA, has been selected as the winner of the annual Young Architects Program in New York.

headline: ‘The Long Wait’
text: I love New York. When I was younger, the city was my playground. You could find me on any given weekend catching brunch with a friend at a cafe, going to an East Village restaurant for dinner and then hopping the subway to a nightclub in Chelsea. But at age 25, nine years ago, I was told I had multiple sclerosis, and I saw my freedoms slowly vanish. I grew up quickly, learning to plan daily activities with precise schedules and strategies for getting from one place to another, while trying to maintain some semblance of the life I’d enjoyed. It’s not M.S. that exhausts me, it’s the barriers that prevent me from conducting my daily activities. Public-transportation challenges have turned my playground into a sand pit.

headline: Dining, Discs and More in Durham, N.C.
text: Take a bite of this town’s motor-to-mortar movement and play a round of golf in the woods on a trip around this Southern city.

headline: 36 Hours in Durham, N.C.
text: THE tobacco and textile industries left their imprint on Durham long ago, but now the historic brick mills and repurposed factories form the backdrop of North Carolina’s re-energized Bull City. Recently, artist studios and upstart galleries have multiplied in the flourishing downtown area, where new bakeries, pizzerias, tapas bars and food trucks — and trailers and buses and even the odd tricycle — seem to surface at every turn. Since Big Tobacco is dead, consider this cool mix of culture and food the new Durham blend.

headline: 3 Tips for Finding Rental Car Deals
text: WITH airfares and hotel rates rising last year, it’s some consolation that prices for rental cars actually decreased on average, and are expected to remain about the same in 2013.

headline: Restaurant Report: The Grove in Toronto
text: English cuisine has taken its hits, many of them, at least in recent years, unjustifiably. Plenty of chefs are doing exciting and innovative things in kitchens across Britain. But beyond the generic fish-and-chips gastro pub, English cuisine has not caught on in other countries.

headline: The Story of Hip-Hop
text: The rap superstar Jay-Z performed eight concerts in September to open the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. It was a crowning moment both for the borough and for this native son, born Shawn Carter, who grew up in the Marcy Houses just up the street in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

headline: Winfrey’s Channel Is Set to Break Through
text: Last Tuesday afternoon, Oprah Winfrey called the co-presidents of her cable channel OWN with some jump-on-the-couch-with-joy news. “Lance wants to talk,” she said, referring to Lance Armstrong, whom she had been courting for a confessional interview about his long-denied use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Pauline Phillips, Flinty Adviser to Millions as Dear Abby, Dies at 94
text: Dear Abby: My wife sleeps in the raw. Then she showers, brushes her teeth and fixes our breakfast — still in the buff. We’re newlyweds and there are just the two of us, so I suppose there’s really nothing wrong with it. What do you think? — Ed

headline: Facebook App Adds Free Voice Calls. Will Anyone Care?
text: Facebook doesn’t just want you to poke, message and stalk your friends. Now it wants you to actually talk to them.

headline: U.S. Calls for ‘Cooler Heads’ in Dispute Over Asian Islands
text: TOKYO — A top American diplomat called Thursday for “cooler heads to prevail” in an emotional quarrel over disputed islands that has raised tensions in Asia, and he urged the leaders of China and Japan to begin private consultations to avoid a potentially dangerous escalation.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: A Guest List That’s About Who You Know, and Don’t Know

headline: Preoccupying My Mind With Summer Plans as Colleges Decide My Fate
text: With the college application process now complete on my end, I have all the time in the world to focus on my class 12 board examinations.

headline: 7-Year-Old Takes Gun to School
text: A handgun was found in the backpack of a 7-year-old student at a public elementary school in Queens on Thursday morning, New York City officials said, leading to a tense few hours as the school was placed on lockdown while the police made sure there was no danger.

headline: Rendering a City With a Blowtorch
text: Something mythic — a sight to inspire fear and wonder — tears its way into existence toward the end of “Minsk, 2011,” the beautiful and brutal performance piece from the Belarus Free Theater. Like many of the richest moments in theater, this one involves very simple elements: black ink, a long roll of brown paper and a naked woman.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Brotherly Love
text: There are a lot of things about having cancer in your 20s that feel absurd. One of those instances was when I found myself calling my brother Adam on Skype while he was studying abroad in Argentina to tell him that I had just been diagnosed with leukemia and that — no pressure — he was my only hope for a cure.

headline: Reporting in The Times on Football Star’s Nonexistent Girlfriend Was Glancing, but Still Troubling
text: The truly strange – and still unfolding – tale of the Notre Dame football star and his nonexistent dead girlfriend has lessons for journalists, including those at The Times.

headline: Tanoshi
text: Inside the omakase surprise of a sushi restaurant on the Upper East Side.

headline: Car-Seat Installation in the Real World: Harder Than It Looks
text: Where’s the real-world video of car-seat installation?

headline: Web Hunt for DNA Sequences Leaves Privacy Compromised
text: The genetic data posted online seemed perfectly anonymous — strings of billions of DNA letters from more than 1,000 people. But all it took was some clever sleuthing on the Web for a genetics researcher to identify five people he randomly selected from the study group. Not only that, he found their entire families, even though the relatives had no part in the study — identifying nearly 50 people.

headline: Sushi That Delights in the Details
text: “DON’T WAIT TOO LONG to eat,” the waiter half-whispered, bending slightly so the other diners wouldn’t hear. “The seaweed will lose its crispness.”

headline: Photos of The Moment | 3.1 Phillip Lim
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Simpler Form for Home Office Deductions
text: If you work at a home-based business, the Internal Revenue Service has some (potentially) good news: It’s going to offer a simpler option for taking a tax deduction for home offices.

headline: The Appetite Workout
text: Every January, many people start working out, hoping to lose weight. But as studies attest, exercise often produces little or no weight loss — and even weight gain — and resolutions are soon abandoned. But new science suggests that if you stick with the right kind of exercise, you may change how your body interacts with food. It’s more than a matter of burning calories; exercise also affects hormones.

headline: Channel Surfing: Faking It With ‘Newsreaders’
text: In the narrow programming niche of 15-minute late-night television comedies, there is a handful of auteurs: Seth Green (“Robot Chicken”), Jon Glaser (“Delocated”) and Rob Corddry (“Children’s Hospital”). Their faces pop up before midnight — Mr. Corddry on “Ben and Kate,” Mr. Glaser on “Parks and Recreation,” Mr. Green, reunited with his “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” co-star Alyson Hannigan, on a recent episode of “How I Met Your Mother” — but in the wee hours they’re nobody’s guest star.

headline: New York City Elections Are Becoming Ever More Costly
text: It’s often been said that democracy can be messy. In New York City, it’s also increasingly expensive, especially the way the Board of Elections operates.

headline: Quirks of the Game: For Coaches, a Tough Road Back to Super Bowl
text: First, Robert Griffin III’s knee buckled and took the Washington Redskins’ season down with it, then Peyton Manning took a knee and down went the Denver Broncos’ season. Both Mike Shanahan and John Fox are being questioned for their coaching decisions, but these were more than typical playoff losses — both men lost out on a chance to make history.

headline: Dell’s Ups and Downs With Options
text: It was an amazing American success story, in which a college student in his dorm room created what became one of the largest computer companies in the world. In the 1990s, its share price tripled in each of three consecutive years. But after the bubble burst, it resorted to accounting fraud to persuade investors it was doing better than it really was.

headline: Three Windows 8 Features Worth Celebrating
text: You already know my overall opinion of Windows 8: that it’s two very good operating systems — one for touch screens, one for mouse and keyboard — idiotically superimposed on each other. You wind up with duplicate everything: two Web browsers, two help systems, two search features, two control panels (actually three, but never mind). It’s very confusing.

headline: No Deal on Teacher Evaluations; City Risks Losing $450 Million
text: The Bloomberg administration and New York City’s teachers’ union said Thursday that they had failed to reach a deal on a new system for evaluating 75,000 public school teachers, putting the city into immediate danger of losing out on up to $450 million in state and federal money and raising the possibility of cuts to staff and programs.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2013 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Robson Does the Dirty Work in Beating Kvitova
text: Laura Robson of Great Britain prevailed over Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic in an error-filled match at the Australia Open Friday that was nonetheless dramatic. In a match pitting two powerful lefthanders, each seeking to take control of the point with big first-strike tennis, Robson made the necessary adjustments to will her way to a stunning upset, 2-6, 6-3, 11-9, over Kvitova, the No. 8 seed and the 2011 Wimbledon champion.

headline: Dries Van Noten
text: Men’s fall 2013 collections in Paris.

headline: Lance Armstrong’s Other Career: Auto Pitchman
text: On a logistical level, the Tour de France is as much a chaotic auto rally as it is about the cyclists. Hundreds of cars carrying team officials, doctors, mechanics, reporters and V.I.P.’s constantly jostle for position in front of and behind the riders while dozens of motorbikes flit in between to add to the general noise and confusion.

headline: Few Silver Linings in Gloomy Bank Reports
text: Bank of America and Citigroup are giving investors nothing but reasons to fret.

headline: Livestrong and the Perils of Corporate Sponsorships
text: On Tuesday, Sporting Kansas City announced it had severed its sponsorship agreement with Livestrong, the cancer charity founded by the disgraced cyclist Lance Armstrong. The announcement came two days before Armstrong was to confess on television to doping during his career, which included seven Tour de France titles.

headline: A Smattering of Food Links
text: Potentially big: A superior court in Hyde County, N.C., ruled that the state has authority to require Rose Acre Farms, a facility housing nearly four million egg-laying hens, to be regulated under the federal Clean Water Act because of pollutants released from ventilation fans in the henhouses. Unprecedented. The F.D.A. proposed two sweeping rules aimed at preventing the contamination of produce and processed foods, taking a long-awaited step toward codifying the food safety law that Congress passed two years ago. And New Mexico lawmakers have introduced legislation that calls for the mandatory labeling of G.M.O.s within the state. Washington State joins the state, along with a half-dozen others.

headline: What Was Dear Abby’s Most Helpful Advice?
text: Pauline Phillips, who was better known for nearly 60 years as Abigail Van Buren, the author of the syndicated column Dear Abby, died Wednesday in Minneapolis at 94, her syndicate said in a statement.

headline: Look of The Moment | Marion Cotillard
text: The Look: Mad for Plaid. A dress with a trompe l’oeil tartanesque effect in sequins is made even prettier with pastel rose appliqués.

headline: At Republican Retreat, Ryan Urges Unity on Fiscal Issues
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. — As House Republicans hunkered down here for a two-day retreat to discuss the future of their conference, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin warned members that they had to “recognize the realities of the divided government that we have” and urged members to unite behind leadership on the coming fiscal debates.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Meredith Vieira Said to Be in Talks for Daytime Show
text: Meredith Vieira, the former co-host of NBC’s “Today” show, is in talks with another division of NBCUniversal about hosting a syndicated talk show.

headline: News and ‘News Analysis': Navigating Fact and Opinion in The Times
text: Overview | Why is it important to be critical consumers of news media? How do we discern fact from opinion in The New York Times, and in other news reports? In this lesson, students will become familiar with the layout of the NYTimes.com home page and learn how news and opinion articles are labeled and organized for clarity. Then students will carefully consider the difference between fact and opinion and create guiding questions to help discern between the two when reading a news or opinion piece from any news source. Finally, they will use their guiding questions to compare two pieces on the same news event, separating opinion from fact on the sentence level.

headline: Digital Notes: Amazon Enters Apple’s Phones to Compete on Music Downloads
text: Amazon has stepped up its competition against iTunes with a version of its MP3 store for Apple’s iPhones and iPod Touch devices.

headline: Rosa Parks Statue to Be Added to the Capitol
text: Rosa Parks, the civil rights leader, will become the first African-American woman to have her likeness depicted in the Capitol’s Statuary Hall when a statue of her is installed later this year, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said in an interview Thursday.

headline: Drawing Upon Diverse Interviews
text: One of the first projects done in the United States by the French-born, British-raised artist Alexandre Singh was a sprawling, delirious collaboration with Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe titled “Hello Meth Lab in the Sun,” installed at the Ballroom in Marfa, Tex., in 2008. (Mr. Freeman and Mr. Lowe went on to show a similar version in New York.) It was a virtuosic display — a warren of varied spaces that included a motel check-in counter, a hippie hide-out and an abandoned meth lab — that was perfectly suited to that decadent art-world moment and that piggybacked on the extreme environments of artists like Mike Nelson, Christoph Büchel and Gregor Schneider.

headline: A Beat Poet’s Colorful Crew, in Black and White
text: Allen Ginsberg (1926-1997) was a great poet but not a great photographer. So while “Beat Memories: The Photographs of Allen Ginsberg” at the Grey Art Gallery is an interesting exhibition, it is in certain ways disappointing. The best you can say about the pictures Ginsberg took during two periods in which he dabbled in the medium — the ’50s and early ’60s and the ’80s and ’90s — is that they are the works of a competent amateur. The bigger disappointment, however, is that much of the history that Ginsberg lived through and did so much to alter as a countercultural activist is missing.

headline: A. Scott Berg to Publish Biography of Woodrow Wilson
text: A decade after he began work on it, A. Scott Berg, the author of best-selling biographies of Katharine Hepburn and Charles Lindbergh, has finished his biography of Woodrow Wilson. Titled “Wilson,” it will be published in September, G. P. Putnam’s Sons said Thursday.

headline: Few Possibilities for Prosecution at JPMorgan
text: The internal report released by JPMorgan Chase this week related to a disastrous bet on a hedging strategy may not be a good guidebook for federal prosecutors.

headline: 16.2 Million Vehicles Recalled in 2012, Safety Agency Says
text: A total of 16.2 million vehicles were recalled last year, with slightly more than half made by Toyota and Honda, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Thursday.

headline: Russia Warns of Retaliation Over U.S. Ruling on a Jewish Collection
text: MOSCOW — The Russian government warned angrily on Thursday that it would retaliate against any effort by the United States to enforce a ruling by a federal judge in Washington who has ordered Russia to pay fines of $50,000 a day for refusing to return a disputed collection of Jewish books and documents to the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic group.

headline: A Popularity Present for Michelle Obama
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll offers a gift of another sort for Michelle Obama on her 49th birthday Thursday – Americans’ positive views of her outstrip the negative by about 4 to 1.

headline: Biden Getting an Autobiography From The Onion (Whether He Wants It or Not)
text: “Hombre, you’ve just done Uncle Joe a real solid buying this book,” begins the foreword to a new autobiography attributed to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. “I ain’t the kind of guy who forgets his debts. Next time we meet there’s a tallboy of ice cold Beast on me. And if you’re a lady, I know a few tricks to repay you with interest, if you catch my drift.”

headline: Thompson Says He Wouldn’t Raise Taxes if Elected Mayor
text: Differentiating himself from his likely Democratic rivals in the mayoral race, William C. Thompson Jr. vowed on Thursday that he would not raise taxes if elected.

headline: What Issue? Stern Wants More Audio Taping at N.B.A. Games
text: LONDON — In his first public comments on the Knicks’ use of recording microphones at Madison Square Garden last weekend, N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern said that he doubted there was any issue for him to address and that he would actually like to see “more mikes around” in league arenas so that the audio records of games would be “more robust” than they are now.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Knicks Defeat Pistons in London
text: As the N.B.A. continues its plan to extend its brand globally, the Knicks played the Detroit Pistons before a sold-out crowd at the O2 Arena in London. Steven Cotton will supply occasional updates from the game.

headline: A Swollen Stream of Consciousness
text: Ken Kesey, the author of that great American novel of mental illness “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” once cited with approval a precept of his father’s: “Good writing ain’t necessarily good reading.”

headline: Anna Deavere Smith Wins Gish Prize
text: One of the largest prizes awarded in the arts, the $300,000 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, is going to the actress and author Anna Deavere Smith.

headline: Eyes Wide Shut
text: That crunching sound you hear is Lawrence Wright bending over backward to be fair to Scientology. Every deceptive comparison with Mormonism and other religions is given a respectful hearing. Every ludicrous bit of church dogma is served up deadpan. This makes the book’s indictment that much more powerful. Open almost any page at random. That tape of L. Ron Hubbard, Scientology’s founder, that Wright quotes from? “It was a part of a lecture Hubbard gave in 1963, in which he talked about the between-lives period, when thetans are transported to Venus to have their memories erased.”

headline: Red Bulls Take Midfielder in Draft
text: And with their sole pick in the 2013 Major League Soccer SuperDraft, the New York Red Bulls select Georgetown midfielder Ian Christianson …

headline: Crowds Gather in Turkey to Honor 3 Kurds Killed in Paris
text: HATAY, Turkey — Tens of thousands of people gathered Thursday in the southern city of Diyarbakir to mourn the deaths of three Kurdish activists murdered in Paris last week, an outpouring that some said amounted to the largest political gathering that the Turkish authorities had ever allowed the Kurds to stage.

headline: An Uneasy Turn at the G.O.P. Retreat
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. — Well, that was awkward.

headline: Rock, Paper, Scissors, Guitar and Sound
text: Keith Rowe is 72, and the instrument he’s been associated with for nearly 50 years is an electric guitar, laid flat on a table. Near the guitar are the things he uses for manipulating the sound of the guitar or interacting with it: flat objects of various weights and hardnesses, a couple of effects pedals, a small electric fan, a wad of steel wool, a small radio, an iPod, a sound mixer.

headline: Irish Hostage Is ‘Safe and Free’ in Algeria, but Britons Are Told to Brace for Bad News
text: Following a military raid on a gas facility in Algeria, where a heavily armed group of Islamist militants took dozens of workers hostage, the Irish government confirmed on Thursday that a man from Belfast who had been part of the group taken captive was freed. The fate of other hostages remained unclear.

headline: E*Trade Names Former Barclays Executive as New Chief
text: E*Trade Financial on Thursday named Paul T. Idzik, a former executive at Barclays, as its new chief, ending a five-month search for a new leader.

headline: 2 Reports on Oil Sands Paint a Dire Picture
text: Opponents of the Keystone XL pipeline and the heavy Canadian crude oil that it would carry released two reports on Thursday asserting that the environmental impacts of the project are worse than previously estimated, and urged the Obama administration to veto it.

headline: An Evening of Finnish Pride and Germanic Brio
text: Many oppressive regimes have tried to manipulate the role of music in their citizens’ lives. The Taliban banned it almost entirely, and the Nazis prohibited performances of works by “degenerate” composers. The Soviets branded as “formalist” scores that didn’t meet the requirements of Socialist Realism, demanding patriotic and folk-tinged pieces.

headline: Intel’s Profit Falls 27% as PC Sales Drop
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel has money, smart people and resolve, but it still doesn’t have a quick fix for the deterioration of its largest market — personal computers.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 17
text: A view of the day in sports, including a Knicks-Pistons game in London and sled dog racing in France.

headline: Maybe Naked, Curvy or Clumsy, and Probably Socially Unorthodox
text: By presenting a theatrical account of human energy, each choreographer offers us a distinct view of human potential. So does each dance company and each dance festival. This week presents us with an exercise in compare-and-contrast: the American Realness festival (through Sunday) continues, just as New York City Ballet has commenced its winter season (through Feb. 24); there are days when you can go from one to the other.

headline: Meet Dave Grohl, Film Promoter
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Sundance doesn’t officially start until Thursday night. But already a rock star has given the movie crowd a master class in how to use the festival as a launching pad for a new film.

headline: The Past Is Haunting Them
text: A facetious nickname for the chilly psychological thriller “Brief Reunion” might be “The Rat and the Bat.” The rat is the movie’s wary, furtive protagonist, Aaron (Joel de la Fuente), a successful software entrepreneur who lives in a picture-perfect New Hampshire farmhouse with his wife, Lea (Alexie Gilmore). The bat is an unwelcome visitor from his past.

headline: Inquiry Questions Actions of N.B.A. Union Chief, but Finds No Criminality
text: A nine-month independent investigation determined that Billy Hunter failed in his fiduciary responsibilities as the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association and that the union’s executive board should consider replacing him.

text: New art books look at Winslow Homer in Maine, Mati Klarwein’s album covers and more.

headline: This Year’s Jazz & Heritage Festival Leans Heavily on Pop
text: Jazz acts are scarce in this year’s New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, the sprawling outdoor event that runs for two weekends in late April and early May. The headliners announced on Thursday include Billy Joel, Fleetwood Mac, Maroon 5, the Black Keys and John Mayer. The city’s spring music festival has become a potpourri of American genres, including pop, blues, jazz, funk, country, rock, gospel, zydeco and salsa. Some of the other big-name acts on the bill are Earth, Wind & Fire; Willie Nelson and Family; the Dave Matthews Band; Jill Scott; Widespread Panic; Jimmy Cliff; the Gipsy Kings; and B.B. King. Among the well-known jazz artists will be Ellis Marsalis, Nicholas Payton, Wayne Shorter and Stanley Clarke. Much of the lineup still includes musicians born in New Orleans or Louisiana, and the list of local heroes appearing this year includes Irma Thomas, the singer and pianist Allen Toussaint, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, the Nevilles and Dr. John.

headline: Old All-Stars Who Still Dazzle the Eye
text: Those of us who love the arts often deify the arcane. We don’t want to lurk with the herd as it grazes on “Lincoln.” We don’t want to get spattered by another colossal hemorrhaging of Picasso’s profligate genius.

headline: Alejandra Villagra, Jason van Dalen
text: AMONG mountaineers it’s known as the E-bomb, letting it drop that you have climbed Mount Everest — an accomplishment with an unassailable mystique, occupying a higher plane than, say, running with the bulls in Pamplona or scuba diving off the Great Barrier Reef.

headline: Former Bookkeeper Accused of Stealing From Masa
text: The thefts at Masa, the high-priced sushi restaurant in the Time Warner Center, began slowly, and in small amounts. One day in June 2011, $100 was taken from that day’s substantial sales receipts. But the amounts that went missing kept growing, and at first went unnoticed.

headline: Test Run: Maura Magazine, an iPad Mini-Mag
text: Something interesting is happening in the world of iPad publishing.

headline: It’s as Good as Glue: Mending Shattered China
text: Clunky repairs on antique china are attracting a growing circle of fans.

headline: White House Posts Videos of Children Asking Obama to Address Gun Violence
text: A day after President Obama called for broad new gun laws, the White House published on its YouTube channel videos of four children reading their own letters about guns.

headline: Will Congress Approve Obama's Gun Plan?
text: The Times's Michael D. Shear takes a look at the chances of President Obama's gun control package getting through the House and Senate.

headline: A Place to Put All Those Curiosities
text: Many exhibitions convey the propulsive force of human curiosity, but few manage to do so as engrossingly and with as much immediacy as “Rooms of Wonder: From Wunderkammer to Museum, 1599-1899,” a lavish repast of illustrated rare books and ephemera at the Grolier Club. The appetite for knowledge about foreign lands, unfamiliar animals and all the workings of the world — both natural and man-made — permeates this show, which delves into the origins of the modern museum.

headline: A New Obama Cabinet Takes Shape
text: The Times's Peter Baker examines the new team of White House advisers, including Denis R. McDonough, considered to be a top choice to replace Jacob J. Lew as the White House chief of staff.

headline: New Showcase for a Neglected Era
text: When the curator of American art at the Brooklyn Museum began work on an exhibition to coincide with next year’s anniversary of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, she happened on a trove of works from the Black Arts Movement, the cultural arm of the black power movement of the 1960s and ’70s. This was an area of the art market long neglected but recently attracting attention.

headline: 2014 Corvette Stingray Has Its New York Coming-Out Party
text: Only days after making a worldwide debut at the Detroit Auto Show on Sunday evening, the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette, now with the retro-inspired Stingray name attached to it, traveled about 600 miles east for its first appearance in New York City. Compared to the glitz and glamor that greeted the sports car upon its introduction in the Motor City, the Big Apple event was noticeably less frenetic and much more informal.

headline: Twists and Turns in Becoming a Man: A Day in Baltimore
text: By his own account Vincent is a man who knows how to handle his business, and at first glance, you might take him for a conventional kind of businessman. His trim gray suit and chunky gold wristwatch go nicely with the black Mercedes-Benz sedan parked in front of his mother’s modest Baltimore house. Vincent’s young nephew, Woody, idolizes his uncle, drawing him, in a school notebook, as a fearless, muscle-bound superhero.

headline: Society Membership Proposed for Yale Club
text: YES, it’s a filing cabinet, but the 22-story Yale Club, at Vanderbilt Avenue and 44th Street, is a very nice filing cabinet! That is, it’s incrementally more attractive than the rest of Midtown’s World War I-era buildings.

headline: The Spirits Are Back in Force in Brooklyn
text: For generations, one of the first things visitors to the Brooklyn Museum encountered was the Hall of the Americas, the two-story rotunda right off the main lobby. And when you were in it, you knew you were home. Its towering, glowering Northwest Coast totem poles were city landmarks the way the New York Public Library lions were. Its fantastic kachina dolls radiated a celebrity glow. The 2,000-year-old “Paracas Textile,” one of the world’s rarest Andean weavings, was high on the list of best-kept art secrets in town. Knowing its value made Brooklyn regulars a society of connoisseurs.
