headline: Carnegie Hall’s ‘Spring for Music’ Will Expire on Fitting Notes
text: The final performance of the final season of “Spring for Music,” an orchestra festival at Carnegie Hall, will have a fittingly morbid theme, according to programming announced on Tuesday. The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, on May 10, 2014, will present the last scene of Poulenc’s opera “Dialogues of the Carmelites,” in which a group of nuns are serially guillotined; the first New York performance of James MacMillan’s “Woman of the Apocalypse,” based on the Book of Revelation; and a mélange of Mozart music — titled “Requiem and Death in Words and Music” — centered around his completed sections of the “Requiem.” Pittsburgh’s music director, Manfred Honeck, will conduct.

headline: In Saint-Émilion, Rich and Proud of It
text: SAINT-ÉMILION, France—There is a saying in France: Vivre cachée, vivre heureux; “live hidden, live happily.” It applies especially to the country’s rich people. Not only do public displays of wealth draw the covetous gaze of tax collectors, they are frowned on by a culture that values solidarity.

headline: A Break in the Case of the Kunsthal Heist
text: Three people have been arrested in connection with the theft of seven paintings from a museum in the Netherlands, the police in Rotterdam announced Tuesday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: How ESPN Missed the Hoax Story and Hard Times at Sundance
text: ESPN had been trying to confirm the story that Manti Te’o’s girlfriend – whose apparent death from leukemia became a rallying cry for Notre Dame football and a selling-point for the linebacker’s Heisman candidacy – was a hoax. But the network was hoping for an interview with Mr. Te’o and lost the story to Deadspin.

headline: Britons Promised Vote on Europe, Again
text: LONDON — A British political leader faces dissent within his own party over the country’s membership in Europe. He promises to renegotiate the terms and to hold a referendum on the issue if he wins the next election.

headline: Clinton’s Full Statement on Benghazi Attack
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday on the September attack in Benghazi.

headline: From Jolie-ing at the Oscars to a Sundance Ovation
text: PARK CITY, Utah – Nat Faxon and Jim Rash arrived at Sundance with their first feature, “The Way, Way Back,” in an enviable position: they’re already Oscar winners. Mr. Faxon and Mr. Rash took the prize last year, along with Alexander Payne, for adapting the screenplay for “The Descendants.” They also created one of the more memorable memes of the show. But more on that later.

headline: I.M.F. Forecasts Modest Global Economic Growth
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund said on Wednesday that it continued to expect a modest upturn in global growth in 2013, with fewer risks of major policy mistakes and lower levels of financial stress.

headline: Russian Minister Backs Assad, and Adoption Ban
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, said on Wednesday that the main obstacle to peace in Syria was the opposition’s “obsession with the idea of toppling the Bashar al-Assad regime.” He also said that the Kremlin’s Emergency Ministry flights that removed 77 Russians from the war zone early on Wednesday had not signaled the start of an evacuation.

headline: Possible Second Suspect Sought in Houston Shooting
text: HOUSTON — Law enforcement officials said Wednesday that they had not recovered the pistol used in a shooting at a community college on Tuesday that left four people hospitalized, but that they had charged the student they say fired the shots and were still searching for a possible second suspect.

headline: Fitting In/Standing Out
text: In high school, there’s a hazy line between the right kind of standing out and the wrong kind, between fitting into the crowd and being just another follower. Veer too far to one extreme and you risk ostracism; too far to the other, and you risk ordinariness.

headline: Movie Attention for Chastain Gives ‘Heiress’ a Broadway Bounce
text: The actress Jessica Chastain, fresh off an Oscar nomination and Golden Globe win for “Zero Dark Thirty,” wasn’t just generating ticket sales at the movies last week. Her Broadway play, “The Heiress,” had its best week since mid-November, according to box office data released on Tuesday by the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers.

headline: New Path for Trade: Selling in China
text: Like many American businesses fighting to keep their prices competitive, Vision Quest Lighting turned to China about six years ago. It now imports about a sixth of the two dozen to three dozen parts required to make its lighting fixtures from there. Recently, however, the Long Island company began to see China in a different light: as a sales target. The growing economy of the world’s most populous nation made it ripe for Vision Quest’s architectural lighting fixtures, many custom-made for hotel and restaurant chains like Hilton and KFC.

His case is pretty much the same one I’ve been making; also, unlike Larry Summers yesterday, his piece doesn’t blur its point by starting with an extended exercise in dutiful deficit-bashing.

headline: Have You Tried Selling in China?
text: A small-business guide we have just published quotes Savio S. Chan, who is president and chief executive of U.S. China Partners, a consulting firm that over the last eight years has helped nearly 100 American companies do business in China. Initially, the firm connected these companies with manufacturers and suppliers in China; of late, it has helped more clients market and sell their products and services in China. Both the Golden State Warriors and the New Jersey Nets of the N.B.A. called upon Mr. Chan to seek corporate partners in China to capitalize on the Chinese heritage of roster players.

headline: Where Dead Animals Seem Alive

One of my first trips there was with my drawing class during my freshman year at the School of Visual Arts. We were assigned to make a series of drawings based on a shape that inspired us at the museum. I chose a shape that I saw on a 3-D cross-section of a space rock.

headline: Royal Shakespeare Company to Stage ‘Wolf Hall’ and ‘Bring Up the Bodies’

The Royal Shakespeare Company announced on Wednesday that Mike Poulton, known for his theatrical versions of classic works like “The Canterbury Tales” and “Le Morte d’Arthur,” is adapting both books for the company, and that the stage versions, directed by Jeremy Herrin, will appear in repertory starting in December.

headline: Wayne LaPierre Strikes Again
text: President Obama made only glancing reference to gun control in his Inaugural Address, merely saying that we need to keep our children safe “from the streets of Detroit to the hills of Appalachia to the quiet lanes of Newtown.” But he didn’t fool Wayne LaPierre, the ever-vigilant executive vice president of the National Rifle Association.

headline: Below the Line: Dressing ‘Snow White’
text: Colleen Atwood is no stranger to the Oscars. The much sought-after costume designer has been nominated for 10 Academy Awards and has won three for her work on “Chicago” (2002), “Memoirs of a Geisha” (2006) and “Alice in Wonderland” (2010).

headline: Before Setting Off, a Drill
text: The cruise industry has instituted 10 new safety policies in response to the Costa Concordia crash that killed 32 people a year ago. The Cruise Lines International Association, the trade group that represents major cruise lines globally, has developed requirements over the last year that muster drills, passenger emergency drills, be conducted before departing from port rather than within 24 hours of sailing, and that the crew receives more mandatory lifeboat training, among other measures. The International Maritime Organization, a United Nations agency that oversees maritime safety, said it expects to make muster drills before departure mandatory.

headline: Protecting Teenagers From High School’s ‘Big Box’
text: If high school is, as Jennifer Senior writes in “Why You Truly Never  Leave High School” for New York magazine, corrosive and traumatizing, then it begs a question: how (barring home schooling) can we steel our teenage children against the institution’s effect on their sense of themselves?

headline: More Than 20 Million Viewers Watched Coverage of Inauguration

headline: Suspects in Dutch Art Heist (if Not the Art Itself) in Custody
text: Three suspects in the theft of seven masterpieces from the Kunsthal Museum in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, have been arrested in Romania, but there is still no word on where the stolen art might be, the BBC reported. The paintings, which include works by Monet, Picasso, Matisse and Lucien Freud, were taken from the gallery on Oct. 16. A spokeswoman for the Rotterdam police, Yvette van den Heerik, said that the suspects’ involvement was still being investigated.

headline: Site to Be Seen | constrvct.com
text: To established fashion designers, Mary Huang and Jenna Fizel may well appear as the Visigoths did to the Romans: outsiders bent on cheerfully upending civilization as they know it. Interaction designers by training and novices to the fashion world, the two have started a clothing label that essentially eliminates the need for the creative vision of one person. Instead, they’ve created software that puts that power in the hands of consumers, a process Huang calls “fashion design for the Instagram generation.” Shoppers logging on to constrvct.com can upload a photograph that will later be translated into a print, choose from a variety of basic silhouettes (the sheath dress is currently the most popular), then plug in their measurements. Three weeks later, a dress arrives in the mail, a time scale Huang estimate will be cut by two-thirds once the partners raise the funds to bring production in-house. Soon, pre-existing images will be available for selection, with royalties going to the artists who created them. And plans are afoot to add further customizing options like neckline, sleeve and hemline choices. “We don’t even need to make a pattern,” Huang says. “We can make the dress directly from the 3-D model. It’s basically you press the button, we make the dress. If we can do this at scale, it could change the way the whole industry works.”

headline: Hats Off to President Obama
text: David Brooks: Let’s get to the big news of the week first, at least to me. Did you know that Jimmy Carter once allegedly went after a dog with a saw because it ate some of his cat’s food? This is an old story, I guess, told by a disgruntled former Secret Service agent, but I’d never heard it until it had a viral resurgence this week.

headline: House Vote Sidesteps an Ultimatum on Debt
text: WASHINGTON — Avoiding an economic showdown with President Obama, the House on Wednesday passed legislation to eliminate the nation’s statutory borrowing limit until May, without including the dollar-for-dollar spending cuts that Republicans once insisted would have to be part of any debt limit bill.

headline: Federer Prevails Over Tsonga to Set Up Match With Murray

headline: Ryan Expects Debt Deal but Takes Taxes Off the Table
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan predicted on Wednesday that the two parties would produce “a big down payment” on reducing federal debt this year, yet outlined Republican conditions – chiefly no new tax revenues – that would seem to rule out any budget agreement with President Obama and the Democratic-controlled Senate.

headline: Players Discuss Anchored Putting at Meeting
text: SAN DIEGO — Tim Clark, who is not entered in this week’s Farmers Insurance Open, at Torrey Pines, traveled here from his home in Scottsdale, Ariz., to attend the annual players’ meeting Tuesday night. It was Clark’s first opportunity to ask Mike Davis, the executive director of the United States Golf Association, questions about the ban on anchored putting, which was proposed in November by the U.S.G.A. and the Royal & Ancient.

headline: Can You Read the Face of Victory?
text: Picture a tennis player in the moment he scores a critical point and wins a tournament. Now picture his opponent in the instant he loses the point that narrowly cost him the title. Can you tell one facial expression from the other, the look of defeat from the face of victory?

headline: Rand Paul at the Benghazi Hearing
text: Prior to this morning’s hearing on Benghazi, Senator Rand Paul swore he’d press Secretary of State Hillary Clinton over the attack that left four Americans dead. He said she would have to accept full responsibility, and went so far as to compare Mrs. Clinton’s alleged failings with those of government itself: “That’s the problem with government — government is anonymous and so no one is accountable.”

headline: Up Ahead: The World According to Gore
text: “The Future: Six Drivers of Global Change,” the title of Al Gore’s ambitious, drily written new book, sounds like a snoozy think-tank talk. And while it’s about 30 times as long, that’s exactly what this volume is, a wonky overview of the forces that are remaking the world: economic globalization, the digital revolution, climate change, dwindling natural resources, shifts in the global balance of power and advances in the life sciences.

text: The family of Junior Seau, a former star linebacker who shot and killed himself last year, sued the N.F.L., the helmet maker Riddell and others on Wednesday, accusing them of hiding information about the link between head hits and long-term cognitive issues.

headline: Vermont Lawmaker Moves to Repeal Protection for Drug Maker
text: A Vermont lawmaker on Wednesday introduced legislation that would repeal language passed into law in early January that benefits a California-based biotechnology company, saying the deal “confirms the American public’s worst suspicions of how Congress operates.”

headline: Stretching Technique in All Directions
text: Those who worry that the great tradition of the piano concerto is losing its hold on living composers should rest assured: The brilliant British pianist Nicolas Hodges, a champion of contemporary music, is on the case. Right now six composers, among them Pascal Dusapin and Gerald Barry, are writing concertos for Mr. Hodges, who resides in Stuttgart, Germany, where he teaches at the city’s conservatory.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: What Steve Jobs and Palm Said, and Explorer Nostalgia
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Putting a Number on Smoking’s Toll
text: It is often said that smoking takes years off your life, and now a new study shows just how many: Longtime smokers can expect to lose about 10 years of life expectancy.

headline: A Concert of Quirky Gems Becomes a Memorial
text: The conductor Stephen Simon founded L’Orchestre des Portes Rouges in 2010 as a chamber ensemble dedicated to presenting lesser-known instrumental works in the Church of the Resurrection on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, naming it after the building’s cheerful red doors. On Tuesday evening the orchestra presented a program of radiant and quirky gems that Mr. Simon had put together with an eye for humorous details and solo opportunities for his players.

headline: Distribution Options Grow at Sundance
text: Brooks Barnes takes a look at how the Sundance Film Festival has changed over the years and the growing options for filmmakers trying to sell their movies.

headline: Not So Innocent, Nor So Polite
text: Sooner or later the eternal boy becomes a man. It happened to Robert Morse, once the embodiment of a juvenile male lead in Broadway musicals who eventually turned into Bertram Cooper, the crabby senior ad executive in “Mad Men.” And it has happened to Jeff Harnar, the ingenuous cabaret crooner who in the 1980s and ’90s might have played the same chirpy eager-beaver roles associated with Mr. Morse had they been created.

headline: House Democrats Seek to Pass Expansive Domestic Violence Law
text: A day after the Violence Against Women Reauthorization Act was reintroduced in the Senate, House Democrats declared that they would do everything in their power to ensure that it also passes the House.

headline: Setting the Record (and the Hair) Straight
text: An article last Thursday titled “Memorable Clips,” about career-changing haircuts, said that Mia Farrow had long, blond hair until Vidal Sassoon gave her a pixie cut for the 1968 film “Rosemary’s Baby.” “According to Hollywood legend,” it added, “Frank Sinatra, Ms. Farrow’s husband at the time, was so against the cut that he had her served with divorce papers after seeing it.”

headline: Apps and Other Digital Tools Lend a Hand to New Mothers
text: Everyone tells you that having a new baby at home is hard, but I did not understand what they meant until ours arrived. The sleep deprivation. The constant nursing. The endless laundry. Did I mention the sleep deprivation?

headline: A Sound Dock That Docks With a Dock
text: Zagg has simultaneously entered two markets with one device, the Origin.

headline: A Resurgent Netflix Beats Projections, Even Its Own
text: 1:51 p.m. | Updated For all those who have doubted its business acumen, Netflix had a resounding answer on Wednesday: 27.15 million.

headline: A Singer’s Life and Her Songs, Separated by the Thinnest Line
text: Iris DeMent released “Sing the Delta” (Flariella) late last year, eight years after her previous release — “Lifeline,” a collection of religious songs — and 16 years after her last album of original material.

headline: Fox Shelves ‘Ben and Kate’ on Tuesdays
text: The dismal year for new television comedies continued Wednesday with Fox pulling “Ben and Kate” — one of the few modestly praised new comedies of the year — from its schedule

headline: Heady Returns, but Apple Finds Its Stock Falling
text: Apple on Wednesday reported the kind of quarter most big companies would envy, posting a profit of $13.1 billion and selling 28 percent more iPhones and 48 percent more iPads, its two biggest products.

headline: K.K.R. Takes 25% Stake in Firm That Invests in Natural Disasters
text: In its latest move to bolster its asset management arm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has found an unusual partner: a hedge fund seeking to invest in natural disasters.

headline: Roller Derby Exerts Its Pull on Everyman
text: Slap on some wheels and chase your dream, or stay stock still and remain true to the girl you love? That’s the hard choice faced by Jack Lovington (Patch Darragh), the would-be skating star and Everyman hero of “The Jammer,” the slightly tattered comic book of a play by Rolin Jones presented by the Atlantic Theater Company at the troupe’s smaller stage on 16th Street in Chelsea.

headline: Urging Action, Report on Brutal Rape Condemns India’s Treatment of Women
text: NEW DELHI — Women in India face systemic discrimination and are regularly confronted with sexual harassment and violence, even as the police often fail to provide protection and the government has failed to enforce laws and policies intended to safeguard women’s rights, according to a scathing special report released on Wednesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Mali and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Mali, Israel, India and more.

headline: ASAP Rocky, From Mixtape Darling to Top of the Chart
text: The Harlem rapper ASAP Rocky became a mixtape darling two years ago, and now, with his proper debut released on a major label, he has a No. 1 album as well.

headline: Small Gestures, Big Statements
text: PARIS — What’s so likable about the Paris men’s shows is that they’re modest affairs. Half the time you’re squashed with your comrades in a chilly room that resembles a garage, looking at some guys in tailcoats seemingly fashioned from Mom’s chenille robe. Even the allusions to the awkward shift into manhood — here from the great Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garçons — are modestly dispensed.

headline: A Country House on the Isle of Guernsey
text: A three-story Victorian with a pool and English Channel views is on the market for $3.1 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... the Channel Islands
text: A VICTORIAN COUNTRY HOME ON THE ISLE OF GUERNSEY

headline: A New Kind of Holster for the iPhone
text: Unless you carry a Bushmaster Adaptive Combat Rifle around, the Sector 5 Black Ops iPhone cover from Element Case is likely to be the most polarizing accessory you own.

headline: Precision Abounds During Couture Fashion Week
text: Young designers are learning to use the extraordinary skills of a couture atelier to be more self-critical and demanding, something Karl Lagerfeld has been doing for years.

headline: And Precisely So
text: PARIS — Outwardly, the spring haute couture shows were about the joys of gardening and how many brides you could put on a runway. (Dior, 5; Chanel, 2, though Karl Lagerfeld might have upstaged Raf Simons of Dior by having a pair of lesbian brides.) Not to be left out, the house of Valentino also dug a garden theme.

headline: Sounds of Sundance
text: During the Sundance Film Festival, you can see movies and also hear performances from established stars like Nas, Dave Grohl and Andrew Bird or promotional concerts for music documentaries.

headline: Homes for $1.1 Million
text: Properties in Pennsylvania, Phoenix and Tennessee.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
text: LUMBERVILLE, PA.

headline: From Midwest to East, Subzero Temperatures Turn Mild Winter Deadly
text: ST. PAUL, Minn. — A bracing wave of Arctic air swept across much of the nation on Wednesday, suddenly turning what had been a relatively mild winter into a shivering misery that has caused several deaths in the Midwest and prompted cities along the Eastern Seaboard to open emergency shelters.

headline: Rolling Stone Lays Off Two Noted Staff Members
text: 6:02 p.m. | Updated Rolling Stone, amid a variety of magazines responding to a troubled advertising environment by trimming staff, laid off two of its bigger names this month.

headline: AT&T’s TV, Phone and Internet Service Is Down in Some States
text: 6:33 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from AT&T in response to whether customers will get refunds.

headline: Chef Who Refuses to Be Defined by His Wok
text: The firebrand chef Eddie Huang took over a table at Hot Kitchen, a Sichuan restaurant in the East Village, and commandeered the remote control. It was a Saturday night, and the Orlando Magic was losing to the New York Knicks. As Carmelo Anthony worked his way to 40 points, Mr. Huang’s body jerked in sympathetic rebound.

headline: Things We Love … Shoes Glorious Shoes
text: Bob Dylan once sang of “Boots of Spanish Leather,” though these days soccer boots, cleats, shoes (your choice of nomenclature) are more likely to be made of the finest synthetics concocted in the laboratories of Beaverton, Ore.,  (Nike) and Herzogenaurach, Germany (Adidas and Puma).

headline: Letter From Gen. Martin E. Dempsey
text: A letter from Gen. Martin E. Dempsey to Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta proposing removing the restrictions on women from many positions in the infantry and artillery.

headline: Australian Open Chronicles: Melbourne Memories
text: Irina Falconi, an American who played at the Australian Open, wrote posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets as she did during the United States Open last year. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

headline: Iran Is Accused of Delaying Resumption of Nuclear Talks
text: A spokesman for the representative of the six big powers in nuclear talks with Iran expressed irritation on Wednesday with what he described as repeated changes and delays by the Iranian side in finalizing the date and place for the next round of negotiations.

headline: The Slipper Room
text: When the Slipper Room, a beacon in the New York burlesque scene, shut its doors in 2010, supposedly for a renovation, downtown denizens wrung their hands, lamenting, “There goes the Lower East Side.” It would be, they assumed, replaced by condos or some anodyne macaron store. But the Slipper Room did finally reopen last fall, offering burlesque and comedy shows in a larger, three-story building. The acts are just as blue as before. On a recent night, a performer named Gal Friday, who wore little more than a string of red sequins around her waist, gyrated to a rock classic, “Shortnin’ Bread,” and picked up a dollar bill without the aid of her hands.

headline: Attention, Narcissists
text: GO ON, ADMIT IT. What fashion-conscious person hasn’t fantasized at some point in the last 70-some years of finding themselves on the International Best-Dressed List?

headline: When Australia Soared on Film
text: The Last New Wave, the title of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s retrospective of the late-1970s resurgence of the Australian movie industry, might not sit well with everyone. What about Romania, you might ask, or Iran or South Korea?

headline: Israel’s Election
text: The political opponents of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel were ecstatic at his apparent losses in Tuesday’s elections. Haaretz, the left-leaning newspaper, called it a vote of no confidence that showed Mr. Netanyahu has “failed in the political sphere, the foreign policy sphere and the socioeconomic sphere.”

headline: Unsettling News Intrudes Upon a Production’s Smirk
text: At some point during rehearsals “Collision,” Lyle Kessler’s new play about a college roommate from hell, underwent a metamorphosis, or at least a branding change. A press representative for the show announced last week that its creators, the Off Broadway troupe the Amoralists, “are now billing the play as a drama, not a black comedy as originally announced.”

headline: A Choreographer Is a Centerpiece in a Show of Juxtapositions
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Philadelphia Museum of Art’s exhibition celebrating Marcel Duchamp, John Cage, Merce Cunningham, Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns — which closed on Monday — was in several ways a triumph. The show, called “Dancing Around the Bride,” successfully illustrated many (by no means all) of the connections among these five very different men — still provocative, still rightly controversial — and proved stimulating, informative, enlightening.

headline: Sony Makes Deal for Electronic Dance Music
text: In the latest sign of the music industry’s gold rush over electronic dance music, Sony Music has struck a deal with a leading independent dance label, Ultra Music. The arrangement calls for the labels to share acts, and gives one of Sony‘s divisions distribution rights to Ultra’s catalog in North America, which includes top D.J.’s like Deadmau5, Steve Aoki, Calvin Harris and Benny Benassi.

headline: Kashkari, Onetime $700 Billion Man at Treasury, Weighs Political Bid
text: More than four years after the financial crisis, one of the top figures behind the Bush administration’s sweeping rescue plan is considering a return to government service.

headline: Making a Film a Philanthropic Event
text: PARK CITY, Utah – “Girl Rising” is rapidly becoming one of the hottest “cause” documentaries in years, and it’s not even finished yet.

headline: Ex-Outsiders, Now Basking in the Moment
text: PARK CITY, Utah — It was almost exactly one year ago that Quvenzhané Wallis, the star of “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” made her bad little self known to the world. After the premiere of the movie here at the Sundance Film Festival, Ms. Wallis, then 8, took to the stage with her cast mates and film crew. She received a standing ovation. Handed a mike, she introduced herself and announced, “I like to have a party!” Cue the hearts melting of 1,300 audience members.

headline: Exploring the Many Options That Make  Recording Easy
text: Remember pocket voice recorders, and their fiddly (but cute) miniature cassette tapes that stored your business memos and interviews? These gadgets have largely gone the way of the dodo, because digital voice recorders replaced them. Digital recorders don’t need the tiny tapes, they can record with less audio distortion and they offer extras like easy downloading of your recordings to a computer.

headline: New York’s Naked Trees
text: Trees in winter, at the New York Botanical Garden and Central Park.

headline: Dormant but Not Forgotten
text: Winter is a lie.

headline: App Smart: Digital Audio Recorders
text: Kit Eaton reviews apps that transform your phone or tablet into digital audio recorders.

headline: A Legacy Threatened by Scorn
text: Teachers Julie Cavanagh and Adam Stevens listen to New York’s mayor pour boiling oil on their union, to his talk of imposing more tests and using the scores to draw a stringent measure of each teacher, and they wonder what world he inhabits.

headline: District 3 Winter Regional
text: Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Chuck Lamprey of White Plains, N.Y., won the Senior Pairs on Saturday at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y. They finished more than two boards ahead of Howard Cohen of Oceanside, N.Y., and Charles Sharf of North Baldwin, N.Y., with Susan Schwartz of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Ed Hill of Bedminster, N.J., third.

headline: A Constantly Changing Landscape
text: In Buffalo, an architecture of castoffs.

headline: A Master of Accumulation
text: BUFFALO — In 2009, Dennis Maher, a professor of architecture at the University at Buffalo, bought an abandoned property from D’Youville College for $10,000. It was a Buffalo double house, built just before the turn of the 20th century, as common a sight here as a maple tree.

headline: A Tall House of Water
text: Leigh Osborne and his partner, Graham Voce, spotted the derelict water tower in 2010, from their apartment on the 36th floor of the Strata Tower in the city’s Elephant and Castle neighborhood. From what they could tell, the lonely brick water tower in the nearby Kennington area, surrounded by a ring of new condominiums, was vacant and disintegrating. But Mr. Osborne, a property developer who is now 40, had to have it.

headline: The High Life
text: A couple turned a landmarked water tower into a home.

headline: Video: When Park City Becomes Music Central
text: “This ain’t Hollywood, this is Park City!” Nas shouted from the stage on Saturday night. He was performing in a pop-up club at the base of a ski lift on Main Street here (“I’m usually at Tao in Vegas or New York City. This is Tao in Utah. How real is that?”), one of many musical acts to appear in the Sundance orbit. Here, a sampling of the nonfilm shows around town during the festival.

headline: Shopping for Scandinavian Designs
text: Richard Wright, the Chicago auction house owner, goes shopping for modern designs produced from a region that he says deserves extra attention: Scandinavia.

headline: Scandinavian Designs
text: AS THE OWNER of Wright auction house in Chicago, Richard Wright spends his days surrounded by covetable midcentury modern furnishings from around the world. For Mr. Wright, however, there is one region that deserves extra attention: Scandinavia.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Our house has wood trim with an orangy varnish in most of the rooms. Should we paint or refinish it before putting the house on the market, or leave it as is?

headline: Mix Master
text: The French designer Matali Crasset has built a highly successful career in a profession dominated by men. There are other prominent women designers, but their numbers are small, and Ms. Crasset, 47, whose signature mushroom-cap hair style has led some to call her the Joan of Arc of design, has created a special niche marked by a rigorous aesthetic. She began her career in 1991 in the office of the Italian designer Denis Santachiara. Two years later, she went to work for Philippe Starck on high-tech projects for Thomson, the consumer electronics company. She set up her business in 1998.

headline: Warming Trend
text: A colorful spot in snow-covered Paris was a display of blankets from Zuzunaga, a company based in Barcelona and London, which took the top prize for textiles at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair last year. Founded in 2010 by Cristian Zuzunaga, a 34-year-old designer, the company specializes in bright, woven grids and organic abstractions. Mr. Zuzunaga has noted that his first love was biology, and that his early experience with microscopes led to an interest in close-ups. He named this collection Bitmap because of its pixilated motif, but he was also thinking about 21st-century modern architecture found in Tokyo, New York, Shanghai and London, he said.

headline: Lamps That Leave an Afterglow
text: At Maison et Objet, a trade fair in Paris that ended Tuesday, Forestier, a French lighting manufacturer, showed its new collaborations with Arik Levy, the Paris-based designer, who was born in Israel. The results were predictably polished. Mr. Levy, who divides his time between high art (he’s had several gallery shows of his sculptures) and industrial production for clients including Lanvin, Boucheron, Renault and Vitra, has enjoyed a long relationship with Forestier. This year he designed a hanging lantern of Tyvek and steel for outdoors that will be available at the MoMA store this spring. His Antenna series for Forestier (pendant version, shown) employs delicate metal wire, which was hand-woven to create subtle lighting screens. Mr. Levy also designed a table version of Antenna, in three sizes. All the lights take compact fluorescent light bulbs. Antenna is not yet available in the United States. Information: 011-33-1-40-36-13-10 or forestier.fr.

headline: Sharing a Wealth of Ideas
text: Japan Creative, a nonprofit organization, supports traditional Japanese crafts, and the businesses that produce them, by matching leading Japanese artisans with Western design lions. Last year, Jasper Morrison created cast-iron cookware with the Oigen foundry, and Inga Sempé collaborated with Koubei-gama (founded 1804) on ceramics with the traditional green glaze of Oribe ware. At Maison et Objet, Japan Creative introduced an alliance between Fujisato Woodcraft and the Israeli designer Ron Gilad. The result was monastically simple walnut chests with interiors of paulownia, a wood typically used for storing kimonos. Mr. Gilad devised the elegant wrought-iron hardware. The pieces are still prototypes and the company has not as yet set prices.

headline: Flatware With an Eastern Flavor
text: Toyo Ito is as sure-handed with tableware as he is with buildings. Mr. Ito, the Japanese architect whose team won a Golden Lion Award at the 2012 Venice Architecture Biennale for its concepts for new housing after the Tohoku earthquake and tsunami, recently designed flatware called Mu. Introduced in Paris by the Italian company Alessi, the pattern complements Ku, the delicate porcelain service Mr. Ito created for Alessi in 2006. Mu (hexagon in Japanese) refers to the six-sided shape of the handle, which resembles chopsticks and creates a sharp contrast with the oval spoon bowls and knife blades. The pattern is embodied in a wide range of utensils, including serving pieces. A five-piece place setting is $87.50 and will be available next month. Information: (212) 941-7300 or alessi.com.

headline: Sales at Canvas, South Street Linen and Others
text: Canvas is discounting all colored glass as much as 50 percent, through Sunday (the Ash ball-stemmed goblet, shown, originally about $12, is about $8; the Bario bubble goblet, originally $10, is about $6); 199 Lafayette Street (Kenmare Street), (646) 873-6698 and 123 West 17th Street (Avenue of the Americas), (212) 372-7706, canvashomestore.com.

headline: Behind Park’s Name, a Civil War Soldier Who Helped Give the N.R.A. Birth
text: A few months ago, Andrew Soar wondered why somebody named Wingate was so important that a park had been named for him — the 5.89 acres in the shadow of Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn where Mr. Soar sometimes works out.

headline: Robots for Tasks Large and Small, Light and Heavy
text: At the Automate 2013 trade show in Chicago, makers of industrial robots and machine-vision equipment demonstrated factory applications like medication sorting and burger making.

headline: Robot Makers Spread Global Gospel of Automation
text: CHICAGO — The robot equipment industry has one word for the alarmist articles and television news programs that predict a robot is about to steal your job: Fiddlesticks!

headline: Why A.I.G. Did Not Sue the Government
text: When American International Group’s directors met this month to consider joining a lawsuit against the same federal agencies that rescued it with a $182 billion financial crisis bailout, they received a stark warning from their lawyers. One lawyer said that the lawsuit had only a 20 percent chance of succeeding, according to a document released on Wednesday.

headline: Dodgers and Time Warner Cable Near Deal for TV Channel
text: Well before a group led by Guggenheim Partners acquired the Los Angeles Dodgers for $2.15 billion last year from Frank McCourt, the team expected a financial windfall from its cable television rights.

headline: Does Apple Need a Cheaper iPhone?
text: In the past month, there have been reports that Apple is working on a smaller, cheaper iPhone. But the latest sales numbers do not make it appear that Apple needs to sell one.

headline: Honoring Drug War Dead, and Spurring a Debate
text: MEXICO CITY — Reeling from a drug war that has killed tens of thousands and a boom in violent crime in general, Mexico has built a memorial to victims of violence. But like a crime scene still under investigation, it sits off limits behind white tarp, wrapped in questions and uncertainty.

headline: Hurdles Remain for Jaguar Habitat
text: Last fall, remote cameras in a rugged expanse of desert grasslands in Southern Arizona captured arresting images of a jaguar slinking through the underbrush, its yellow eyes fixed on some distant sight. The photos add to the dozen or so documented sightings of the endangered cat on American soil in the last century.

headline: How to Gain From the Pain of a Squandered Lead
text: SAN DIEGO — On the 18th fairway of the South Course at Torrey Pines, roughly 85 yards from the pin, Kyle Stanley stood with a club in his hand. It was Tuesday afternoon, 359 days after he stood in roughly the same spot holding a sand wedge and a three-stroke lead at the Farmers Insurance Open.

headline: Algeria Gas Compound Lacked Armed Guards
text: HOUSTON — The companies operating the gas facility in the Sahara that was attacked last week had chosen not to deploy armed guards inside the sprawling compound, leading security analysts to question whether the assault by more than 30 Islamist militants might have been slowed if security had been tighter.

headline: How to Get America Online
text: ON Monday, President Obama said that during his second term, Americans would act together to “build the roads and networks and research labs that will bring new jobs and businesses to our shores” and that “we cannot cede to other nations the technology that will power new jobs and new industries — we must claim its promise.”

headline: The Taliban of Timbuktu
text: BEFORE the recent French intervention in Mali began, 412,000 people had already left their homes in the country’s north, fleeing torture, summary executions, recruitment of child soldiers and sexual violence against women at the hands of fundamentalist militants. Late last year, in Algeria and southern Mali, I interviewed dozens of Malians from the north, including many who had recently fled. Their testimonies confirmed the horrors that radical Islamists, self-proclaimed warriors of God, have inflicted on their communities.

headline: The Last Holdout in New England, Rhode Island Weighs Gay Marriage
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Rhode Island, the only state in New England that has not legalized gay marriage, began taking up the matter this week. The State House is expected to pass a bill Thursday that would allow anyone to marry “any eligible person regardless of gender.”

headline: For Obama’s New Term, Start Here
text: Point to a group of toddlers in an upper-middle-class neighborhood in America, and it’s a good bet that they will go to college, buy nice houses and enjoy white-collar careers.

headline: A Month After His Firing, a Coach Understands
text: LUTHERVILLE, Md. — The day he lost his job, Cam Cameron decided to go to his son Danny’s high school basketball game. As soon as Cameron arrived at the gymnasium, he could sense that people were staring at him. It struck him as pity, or perhaps morbid curiosity.

headline: True Believers in Justice
text: The filmmaker Dawn Porter follows Travis Williams, a young public defender in the Deep South, who struggles against long hours, low pay and staggering caseloads to bring justice to all.

headline: Netanyahu-Obama Ties May Thaw After Israel Election
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, whose relationship with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has often resembled that of a couple trapped in a loveless marriage, the last three months must have offered some grim satisfaction.

headline: ‘True Believers in Justice’
text: I’d always wanted to be a lawyer, but unlike Travis Williams — the subject of this Op-Doc video — I never wanted to be a public defender. I didn’t understand how anyone could represent people who did terrible things. “Criminals” were not people I wanted to help.

headline: The Making of Israel’s New Power Broker
text: TEL AVIV — They pitched tents along Rothschild Boulevard and took to the streets in unprecedented numbers, hundreds of thousands demonstrating against the rising costs of gas, apartments, even cottage cheese.

headline: Democrats in Senate Confront Doubts at Home on Gun Laws
text: BECKLEY, W.Va. — Talk of stricter gun control has stirred up a lot of unease here, a place where hunters vie for top prize (a 26-inch LED television) in the Big Buck Photo Contest, and ads for a gun-simulator game ask, “Feel like shooting something today?”

headline: Helping Degree Seekers Finish What They Start
text: There is a paradox in American higher education: of the millions of students who apply to and enter postsecondary degree programs, only about half end up graduating within six years.

headline: Misconceptions
text: Francis Lorson, the longtime chief deputy clerk of the Supreme Court, once told me the following story. On a January day in the mid-1970s, he and Justice Potter Stewart were in an official car traveling from the court to the White House, where the justice was to preside at a swearing-in ceremony. As they rode along Pennsylvania Avenue, they saw a crowd heading in the opposite direction, up Capitol Hill toward the court.

headline: Redistricting in Virginia Hurts Blacks, Democrats Say
text: On Monday, one of Virginia’s state senators attended the inauguration: Henry L. Marsh III, a longtime civil rights lawyer, who played hooky to witness a milestone for an African-American president.

headline: Mexican Court Frees Woman Imprisoned in Kidnapping
text: MEXICO CITY — A Supreme Court panel in Mexico voted Wednesday to free a French woman serving a 60-year sentence for kidnapping, ending a case that has become emblematic of problems in the country’s opaque justice system and that has strained relations with France.

headline: Republican Myopia
text: Congressional Republicans like nothing more than beating a dead horse if it might embarrass the Obama administration — like their unceasing attempt to accuse the administration of lying to the American people about the attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

headline: Hollywood Stardom by Way of Doughnuts
text: Melena Ryzik visits the New Orleans bakery of Dwight Henry, a non-actor who was cast as a lead in the Oscar-nominated movie “Beasts of the Southern Wild.”

headline: First Overwhelmed by the Hurricane, Now Struggling to Fight Off the Cold
text: It was too cold for Daniel Choi to stay in his storm-gutted home in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, so he left his two pet turtles, Michelangelo and Leonardo, behind to move in temporarily with friends. But on Wednesday, when he stopped by his home to feed them, he made an upsetting discovery. Plummeting temperatures in the still-heatless house had left the two turtles frozen under a sheet of ice.

headline: What Should Tax Reform Do?
text: If Washington is serious about tackling the budget deficit and growing the U.S. economy, how would our tax system need to change?

headline: Digital Medical Records
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clinics in New York City Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Future of Catholic Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: At the Library, a Lending Doll to Spread the Joy
Individualism vs. the Common Good
text: To the Editor:

headline: Keds Enlists Taylor Swift to Transmit Girl Power
text: IN the 1960s, among fads like Mad Libs and the Twist, there was a popular type of joke known as a “Tom Swifty,” named for the children’s-book hero Tom Swift, in which a punning verb or adverb set off a sentence: “I’ll have a martini,” Tom said dryly. “We just struck oil,” Tom gushed. “Hurry up and get in the back of the ship,” Tom said sternly.

headline: Obama Reboot
text: President Obama’s Inaugural Address was an unapologetic, unequivocal progressive manifesto of domestic policies.

headline: Either With Him or Against Him
text: Nobody knows what Kevin Garnett will say or do when Carmelo Anthony steps onto the floor in Boston on Thursday night, when the Knicks and the Celtics meet for the first time since Garnett’s on-court posturing turned Anthony into a backstage vigilante early this month in New York.

headline: Indiana’s Gambling Lock Loosened by Competition
text: HAMMOND, Ind. — There is Las Vegas. There is Atlantic City. But when it comes to listing popular American gambling locations, another powerhouse often gets overlooked: Indiana.

headline: Heart Big Enough to Care for 7 Children
text: One day almost four years ago, Genesis McBride was watching television in her Brooklyn apartment when the phone rang. It was a caseworker from New York City’s Administration for Children’s Services. There was an emergency.

headline: Arms and the Women
text: Women in the military are going to get to serve in combat. They killed the Equal Rights Amendment to keep this from happening, but, yet, here we are. And about time.

headline: N.C.A.A. Admits Mishandling Miami Inquiry
text: The N.C.A.A., facing increasingly fierce scrutiny regarding its role as the administrator of college athletics, said Wednesday that its enforcement staff improperly obtained information in its high-profile investigation involving the University of Miami.

headline: Cleared of One ’95 Murder, 3 Men Have Conviction Vacated in a 2nd
text: Three men who had been imprisoned for 17 years for two murders they had long denied committing were released on Wednesday night after a judge granted the prosecution’s request to vacate the last remaining convictions.

headline: A Debt Crisis Averted, for Now
text: In an unusual recognition of reality, House Republicans backed away on Wednesday from a chaotic default crisis and dropped their ruinous demand that spending be cut on an equal basis with a rise in the debt ceiling. On a vote of 285 to 144, the House agreed to suspend the debt ceiling for three months, adding the puerile condition that the Senate’s pay should be delayed until it passes a budget. The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, said the extension would pass his chamber and promised to come up with a budget, four years late.

headline: Air Force Leaders Testify on Culture That Led to Sexual Assaults of Recruits

headline: Anthony Shoots More as Knicks Win Less

headline: His Conviction Overturned, Man Is Let Out of Prison After 23 Years
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office agreed on Wednesday to release a man who served 23 years in prison for murder, a week after a federal judge tossed out the man’s conviction, calling it “rotten from Day 1.”

headline: Cameron’s Speech a Gamble for Tories as Much as for Europe
text: LONDON — It was a speech months, even years, in the making. When it was finally delivered, Prime Minister David Cameron had essentially reset the tables for what has the makings of a giant political poker game — for himself, Britain, Europe and his Conservative Party.

headline: Egypt: Polio Virus Is Found in Cairo’s Sewers
text: The polio virus has been found in the sewers of Cairo, and it appears to have come from Pakistan, the World Health Organization said Wednesday. Egypt has not had a case of polio since 2004. A vaccination drive is being planned for Feb. 25, and health workers are canvassing the neighborhoods where the sewage samples were taken, looking for children or adults who may have recently been paralyzed, said Sona Bari, a spokeswoman for the W.H.O.  Pakistan has said it will post teams at its international airports vaccinating all outward-bound passengers under age 5. Last month, at least nine Pakistani volunteers in an internationally supported polio vaccination drive were killed by militants across Pakistan in a campaign of intimidation that has hurt efforts to eradicate the disease there. Pakistan is one of the last three countries, with Afghanistan and Nigeria, with indigenous polio.

headline: Venezuela: Officials Say Plot Targeted Vice President
text: Officials said Wednesday that they had uncovered a plot to assassinate the top two government figures who have been running the country during the absence of the cancer-stricken President Hugo Chávez. Justice Minister Néstor Reverol said “the Venezuelan ultraright in complicity with the ultraright outside the country” were behind a plot to kill the two officials, Vice President Nicolás Maduro and the National Assembly president, Diosdado Cabello. Speaking later at a pro-government rally, Mr. Maduro mentioned the plot allegations and promised to use a “hard hand against the right-wing conspiracy.” Mr. Reverol said that security had been increased.

headline: A Mulligan by Mickelson on Tax Talk
text: SAN DIEGO — Three days after creating a firestorm with his public airing of his tax grievances, Phil Mickelson apologized for being, well, himself.

headline: Rockets’ White Says He’s Close to Returning

headline: Tracking Battery Problems
text: From March 20, 1991, through Oct. 9, 2012, the Federal Aviation Administration logged 132 incidents involving batteries on airplanes.

headline: China: Former Powerful Official Hires Lawyers
text: Employees at the office of two lawyers in Beijing, Li Guifang and Wang Zhaofeng, have said in telephone interviews that the two have been hired to represent Bo Xilai, the former Communist Party chief of Chongqing who was felled by a scandal last year. Mr. Bo’s wife, Gu Kailai, was given a commuted life sentence last summer after she was found guilty of murdering Neil Heywood, a British businessman. The party announced last September that Mr. Bo, whose father was a Communist elder, would be tried on criminal charges including corruption and trying to cover up Mr. Heywood’s murder. Mr. Li and Mr. Wang were unavailable for comment on Tuesday, but their assistants at the law office, Deheng, said Mr. Bo, who has been detained since last spring, and his family had appointed them to represent him. The assistants said they had no information on any date or location for a trial. In early January, an official news media report said Mr. Bo’s case had been handed to “judicial organs,” which ignited speculation that Mr. Bo’s trial might take place soon.

headline: Cardinal Jozef Glemp of Poland Is Dead at 83
text: Cardinal Jozef Glemp, the spiritual leader of Poland’s Roman Catholics for 25 years, who helped steer his nation through a historic and relatively peaceful transition from Communism to democracy in 1989, but who was dogged by allegations of anti-Semitism, died on Wednesday in Warsaw. He was 83.

headline: Lopez Continues All-Star-Caliber Season as the Nets Keep Winning

Not that Lopez will be sweating Thursday’s televised announcement, which comes on an off day in Memphis.

headline: Japanese Trade Deficit Was $78 Billion in 2012
text: TOKYO — Japan on Thursday reported a record annual trade deficit in 2012, the second straight year in the red for an exporting nation that has long built its wealth on its vast trading surpluses.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK Liz (Tina Fey) tries to save “TGS” from cancellation; Tracy (Tracy Morgan) and Jenna (Jane Krakowski, above, with Mr. Morgan) start to work on their Plan B’s; and Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) helps Jack (Alec Baldwin) appoint a new president of NBC. On “Parks and Recreation,” at 8:30, Leslie (Amy Poehler) and April (Aubrey Plaza) handle a garbage route to get more women hired in government; Tom (Aziz Ansari) tries to build his business by persuading Andy (Chris Pratt) and Ben (Adam Scott) to teach him more about basketball; and Ron (Nick Offerman) baby-sits for the children of Diane (Lucy Lawless). On “The Office,” at 9, Dwight (Rainn Wilson) struggles to keep Darryl (Craig Robinson) from moving to Philadelphia, and Jim (John Krasinski) is forced to miss Cece’s first recital. On “1600 Penn,” at 9:30, President Gilchrist (Bill Pullman) uses his position to track down someone of importance to the family, while Emily (Jenna Elfman) is determined to defy protocol when the Austrian chancellor (David St. James) and his wife (Rebecca Wisocky) visit.

headline: Cat Rescues in China Raise Host of New Questions

headline: Grief Over New Depression Diagnosis

Everyone from advocacy groups to insurance companies to litigators — all have an interest in what’s defined as mental illness — pays close attention. Invariably, complaints ensue.

headline: The Price of a Stolen Childhood
text: The detective spread out the photographs on the kitchen table, in front of Nicole, on a December morning in 2006. She was 17, but in the pictures, she saw the face of her 10-year-old self, a half-grown girl wearing make-up. The bodies in the images were broken up by pixelation, but Nicole could see the outline of her father, forcing himself on her. Her mother, sitting next to her, burst into sobs.

headline: An Insurance Company With an Army
text: Jonathan Chait and Greg Sargent both weigh in on the absurd Republican claim that they’ll produce a plan to balance the budget in 10 years, without a penny in additional revenue. Chait points out that the Ryan plan, even if you accepted all its magic asterisks, still didn’t produce a balanced budget until 2040. Sargent, armed with numbers from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, points out that if the GOP were to honor its promises not to cut military spending or benefits for those over 55, you’d have to impose savage cuts on everything else.

headline: Supernatural Tales: Manuel Gonzales Talks About ‘The Miniature Wife’
text: The stories in Manuel Gonzales’s first collection, “The Miniature Wife” (Riverhead), are shot through with outlandish events relayed in an understated tone. In the first story, passengers in an airplane circle above the same city for more than 20 years. In the title story, a husband accidentally shrinks his wife to the size of a coffee mug. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Gonzales discussed his use of the supernatural, the writing center he runs in Austin, Tex., and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

He argues that many Americans still do not understand what went wrong, and he contends that the government still does not get enough credit for the successes of its policies.

headline: On Our Radar: Salt Lake Smog

The air is so tainted that more than 100 Utah doctors are pressing the authorities to lower highway speed limits, curb industrial activity and make mass transit free for the rest of the winter. [Associated Press]

headline: Dalai Lama Stresses Science and Secularism in Jaipur
text: As an eager audience settled into their seats on a chilly Thursday morning, the first day of the Jaipur Literature Festival, six monks from the Drepung Loseling monastery, clad in orange robes, sat on the stage with their legs crossed and hands pressed together as in prayer. A calm settled over the audience as the monks’ deep, throaty chants echoed across the front lawns.
