headline: Good News for Bad People as Showtime, Cinemax and BBC America Renew Series
text: Tuesday was a good day for being bad, especially if you do so in the context of cable-TV comedy or drama. Showtime said that it had ordered new seasons of its dark comedies “Shameless” (about a Chicago family gone to seed); “Californication” (about an author struggling — and sometimes not struggling — with his sex life); and “House of Lies,” about a group of unscrupulous management consultants. All three series have seen their viewership grow over previous seasons, Showtime said, and will resume production later this year in Los Angeles to begin new seasons in 2014. Don Cheadle, a star of “House of Lies,” was a surprise winner of the Golden Globe for lead actor in a comedy or musical series earlier this month.

headline: The Case for Shaking Up the Hess Board
text: An activist investor has exposed Hess as the latest governance villain in the energy patch.

headline: CBS Renews Four Daytime Shows
text: CBS, which emphasizes the overall stability of its network, reinforced that point Tuesday, when it ordered renewals for four programs at once, ensuring that its entire daytime lineup will return intact for another season.

headline: Under Attack, Cairo Hotel Tweets an S O S
text: Last Updated, 5:57 p.m. As our colleagues Kareem Fahim, David Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh report, the mayhem on Cairo’s streets briefly spilled into the lobby of one of the city’s luxury hotels, the Semiramis InterContinental, during intense clashes between riot police and protesters along the Nile Corniche overnight.

headline: Obama Urges Speed on Immigration Plan, but Exposes Conflicts
text: LAS VEGAS — Seizing an opening to rewrite the nation’s immigration laws, President Obama challenged Congress on Tuesday to act swiftly to put 11 million illegal immigrants living in the United States on a clear path to citizenship.

headline: Tanqueray Brings Back Malacca Gin for a Spell
text: In 1997, Tanqueray introduced a new gin called Malacca. It was softer, “wetter” and less juniper-forward than its London Dry counterpart, and bottled at a lower proof. But by 2001 it was pulled from the market as the company focused on other products. From there, the legend grew. Mixologists who tasted it said it was as close as you could get today to Old Tom Gin, a sweeter, 19th-century style of gin essential to recreating certain pre-Prohibition cocktails. The thirsty hunted for stray bottles.

headline: Look of The Moment | Victoria Beckham
text: The Look:  Blue Note. A nubby knit and skinny jeans in muted ocean tones are emboldened by an oversize tangerine tote.

headline: Wheelies: The Velocity Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Room Fit for a Queen
text: The Goring Hotel in London was recently awarded a royal warrant by Queen Elizabeth, becoming the sole recipient of the honor for lodging. Royal watchers may recognize the name: The hotel is where Kate Middleton stayed before being married to Prince William last year.

headline: That Cuddly Kitty Is Deadlier Than You Think
text: For all the adorable images of cats that play the piano, flush the toilet, mew melodiously and find their way back home over hundreds of miles, scientists have identified a shocking new truth: cats are far deadlier than anyone realized.

headline: The Gang’s All Here, at Least in Spirits
text: Writing of a trip to New York in 1842, Charles Dickens noted the things he saw in bars, among them the images of George Washington and the American eagle. Both have their place in a new time portal of a tavern in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Women in Combat? Some Marines React
text: When my squad arrived at our outpost in Afghanistan in 2010, one of the first things we did was outfit our living quarters with trash bags, cardboard and salvaged wood to ease the vicious winds. Going to the bathroom proved equally challenging. We urinated into a metal pipe fed through a Hesco barricade filled with dirt and burned our feces in a metal drum. There were no showers or water for showers, so, after each day’s long and grueling foot patrols we pulled on new socks and used baby wipes and body powder. It was miserable but we endured the misery together.

headline: Grand Central’s Flesh-and-Blood Landlord
text: There is some confusion over whether Andrew S. Penson had even been invited to the gala celebration of Grand Central Terminal’s centennial on Friday night. Regardless, Mr. Penson says characteristically, he will be the man who didn’t come to dinner.

headline: No Pay? Little Sacrifice for Many in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — In principle, it sounds self-sacrificing, even noble: Congress swears off collecting its paychecks until it passes a budget.

headline: Bouillabaisse
text: Mark Bittman shows how to make classic bouillabaisse with vegetables.

headline: Harvey Weinstein’s Regrets
text: Harvey Weinstein is going for an unprecedented three-peat as a best picture Oscar winner with either “Silver Linings Playbook” or (less likely) “Django Unchained,” following the Weinstein Company wins for “The Artist” and “The King’s Speech.” But even the master of Academy campaigning isn’t infallible, as he revealed in an interview with Mike Fleming of Deadline.com. At Sundance, Mr. Weinstein admitted that he felt he had hurt Quentin Tarantino’s Oscar chances for a best director nomination by not releasing screeners of “Django Unchained” as soon as it was finished.

headline: Tools of Modern Gunmaking: Plastic and a 3-D Printer
text: A man in Wisconsin viewed it as a technical challenge. Another, in New Hampshire, was looking to save some money. And in Texas, a third wanted to make a political point.

headline: Bahrain Criticized for Use of Tear Gas Following Boy’s Funeral
text: The government of Bahrain has drawn renewed criticism for its use of tear gas after activists said an 8-year-old boy died this month when his village was exposed to tear gas. But Bahrain’s government contradicted that claim, saying the boy died after being admitted to the hospital with severe pneumonia.

headline: At a Performance, Dreaming of Dinner
text: At 35, Alessio Bax is a rising star in classical music. A pianist, he’s also obsessed with food, and his multicourse New York dinner parties are epic, featuring dishes like pasta with Santa Barbara sea urchin, crostini with foie gras, and slow-roasted, bone-in rib-eye. We spoke with Mr. Bax, who was born in Italy and now lives in Harlem with his wife and fellow pianist, Lucille Chung, about his childhood eating habits and post-show cravings.

headline: French Automakers’ Biggest Problem? French Consumers
text: PARIS — Shoppers at the Citroën showroom on the Champs-Élysées were conspicuous mostly by their absence on a recent weekday. Earnest-looking employees outnumbered the lone visitor by at least 10 to 1.

text: Office is one of the great gushers of profits in the software industry, so it is noteworthy when Microsoft starts fiddling with how it charges for its suite of productivity applications.

headline: Guantánamo Lawyers Seeking 48-Hour Visits
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — Defense lawyers for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others accused of being accomplices in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, asked a military tribunal judge in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on Tuesday to let them stay in prison with their clients for 48-hour periods every six months. But military prosecutors called that request unreasonable, saying the defense should be allowed only a single two-hour visit.

headline: Honduras Roster Includes 5 From M.L.S.
text: Honduras has named its 23-man roster for next week’s regional World Cup qualifying match against the United States. It includes 11 players who play domestically, six of them from the top domestic club, Olimpia, and five who play in Major League Soccer.

headline: Man Arrested in Attacks on Asians in East Harlem
text: Nearly two weeks after a violent robber began attacking Asian residents of East Harlem, the authorities arrested a man on Tuesday aboard an interstate bus in southern New Jersey.

headline: Walter O’Malley, Almost a Pay-Per-View Pioneer
text: Nearly 60 years ago, long before the Dodgers would make a nearly $8 billion television deal with Time Warner Cable, the Brooklyn Dodgers owner Walter O’Malley embarked on a plan that would make his team a lot of money: charging fans to watch home games on a pay-per-view basis.

headline: Talking Talent | Benjamin Walker
text: The Juilliard-trained theater actor Benjamin Walker, who played the 16th president on the silver screen in “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter” and Andrew Jackson on Broadway, has taken a break from American politics to star as the booze-swilling Brick in “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” at the Richard Rogers Theater through March 30. At a sculptured 6-foot-3, Walker successfully embodies Brick with bourbon-soaked vulnerability and plenty of southern charm. Thirty minutes before curtain, a cool and collected Walker answered T’s questions about crutches, lap dances and his almighty mother-in-law, Meryl Streep.

headline: Nail It Down, Tie It Down or Hold On Tight
text: New Yorkers, who have been enjoying a brief respite from the bitter cold of recent days, are being warned to batten down the hatches as weather forecasts predict strong winds and fierce thunderstorms across the city for Wednesday.

headline: Everyday Voices: Finding Black History in Unexpected Places
text: How can we teach African-American history through the everyday voices of ordinary people and not just iconic leaders? How does history have a way of cropping up where you least expect it: at the bottom of a forgotten old storage box, under the dirt of Central Park or in the memories of a long-running TV dance show?

headline: Alvin Ailey Troupe Headed to the David H. Koch Theater
text: The march to the Koch continues. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has become the latest dance company to take up residence at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center. Ailey said on Tuesday it would present seven performances at the Koch from June 12 to June 16, in addition to its touring and regular season at City Center.

headline: The 49ers’ Quarterback Drama? Steve Bono Has Been There
text: The Fifth Down recently talked with former Pro Bowl quarterback Steve Bono about one of his former teams, the San Francisco 49ers, who will play the Ravens in the Super Bowl on Sunday. Bono went 5-1 for San Francisco in 1991 when he replaced an injured Steve Young (Joe Montana was out for the season). Bono, 50, also played for the Vikings, Steelers, Chiefs, Rams, Packers and Panthers in his 14-year career. He now is a partner with Constellation Wealth Management Associates.

headline: The King of Cakes
text: In New Orleans, the king cake reigns supreme — just don’t find a baby in your slice.

headline: Catsimatidis Announces Bid for Mayor
text: John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of the Gristedes grocery chain, stood on the steps of City Hall on Tuesday and announced that he would seek the Republican nomination for mayor of New York City.

headline: A City Drenched in Sugar
text: NEW ORLEANS — Other cities might be trudging through cabbage season at this point in winter, but New Orleans is eating cake. From Twelfth Night to Mardi Gras, which is Feb. 12 this year, daily consumption of king cake — a round of sweet dough glazed with purple, gold and green sugar — is more or less compulsory. It’s a clue that although this city’s rémoulades and gumbos and Sazeracs are renowned, there is also a world of sweet treats to explore.

headline: Producers Scramble After Investor Withdraws From ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’
text: The Broadway producers of “Truman Capote’s ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’” are scrambling to raise $1 million after an investor pulled out of the $4 million show, according to a spokesman for the production, which began rehearsals on Monday and is scheduled to begin performances on March 4. The cast, led by Emilia Clarke (HBO’s “Game of Thrones”) as Holly Golightly, have been told that the production would be in jeopardy if the money was not replaced quickly. The play’s spokesman, Rick Miramontez, declined to identify the investor who dropped out, but said some additional money had already been raised and the producers were working hard to find the rest. Another Broadway-bound show this season, “Rebecca,” fell apart because of money problems after four of its investors were revealed to be phantoms. The producers of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” – Colin Ingram Productions Limited, Donovan Mannato and Dominic Ianno – are relative newcomers to Broadway.

headline: Streaming and Micropennies: The Footnotes
text: In Tuesday’s paper, I wrote about the royalties that musicians and record companies earn from online streaming companies like Spotify, Pandora and YouTube.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Publicist Sued Over E-Mails to Investor

headline: With Attitude and Tonics, 22 Gins Mixed and Matched
text: Cata, which opened on the Lower East Side last September, specializes in tapas and gin and tonics, a combination, it’s fair to say, that is not available on every corner. Not like burgers and fries. Soup and salad. Or even gin and tonic.

headline: Carville and Matalin Part Ways With CNN
text: 3:59 p.m. | Updated James Carville and Mary Matalin, staples of CNN’s political programming for over a decade, are parting ways with the channel, CNN confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Altidore the Target of Racist Chants
text: Jozy Altidore scored another goal for AZ on Tuesday in a Dutch Cup match, but it was the events before and after he scored that have brought condemnation.

headline: Ex-Janitor Convicted of Raping Girl in School Basement Repeatedly
text: A former Brooklyn middle-school janitor was convicted Tuesday of repeatedly raping and sexually abusing an eighth-grade girl, the district attorney’s office said.

headline: Hiring Help to Lure a Husband Out of a Bedroom
text: It takes extensive puppeteering to get Jeff Backhaus’s debut novel where he wants it to go. The first thing that “Hikikomori and the Rental Sister” must do is come up with an American hermit and agoraphobe with a set of traits that are much more common in Japan. This book needs a man who has withdrawn from society and will not leave his room, although Mr. Backhaus cannot replicate the subtle ways Japanese society enables traumatized young adults to try to erase themselves that way.

headline: From a Chance Meeting, ‘Lincoln’ Emerges
text: Watching the two-and-a-half-hour “Lincoln,” with its wartime scenes, epic Congressional and marital showdowns and presidential death, viewers might not think that its backstory involved a lot of winnowing and trimming. And yet, that’s exactly what was necessary, as Kathleen Kennedy, a producer of the film, revealed in a recent panel discussion hosted by the Producers Guild of America.

headline: Audience, Ready to Play Your Part?
text: For Claude Wampler, subterfuge isn’t a fashionable artistic device. She needs it.

headline: ‘The Test’ Will Join Television Talk Shows
text: MIAMI — Imagine a tabloid talk show like “Maury” distilled to its essence: the enduring question, “are you the father?”

headline: Lewis Avoids Questions About Banned Substance
text: NEW ORLEANS — Amid all the hoopla at Tuesday’s Super Bowl media day, Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis dismissed a report that he had used a banned performance enhancing substance this season to help recover from a torn triceps.

headline: Incestuous Amplification, Economics Edition
text: Back during the early days of the Iraq debacle, I learned that the military has a term for how highly dubious ideas become not just accepted, but viewed as certainties. “Incestuous amplification” happen when a closed group of people repeat the same things to each other – and when accepting the group’s preconceptions itself becomes a necessary ticket to being in the in-group. A fundamentally flawed notion – say, that the Germans can’t possibly attack though the Ardennes – becomes part of what everyone knows, where “everyone” means by definition only people who accept the flawed notion.

headline: Under Fire, Chesapeake Co-Founder to Depart

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Stolen Facebook IDs and All About Zelda
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: A Story Known Far and Wide, in Denmark at Least
text: Until this month, if the Danish director and screenwriter Nikolaj Arcel was known at all in the English-speaking world, it was as the co-writer of the screenplay for the original version of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.” But after winning two prizes at the Berlin Film Festival a year ago, the latest film he directed, “A Royal Affair,” is now getting attention in Hollywood as one of the five contenders nominated for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film.

headline: Right Tune, Right Singer: Pure Alchemy
text: “Bemused,” the title of the singer Christine Andreas’s deliciously tangy show at 54 Below, is one of the most misused and hard-to-pin-down words in the English language. As Ms. Andreas reflected on its meanings at Sunday evening’s opening-night performance, one synonym, “thunderstruck,” stood out.

headline: BlackBerry 10 Critical to Research in Motion
text: OTTAWA — Research in Motion’s introduction on Wednesday of a new BlackBerry phone will be the most important event in the company’s history since 1996, when its founders showed investors a small block of wood and promised that a wireless e-mail device shaped like that would change business forever.

headline: A Better Immigration Plan
text: President Obama hit the right notes when he made the case for overhauling the immigration system in a speech in Las Vegas on Tuesday. He spoke one day after a bipartisan group of eight senators released their own blueprint for a comprehensive reform bill, and the back-to-back events gave the odd sensation — rare during the Obama administration — of seeing Congress and the White House moving in more or less the same direction.

headline: Where to Eat in Staten Island: Lakruwana and Beyond
text: This week I review Lakruwana, a showcase for Sri Lankan food and crafts in Staten Island, a part of town that Times restaurant critics have not often written about.

headline: Modernizing the New York Public Library
text: Michael Kimmelman on the $300 million plan to renovate the legendary structure.

headline: In Renderings for a Library Landmark, Stacks of Questions
text: None of New York’s great buildings embody the spirit of the city more than the New York Public Library, the cherished century-old Beaux-Arts landmark in the heart of Midtown Manhattan. But cities change — New York all the time — and even the greatest buildings may need to change with them. So it was that more than four years ago the library announced a $250 million plan (since revised upward to $300 million and still rising). Norman Foster, the celebrity architect, was enlisted to revamp and modernize the 42nd Street building.

headline: If You Like A Taste of Honey, Try Little Dragon
text: If you hated disco back then, chances are you might stop reading. But if there is even a tiny possibility of reconsidering, I ask you to stick with me and give this week’s post a chance. According to an online biography of the group, the opening line of A Taste of Honey's 1978 hit song, "Boogie Oogie Oogie," was inspired by an especially tough and unresponsive audience at an American military base. Hazel Payne, one of the singers, yelled to the hostile crowd: "If you're thinkin' you're too cool to boogie, boy oh boy have I got news for you! Everybody here tonight must boogie, let me tell ya, you are no exception to the rule!"

headline: Does Championing Marriage Exclude Single Parents?
text: The Institute for American Values has issued a fairly remarkable “Call for a New Conversation on Marriage.” Its president, David Blankenhorn, is perhaps best known as the expert who testified against gay marriage in the Proposition 8 trial in California, and then changed his mind, publicly, with an Op-Ed article in The New York Times.

headline: ‘Requiem for the Barflies’

headline: ‘Bloomberg: The Musical’: He’s Not Calling the Tunes
text: BEGINNING on Wednesday, Encores! is bringing back “Fiorello!,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning 1959 musical about Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, to celebrate its 20th season. “Fiorello!” was the first show to be revived at City Center in a concert staging, the Encores! format that has become a New York cultural fixture. Why that show? “La Guardia saved City Center from the wrecking ball,” explained Jack Viertel, the program’s artistic director.

headline: In Energy Taxes, Tools to Help Tackle Climate Change

headline: In Limbaugh Interview, Rubio Charms the Host

The back and forth went so well, from Mr. Rubio’s point of view, that at 6 p.m. his office was still tweeting out highlights from the exchange.

headline: History-Rich Georgia Island Wins Second Look on Taxes

headline: A Jazz Reunion at the ‘Fame’ School
text: This is about jazz, so we’ll improvise, starting with Jimmy Owens, the renowned trumpeter, composer and bandleader. In cool threads (red jacket and green scarf), he’s remembering back more than 50 years to his days at the city’s High School of Music & Art, before it merged with the High School of Performing Arts — the “Fame” school — and before they moved together to Lincoln Center — before there really was a Lincoln Center.

headline: After Fire, Some Brazilians Fault a Nation’s Sense of Fatalism

Margaret Thatcher successfully tamed the unions and turned London into a powerful international financial center by deregulating the financial markets.

headline: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence

The gun lobby’s opposition to reasonable controls is already fierce, and political courage is, as ever, wavering in Congress. But this singular opportunity to curb the gun violence must not be wasted in more of the posturing in Washington that tolerates 30,000 gun deaths a year.

headline: Strict Gun Laws in Chicago Can’t Stem Fatal Shots
text: CHICAGO — Not a single gun shop can be found in this city because they are outlawed. Handguns were banned in Chicago for decades, too, until 2010, when the United States Supreme Court ruled that was going too far, leading city leaders to settle for restrictions some describe as the closest they could get legally to a ban without a ban. Despite a continuing legal fight, Illinois remains the only state in the nation with no provision to let private citizens carry guns in public.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WHO KILLED LINDBERGH’S BABY? On March 1, 1932, Charles and Anne Lindbergh’s 20-month-old son, above, was kidnapped from the family’s home near Hopewell, N.J. Negotiations stretched out for weeks, but the boy was never returned. His body was found two months later less than five miles from Hopewell, and, after a two-year investigation, Bruno Richard Hauptmann, a German immigrant living in the Bronx, was ultimately found guilty of extortion and murder. He was executed on April 3, 1936. This “Nova” episode reopens the case as investigators use contemporary forensic and behavioral-science techniques to determine what really happened to the child, and why.

headline: The Spy Novelist Who Knows Too Much
text: Last June, a pulp-fiction thriller was published in Paris under the title “Le Chemin de Damas.” Its lurid green-and-black cover featured a busty woman clutching a pistol, and its plot included the requisite car chases, explosions and sexual conquests. Unlike most paperbacks, though, this one attracted the attention of intelligence officers and diplomats on three continents. Set in the midst of Syria’s civil war, the book offered vivid character sketches of that country’s embattled ruler, Bashar al-Assad, and his brother Maher, along with several little-known lieutenants and allies. It detailed a botched coup attempt secretly supported by the American and Israeli intelligence agencies. And most striking of all, it described an attack on one of the Syrian regime’s command centers, near the presidential palace in Damascus, a month before an attack in the same place killed several of the regime’s top figures. “It was prophetic,” I was told by one veteran Middle East analyst who knows Syria well and preferred to remain nameless. “It really gave you a sense of the atmosphere inside the regime, of the way these people operate, in a way I hadn’t seen before.”

headline: Tune in To | Rachel Zeffira
text: Rachel Zeffira is nothing if not a lateral thinker. When she was 17, a bureaucratic error nearly resulted in her deportation from Britain and caused her to lose her place at a music school in London. So Zeffira, who is from Canada, reinvented herself as a 26-year-old substitute French teacher (“a language I don’t speak”) and stayed in England until she raised enough money to continue her studies in Verona, Italy. Years later, when she and her bandmate from Cat’s Eyes, Faris Badwan (the frontman of the Horrors), were looking for a venue to play their first gig, she used the contacts she’d made in Italy to secure an appearance at a Vatican Mass attended by several cardinals. “I told them we were a choir,” she says. “They thought our backup singers looked a little too sexy. At the last minute we had to rush out and buy opaque tights and shawls.” In her latest example of creative adaptation, the classically trained soprano and multi-instrumentalist has melded sacred music with a baroque pop sensibility on her debut solo album, “The Deserters.” It was released late last year in Britain (the North American release, on Paper Bag Records, is scheduled for March) and is earning rave reviews, with the BBC memorably describing it as “tummy meltingly wonderful.” Dreamy, seductive and sparse, “The Deserters” has a quiet lushness that’s markedly different from the girl-group-tinged sound of Cat’s Eyes, though Zeffira hesitates to specify how. “I like to leave it to the listener to describe the music,” she says. “I don’t like it to be spelled out.”

headline: The Gun Report: January 30, 2013
text: After my column on Tuesday about a week’s toll of gun violence, a number of readers suggested that I continue to publish examples of gun deaths that resulted from accidental shootings, momentary rage, a feud with a neighbor, a drive-by shooting—and all the other reasons American kill each other with guns. I think it is a good idea. For the foreseeable future, my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I, will be culling one or two news stories each day, and linking to them on my blog.

headline: Dutch Arts Groups Shut Down as Funding Vanishes
text: AMSTERDAM — In the 1980s and ’90s, the Netherlands had a reputation as a kind of paradise for artists. Graduates of fine arts academies could receive long-term grants and special housing subsidies to support them so they wouldn’t have to get day jobs. Edgy theater groups and small contemporary classical ensembles were fully financed to create innovative and experimental work. The government even bought art directly from artists who weren’t particularly commercial, maintaining it in large storage facilities, simply to support artistic production.

headline: Going Abroad? How the State Department Can Help
text: Here’s some perspective on how drastically our travel habits have changed in recent years: In 1989, seven million Americans had passports, according to the State Department. Today 113 million do. Gone, too, are days when Americans stuck almost exclusively to the London-Paris-Rome circuit, said Brenda S. Sprague, the State Department’s deputy assistant secretary for passport services. “That gives them the potential to get in more trouble,” she said. “But now they’re better able to keep in touch with us, and we with them.” Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Sprague on what help the State Department can offer you abroad.

headline: Stone Links: Jane Austen, Ethicist? Pope Benedict, Marxist?
text: Like his predecessor John Paul II, who wrote his doctoral dissertation on the German phenomenologist Max Scheler, and wove a keen understanding of philosophical history into encyclicals like “Fides et Ratio”, Pope Benedict XVI also seems quite comfortable engaging in philosophical debate. Judging by his interactions with Jürgen Habermas, among others, one might assume that the Pope stands for a political and theological conservatism quite at odds with Marxist tradition. Yet they, and indeed Benedict himself might be surprised to find that, as a post at First Things explains, he evidently has his admirers on the left. Four Italian “Ratzingerian Marxists” of the “Old Left” have issued a “manifesto” hoping to enlist the Pope in their fight against a “consumerist-inflected secularism.” Strange bedfellows? Maybe not, considering that a few close readers of Benedict’s 2007 encyclical “Spe Salvi” have noted that the Pope cites Max Horkheimer and Theodor Adorno to help refute the plausibility of the thesis that, with the waning of theistic belief, “man himself is now called to establish justice.”

But thanks to a culinary newcomer, there’s a reason to return. Opened last April by Giovanna Arcangeli — a Murano native who planned events at the legendary Harry’s Bar for a decade and knows a thing or two about preserving a cultured calm in the midst of a touristy enclave — Acquastanca is a refuge from all that. “We wanted to create a place where guests would be able to relax and enjoy good food in a warm, quiet atmosphere with locals,” Ms. Arcangeli said.

text: 4:15 p.m. | Updated A new long-range product plan for Chrysler Group, revealed on Wednesday in Detroit, confirms a broad expansion of the availability of Fiat and Alfa Romeo models in North America over the next three years.

headline: Somalia Moves to Prosecute Woman Who Accused Soldiers of Rape
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Somali government, in a move that has outraged human rights groups, has charged a woman who said she was gang-raped by soldiers with making a false accusation and having “insulted and lowered the dignity of a National Institution,” crimes that could mean many years in prison.

headline: Less Than Zero (Growth)
text: Pay no attention to that minus sign! The consensus among economists seems to be that the economy did not really contract in the last quarter of 2012, despite the government’s initial measure, released this morning, which shows the economy shrinking at an annual rate of 0.1 percent, its weakest performance since the spring of 2009.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: BlackBerry Z10
text: David Pogue reviews the BlackBerry Z10.

headline: With BlackBerry’s New Name, an Abridged History of Corporate Rebranding
text: As the new BlackBerry line was introduced on Wednesday, a corporate name was sent to the dustbin.

headline: Intense Fighting in Damascus
text: Free Syrian Army fighters battled government forces in the Ain Tarma neighborhood.

headline: Give Us Your Best Honking Haiku
text: So the city is taking down all those “No Honking” signs, as The New York Times reported Tuesday, having concluded that their efficacy is, at best, uncertain.

headline: Judge Allows N.C.A.A. Lawsuit to Include Television Revenue
text: A federal judge on Tuesday rejected a motion by the N.C.A.A. to preclude live broadcast revenues from a lawsuit by men’s football and basketball players, which means college sports faces a much steeper paycheck should the players prevail in their class action lawsuit.

headline: Youthful Memories, Reinvented
text: You can’t underestimate the transformation of what seems like an ordinary song when an interpreter like Sharón Clark, a Washington-based jazz and soul diva, tears it apart and peers inside. A prime example in her show “Blame It on My Youth,” at the Metropolitan Room on Monday evening, was her ruminative interpretation of the old Carpenters’ hit, “Rainy Days and Mondays,” supported by Chris Grasso on piano, Tony Jefferson on drums and Neal Miner on bass.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Two eerie story collections and two comic novels are part of this month’s crop, along with an anthology that has science writers aiming to explain, well, everything.

headline: Trees of Life
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Israeli Airstrike in Syria Targets Arms Convoy, U.S. Says
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli warplanes carried out a strike deep inside Syrian territory on Wednesday, American officials reported, saying they believed the target was a convoy carrying sophisticated antiaircraft weaponry on the outskirts of Damascus that was intended for the Hezbollah Shiite militia in Lebanon.

headline: Scene City: A Yoga Break Before Fashion Week
text: Donna Karan and other celebrity yogis attended a gala for Bent on Learning, which brings yoga to public schools.

headline: An App That May Overshare on Facebook
text: Since its copyright blunder last month, Instagram, the wildly popular photo sharing service, has been besieged by rivals claiming to give users better control and privacy.

headline: 64 Gigabytes Can’t Be Wrong: Elvis USB Drives
text: Mimoco, the company known for its Mimobot flash drives made to resemble geek-friendly characters like Boba Fett, Captain Kirk and Batman, has added a figure from a distinctly different sphere of pop culture, Elvis Presley.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: BlackBerry Has High Hopes for New Phones
text: A closer look at the reinvented BlackBerry. Behind the scenes at Super Bowl media day. David Pogue’s 60-second BlackBerry review. Go to the Bits blog to see the video.

headline: When a Divorce Makes a Better Dad
text: Divorce stinks. Don’t get me wrong. The excruciating pain of leaving your child on Mom’s doorstep, of missing holidays and first steps, of having to schedule visitation are nothing to sign up for unless there is no other choice. My divorce involved the kind of pain that makes you think walking in front of a train would be a piece of cake if not for your responsibilities. But buried deep within that pain is a silver lining — a motivation, an aspiration, a hands-on learning — that “normal” dads don’t get.

headline: Bending and Breathing to Fashionable Wills
text: What’s on Deepak Chopra’s playlist this year?

headline: After Heart Attack, Ship Engineer Is Rescued by Helicopter
text: The New York police staged a nighttime helicopter rescue mission in New York Harbor on Tuesday, saving the life of the ship’s 60-year-old chief engineer, who had a heart attack while the 360-foot cargo vessel was anchored far from shore.

headline: Intense Fighting in Damascus
text: Free Syrian Army fighters battled government forces in the Ain Tarma neighborhood.

headline: Post These Letters, Jeeves. Thanks, Old Bean.
text: Writing to his agent in 1935, the comic novelist P. G. Wodehouse (1881-1975) proposed an essay about literary criticism that he planned to call “Back to Whiskers.” This piece is still worth rooting around to find.

headline: The Battle for Syria’s Minakh Air Base
text: Since late last spring, when fighters opposed to President Bashar al-Assad began pushing government security forces out of parts of northern Syria, one military compound north of Aleppo has been a stubborn holdout: the air base at Minakh.

headline: An Early Trip to Ralph Lauren’s Land
text: A few designers are getting a jump on the Fashion Week festivities by showing their fall collections now, either in small showroom presentations, or very big ones, as did Ralph Lauren with his men’s wear on Tuesday.

headline: Then There Was One: An Illinois Ex-Governor Leaves Prison
text: CHICAGO — George Ryan was released from a federal prison in the dark on Wednesday morning, and Illinois became a state with only one former governor behind bars.

headline: Timeless Book May Require Some Timely Fact Checking
text: Journalism is meant to be the first draft of history, and newspaper articles fit that mold nicely, fading into the archives. But books are not so neat.

headline: Pakistani Girl Shot by Taliban to Get Skull Surgery
text: The Pakistani teenager who was shot in the head by the Taliban last year for advocating for the education of girls will return to a British hospital for skull surgery and has asked to keep a fragment of bone from her skull as a souvenir, medical staff said on Wednesday.

headline: Martin Sheen, No Longer a ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ Opponent
text: 4:49 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES —On consideration, and widespread reports to the contrary notwithstanding, Martin Sheen said he did not believe that Oscar voters or anyone else should shun “Zero Dark Thirty.”

headline: Marcum Will Fill Dickey’s Innings, if Not His Shoes
text: The Mets on Wednesday officially introduced the right-handed starter Shaun Marcum, whom they signed to a one-year contract to fill out their rotation after the departure of R. A. Dickey.

headline: The Dangerous Game
text: Football’s reputation is taking a beating, with each troubling new report on the advancing science of brain injury, each new account of some brutal hit or serious injury at the collegiate or professional level, and each revelation about the damage the sport does to the lives and health of the men who play it.

headline: The Man Behind the Ravens’ Curtain
text: NEW ORLEANS — Just inside the front door of the Baltimore Ravens’ chateau-with-shoulder-pads training center hangs an enormous portrait of the former owner who still hovers over the franchise and the city as surely as that oil painting over the big stone fireplace.

headline: A Bigger Spotlight on Young Talents
text: This has been a big week for emerging talents.

headline: For Manningham, a Frustrating End to the Season
text: Mario Manningham took a gamble last off-season when he signed with the 49ers. On the Giants, he had to fight for the ball with fellow wide receivers Victor Cruz and Hakeem Nicks. But the Giants were also defending Super Bowl Champions thanks in part to Manningham’s acrobatic catch on the team’s game-winning drive.

headline: France Will Dim Its Lights to Conserve Energy
text: PARIS — The City of Light is about to get dimmer.

headline: California Suspends Fine Against Lyft, a Hail-a-Ride App
text: The ability to summon a car with a smartphone app sounds convenient, but lawmakers and city governments have been nervous about how these apps might pose risks to consumers. A car-requesting app called Lyft has persuaded California to loosen up.

headline: Ratings Drop for Season Premiere of ‘Dallas’
text: The ratings for the two-hour premiere of season two of “Dallas,” the revival of the fabled soap on the TNT cable channel, are not going to do much to relieve the down mood left after the death of the show’s central star, Larry Hagman.

headline: Big Investor Supports Elliott Push for Shake-Up at Hess
text: A big investor in the energy company Hess Corporation said on Wednesday that it supported the changes called for by the hedge fund Elliott Management.

headline: All He Touches Turns to Cashmere
text: Greg Chait, the designer of the Elder Statesman, is not someone you would expect to be named the class of 2012’s most likely to succeed.

headline: Songs for the Week, Surpassingly Cool Edition
text: Wm. Ferguson creates “The Music They Made,” an end-of-the-year tribute to musicians as part of our annual The Lives They Lived  Issue. Here he presents three songs you should listen to this week.

headline: Lewis Responds to Allegations
text: Ray Lewis and his coach, John Harbaugh, denied the validity of a report that Lewis had used a banned performance enhancing substance this season to help recover from a torn triceps.

headline: Facebook’s Solid Results Are Greeted Cautiously
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook made a lot of money in the last quarter. It also spent a lot. And that made investors once again cautious about the company.

headline: Aaron Sorkin Drops Out of Broadway ‘Houdini’
text: Aaron Sorkin, who was to make his debut as a librettist with the Broadway musical “Houdini,” has pulled his own disappearing act and dropped out of the production because of scheduling conflicts, the producers confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Answer in Sight for ‘How I Met Your Mother’
text: It will take, in total, nine years, but yes, there will be an answer to “How I Met Your Mother” — and it will be revealed in spring 2014.

headline: Table Talk | Raven & Rose in Portland, Ore.
text: “It’s about creating a space that combines old world traditions with new world sensibilities,” says David Padberg, the chef of Raven & Rose, a newly opened restaurant in Portland, Ore. Located in downtown’s 1883 historic Ladd Carriage House, which the owner Lisa Mygrant meticulously restored and renovated, the restaurant makes references to the past in a most fitting way with its food and drink.

headline: Wall Street Prepares to Crack BrickBreaker Habit
text: Another Wall Street mainstay may be facing extinction.

headline: Myths of Weight Loss Are Plentiful, Researcher Says
text: If schools reinstated physical education classes, a lot of fat children would lose weight. And they might never have gotten fat in the first place if their mothers had just breast fed them when they were babies. But be warned: obese people should definitely steer clear of crash diets. And they can lose more than 50 pounds in five years simply by walking a mile a day.

headline: In the Austrian Alps, an Antique Tyrolean Chalet
text: A four-bedroom chalet with an ornate scalloped fascia and two intricate lathed balconies is on the market for $3.06 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Austria
text: A MID-18TH-CENTURY TYROLEAN CHALET IN THE AUSTRIAN ALPS

headline: Using a Smartphone to Keep Track of the Pennies
text: “Look after the pennies, and the pounds will look after themselves” is a British proverb that works equally well when you translate it into dollars and cents. In either form, it means that if you’re careful with the details of your spending, then you’ll save more money.

headline: With a Smile, Ray Lewis Denies Extract Allegations
text: A day after swiftly brushing off a report that he had used a banned performance enhancing substance this season to help recover from a torn triceps, Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis strongly rebuffed the allegations on Wednesday.

headline: A Tiny Computer Attracts a Million Tinkerers
text: Raspberry Pi may sound like the name of a math-based dessert. But it is actually one of the hottest and cheapest little computers in the world right now. Almost one million of these $35 machines have shipped since last February, capturing the imaginations of educators, hobbyists and tinkerers around the world.

headline: Knoedler Gallery Again Accused of Fraud in New Lawsuit
text: The once-grand Knoedler gallery has been accused again of selling a forged painting for $5.5 million that was attributed to an American master, in this case, the artist Mark Rothko.

headline: Kaleidoscope of Destiny’s Patterns
text: New York City Ballet’s season grows both worse and better. The ghastly art installation in the foyer of the David H. Koch Theater, titled “Les Ballets De Faile,” has now spread over into boards in the side foyers downstairs and diminishes the pleasure in attendance by several more degrees.

headline: A Cyclical View
text: Highlights from the New York City Ballet’s performance.

headline: A Ticket to Love (and New Sandals, Too)
text: There are some essential New York experiences: dining one table over from Woody Allen, learning which subway car will land you closest to the exit, mocking the size of the apartments on “Friends.”

headline: Nuclear Test Could Open Window on North Korea
text: WASHINGTON — The world is warning North Korea against going ahead with its third nuclear test, but inside the American intelligence community, some officials are quietly hoping it happens. A test could give them their first real view in years into whether the North has made significant progress toward a weapon that could threaten the United States or its allies.

headline: Off the Tourist Grid in the Bahamas
text: Waves rolled through the night, pitching the ship from side to side. From the bridge deck, the white sand beaches of the Exumas glowed blue-white under the starlight, and the rising moon spread a thin layer of silver over the sea. A few miles north, toward our destination in Nassau, lightning flickered.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 31
text: How to get “gangster style”; shopping for gold cuff earrings; and a new line of vintage-looking sneakers and high-waist jeans.

headline: Homes for $2.5 Million
text: Properties in Virginia, Colorado and California.

headline: What You Get for ... $2.5 Million
text: BROOKNEAL, VA.

headline: Shoulder Injury Sidelines the Rangers’ Captain
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers breathed a sigh of relief Wednesday when they learned that the injury to their captain, Ryan Callahan, was not as serious as some had feared.

headline: Excerpt: ’30 Rock’ Finale
text: The NBC sitcom starring Tina Fey and Alec Baldwin ends on Thursday.

headline: Rethinking Seacrest
text: IT’S EASY TO MAKE FUN of Ryan Seacrest — for his ubiquity on the show business landscape, for his overweening ambition, for his role in unleashing the Kardashian clan on America and for his relentless pursuit of celebrities as they head into award shows (captured most memorably a few years ago when he was shown on camera practically chasing Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie down the red carpet as they seemed determined to avoid him and his E! camera crew).

headline: ‘Katie’ to Return for a Second Season
text: Not many syndicated talk shows survive to a second year, but if one show was a likely candidate, it was the new entry starring Katie Couric. On Wednesday, Disney-ABC Domestic Television made it official: the show will return for a second season.

headline: Story Lines Built by the Global Economic Slowdown
text: Before you tackle an issue, remember to tell a good tale. That’s a quick and dirty rule for playwrights looking to explore big topics onstage. After all, if you can’t earn an audience’s attention, your ideas are sure to be ignored.

headline: Bond Set at $11 Million for Spanish King’s Son-in-Law
text: MADRID — A Spanish judge on Wednesday demanded that the son-in-law of King Juan Carlos and his former business partner post bond of $11 million as the state deepens its investigation into whether they embezzled millions of dollars in public money allocated to sports and tourism events.

headline: Tina Fey Signs Off, Broken Barriers Behind Her
text: Tina Fey leaves prime time television pretty much the way she entered it seven years ago, as a sly observer who bites the network that feeds her so much material.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Egypt, Mali and Greece.

headline: The Doctors Are In, and the Knives Are Out, in Two Medical Dramas
text: If hospitals already scare you, you might want to avoid both of the new doctor dramas, “Do No Harm,” on NBC (Thursday) and “Monday Mornings,” on TNT (Monday). Critic’s orders.

headline: Tuesday in the Hall With Stephen
text: “Attend the score of ‘Sweeney Todd,’ ” Nathan Lane said, tweaking the lyric to the ballad that opens the masterpiece musical by Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler. The occasion was a special New York Philharmonic program on Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, titled “Symphonic Sondheim,” devoted to orchestral arrangements of suites from four of Mr. Sondheim’s musicals, along with incidental music to a play, “The Enclave,” and a suite from the film score for “Stavisky.” Mr. Lane was the droll host. On the podium was the great Sondheim maestro Paul Gemignani.

headline: Tolerance, Intolerance and Soccer
text: With nasty occurrences of racist behavior by some soccer fans in Europe fresh and acrid (including those involving the United States international Jozy Altidore during a game in the Netherlands on Tuesday), Wednesday brought a strange coincidence — stretching from Germany to Israel.

headline: Museum Leaders Toughen Artifact Acquisition Guidelines
text: The Association of Art Museum Directors has voted to strengthen rules requiring museums to publish pictures and information about antiquities they have acquired that might be subject to questions of looting.

headline: Poured Into Clothes, Literally
text: Jill Paul, 65, of Westminster, Colo., used to pour “a gallon” of moisturizer on her legs every day, she said. But then a friend told her about Proskins SLIM, a line of nylon and Lycra clothing that claims to fight cellulite, improve circulation and promote lymphatic drainage.

headline: Life in the 1930s
text: Peter McGough, half of the time-bending art duo McDermott & McGough, owns a home in the Italian Moderne style in the West Village in New York City.

headline: Living in Sepia
text: They were the dandies of Avenue C, swanning about in cutaway suit coats, top hats and detachable starched collars. They made paintings the old-fashioned way, dressed in smocks and using rabbit skin glue primer and lead gesso on linen tacked, rather than stapled, to stretchers they found in the garbage. They backdated their work to the early 1900s, or before.

headline: Rock Star Toasts the Glory Days of Analog
text: Dave Grohl takes another step toward Renaissance-man status with “Sound City,” his likable debut as a documentary director.

headline: Living Dangerously Without Ring-Fencing
text: European banks won’t have to ring-fence their risky activities after all.

headline: An Eden of Houseplants
text: Tovah Martin’s indoor jungle.

headline: Inviting the Garden Inside
Knockout Teams at the District 3 Winter Regional
text: The Friday-Saturday Knockout Teams at the District 3 Winter Regional this month was won by Susan Schnelwar, Jesus Arias and Bjorn Fallenius of New York City and John Kranyak of Las Vegas. In the final, they defeated Justine Cushing, Melih Ozdil and Joel Wooldridge of New York City and Sadik Arf of Saratoga, Calif.

headline: Germans Press Morsi on Slurs Against Jews as Berlin Marks Somber Anniversary
text: Last Updated, 7:32 p.m. During a visit to Germany that coincided with somber commemorations of Hitler’s rise to power eight decades ago on Wednesday, Egypt’s president was pressed several times to explain anti-Semitic comments he made in 2010, when he called Israelis “bloodsuckers” and “the descendants of apes and pigs.”

headline: Jesse Jackson Proposes Creation of a New Lender
text: There’s been no shortage of ideas for how to jump-start economic growth in the aftermath of the financial crisis. But a new one comes with a high-profile backer: the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.

headline: Malnourished Gain Lifesaver in Antibiotics
text: Two studies of malnourished children offer the first major new scientific findings in a decade about the causes and treatment of severe malnutrition, which affects more than 20 million children around the world and contributes to the deaths of more than a million a year. Merely giving children a cheap antibiotic along with the usual nutritional treatment could save tens of thousands of lives a year, researchers found.

headline: ESPN Gets Mexico Games, and U.S. Fans Get a Bonus
text: ESPN and Univision Deportes on Wednesday announced an agreement in which ESPN will provide English-language coverage of 20 Mexican national team games, including exhibitions and World Cup qualifiers, while Univision broadcasts the games in Spanish.

headline: Animation Basks in Oscar Spotlight
text: LOS ANGELES — At one minute 45 seconds, with credits, “Fresh Guacamole“ is the briefest film ever nominated for an Oscar. It’s a stop-motion short in which that popular avocado dish is remade with different ingredients, starting with a grenade in place of the avocado. The short, made by an animator known as PES, is a sequel of sorts to “Western Spaghetti,” a stop-motion recipe of pickup sticks pasta and Rubik’s cube garlic. It’s the first film PES, born Adam Pesapane, submitted for Oscar consideration, a process that presented some challenges for a filmmaker whose work usually lives on YouTube.

headline: Ensconced in His Closet
text: For his most recent extravaganza, a Halloween party with the unlikely theme of a socialite’s funeral circa 1950, David Hopkins lined the sidewalk outside his building with more than 500 memorial candles and hired musicians to perform a funeral dirge on accordion, banjo and musical saw. Later that evening, he led a procession of partygoers to an outdoor space behind the two adjoining apartments he rents, where a pasty truck served British street food under a crystal chandelier Mr. Hopkins had suspended from the building’s exterior.

headline: How to Support a Decorating Habit
text: In Chicago, David Hopkins has turned his apartment into a laboratory of style. To finance it, he rents out the space and sleeps in the closet.

headline: Shopping for Cutting Boards
text: Richard Blais, a chef and restauranteur, says that cutting boards are too important to be neglected.

headline: Cutting Boards
text: ON THE COVER of Richard Blais’s new cookbook, “Try This at Home,” out next month from Clarkson Potter, is a close-up of the 40-year-old chef’s head on a plate. It’s intended as a comic reference to the book’s tagline, “Recipes From My Head to Your Plate,” but it also reminds readers of the proverbial chopping block Mr. Blais faced on “Top Chef,” on Bravo, where he was cut in the final round of the 2008 season (although he went on to win “Top Chef: All Stars” in 2010).

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Would putting a washer and dryer in my apartment increase the resale value?

headline: Yankees Consider Hafner as Designated Hitter
text: The Yankees are considering the veteran free agent Travis Hafner as a possible left-handed designated hitter, according to a person familiar with the team’s planning. No deal is close, and the Yankees continue to look at other candidates.

headline: In Dispute Over Ray Charles Songs, Family Gains Victory in Court
text: A dispute between the children of Ray Charles and the foundation to which he left most of his money is the latest battleground in one of the entertainment industry’s most contentious issues: the “termination rights” that allow artists and their families to recover the copyrights to their work from third parties like record companies or publishers.

headline: Putting a Lid on It
text: Unremittingly famous for defining a generation, Douglas Coupland is, himself, a creative whirl. Last week, at the Interior Design Show in Toronto, the 51-year-old “Generation X” novelist, essayist, sculptor, painter, digital artist and designer introduced his furniture for the luxury design company SwitzerCultCreative.

headline: Piecing Together Accounts of a Massacre in Syria
text: As my colleagues Hania Mourtada and Alan Cowell report, the bodies of dozens of young men, shot in the head from close range with their hands bound, were found in a narrow river in a neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, on Tuesday.

headline: G.D.P. Shrinks
text: The gross domestic product shrank last quarter for the first time since mid-2009, partly as a result of declines in military spending and exports. Private residential investment continued to grow, indicating that the housing market is still recovering.

headline: Designing Brothers on Display
text: From Friday through March 31, Longue Vue House & Gardens, the eight-acre estate in New Orleans formerly owned by the philanthropists Edith and Edgar Stern, will host a 30-year retrospective of the work of the versatile designing brothers Gene and Doug Meyer. The show will permeate building and grounds with a panoply of the brothers’ creations that reveal their ebullient way with color and striking mixes of art and fashion. “Joe Baker, the director, has been calling it an intervention,” Doug Meyer said. Garments, pillows and fabrics will be presented on mannequins throughout the main house. A 10-foot-square mirrored Plexiglas box set inside the Whim House — a guest house that had previously been closed to the public — will be a showcase for rugs. The catalog is $12 from dougandgene.com. Information: (504) 488-5488 or longuevue.com.

headline: Remember ‘Moose Murders’? She Was There — Onstage
text: “From now on, there will always be two groups of theatergoers in this world: those who have seen ‘Moose Murders,’ and those who have not.”

headline: Illness Walks the Runway
text: A top fashion designer quarantines a sneezing underling, forcing her to work in a closet. An industry P.R. executive makes colleagues douse their hands with Purell. Germ-phobic magazine editors are powerblasting offices with antiseptic wipes and Lysol.

headline: Echoes of an Ancient Civilization
text: Forrest Lesch-Middelton, a potter in Petaluma, Calif., makes ceramics that look like the products of an ancient civilization whose people proudly insisted on being buried with their dishware. The surfaces are mottled, the decorations irregular and the tones earthy siennas and fawns. Mr. Lesch-Middelton invented a technique for transferring Islamic starbursts, scrolls and flowers to the surfaces of his pots while they are still on the wheel, requiring him to shape the vessels from the inside. (He began this work in 2003, the year the United States invaded Iraq, saying he wanted to show off the artistic heritage of a culture he believed was misunderstood.)

headline: Stay Tuned for Another Flicker
text: You might not be home every evening watching television, but no burglar needs to know that. The coruscating light of a television set — signature feature of an occupied home — might be enough to scare prowlers off.

headline: Living Small
text: The Vermont artist Leslie Fry is known for her large outdoor sculptures, often fanciful creatures that are part flora, part fauna. Last year, in South Korea, she created a 10-foot-long piece for the Songchu Art Valley of a human head with flowers, which seems, like many of her works, to be growing up out of the ground. Recently Ms. Fry attempted sculptures scaled for inside the house. “I have a lot of architectural elements in my work” she said, “and I wanted to try pieces that were small and inexpensive.” The result, a perfect antidote to the gray days of winter, is the Rainbow Rowhouse, a translucent resin house 5 inches tall and 3 inches wide. The houses can be ordered individually for $25, or as a set of eight for $150. Upon request, a hole will be drilled in each house to enable it to be hung. Information: etsy.com/shop/FryDay.

headline: Sales at Gretel Home, Urban Archaeology and Others
text: Housewares are up to 50 percent off at Gretel Home, while supplies last (the Arbour cake stand by Y’a Pas le Feu au Lac, shown, usually $150, is $90); (786) 247-9003, gretelhome.com.

headline: Scouting Report
text: Pop-Ups

headline: Books in the Sun
text: As a graphic designer for a print publication, I am heavily invested in the question of whether print will ever die. (No!) One way I reassure myself is by looking at the niche market of art books, which appears to be alive and well.

headline: Renewable Energy Industries Push for New Financing Options
text: For years, green energy industries like wind and solar have been telling Congress that they cannot yet compete with fossil fuels without hefty tax breaks intended especially for them.

headline: Contrary to 49ers’ Stance, Culliver Says He Wouldn’t Accept a Gay Teammate
text: 11:44 p.m. | Updated NEW ORLEANS — In a media circus — with questions involving supplements made from deer antlers and players discussing the terrifying nature of head injuries — the conversation has turned back to how the N.F.L. would accept an openly gay player.

headline: Take Your Surge Protector for a Spin
text: Surge protectors aren’t very exciting to think about, but they do serve a necessary purpose: safeguarding our gadgets while supplying them with juice. So, hats off to 360 Electrical for giving them a little extra thought.

headline: The Lady, the Dog and the Deli Sandwich Order
text: Updated, Thursday | See lengthy update below (we talked to the woman with the dog).

headline: Edward M. Kresky, Who Calmed Fiscal Panic, Dies at 88
text: Edward M. Kresky, an investment banker who was an architect of the debt refinancing plan that saved New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s, died on Jan. 23 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Coming Soon: An Android Game System From Nvidia
text: What do you get when you cross an Xbox controller with a five-inch Android tablet with beefy stereo speakers? Nvidia’s new touch-screen portable gaming system, code-named Project Shield. The handheld game system was unveiled at the Consumer Electronics Show this month in Las Vegas, and it could spell more bad news for the Sony Vita, Nintendo 3DS or any other entry in the mobile gaming market. Why? Because it further stretches how consumers can buy and experience video games.

headline: Video: Tornadoes Rip Across Southeast
text: At least two people were killed when a powerful line of storms in the Southeast spawned tornadoes, demolishing homes and businesses, downing trees and flipping more than 100 cars and several tractor-trailers on a major interstate in northern Georgia.

headline: Super Bowl Ad Previews Draw Online Attention, With Criticism
text: Don’t misunderstand John Norman, the chief creative officer at TBWA/Chiat/Day Los Angeles. He is excited to be working on a commercial, for Pepsi Next cola, that will appear during Super Bowl XLVII on Sunday — the biggest day of the year for advertising as well as for football.

headline: Making ‘Every Patient Counts’ a Business Imperative
text: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — Drug companies are fond of saying that every patient counts, but in the world of orphan diseases, entire business plans are built around the idea.

headline: Drone Strike Prompts Suit, Raising Fears for U.S. Allies
text: The death of Malik Daud Khan, a Pakistani tribal elder, in a C.I.A. drone strike might have remained widely unremarked upon, lost amid thousands of others analysts have tallied in the American drone campaign, had not the British courts been brought into it.

headline: Patty Andrews, Singer With Her Sisters, Is Dead at 94
text: Patty Andrews, the last of the Andrews Sisters, the jaunty vocal trio whose immensely popular music became part of the patriotic fabric of World War II America, died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: Prominent Prosecutor Is Expected to Join the Private Sector

headline: Judge Overrules Censors in Guantánamo 9/11 Hearing

headline: Take a Bow, H.C.
text: Friday is Hillary Clinton’s final day at the State Department. As we’ve all been reminded, over the past four years she’s traveled 956,733 miles to 112 different countries in order to conduct 1,700 meetings with world leaders. While consuming 570 airplane meals.

headline: 2 Campaign Aides Going on Trial, but Comptroller May Face Judgment

Liu, a councilman from Flushing, Queens, who would soon be elected New York City comptroller.

headline: Wal-Mart’s Modest Steps on Fire Safety
text: Wal-Mart Stores last week adopted a “zero tolerance” policy for weak fire safety standards at foreign factories that make clothes sold by the company. The new policy, following a devastating fire in November that killed 112 workers at a Bangladesh factory, includes some positive changes like periodic safety audits, but it does not go far enough in imposing strict standards or in helping factory owners pay for improvements to protect laborers.

headline: Israel Ducks on Human Rights
text: Israel has increasingly isolated itself from the world with its hard-line policies on West Bank settlements, the Gaza embargo and other issues. This week, it unwisely set itself further apart with a decision to withhold cooperation from a United Nations Human Rights Council review of its human rights practices.

headline: Chasing Respect, Ravens Earn It From Their Inspiration, Ali
text: NEW ORLEANS — Jim and John Harbaugh compete on many levels, most notably as coaches of opposing teams in the Super Bowl on Sunday. But when it comes to inspirational first fans, John seems to have the upper hand.

headline: Russia Cancels Agreement With U.S.
text: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev said Wednesday that Russia would cancel a decade-long agreement with the United States that called for cooperation on law enforcement efforts including drug control and combating human trafficking. Relations between the two countries have been particularly troubled since December, when the United States adopted a law aimed at punishing Russian human rights abusers. Aleksei Pushkov, a Parliament member, said that Russia could afford to fight crime on its own. Russian officials also announced that they would ban certain frozen meat and meat products from the United States because of evidence farmers were using an artificial growth stimulant called ractopamine.

headline: Political Power Needs to Be Used
text: If ever there were a moment for Democrats to press their political advantage, this is it. Their message on many of the biggest national issues — taxes, guns, education spending, financial regulation — has widespread support, and they have increased their numbers in both houses of Congress. But after years of being out-yelled by strident right-wing ideologues, too many in the Democratic Party still have a case of nerves, afraid of bold action and forthright principles.

headline: Officials Back Deep Cuts in Atlantic Cod Harvest to Save Industry
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Fishery management officials meeting here on Wednesday voted to impose drastic new cuts to the commercial harvest of cod along the Atlantic coast, arguing that the only way to save the centuries-old cod fishing industry was to sharply limit it.

headline: Kerry Says Goodbye to the Senate
text: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts bade a long and emotional farewell to the Senate  on Wednesday, as he prepared to leave it after 28 years to become the secretary of state.

headline: Factory Owners Arrested in Bangladesh
text: The Bangladeshi police have arrested two owners of a factory that caught fire last week, resulting in the deaths of seven workers, in the latest blaze to strike the country’s garment export industry. Late Tuesday night, the police arrested Sharif Ahmed, chairman of Smart Export Garments, and his colleague, M. D. Zakir Ahmed. The Smart Export factory was manufacturing clothing for several European clothing brands.

headline: Hackers in China Attacked The Times for Last 4 Months
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last four months, Chinese hackers have persistently attacked The New York Times, infiltrating its computer systems and getting passwords for its reporters and other employees.

headline: Super Bowl Tickets Available; Bring Cash, Lots, to the Hotel
text: NEW ORLEANS — Steve Sigel has spent Super Bowl week running around this city with backpacks stuffed with thousands of dollars in cash. After leaving their base of operations — a recently rented house in a residential neighborhood — he and an associate dart in and out of public places like coffee shops and hotel lobbies, locations they have deemed safe for the frequent, high-money transactions they deal with.

headline: Meet the Champs
text: You see America and its education system in all their glorious, exhilarating, crushing, infuriating contradictions in our national high school chess champion team.

headline: Soft and Deadly
text: You may not think of your cat as an invasive species. But it is, in fact, a kind of superpredator, camouflaged by its affinity for humans, its playfulness, its ingratiating independence. Anywhere outdoors, the domestic cat occupies a dominant and unthreatened niche; its few natural enemies, like coyotes, are no match for tens of millions of free-roaming cats, including beloved pets and feral cats.

headline: Blocking Path of Baseball’s Drug Inquiries
text: WASHINGTON — As the United States Anti-Doping Agency moved forward last year with its investigation into Lance Armstrong, it used a powerful tool in building its case: the ability to offer other cyclists reduced suspensions if they provided information about Armstrong’s doping.

headline: Federal Rule Limits Aid to Families Who Can’t Afford Employers’ Health Coverage
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration adopted a strict definition of affordable health insurance on Wednesday that will deny federal financial assistance to millions of Americans with modest incomes who cannot afford family coverage offered by employers.

text: One of the city’s largest and most powerful labor unions plans to endorse the speaker of the City Council, Christine C. Quinn, for mayor on Thursday, giving an early and symbolically important boost to her campaign.

text: PHILADELPHIA — A Roman Catholic priest and a former Catholic school teacher were convicted on Wednesday on nine charges relating to the sexual abuse of a 10-year-old boy at different times more than a decade ago.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Jan. 31, 2013
text: “Thirty years ago if you were looking to get on the escalator to upward mobility you went to business or law school. Today the law school escalator is broken.”

headline: Leader of Players Union Offers to Make Changes
text: Billy Hunter, the embattled head of the N.B.A. players union, announced a modest list of reforms Wednesday — measures intended to rectify concerns about his stewardship and perhaps save his job.

headline: The Hidden Prosperity of the Poor
text: A concept promulgated by the right — the notion of the hidden prosperity of the poor — underpins the conservative take on the ongoing debate over rising inequality.

headline: Script Read to Suspects Is Leading to New Trials
text: A panel of New York State appellate judges overturned the convictions of three men on Wednesday after finding that their constitutional rights had been violated by a method of interviewing suspects, used only in Queens, before they are arraigned in court.

headline: Threaded Across and Down
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — How is this Thursday puzzle by Mike Buckley different from all other puzzles, you ask? Well, maybe not all puzzles, but we’re used to seeing a Thursday puzzle where the tricky part is discovering the theme, and the black squares are distributed like their earlier week counterparts. Today, the black square distribution looks slightly more wide open, almost to the point of looking like a themeless. It’s not themeless, however, and there are actually the same number of black squares in this grid as there are in most 78-word puzzles.

headline: Across a Wilderness to an Obscure Place Called ‘Self’
text: Martin Moran has spent time with more than a few therapists. He mentions a Sanskrit mantra that he recites in moments of stress, so you assume there’s been a meditation guru somewhere in his life. And he quotes the eternally helpful words of philosophers like Seneca and Aristotle.

text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Was hate speech by a young Somali-American who talked about the glories of jihad and the killing of American civilians the precursor to a life of violence and terror, or merely hot air from a confused and impressionable young man?

headline: Nets Given Humbling Message by the Heat
text: For the better part of five weeks, the Nets evolved. They focused a bit harder, reached a bit higher, listened more intently and became a better version of themselves. But evolution is a squiggly path, not a straight line, and that path was obliterated Wednesday by a team that needs no growth or introspection.

text: At town hall meetings at the East River Landing housing cooperative in East Harlem, the first question was always the same, said William Dames, president of the 1199 Housing Corporation. When will the recreation center reopen?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Alabama: Boy, 6, Is Held Hostage
text: A man who distrusted the government and was “a survivalist type” shot and killed a school bus driver on Tuesday in Midland City, then took a 6-year-old rider hostage, law enforcement officials said. After more than 24 hours, he was still holding the boy, who has a form of autism, in a well-supplied bunker buried on the man’s property while the F.B.I. tried to negotiate the boy’s release. The police delivered medication for the boy to the bunker, which was surrounded by SWAT teams. The Dale County Sheriff’s Department identified the suspect as Jimmy Lee Dykes, 65. It said the episode began when Mr. Dykes stopped the bus and demanded to be let on. The driver, Charles Albert Poland Jr., 66, refused. As children escaped, Mr. Dykes fired at least four shots at the driver and grabbed the boy, according to the police and parents. The standoff continued into the evening Wednesday. The police said Mr. Dykes had been scheduled to appear in court Wednesday to face charges of menacing. He is accused of shooting at neighbors in an altercation involving a neighbor’s driving on his property.

headline: Where Waters Receded, Scars Remain
text: NEW ORLEANS — Back in town for the Super Bowl, Marshall Faulk paid a visit Tuesday to his alma mater, George Washington Carver High School. It was a place both familiar and foreign, a rearranged tableau that he found encouraging and discouraging and, for a second, a bit disorienting.

headline: Law Schools’ Applications Fall as Costs Rise and Jobs Are Cut
text: Law school applications are headed for a 30-year low, reflecting increased concern over soaring tuition, crushing student debt and diminishing prospects of lucrative employment upon graduation.

headline: Sports Replay: Jan. 30

headline: Waiting for the Forgetting to Begin
text: My gray matter might be waning. Then again, it might not be. But I swear that I can feel memories — as I’m making them — slide off a neuron and into a tangle of plaque. I steel myself for those moments to come when I won’t remember what just went into my head.

headline: Yoani Sánchez, Cuban Dissident Blogger, Gets Passport

text: Jim Ford, a cod fisherman out of Gloucester, Mass., faces an uncertain future after the New England Fisheries Management Council voted Wednesday on painful reductions to cod harvests.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 4:30 P.M. (HBO Signature) THE DEBT (2011) John Madden’s remake of a 2007 Israeli thriller shuttles between East Berlin in 1965 and Tel Aviv 30 years later. Helen Mirren, left, portrays Rachel Singer, a celebrated Mossad operative who, with two other agents; her ex-husband, Stephan Gold (Tom Wilkinson); and David Peretz (Ciaran Hinds), captured and killed the Mengele-like Nazi fugitive Dieter Vogel (Jesper Christensen). Eventually the accepted account of Rachel’s actions begins to erode. Jessica Chastain, Marton Csokas and Sam Worthington play the agents as young adults. “The claustrophobic, unspoken bonds and rivalries that link Rachel, David and Stephan in their younger and older incarnations are overshadowed by Vogel and everything he represents, and a finely observed study of desire under duress gives way to a breathless and pedestrian globe-trotting thriller,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Not a bad one, it should be said.”

headline: News Quiz | January 31, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Assad Supporters Rally After Israeli Airstrike
text: JERUSALEM — Supporters of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Thursday condemned a strike by Israeli warplanes near the Syrian capital, Damascus, saying they rejected foreign intervention in the country’s civil war and offering support in varying degrees for its leader. Iran, Mr. Assad’s closest regional backer, warned of “grave consequences” after the attack.

headline: U.S. Navy to Scrap Vessel Stuck on Philippine Reef
text: MANILA — The United States Navy has decided to scrap the $277 million minesweeper stuck on an environmentally sensitive Philippine reef, a spokesman said on Thursday, while Philippine officials examined potential legal violations and fines to be levied against the United States.

headline: Tip Sheet: 5 Study Strategies for the SAT
text: Shaan Patel, who scored a perfect 2400 on the SAT, is the author of “SAT 2400 in Just 7 Steps” and a co-creator of an SAT prep course for Veritas Prep. He is a medical student at the University of Southern California.

headline: Super Bowl Probability: Excellence Versus Momentum
text: This year’s Super Bowl provides a familiar narrative. One team is as complete as a team can be, very strong on both sides of the ball. The other team got hot at the right time, having upset two of the best teams in the league en route to the big game.

headline: Advice for Car Collectors: From First Rides to Last Rites
text: Newcomers buying a classic car face a potentially confusing first-time experience: What car should I buy? Where should I buy it? How do I know I’m paying the right price?

headline: Iran Said to Be Set to Hasten Uranium Enrichment
text: LONDON — Iran has told the United Nations nuclear supervisory body that it plans to install more sophisticated equipment at its principal nuclear enrichment plant, a diplomat said Thursday, enabling it to greatly accelerate processing of uranium in a move likely to worry the United States, Israel and the West.

headline: Off on a Book Leave…
text: Today’s column is my last one for a number of months. I’m taking a book leave from my column to work with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, on a new book. The theme is the benefits to ourselves when we engage in a cause larger than ourselves, and, given that, how we can engage in a way that actually works. In other words: the emerging science of how to make a difference. We do need a title, so ideas most welcome.

headline: Chinese Court Issues Severe Sentences in Tibetan Self-Immolations
text: BEIJING — A court in southwest China gave severe prison sentences on Thursday to two Tibetans who court officials said were guilty of urging eight people to self-immolate, three of whom died, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: South Korean Executive Imprisoned
text: SEOUL — The head of SK, one of the largest South Korean conglomerates and owner of the country’s biggest mobile carrier and oil refiner, was arrested in a Seoul courtroom Thursday after he was sentenced to four years in prison for embezzlement.

headline: Sandy Hook Elementary Children to Sing at  Super Bowl
text: Twenty-six children from Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., will sing at the Super Bowl to honor the 26 children and school staffers killed in a shooting massacre last month.

headline: All Nippon Says Grounding of 787s Has Cost $15 Million
text: TOKYO — All Nippon Airways, an enthusiastic Boeing customer now reeling from battery problems on its Dreamliner jets, said on Thursday that the grounding of its 787 fleet hurt sales by about $15.4 million in January, casting a shadow on the airline’s future earnings.

headline: India’s Prime Minister Asks Developed Nations to Use Less Energy and Water
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh on Thursday called on developed nations to strive for gains in energy efficiency and to reduce their environmental impact to help protect the world’s poor from a growing paucity of electricity and water.
